description:
A great museum just a hop, skip, and a jump away from other major attractions like the Golden Gate Bridge, Crissy Field, and Presidio Park!

The Walt Disney Family Museum tells the story of the Disney family and how their most son grew up and became the household name he is today, long after his passing. Honestly, the museum is not what you would expect when you hear "Disney Museum", thinking first of bright lights, theme parks, laughing cartoons, and smiling children. Rather, the opening rooms of the museum are a bit sobering, with a focus on the toughest moments of Walt's life as he struggled to get started and make his brilliant ideas into reality. You hear about his failures and bankruptcies in his early companies and studios, which, although were certainly heartbreaking for him at the time, each taught him something and moved him closer and closer to the success. In particular, the museum, at least for the moment, offers a window into the early years of Disney Studios, especially into the lives of those who surrounded Walt, through an Exhibition on the Nine Old Men, the core group of animators at the studio which brought it to life. 

The museum itself is easily accessible in terms of content, making us of multi-media displays and important artifacts from the era. You feel like you are going on a personal journey as you walk through the museum, with smooth transitions from one period to the next. The staff are very friendly and make sure you feel welcome. Do know that you can get lost in the content of this museum, though, and should expect to spend at least a few hours here. Overall, a highlight of my trip to San Francisco!
author: Tim K.

description:
The museum was a lovely weekend get away destination. I made a day trip out of it by taking advantage of Amtrak's buy-one get-one capital corridor promotion and the museum membership to the North American Reciprocal Museum (NARM) group. The Amtrak bus from Emeryville brought us to the Pier 39 and from there it was a $14 Lyft ride between the museum to the wharf. There is also a free bus called Presidigo that roams around Presidio and downtown that may be helpful for some weekenders visting.

The museum is a heartfelt tribute to Walt Disney and the warmth of staff members make the experience magical. Upon entering the staff member helping us with entry tickets gave us a great preview of the museum and perhaps noting how wind swept we looked, he helpfully pointed us to a free coat check/restroom downstairs from the cafe. 

The museum tells Walt's story with as much creativity and diversity as you find in his many projects  You will travel his life via video, audio, photographs, sketches, paintings, models, memorabilia and trains. If you have a chance, catching a talk by a museum docent is a must. The one I managed to hear was a wonderful history of Disneyland, and much longer than the advertised 5-10 minutes. 

At the end, the cafe and museum store await for more shopping. The cafe was decent though the food over-salted for my tastes. The museum store was a nice browse, but other than a set of postcards from artist Tyrus Wong, items were bit overpriced for me.

In all, this was a great place to spend an afternoon on a foggy day by the bay.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I had purchased a Mickey doll from the museum store and gifted it to a friend. My friend later said there was a hole on the seem on the face and that it's too noticeable. I called the museam and spoke to Mark about the situation and that it's really hard  to make it back to museam and swap it out. He completely understood and asked if meeting in the city could work out.

To my surprise he had said let me apologize and make it up to you by just buying you the replacement doll as well. Beyond happy of not having to commute back to the museum. I was really moved Mark's compassion and friendliness the Disney Family Museum should be honored to have such an amazing Mark at there location. Also the museam was nice and staff was knowledgeable. 

Thanks again Mark!!!
author: Kevin M.

description:
I absolutely loved this place. I could've stayed here all day! Being a big Disney fan, I always find it fascinating to learn more about his life, and the events that drove this man to become the visionary he came to be. I have read multiple books about Walt and seen multiple documentaries and movies, as well as having a large collection of books and items about the parks and characters. This was a totally different experience, for someone like me, that is familiar with the background story about Walt himself it was a validation that al I've read through the years was factual, getting to see and read some of the original telegrams and photographs was amazing. This museum has a great flow, you literally have to spend a great amount of time to see everything and it's a tribute to Walt Disney the man and his family. A great experience overall. 
I thought that it was so cool that they show classic movies at the theater and little princesses can come dressed up for a showing of Cinderella, etc! Such a fun and intimate setting! Finally the gift shop had many original items that you don't get to see at the parks. Also it's in such a beautiful area of San Francisco! Worth the trip and a true window into the life of a man that to this day makes me smile with his amazing movies.
author: Gabriela K.

description: I'm a huge Walt Disney fan but I didn't know what to expect from this museum. It looks deceptively small but it's huge - it took us 2 hours to navigate through the exhibits. It was interesting to learn about Disney's life from beginning to end, and how his empire came to be what it is today. There are a lot of sketches, storyboards, character designs, etc., and it was cool to see the painstaking process of animation. You get information about the historical context of each stage of Disney's life, and how it impacted his work. Not going to lie, I was feeling a bit emotional in the last section that talks about Disney's legacy lol. I think it's a great way to spend an afternoon if you haven't checked it out already.
author: Jen L.

description:
What a fun find in the Presidio. If you love Disney, then this is great! It is all about Walt -his life from childhood to his death. All the trials and tribulations and convoluted paths he took to create all that Disney does. 

They also have special exhibits and interesting talks.  The location has the MOST AMAZING views of Chrissy Field and the Golden Gate bridge.  On site parking (metered) and a big grassy area out front.  

Great way to spend a few hours.
author: Sharon V.

description:
This museum is absolutely charming! We did not visit the special exhibit at the time, only the basic part of the museum. I could have stayed here for hours! However there were some people in my party who grew a little bored and hungry. 

That being said, even though the museum is "Disney", I do not know how suited it is for children. Much of the museum covers the history of Walt's family and the history of animation. While I found this fascinating, I can see how a child would become easily bored from all the reading. 

Only a portion of the museum is devoted to Disneyland and Walt Disney World. At first this bummed me out. Then I realized how much "Disney history" focuses on the parks and how few really honor Walt's life and struggles. I knew Walt was a great man going into this museum, but he faced so many more struggles and hurdles than I thought. Turns out, Walt Disney and his family were real people (; 

Truly I wish I could have stayed longer. The surrounding area is very beautiful and peaceful too. I should have planned better so we had a chance to explore the surrounding area as well.
author: Madison B.

description:
I've been wanting to visit this museum for awhile now and I finally got the chance to yesterday! Yaya! The museum is in the Presidio, right by Chrissy Field and the Golden Gate. Absolutely beautiful area. When we arrived, the only place to park is on the street. Luckily we found parking down the street from the museum. Ovviously,  SF parking isn't free so I paid $6 for 3 hours of street parking at a pay station. Plenty of time for us to explore the museum.

Anyways, the building is a beautiful brick building and when you walk up they do a quick bag check (safety first!) Then when you enter -- to your right is where you buy tickets. While waiting in line (only one person ahead of us; they're pretty quick), my friend and I decided "hey maybe we should just get a CityPass?" So we decided that was the route we were going to go for so we had something to do after the museum. However, much to my surprise, the lady behind the counter who was going to help us was an old high school friend. We asked her about the CityPass to see if we can buy them there but she said they don't currently sell them in the museum but she was so kind that she offered us to be her guests for the day! We were super excited and so grateful (thaaaank you). After getting our tickets, we started our exploration. The museum is full of Walt Disney's memories, stories, pictures, etc, of himself, his family, and colleagues journey to making Disney what it is today. It was interesting, educational, and fun. It's a beautiful museum that will get any Disney fan excited! My favorite part of the museum is the mini Disneyland of what Walt envisioned Disneyland to be; it was pretty dope. Also, the gift shop is great -- as A Disney Pin collector, I was super excited to get a Walt Disney Family Museum pin. 

Overall, we had a great experience. For a Saturday in the middle of summer, the museum wasn't too crowded (there were still quite a few people there) and we were offered to be guests at museum for the day by a long time friend, it seems we were meant to be there. And, I'm so happy I finally got to visit the museum -- It's a gem!Usually I don't like visiting museums more than once but I'd be happy to visit it again.
author: Misty T.

description:
This place is awesome! Wifey and I are a couple of Disney nuts so we enjoyed seeing the life and they times of Walt Disney. The museum is located at the Presidio which is located at this beautiful building right next to this huge grass area. Why a great place to hang out. 

Everything is well laid out. It will take a couple of hours to see everything but it is well worth the time. They present the whole animation process that Disney and his people invented. The best of it is one of Disney's multi plane animation photography thingy they invented. That thing is cool! We also bought tickets to have a reading by Claire Keane which was fun. 

If I knock anything about the museum is this. You have to pay for everything extra. You pay to get in to see the main exhibit. If you want to see any of the other exhibits or talks...show me the money! This should be surprising as it's Disney but still. The other thing to note is it is more geared for adults. There are some child centric activities but mostly it's for people that can walk, watch, and read a lot of static displays. 

All in all it's a wonderful place.
author: Don P.

description:
I learned everything about Walt Disney from birth to his passing and everything in between. It was pretty neat to learn about the in and out on a basic scale of animation to the creation of Disneyland. 

On top of all the learning, the location is amazing. Stunning buews if the Golden Gate bridge. Absolutely stunning. The museum is located in the Presidio, which has so much going on. The evening I went to the museum there were food trucks and a ton of individuals picnicing on the grass.
author: Malisa R.

description:
Me and my wife are big fans of everything Disney. I have been to both Disneyland and Disney world multiple times and my wife has been to Disneyland more times than I can count. 

So after repeatedly seeing this place advertised we decided to give it a try. It's tucked away in the very nice presidio. I love coming to visit this part of San Francisco. Not to mention it's right on the water so you get a spectacular view. 

We walked in and initially it feels a bit dull. But we paid (somewhat expensive, $25 a person). So you pass the front desk, your bag is checked by security, and your on your way. It starts with all of his awards he won for animation. Very cool seeing as I have never really read much into the man that was Walt Disney. 

Once you enter the actual museum, it is amazing. It is full of historical articles and items from Disney's life. It shows in great detail where Disney met his original staff. It showed where he started his first animation company, that his first company failed etc. 

Fun place to visit, and a fun place for adults and older kids to see. I don't know that I would recommend it for young children as not a lot of it is interactive. But some have creative imaginations and would have a blast! 

I highly recommend checking this place out of you have spare time in The City.
author: Matt H.

description:
Journey through Walt Disney's Life... and the birth of Mickey!

The Walt Disney Family Museum general admission is $25 but many of the guests we were with were in a special group and doing some kind of scavenger hunt. The general admission is a self-guided tour which took us to 10 different sections of the museum in two levels. Non-flash photography is allowed inside (at least for the general admission tour)

After touring the 1st section we were immediately directed to the second floor by way of elevator to where most of the exhibits were. Here is a summary of each gallery:

Level 1
1- Small Beginnings and Dawn of a Career

Level 2
2- Hollywood and Oswald, Mickey, & The Walt Disney Studios
3- New Horizons in the 1930's
4- The Move to Features
5- "We Were in a New Business"
6- The Toughest Period
7- Postwar Production and Walt's Collections & Family Treasures 
8- Walt & the Natural World
9- The 1950's & 1960's, The Big Screen, & Beyond

Level 1
... continuing section 9 - Walt's Final Projects
10- Epilogue and gallery exit. At exit there is a museum store as well as a cafe which is open to the public during museum hours.

Why is the museum in San Francisco as opposed to having it near Disneyland in LA?? Having the museum in San Francisco offers neutrality that could have been overshadowed in Hollywood, Burbank, or even Anaheim. It is the work of Walt's surviving daughter, Diane Disney Miller. 

One thing was for sure... after touring the museum I wanted to drive to LA and visit Disneyland. It was interesting exploring the life and times from Walt Disney's humble beginnings to his success by interactive galleries that featured many artwork, artifacts, photographs, documents, videos, and animations. Great museum!

Review #0957
author: May A.

description:
Visited here for the first time in my life after my 7th trip to SF. Anyone who's even interested about Disney, whether you like Disneyland, been to Disney world, or watched many Disney films, then this museum should be of a priority on your traveling list! 

It's a pretty big mansion museum with all of Walt Disney's history in details. So if you're planning to learn all about him, then spend at least 3 hours! Go earlier because the museum does close pretty early. I underestimated the length of the place and didn't gauge the timeframe well. Therefore, I had to rush the last bit of the museum when I could probably spend up to another hour. 

Parking is super easy. I believe it's mostly street parking, but it's plenty and gives you a lot of time!
author: Allen W.

description: This is an awesome, newer museum in San Francisco. I think of southern California when I think of Walt Disney. Walt Disney changed the world with Mickey Mouse and animation. That is a bygone time and now there's Pixar. This is an old-time Americana museum. There's 2 buildings. The special exhibition and permanent collection. I went here for free today and brought Zane because SFMOMA offered free museums with parternership..sweet. I thought it was a fun museum adventure that was good for tourists and locals. The special exhibition featured old original animation from the movies. It's in the Presidio. It's great for SF!
author: Denise C.

description:
We are Annual Passholders that live in the North Bay. 

When we can't make it down to the parks we get our Disney fix at the Museum. It's great for the kids who are interested in who Walt was more than just the opening credits to their favorite movies. 

Large scaled models of what the park looked like. ( I spent quite a while here seeing what has changed since then. 

See the evolution of 'The Mouse'. Also some of the war propaganda that Walt did. 

They have a wall of a movie that was sketched out and some of the photos of the sketches are screens that play sections of the movie. 

On the second floor you can look out and see the Golden Gate Bridge on a clear day. It's sometimes cool in the city so be sure to at least bring a light jacket. 

The gift shop was a bit expensive and the line for the Cafe was horribly long.
author: Danielle F.

description:
An utterly brilliant collection documenting the life of Walt Disney & his contributions to art & entertainment, the Walt Disney Family Museum is a must visit in San Francisco. The only downside is that it is so far from Disneyland down in Anaheim that it may make doing both an issue for some.

The museum, located in the Presidio complex, is steps away from Lucasfilm & within sight of the Golden Gate Bridge, making it an ideal location for tourists & travelers. 

Its content crosses all media types, with audio visual & even interactive elements, & like most things connected with Disney, a substantial gift shop with many exclusive & hard to find items. The museum has a core collection & special exhibits that rotate regularly. As you can imagine, there is often merchandise tied into these special events available for purchase. While that may sound cynical to some, it's more often than not quality products that should appeal to souvenir hunters & collectors alike. 

I've visited twice & spent hours each time as there is so much to pour through. While I'm more engaged by Disney history than many, Walt & his legacy have had a substantial enough impact on popular culture that even casual fans should find themselves immersed in this look back at the life of one of the 20th century's most gifted entertainers.
author: Shawn F.

description: I visited this museum on a Thursday and explored the area. Great experience and super interesting to read about the location - since they were barracks for WW2. Parking is very accessible. The museum itself has great attractions and amazing views! Highly recommend :)
author: Jazmin J.

description:
I'm not a big Disney fanatic, but I do like Disney. I wouldn't have known that this place existed. My friend wanted to hit up this museum, and although I wasn't interested at first, it was a good experience to go to. You get to learn a lot about Walt Disney, his life, career, and family. I seriously felt like I was inundated with information overload! But it was interesting and glad I visited. 

We were there for a couple hours, and there is so much memorabilia to read and watch. There are specialists who also give talks. The museum wasn't busy, so glad it was crowded and there was space to move and roam around. 

Adult tickets are priced at $25 for general admission. Be sure to check for discounted prices. There's a small cafe and souvineer shop on the first floor, and downstairs you'll find restrooms.
author: Maria C.

description:
Because of a lot of readings we spent more time than we expected. Remember to refill the parking meter ;) General admission is $25 per person, for a such small museum, I think the price is little expensive. 

Overall the experience was pretty interesting. The museum has very informative records of Walt Disney. We literally spent 3 hours to study the history of Disney. If you're a fan of animation or Disney, I would highly recommend you should visit and get inspired! 

Idk if children will love this museum, not much exciting but definitely a nice place to visit for a quiet weekend with family. ;)
author: Yoyo L.

description:
I've read two books on Disney, own a Timeshare in Disney and a certified lover of all things Disney. To find a Museum about Disney on my vacation while in San Francisco? Made the trip complete. 

This is how generous Walt Disney was, even to this day. Military get in *free*. Wow. That was such a blessing and I know Walt is smiling as he saw my face. We spent over two hours here, lets get started with this review.

Walking in, you start with the Disney family history. The family had their hard times and when Walt Disney first came to Marceline Missouri by train, his eyes were opened to an Idyllic lifestyle. He always hung onto the images of Marceline Missouri and built that into his Main St USA theme parks. Walt felt family was very important and that's how Disneyland was first started. He wanted a place where a father can take his kids on the weekend, to kick back and let loose. 

The museum is really an American treasure. It shows the history and progression of film and how art was integrated into the medium. Walt was a pioneer in this field. He invented special cameras and technologies, won awards and kept on pressing on during and after WWII. 

Here's a story, it's a glimpse of the mans generosity. Walt knew his artists needed to be cutting edge. He goes to a few local art schools and was laughed at except one. He spun it, train my artists. Once my movie is finished, I will pay you in full. True to his word, the movie was finished and Walt paid the final bill. Years later, the proprietor was sick and her home & the school was about to being foreclosed. Walt heard this news, paid off all her debts, set up healthcare for her and a trust to be used until her passing. Folks, that is on a level of sainthood.

Seeing all the wonderful technologies and accomplishments until his passing, Walt Disney was a great American. This museum is a testament to the mans life. I highly recommend 
The Walt Disney Family Museum when you're in San Francisco.
author: Bill S.

description:
You can't come here and not have a desire to go to Disneyland. My kids wanted to go to Disneyland after this. Who wouldn't. My family came after lunch. My husband who is a film maker appreciated the multi camera display. This was the beginnings of blurred backgrounds but the foreground is in focus. 

It was neat to learn about Walt's early beginning and that Main Street in Disneyland was modeled after his home town in Marceline, Missouri.

This place is a Blue Star Family museum. That means that if your active duty this place is free during the summer months for the whole family.
author: Dorothy B.

description:
Loved this museum! I'm not the nerdiest of all Walt Disney nerds, but it was a pleasure to walk through and enjoy the great story and legacy of Walt Disney and his family. 

It roughly took us less than 2 hours to enjoy this museum. Granted, I did not read through everything, but it was a joy to read and look through what I did. There was a good balance of families and individuals visiting the museum. Families with young kids were a bit of a disturbance as I walked through. This place really isn't for young kids, as there really isn't much for them to enjoy.

Adult tickets are priced at $25 for general admission. I was lucky enough to check with work for discounted tickets. Luckily, work did have a discounted option and I paid $8 less! Score! I didn't read the email thoroughly. I was suppose to print it, but the lady said it was OK and took the voucher number from my phone. 

There's a small cafe and souvineer shop on the first floor, from the main entrance. 

Downstairs you'll find the one set of restrooms. There are other restrooms available along your walk through the museum.
author: Antonio L.

description: We rented this site for a work event and got a private tour. Lot of history and you get to see an original Oscar up close. Super clean, nice staff, highly recommend it for a personal visit or a work event.
author: Sunil R.

description: We were Disneyland passholders up to about a year ago. We don't miss the crowds at the parks in Anaheim but we still enjoy Disney culture & movies, so looking at the Disney family memorabilia was a nice way to "revisit" what used to be our favorite weekend family activity. The museum is beautiful, well-organized, & informative. We spent a couple of hours here with my 10 year old and she especially enjoyed the interactive displays and nostalgic pictures of old Disneyland. Would recommend for Disney fans and those who enjoy American history!
author: Kezia B.

description:
I'm a huge Disney fan, so I couldn't resist coming here. It's in the Presidio, so while you are here, you might as well walk down to the Golden Gate bridge and make a day out of it. Stunning view there. 

This place will take you about three hours, so take that into account. Kids won't appreciate the exhibits as much as adults. I could imagine kids racing through the exhibits while their parents stop to read and examine them. Come on your own and take your time, or come with someone who appreciates Disney as much as you do and will leisurely stroll through the museum. 

Now, for the exhibits.  There is a lot of reading, but the reading is broken up with videos, and some interactive exhibits. You'll learn all about Walt Disney's life from birth to death, his struggles with his company, his animation career, his family, and Disneyland, of course. Lots of primary sources including letters that Walt wrote and interviews of him and his colleagues. 

We paid the extra $15, just the museum is $20, to see the exhibit on Eyvind Earle. It was well worth it. Such beautiful art. He was responsible for the backgrounds in Sleeping Beauty. I've actually been inspired to look for and buy some of his art. 

If you are a Disney fan you can't miss this very well put together,  thorough museum.
author: Sean A.

description:
Very inspiring. Definitely a place for all entrepreneurs to visit. 

What a great location for the museum too.

Advice for the pin collectors, bring your pins for trade. Theres this guy in the animation room with cool awesome rare pins... ugh wished I knew I was coming here ahead of time. 

Not really a place for kids to enjoy but definitely worth the visit. 

Unlike the Disneyland ticket price, tbis is place is very affordable. I suggest to skip Eyvin Earle exhibit though unless you are really into art, he does have some cool stuff.
author: Gloria M.

description:
You won't get less than Disney quality at every turn.  This museum is stunning, educational, inspiring, enlightening and entertaining.  My family came with our respite worker so that all could enjoy at their own pace.  
Today Eyvind Earle was being showcased.  Catch it while you can!
Upon entering there is a bag check and then there is the check in counter.  We bought our tickets on line so our time there was minimal.  Yet the attendant was very kind and informed us pretty quickly of the lay out and what was where.  He gave us a map and sent us to explore.
We stared out going in the opposite direction of the usual path since there was a high school field trip in progress.  So the first thing we saw was the model of the Disney home and the train tracks that ran around the property.  What was really cool is that they let our son press the switch to light up the Christmas Lights on the house and out buildings!
Next was a trip to the 2nd floor where all sorts of wonderful started happening.  There we entered the Ribbon Room.  This room has several projections going at one time, different movies and a place to sit and take it all in.  Our son and respite worker took a seat and my husband and I took off to see the sights.  
We did all meet up where the big model of Disneyland is.  We all played with the Animatronic Parrot and simply had a great time with all the interactive displays and showcases.
I personally appreciated being able to see in person the Oscar for Snow White and the 7 little Oscars.  
I don't think it matters what level of Disney-mania or lack of it you may have.  Walt Disney is an iconic figure in American history.  So many different things that we take for granted were pioneered by the founders of Disney film makers and imagineers.  I'm sure anyone who visits will find something of interest and enjoy their time spent.
author: Reba Jane S.

description:
Lots of Surprising History.

Whether you're a Disney fan or not, you'll find this place interesting. Just learning about Walt's history and legacy was quite interesting. Did you know Walt had a Doctorate Degree? Or that Walt essentially put Technicolor on the map? Neither did I until visiting this museum. All of the awards he received during his lifetime, and the creation of the parks. 

You'll also learn about how he use to work on a farm, all the hardships his family endured and came out on top, good values that most take for granted, it was a very educational and took you down memory lane from early years up to the present. 

There are items from Oscars, to medals, to actually internal memos, to the jeep he drove in the war, etc. There are live recordings of him, you'll even get an opportunity to operate one of the animatronics as the puppeteers did, its just simply too much to list in this review you'd be reading forever. 

Tickets in my opinion were a bit high, if you are a student definitely ask for student discount adult tickets are $25 per person. Parking is free which is nice as if you are in the San Francisco area there is no free parking anywhere. 

You are allowed to take as many photos as you like, so long as the flash is OFF as in NO FLASH, its amazing how many people don't understand that, especially with camera phones, a flash is a flash; I digress; as in true Disney fashion all rides must end at the gift shop, so does this tour whether guided or self-guided you'll end at the gift shop. Speaking of said gift shop; it was very pricey and surprisingly there were not a lot of specialty pins and magnets as you would find at any of the parks. I really couldn't justify paying $25 and then spending another $40 on a pin and a magnet. They have a small cafe inside on the bottom level

If in the area, its worth checking out if you have the time, but again it can get pricey if going with a large group. Looks are deceiving when you approach the building looks large, but in reality the museum is not also making it hard to justify the entrance fee. 

If you're a die hard Disney fan, you'll learn the reasoning behind one of Walt's sayings "Let's us not forget, that it all started with a mouse".
author: M W.

description: This is the cutest museum! There is alot of info about Walt, Disney Animation and Disneyland. I enjoyed seeing the vintage Mickey memorabila and old videos of Walt. My favorite part was the minature version of Disneyland. This is a must for Disney fans! If you read everything, I think it could take about 1.5 hours.  I spent about an hour there.
author: Cara H.

description: This is a really interesting little gem in San Francisco's Presidio. It's not a children's museum. If you bring your kids they'll likely be bored. It's a museum focused on the man behind the mouse, Walt himself. Teenagers might be a little more interested but young kids probably not. It's a gorgeous museum and you learn about the evolution Disneyland, Disney films and the empire that we've come to love. I would recommend to anyone studying cartooning or film because you see some of the early ways cartoons were made. It's also fun to look at the old films made by Walt and Co. Free admission for Military folks. Gift shop is tempting. I was proud of myself for not spending a gazillion dollars on random items. Truth be told I was on public transit so I couldn't carry much. It's a nice attraction if you're a Disney fan.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Great for Disney fans, since you'll get to appreciate the history of Walt Disney. There's no rides, there's no Disney characters running around, and there's no electric parade, so don't expect super high hopes of this Disney museum.

Again, it's just a big history lesson on Roy and Walt Disney. With lots of old letters, receipts, pictures, original film cameras and more.

I really like the miniature version of Disneyland. Pretty cool stuff.  

Free for military folks.
author: Mike C.

description: This place is quite intense. Several quick reasons. This place is not a place for kids. That would be Disney World/Land. This place is extreme reading. About 5 stories big. A lot of information stuck into one building. This is about the Disney family...the Historic Family Museum. The ending part is really the part for kids. My brother and I spent about 4 hours in this place. Was it worth $20 a pop? meh..? I don't think so...but to each it's own.
author: Olive R.

description: $25 for adults....but worth it if you're into reading and you enjoy Disney. Very insightful. Also, the museum offered interactive activities that were fun. Wear comfortable shoes! Small cafe inside. Very clean restrooms. Great view of the ocean from one of the hallways also.
author: Devin S.

description: Amazing experience, with a few caveats. Are you the type of person who would gladly spend $25 for a full day's worth of content about Walt Disney, his company, and the history of animation? Then this museum is a must see! The cost of entry will get you a huge, polished museum with well-designed displays, interactive exhibits and unique architecture imbued with that special touch of Disney magic. It had way more content than I thought with plenty of artifacts and information.
author: Eva B.

description: This place was great, it was fun to do the interactive screens and see how Walt Disney became a family name, and to see that anyone can make their own American Dream by working hard and not giving up!
author: Calvin N.

description: When I was visiting San Francisco, I was looking up museums to visit and encountered this. I am a huge fan of Disney and I had to come and visit his heritage. It's interesting to learn where Walt came from and how he came across to create Disneyland. Seeing the evolution of Mickey Mouse was amazing. He has gone through so many touch-ups and it amazes me how time changes. It's not a big museum, but I believe there's so much history and artifacts that you can learn by visiting this museum.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This is an expansive and thorough museum, great for spending hours if you're a fanatic or breezing through the larger text if you want to take it at a clip. Either way, I'd say it's worth the time you spend. It covers the big landmarks and famous stories a Disney fan might already know but also delves deeper into the life and history of the family and the company. You also get the well-designed presentation of information and the artifacts and multimedia that expand on it. 

Bottom line, if you can respect the brilliance in construction and management of the parks then you can understand the care and planning that would go into a museum to represent them.
author: Anna O.

description: As a Disney lover I was obsessed with this place, you learn quite a lot about Walt's background and get to see a lot of original sketches and paintings for many classic movies such as Bambi Pinocchio and Snow White. Very informative overall, and there was another limited edition exhibition of one of the main background artists for Sleeping beauty displaying some of his work from the movie and other paintings outside of Disney. Would recommend to any Disney fanatic like myself
author: Veranda H.

description:
Our family is all about Disney and had to visit the museum when we were in San Francisco. I'll qualify by saying that my wife and I probably had more fun looking around than the kids because it's really an information overload and not as much for kids as for adults.
I probably could have been there the whole day, but we rushed through some of the rooms so that our kids didn't get totally bored. Even though it's not super kid focused, it's still a 5 star experience for any adult Disney fans. I can't believe how much I learned about Walt's life and about the origins of Disneyland. His history is really interesting and all of the stories seem right out of an amazing story.
Once again, not really for kids, but there are enough interesting models and a couple interactive exhibits that the kids will still enjoy.
author: Brian K.

description:
Just like Disneyland the happiest place on Earth the Disney Museum based in San Francisco is a real treat and experience in regards to the life and progression of Walt Disney all the way up in through the creation of Disneyland.

It takes about an hour and a half and they have a tour that is very informative and fun most kids over eight years old would enjoy it but more adults remembering Disneyland and finding about all the parts and history is very entertaining.

The cost is $25 per adult seniors and children are $20.
author: Frank A.

description:
Naturally, as a lover of ALL things Disney, the Walt Disney Family Museum is one of my favorite places to visit.

The history and journey of the life of Walt is one of my favorite stories of all time. Seeing the memorabilia and the love that was put into this place as a way to remember Walt is heartwarming.

One visit will not be enough to see it all, and every so often, there are new exhibits and special things to see. If I lived in the area, I'd definitely be a regular. Heck, I'd be a volunteer just so I could be sure to see everything I wanted and to be a part of the magic contained within.

One of the charms of the museum is that it's in the old WWII Barracks, and the architecture is stunning, inside and out.

If you are in the area and are thinking about a visit, I promise you won't regret it.
author: Angela M.

description:
I absolutely loved my visit here. It was very interesting to learn about the humble beginnings of such a visionary. The old videos, concept art, keepsakes, etc..

It's in a beautiful location as well and certainly worth to see at least once. I'd love to visit again.
author: J J.

description:
A great place to visit if you are a fan of Disneyland and was wondering how it began! There is a lot to see and learn, showing us how Disneyland has transformed over the years. There are some interactive activities, but mostly pictures and graphics to see.

It takes about 2 hours to get through the entire museum so make sure to block out some time! Definitely worth checking out once :)
author: Justin L.

description:
If you are in town for the weekend--this museum in the Presido is well worth your 2-3hours.

If you live in Northern California , this museum is a must on your list.

This museum is a history of the life of the man and innovator, Walter Elias Disney.
It begins with his birth and progresses through his failures and successes to his death.
You will find a lobby full of awards he received including an Academy award with seven mini statues for Snow White and the Seven Dwarves.

Fan of Disneyland? Check out the model with fun facts of the evolution of the park.

Grew up on Disney films? Learn more in the "Ribbon room" with the touch screens.

Several rooms showcase his pioneering in the animation industry with the multi plane camera, colored feature animation, sound and more.

History buff? Look for the period World War 1 ambulance in the first room.

The museum also boasts art programs open to the public, a gift shop and tasty cafe.

Plus...they are a venue for various guest talks--Pete Docter, Tony Anselmo, and the late Marty Sklar have all given talks in the past few years. Check out the museum website.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Wouldn't recommend for little kids as there is A LOT of reading throughout the exhibits, but truly an ideal and interesting find for the older Disney fan.  Plan to spend about 2 hours here going through the history of Walt Disney's life.  

There's also a café and gift shop.  Around the back of the museum is a nice view of the Golden Gate bridge.  You can purchase your tickets online as well as in person.
author: Nadia K.

description: Simply one of thee BEST museums I have ever been to. My only disappointment is it may be a little pricy, but after you walk through the entire museum the price seems all worth it. This museum covers the life and career of Walt Disney. There are pencil sketches, posters, filming equipment, videos, statues etc all covering this great mans legacy. While you may get through the museum in one day, you simply cannot appreciate the volume of memorabilia and information contained in its 16 rooms of displays. It is interactive, photo friendly (no flash) and you can re-enter if you want to see something again. This is a great family-friendly kid-friendly activity...A MUST DO FOR ALL FAMILIES!
author: David S.

description:
We have had our eye on going to the museum for a while now. We finally went yesterday and was not disappointed!

We spent a good three hours walking through it. Reading everything, and listen the the audios and videos. It had a stunning 3D replica of the park too! 

It's not very "kid approved." But for an adult who loves history and/or Disney this should be a must on a vacation to San Francisco!
author: Kayla C.

description:
If you happen to be an avid Disney fan or are one of those people that truly enjoys historic Disney memorabilia in one building, then the "Walt Disney Family Museum" just might be what you're looking for. Located in the Presidio area of San Francisco is where you'll find this wonderful exhibit. 

Some might say why this isn't closer to Disneyland or anywhere in the Southern California area. I even ask myself this same question but its definitely a breath of fresh air to be showcasing everything that Walt Disney stood for. Since this place opened in 2009, many people may not even realize its here. And as far as the address, make sure you put in the correct zip code (in your phone or GPS) because there are TWO Montgomery Streets in San Francisco.

I came here on the morning of Monday, Dec. 26th with my lady and her sister. The admission price was $20.00 (which is not a bad deal at all). Not to mention, I also brought a printable coupon good for $3.00 off. There are other various discounts (AAA member, military, etc.) so be sure to do your research online prior to visiting. Parking could be a bit difficult since everything is metered so make sure to watch how much time you spend inside. 

What makes the museum unique is that there are ancient artifacts that were actually used when Walt Disney was still in its early stages. Everything that includes actual cameras, film strips, interactive galleries, equipment, classic Disney character figurines, drawings, animation, music, and even audio being given from Walt Disney himself. There is even a 12-foot diameter model of Disneyland when it first opened in 1955. This place more or less bring Walt's timeline to life. From when he was born (in 1901) to his death (in 1966).

One thing that I do want to point out is that I do NOT recommend bringing kids here! Some might think if it has "Disney" written on the building, kids will love it. Just about everything here is more history-related that the youngsters will find boring. What I found educational is that Walt Disney went through very humble beginnings while getting started in the comic and film business. This place explains how he started his life in Illinois drawing animals to his adult life in Kansas until finally settling in Los Angeles, California.

Finally, while walking in the building, you will see a picturesque view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Additionally, there is a gift shop to purchase Disney souvenirs as well as a small cafe that sells coffee and sandwiches. Overall, this place is a must see for anyone that wishes to know much more about the history of Disney and its characters. Definitely a unanimous five-star rating in my book!
author: Donovan H.

description: Love this museum in the Presidio park. Plenty of parking and pay for 2-3 hrs worth. Lots of artifacts and photographs from the Disney family and company. My husband and I took a little over 2 hours in the museum.
author: Andrea B.

description:
I've been to WDFM twice and It's an informative museum if you're a big fan of Walt Disney. There's a lot to read through so if you want to read through all of Walt Disney's Life and work than plan to be there for 2-3 hours. Make sure you aren't rushed to go somewhere else or you won't enjoy it. This museum focuses on Walt's life and is very well put together from the moment he was born until his death. It doesn't just focus on the parks. 

Parking is fairly easy to find and don't forget to pay at the parking station. There is a lot of information to read through so I don't suggest bringing your toddler's here or they'll be bored quickly since its geared towards adults and not kids. The museum allows you to come in and out all day if you need a break outside or want to go get something to eat. They also allow you to take pictures, but you're not allowed to use flash. The gift shop is also nice to look at once you're done.
author: Karen C.

description:
This review is in regards to the store, as the museum is mind awe phenomenal and the store sells stuff in which even after this review I will still shop there because the stuff inside is so unique and not mass produced.....

However...

I walked in today and there were about four other people in the store and there were four employees all tagging items or folding items at the counter talking about their day. No formal greeting to me. Which was fine they looked busy. As  I made my way half way through the store I noticed 2 people walked in and they didn't get greeted. By this point I could hear what the employees were talking about and singing. The one girl was singing out loud despacito and the other two were talking about their shifts. 

By now I was at the part where I'm facing the cafe though the glass and another couple had walked in and no formal greeting.

I wanted this booked even though the service made me not want to buy it but I needed it for a gift. I went up to the register as well as the first couple that came in after me to the other one. They were talking to each other so really didn't notice they were waiting.

By this point the 4 employees had made their way to talking near the table with the blankets on them. They were so into their conversation they didn't notice they had  people waiting at either of the registers. 

I understand if it was one employee trying to restock and do the registers all at the same time, but to have 4 two girls and two guys working you don't have enough time to greet and to ask atleast once are we finding everything ok and to make sure we don't wait to buy stuff which gives you money for a paycheck.

Slacking on that customer service disney always wanted.

However your singing of despacito Bieber would be proud
author: Ashley T.

description: I came to this museum at the end of June 2018. Like any Walt Disney attraction, there are very specific rules. The staff is nice but kind of bland, not what I would imagine at a Walt Disney museum. The place was really cool and I learned a lot. I did the special exhibition as well, nine old men. I was told when entering that I had to put my backpack on my front or check my backpack at the bag & coat check. I put the bag on my front. I had a large camera around my neck. When I entered the exhibition there were several other people with backpacks still on their backs. I felt like I was told about the bag because he was hoping I would check the bag and the camera because no photos were allowed. Don't worry, guys, I didn't sneak any photos.
author: Brianna L.

description:
What isn't there to love about anything Disney? This museum is in a beautiful location in San Francisco where you are away from the normal city madness! 

Admission is about 25$ per person, which don't be surprised it's a Disney experience so I wasn't upset about the cost. I think it was worth every penny.

This museum is pretty much dedicated to Walt Disney and his family as opposed to Disneyland so that was a great treat! You learn so much about his life and the struggles he dealt with building the Disney legacy. Some things I was even surprised to know that were actually created by Disney himself like musicals and other shows that don't stand out as much as the well known cartoons that we know of. I highly recommend this place it's beautiful.
author: Felecia F.

description: I was surprised by the sheer volume of work that Walt Disney accomplished in his lifetime. Not a kid stop, but rather a thoughtful and comprehensive look at a man and his vision. You'll learn, marvel, and enjoy everything in the exhibit. He was Mickey and Mickey was him. Optimism. Really well-curated and offered as much for your eyes as for your ears.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
This museum is awesome!  Very impressive historical timeline and collection of Walt Disney.  Military friendly, too, with tremendous discounts and deals.  My only regret is not making more time for the (about) 16 galleries of history, videos, and displays chronicaling Disney's life and business.  You need at least 3 hours to truly capture what the museum has to offer.  Great for the entire family.  Our teenage girls (15 and 13) really enjoyed it.  We also loved being able to take the Presidigo back to California and Davis to catch the Cable Car back to our hotel on Powell.

Also, recommend making time to explore the Presidio itself.  It is beautiful.  If spending the day, you could possibly combine your Golden Gate Bridge visit with this.  They have a free shuttle to the Bridge Welcome Center and back!  THIS IS A MUST DO!
author: David L.

description: I honestly could have spent the entire day here! So much cool information about Disney and his creations! There is A LOT of reading and I did find that there were a lot of distractions (other visitors, tour guides, videos playing, games, etc) that made it difficult to focus on what you were reading. Overall though, it was very interesting and I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves Disney!
author: Cassidy R.

description: Wonderful tribute to Walt Disney. This museum is staged in several different stages of Walt's life and perfectly depicts his story truthfully and accurate, using pictures, memos, and artifacts from his lifetime. Located in the presidio part of San Francisco, this museum is also a great place to get a view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Noel I.

description:
If you are a BIG fan of all things Disney and want to learn more about Walt Disney the man and the story behind his successes (and failures) this is a stop that you must make.  It would be boring for small children and those that really don't want to learn more about his history.  There is a lot of rare and special memorabilia that you won't find at a Disney Park.  All of the Academy Awards (including the special one for Snow White that includes 7 dwarf figures along with the standard one) are here.  You will learn about Walt's youth, his days in WWI, and some of his early animation attempts.  I gained an appreciation of him as being a risk taker (who occasionally failed) and an innovator in the field of animation.  There are a lot of personal items as well.  For those of you who know that he had a small steam model train in his back yard that he was able to ride - that train is here.  There are models of Disneyland and sketch art from multiple movies.
So if you have several hours to spend learning about Walt Disney, you will not be disappointed spending them here.
PS - you NEED TO PAY FOR PARKING.  It can be easy to miss the signs and expensive if you don't and get a parking ticket.
author: Mike N.

description:
I've been wanting to check this museum out for a long time and finally went.  I'm glad that I did; the overall experience was interesting and I especially appreciated Disney's resilience in the face of early failure, his strength and optimism, and his management style.  

That said, there were a few things that were frustrating and these surprised me, given the Disney name.  In particular, the rooms didn't introduce the flow of their story.  You'd walk into a room and  it wasn't clear which direction to go - what are you telling me, and why?  For someone who was passionate about storytelling, this seemed ironic.  Also, each room had lots of information in print, which works poorly in a crowded room where you end up craning over other's shoulders just to read whatever is written.  There were some really great interactive elements, but more would improve the experience.  

Just as an example, we went downstairs because the sign said, "learning room" and I thought that maybe there would be something to learn.  Instead, there was an exhibit with the art of another cartoonist, but no introductory sign to say why this person had any relationship to Disney, why his work mattered, or even what the "story" (introduction, why-it-matters, conclusion) of this exhibit was.  We looked and looked, but never found a "learning room."

Also, there was a section about his conflicts with labor and how much they upset him, but though I searched, I couldn't see any resolution.  Why were the workers striking?  In the end did they get better wages?  Is Disney known now for being a fair employer?  The lack of conclusion about this made me suspect that Disney was not (and perhaps still is not?) employee-friendly, but that may not be accurate,,, just an unanswered element to what is really a fairly relevant question.

Also, the overall price was expensive - not "crazy" expensive, but enough that I expected a bit more.    So - worth a visit, but I wouldn't go back... and do hope that maybe the exhibit design team invests a bit more in how they introduce each element of the exhibit, since even minor changes would have improved a good experience and made it great.
author: Katherine S.

description:
Oh my Disney. For any adult Disney fan this place is meant for you. It is a combination of nostalgia and education rolled into lovely displays. Upon entering the museum to buy a ticket you will find beautiful wood and glass cases holding awards. Pretty amazing. Grammys, Oscars, Golden Globes etc... 

A great place for the kid in all of us, gives you a chance to reminisce and the adult in us to learn the background. I'm not too big on the idea of taking small children with you, as it is a museum and you can't touch anything. Which for a kid can be boring. Either way, the museum is wonderful and you'll enjoy the environment along with the rich history of Walt Disney.
author: Katherine S.

description: For $25, it's a really awesome way to spend an afternoon. Keep in mind, the Walt Disney Family Museum is a curation and biopic of Walt's ingenuity, history, and family life. This is very specific to the man who created all of the Disney world we've grown up with and enjoyed all of our lives. It definitely ends on a sad note, but you're left with an incredible amount of history, oral narratives, and memorabilia to keep in your heart and your mind. If you purchase tickets on Groupon, you can get a substantial discount on the special exhibits; they're currently spotlighting Eyvind Earle, who was the lead artist behind Sleeping Beauty (1959). The artwork and insight into the thought process of Walt is something everyone needs to learn about - you only get geniuses like him once in a lifetime.
author: Danny C.

description:
Dropped of my sister in law and her bf. they were there for a good 3-4 hours. They really liked the layout and enjoyed their time there. 

The restrooms were super clean. They had child height sinks.

We had a picnic on the lawn. The red chairs were cool.
author: Jenny L.

description: We really enjoyed this museum. We brought out 3 young children and they enjoyed it as well! Would recommend it to anyone
author: Marisa R.

description:
Great museum. Little pricey. Don't they make enough money at the parks:=)
Great history lessons and behind the scenes stories.
author: Haleh N.

description: Incredibly rude staff. The exhibit employees need new training. Shame, Walt wouldn't approve of them.
author: Colin B.

description:
Super cute museum in the Presidio that is a must-visit for Disney fans! The museum is two floors high and quite wide across. There are elevators and ramps so the museum is handicap and kid-friendly. Due to the location, one part of the museum has a stunning view of the Golden Gate Bridge. 

The museum has a good mix between art pieces and interactive pieces. I loved that the museum is set up in a sequential timeline of Walt Disney's life. The rooms are set up so you follow one path to understand Walt's ambitions and dedication to his business. Don't want to ruin the experience, but I will say my friends and I had all sorts of feels leaving the museum. 

If you are a student, make sure to bring your student ID to save a couple bucks. There is also a coupon online you can print to bring in, which will save you an additional $3. Plan to spend around two hours if you want to look at every piece and play with all their interactive pieces. You could definitely spend the entire day there if you read up on everything! This is one of my go-to-spots to take friends who are visiting the city!
author: Kristi T.

description: I was raised in Central Florida and my stepdad was employed at Disney World for 20 years so I grew up going to the parks, some years just about every month. After I had moved away, a few years later I read they were opening this museum and I vowed to go visit one day. Fast forward a few years later when I moved to the Pacific Northwest and made a road trip down to San Francisco. This museum was my first stop, and it was everything I ever dreamed of. It catapulted me to my childhood and everything I had ever learned from my many books about Walt was featured here and so much more. If you have even an ounce of respect for all that Walt Disney created from his vivid imagination, I suggest you don't miss this museum next time you're in the area.
author: Angela A.

description:
We were only in San Francisco for five days, and we spent two entire days in this museum. OK, yes, we are Disneyphiles. We love everything Disney. And I guess some people would not need two entire days. But we wanted to read every caption and see everything and see the movie Pinocchio and the special Pinocchio exhibit.

If you are visiting San Francisco with children, this museum is an absolute must. If you are a fan of all things Disney, you must visit this museum. Even if you have been to the Walt Disney special exhibit in Hollywood Studios in Florida, you still want to visit this museum. There are things here that you will not see anywhere else ever.

It is definitely an adventure just finding the museum. It is certainly out of the way. But getting there is part of the fun. The public transportation system, consisting primarily of buses (the train system is not nearly as extensive as in other cities such as New York city), will take you just about anywhere in the city.

My recommendation is to arrive first thing in the morning because it's hard to know how much time you will actually need. We thought we would need three or four hours. It turned out we needed two full days.

There is a lot to see. My favorite was the miniature Disneyland. I stopped and listened to every recording of Walt's voice. I read everything there was to read. I saw everything there was to see. I was not bored for one second.

Even the food in the café was delicious and surprisingly not overpriced. The employees could not have been more friendly and helpful and professional and kind.

Once we finally had to leave, a member of the staff was happy to call a taxi for us. Overall, very highly recommended. A memorable experience.
author: Sam S.

description:
If you are a Disney fan, this is a must visit spot. Plan on over 3 hours for your visit. We got through half of the museum and mostly only had time to listen to the audio clips. (Or if you choose you can read everything and there is a lot to read.) The audio clips were wonderful and really told the store. I will need to go back to finish part two of the museum. 

I suggest you either bring food and leave it in your car or take a break and eat at the café. We were 1/3 through and took a break at the café. The museum is really intense and chuck full of information.

The book store is not like going to Disneyland. The item they sell reflect what you saw in the museum. Memorable of times gone by and things that go into the making of Disney.

We went on a Sunday and there was plenty of street parking. You can also get here by public transit.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Today Sofia, Mayer and I went to the Museum. Each floor was educational and brought back fun memories of Disneyland in the 60's ! Walt was way ahead of all others. 
Thank you Walt!
author: Marsha W.

description:
This was a great experience for a first timer like me. This was our final stop after taking a long coast line Highway 1 drive from the Fresno Area. 

My sig other surprised me with this museum because  he knows the big Disney fanatic I am. It was a nice little venture coming here and seeing the history of how it all began. My favorite part was the miniature figurines and the miniature Disneyland layout as well as the first drawings of some of my favorite cartoon movies.

Side note: Not a place for kids. This is a museum not an amusement park. Eat before, they only have a coffee shop and parking may be difficult depending on the time of day.

Overall, I had a great time learning, ooo-ing and ahh-ing at all the very cool things to see here. Will definitely bring my older kids in the near future!
author: Lorraine C.

description:
I LOVE the Walt Disney Family Museum. I am a certified Disney nut and am so pleased that this museum is so beautifully done. It certainly does Walt justice. 

From the moment you walk in, you can feel that Disney quality in the atmosphere. The music, the cast members, the service, the quality, the attention to detail... everything is there when you enter the lobby.

The museum takes you on a journey through Walt's life. From his childhood and family history, to his time with the Red Cross overseas in France during WWI, to his early successes (and failures), to the birth of Mickey Mouse, through his mega success as a visionary, artist, and entrepreneur. You walk from room to room in chronological order. It's a multimedia experience with video, audio, artwork, historical photos and letters, written history, and even an animatronic tiki bird! 

There are some amazing items that belonged to Walt that I was awestruck to see in person; such as the special Oscar award with the seven little Oscars he was given for Snow White, the Showman of the World award, and mementos he brought home from France. There are also great anecdotes and family photos (including a photo booth strip of Walt and Lilly).

There is such a rich treasure of information at the museum I could spend all day and night there taking it in. What a tribute!
author: Maria P.

description:
Great museum--very well curated and super thorough! My partner is a huge fan of Disney (the Land and the Corp) so we thought it would be cool to visit the museum dedicated to the man who created it all.

I was definitely skeptical at first because it's pricey and I don't know anyone who has actually been here *but* I went with an open mind and was pleasantly surprised.

It's definitely a museum about the man: Walt Disney and starts at the beginning of his life. I'm not a huge fan of Disneyland or the characters/brand but there was enough here to keep me interested for hours.

It's a really comprehensive museum. We spent 3.5-4 hours there including a lunch break in the cafe. There's a lot of see and if you read most of the text/entries, you'll need at least 3 hours to do it justice.

The tickets are expensive but you definitely get your money's worth. Staff were kind and the views of the Golden Gate Bridge are great from the second floor.

The cafe food was also decent (we had salads).
author: Semuteh F.

description: This is a must see for Disney lovers like myself! The museum itself was a pretty good size. I loved the layout (timeline style) of Walt's life. I learned so much about Walt and the Disney company that I didn't know before. My favorite part was the huge scale model of Disneyland! It was breathtaking, I wish I had it in my home! The museum was very clean, and had a cafe and a gift shop.
author: Cassidy M.

description:
A day of exploring in our backyard was well worth the time. If Walt Disney sparks your interest this place is informative and enjoyable, not to mention the smiles and fond memories it brings back.
Pieces of his life and Disneyland and how it all came together was nothing short of spectacular.

Then a special separate limited time exhibit 
"Disney's Nine Old Men" these were Walt's core animators and it told their stories. 

We spent a lot of time here as there was much to see and hear - short movies narrated  by Walt himself telling stories. Many cartoons and clips of movies, awards, and memorabilia that would be seen no where else.  

WOW and to think it all started with a mouse!
I can say there isn't one Disney cartoon character or movie or theme park that isn't magical!

It was nice to learn about the man himself Walt 
Disney who brought so much to the world!!!

Worth the time for the while family!
author: Sandi G.

description:
I was finally able to knock this off my bucket list. What a great exhibit place with all things dedicated to Walt Disney himself. All Disney fanatics, this is a MUST! You will fall in love. My boyfriend, who's not a big of a fan as I am, even enjoyed this place. He was very impressed with how much details this museum was able to get on Walt. He thought it was really well done and very interesting. There are two levels for this museum. $20 for adults. There was a small café where you can buy sandwiches, salads, pastries, drinks and coffee drinks in case you get hungry. 

Most people aren't aware that Walt Disney isn't just known for only creating Disneyland. His passion for artwork and cartoons and his perseverance to "make it" is what I commend him for. He came to California with only a few bucks under his name. He was fearless. When the bankers doubted him for his loans, he proved people wrong. He wasn't vengeful...he was a down to earth hard working man. The classic films he made like Dumbo, Pinocchio and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs are still popular to this day.

The most popular and favorite room is the Disneyland room. Pictures, short video clips, and text inserts with all things DISNEYLAND. It was freakin amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I especially love seeing vintage Disneyland photos. Such a beautiful, happy place Walt built.

I have to warn you about the last room though. It was about Walt's death. I knew this was coming and I read above it on Yelp before hand. I got choked up. My throat felt tight and I had to hold back my tears. If I wasn't wear lash extensions, I would have let those tears run. The cartoons artists drew photos and cartoons about this solemn news and it was just so heart breaking. I could only imagine the day of when the entire world heard about the news. 
Walt Disney, you were such an incredible man. Every time I stepped through the gates of Disneyland and I see that light glowing in your apartment above the fire station, I stop and thank you for creating such a magical place. 


So glad I finally got to check this out. Give yourself about 2 hours to fully experience this museum. There's quite a few inserts you can read and multiple short videos to look at.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
First off, don't bring your young kids.
This is an information-intensive museum for people genuinely interested in Walt's history.
They have a couple of small interactive exhibit pieces that are tailored for children, but most of the exhibit is text-heavy.
(Saw one father trying to read an exhibit piece, and his son was obviously bored, just pulling on this arm and not even interested in the wall of Mickey memorabilia!)

Good price for a very in-depth museum, and easy to spend about 3+ hours just leisurely exploring.

Check out the restroom downstairs, kind of artful nice!
author: Heidi P.

description: I had a fantastic time at this museum! My friend and I spent around 3-4 hours going through the special exhibit (Eyvind Earle) and the museum itself. Everything was very well put together and it was all worth the visit. I enjoyed learning about Walt's life and his struggles and seeing all the memorabilia. They have a very cool model of the original Disneyland (everything Walt planned while he was alive) at the end of the museum.
author: Tabitha H.

description: My husband and I being HUGE Disney fans, we had to come here during our first San Francisco trip. We're from OC and have Disneyland passes, so we were really excited to learn about the history. There's a lot to see and do in this museum. Perfect for all ages :)
author: Riley M.

description: Well done and entertaining. Easy to get to and ticketing is easy. Well worth the time with endless opportunity to explore and enjoy.
author: Ben B.

description:
I love this museum! It is located in the beautiful Presidio. Great views all around. About half way through the museum, there is a wall of windows overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge. You can even sit on Walt's bench while looking at the view. The whole place is filled with interesting information on Walt's family and his career. There are some cool audio files that you can listen to of Walt telling his story. I love Disney! I was excited to see how they made the cartoons and learn about the history of the Disney classic movies. Every time I come here and see the mini Disneyland it just makes me want to go and visit the real park. 

There is street parking right in front of the museum and all around the Presidio lawn. 
The pricing is reasonable. Plus, they have discounts for students.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This museum is a great place to spend a good part of your day.  First off, they close at 4:45 P.M. so I wouldn't advise to come that late because they will only allow you to be there until 6:00 P.M.  We didn't go that late but I asked an employee at the end of our visit because I was curious since we'd already been there for over 3 hours.

It's located in the Presidio, lovely clean and all around nice area of San Francisco (next to the Marina District).  Parking was easy too.  We parked in the street right in front but I know there's also a lot in the back of the building.

I wasn't sure about the temperature inside and really didn't want to lug my coat so I left it in the car.  The temperature inside was just right but I did notice that they have a coat check downstairs next to the ladies room in case you don't want to carry your outerwear.

The entire museum is chock full of history with exhibits, interactive devices, etc.  You won't be bored here I promise you that.  And there are plenty of places to sit if you're feet and back start to pain you like mine did.  Mostly towards halfway through.

There's a small café to the left as you walk in and we shared a small "Walt's Favorite Beef Chili" bowl topped with cheese & onions before we started.  Wow, that was really good stuff and I am going to seek the recipe!  No hamburger, but chunks of beef!  They also have complimentary water next to the cash register.  

After a few hours of walking around you think it's the getting to the end but it's not.  The place is really quite large with 2 floors.

I highly recommend that if you are going to visit, plan on staying at least 3 hours to get the full effect of the amazing Mr. Walt Elias Disney.  His daughter Diane is the co-founder and she gives so much of her father and herself in this time capsule that dates back to when her father was only a young ambitious teenager.   

Much to see, read, and hands on.  It was a beautiful day and we went to Crissy Field Beach afterward (so close!) for a nice walk overlooking the Golden Gate bridge.
author: Ruthie V.

description:
Took my daughter who is an illustrator to see Eyvind Earle's exhibition, cuz....she's an illustrator, ya gotta see this cat's work.
The staff are incredibly courteous and informative. Definitely helped us time our visit to include the featured, special exhibit and tour the remaining Disney family museum.

We were totally focused on the Eyvind Earle collection so the rest of the family archive was an afterthought. 
Though, i must say the collected works very comprehensive both technical and cultural as Walt Disney did have a vision of entertainment that is personal and enduring as he saw it.
In our changing cultural landscape, it can be refreshing to look into one person's framework as to how mythical, archetypal and stereotypical imagery and storytelling can provide glimpses into our history of how we have viewed our complex world and yet how we might look forward in embrace.
author: Kurt P.

description:
Great experience to see the history of Walt Disney and see all the interactive exhibits and Disney "things." This museum is really about Walt, and NOT about Disney, so you should expect more of a museum feel rather than a kids/family event feel. It is somewhat quiet inside--just like a museum as a good example. 

The store offers more Walt related things rather than a lot of Disney things, but there are some Disney things. It was neat overall to learn about the history of Walt.

After, you should walk to the nearby Industrial Light and Magic bldg and see the famous Yoda fountain. Not much to see other than that Yoda fountain, but that is cool if you like Star Wars.
author: Ron M.

description: The Walt Disney Museum is located inside SF's Presidio.  When u r outside the museum and it is a clear day, u can have sweepibg views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz.  This museum gives an indepth look about Walt Disney's life.  There r a lot of memorabilia of the thing he created.  It is easy to spend 3 hours walking and looking at everything.  U can park directly in front of the museum.  However,  it is better to park your car in areas longer than 4 hours so u can leisurely walk through the museum as well as walk around the Presidio.  The well manicure lawns,  sweeping views, beautiful trees and historical houses make this place a nice relaxing place to hike.
author: Mei W.

description: This place is great! We didn't expect it to be so big inside. There was plenty to read and do and a few hands on things. Also they have a small cafe when you walk in and they have a giant glass hallway with an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge! Ps the price is so affordable!
author: Keriane K.

description: The museum itself was amazing! A must see for any any Walt Disney fan! We went on a holiday weekend and there were a ton of kids. I think people think that it's away for kids to play since it has Disney in the name. I wasn't able to read all the displays as close as I wanted to but there will always be time for another visit. The staff was very knowledgeable about the Walt Disney Family. I was expecting a larger gift shop but treasure inside was nothing short of amazing!
author: Megan O.

description: I was blown away with the museum.  They thought of every detail and did a wonderful job of bringing you into Walt's life. It was all so beautiful and I thought I was stepping through Main Street for the first time.  I did cry at the end and wanted to start my tour all over. There was always a new surprise each time we turned the corner
author: Laura L.

description: Through all that I have seen was the best yet. There was a very rude employee I didn't like. It started off as me going up to a lady to get my tickets scanned but then she didn't tell us where to go. We went the wrong way but a couple of them did also. When we got to the top there was a person who kept looking at us and judged us like we snuck into the museum. Unlike the other employees he wasn't very nice and understanding. He just said let me see your tickets I am the professor and some University I don't really know where but it wasn't in California. I told the guy I have tickets on my phone and if he wanted to go see the lady I showed them too I'll bring him to them and he was just something else. Like I had done something else wrong but all I did was go the wrong way. Like come on and there were other people going the wrong way too I don't see you complaining about them. Just because we look like young people "that cause trouble" I kind of took it as discrimination basically. That person could've still be nice about it and tell us in a nice way of how it should've went. I am never coming back here again. I gave five stars only because of the history of what Disney has made until today. The five stars does not go to the employee.
author: Charissa Z.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here for the 3 day weekend. I never been to a museum ( I know such an amateur) so he brought me to a fun Disney one since we are going to Disneyland soon! :)

Super cute museum, I never knew the Disney museum was located here. There are different rooms inside like a timeline of how Disney started. It pretty interesting to see the history of how everything was created and some interesting history also! Definitely worth a trip, its a good 2-3 hours of discovery there. They have this whole 3-D module of Disneyland, it was super cool and the Oscars were cool to see up close!

The location of this museum is beautiful, up at presidio and you can see the gold gate bridge and bay!
author: Natalie L.

description:
I went on a sunday to visit this hidden gem in presidio. I chose a good day too the weekly SF picnic in the park was on full swing when I arrived. It was amazing and I really enjoyed this museum. It depicts a lifetime of dedicated work from walt disney to private family heirlooms.
They offer a student discount so it came out to $20 for one. The general admission is $25 and children under 6 are free. Its not a very long tour but its worth visiting. If you're not interested in  the tour there's always the museum shop with it a cute cafe and there's a resting space at the bottom.
author: Anny L.

description:
This museum is tucked in the back of the Presidio among the red brick buildings. There's a simple sign out front and it's easy to miss, but once inside, you've arrived at a wonderful interactive look into the life of Walt Disney. 

Even if you're not a huge Disney fan, this museum is great for anyone interested in history or technology as it covers not only Walt's life story, but gives you a glimpse into the modernization of the motion picture industry. You travel decade by decade through his life and gain an appreciation for all the work that went into making movies in the first half of the 20th century. 

There are photos and artifacts from his life as well as Disney memorabilia. Lots of interactive exhibits allow you to hear Walt's stories through his own words. You can end your day in the gift shop or cafe.
author: Suzanne Q.

description: Wowzers super impressed. Coming back again! This place exceeded my expectation. Check it out, you won't be disappointed.
author: Ari P.

description:
