I learned about Walt Disney's childhood, his struggles growing up, and even how a few people rejected his ideas saying they would "never work". Seeing how his cartoons came to life, as well as his movies, was amazing. Learning more in depth about the building of Disneyland (and how everyone thought he was crazy for building an amusement park as well). I learned more about the park in the 20 minutes I read about it here than I ever did in my four years of being an annual pass holder. There are amazing artifacts and pictures to admire at the museum too. 

If you are a Disney lover, make the time to come see this museum the next time you're in the city!!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description:
This museum has so much history its unbelievable.

Walking in, you may purchase your tickets  at the counter or online(whichever you prefer)
Prices for tickets are very very reasonable! The gift shop isnt too expensive either, besides the clothing which is a little pricier.

I wouldn't recommend the cafe just because it has your standard sandwiches in a box and regular coffee( and to top it off its expensive!)

The whole museum took about 2.5 hrs just to read everything( yet there are a few things I skipped)

Make sure to give yourself some time to read, wear comfortable shoes, and something to stay hydrated.

Thats all folks! ;)
author: Brittany C.

description: I think every Disney lover thinks of Walt Disney as the great grandfather they never got to meet. This museum really allows you to learn so much about the human that changed the way people looked at entertainment. It's not like a tour thing which I think is great because you can roam and take as long as you need to grasp everything.
author: Esmie B.

description:
A very excellent place to go to especially if you are a huge Disney fan! I've noticed some of my other friends and acquaintances going to the Walt Disney Family Museum so I finally decided to check it out myself. The building is at the San Francisco Presidio and there is usually plenty of parking in the area (though of as now you have to pay for parking!). Normally $20 for adult admission (galleries only), I found some coupons online for $3 off (if you also go to your local motel/hotel and concierge or visitor's bureau, there should be the same coupons available).

There is a lot to see along with some interactive exhibits (I didn't really have time for those), so do expect to take at least 1-1/2 to 2 hours to get through everything. When seeing clips from many of Walt Disney's creations, it brought back many memories of what I remember watching from years ago. Fantasia was no doubt one of the most interesting masterpieces put together. You'll also learn about how Walt Disney put together his company and how he was able to make his dream come true. Highlights of great accomplishments and the challenges he faced along the way are also highlighted. Posters, artifacts, models of characters featured (especially Mickey Mouse!) are also seen throughout the museum.

I personally enjoyed the museum a lot more than I was originally expecting to and hope to come back to explore the interactive exhibits a little more next time. Definitely a lot to see! And non-flash photography is allowed in the museum.
author: Paul N.

description:
If you're a big Disney fan,  this is the place to visit!   Located in the Presidio, this museum is quite a gem. A well thought out historical journey of Walt  Disney's beginnings through his accomplishments and all of his success. 

Curated collections of his works and personal belongings through the years are well presented here. There is a lot to read and to see as you make your way through the self guided museum. 

There is also a theater where they have daily movie showings. We were lucky to see our favorite "Snow White."

A wonderful place to see!
author: May N.

description: This place is always amazing. The museum itself does not change and that's ok. Going back a second time gave me a refresher on the life of Walt Disney, his family, and his legacy. I really like how they expanded and have an additional location on site within walking distance for the new and changed exhibits.  That was great to see! I saw the Pinocchio exhibit and seeing the sketches, art, and listening to some of the animators was great! I wanted to know more and wished it was bigger - it was still amazing! I've also been to one class, which was great. I would be thrilled if they had more classes with children's author/illustrators because I would make the drive more frequently!!!
author: Kelsey C.

description: This museum is so much bigger than it seems on the outside! It is filled with interesting and special findings everywhere you turn, so make sure you reserve at least 3 hours, maybe more if you're a huge Disney fan, or plan on visiting the special exhibit, which was really worth the price. We wanted to but didn't get to really read everything because there were just so many and we're taking too long, so I wish there were more tours to explain the highlights or more interactive/hands on activities for when we want a change of pace from admiring and reading everything here. But overall, really enjoyed our visit here!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I loved my visit to the Walt Disney Family Museum. My admission also got me entrance to their current special exhibit on Tyrus Wong. Admission is normally $20, but if you have a student ID you can get a $5 discount. Tickets can be purchased either online or at the entrance to their main gallery, in Building 104 of the Presidio. This houses the gallery, museum store, theater, cafe, and some museum offices. But the special exhibit is in Building 122 (just a minute's walk away), which houses any special exhibitions as well as the rest of the museum offices.

So I started off my visit with learning about Tyrus Wong and seeing his amazing artwork. That man is so talented! I loved his style of art (he's the artist behind Bambi) and his story is quite inspiring. After he retired from painting he took up the art of kite-making and has since been inducted into the World Kite Museum and Hall of Fame for his amazing creations (including hundred-foot-long centipedes!). Apparently he still flies kites once a month on the beach near Santa Monica Pier so I definitely want to check them out in person someday :)

After finishing that exhibit, I headed back to the main gallery to learn more about Walt Disney. He was such an incredible person! I loved learning more about his life and his career. He was so blessed with his mind and creativity, not to mention his family (especially his brother Roy) and their friends. He got screwed over many times in his career but he always managed to get back up and rise even higher. I wasn't able to watch any of the videos (my friend was waiting for me outside) but it was still so great just to read and see everything the museum had on display. The presentation of everything was very nice and I greatly enjoyed walking through the galleries.

Then you finish at the gift shop! They said that their items are not sold anywhere else, including Disney Parks, because they're completely separate from them. So of course I carefully perused the gift shop and bought a few souvenirs for myself and friends. Total time spent here was a little over 2 hours (and that's without the videos, which there are a lot of). So if you're a fan of Walt Disney, I definitely recommend coming here!
author: Esther K.

description:
Honestly one of the cutest little museums out there, and for a good price! You learn a lot about Walt and the Disney business itself, and honestly, it makes you fall in love with that funky little mouse all over again. You get to see and even experience how much work went into making the animations back then and it really makes you appreciate how much Walt put into it.
Would come again!

Mickey Mouse OUT!
author: Brian Y.

description:
This place is just about one of the cutest museums I've ever been to. It's giving the Snoopy Museum in Santa Rosa some stiff competition! 

The permanent exhibit of the museum focuses on the life and times of Walt Disney - his beginnings to his career (both the ups and downs) to the birth of the most famous mouse in the world to the first full length animated film Snow White to Walt's death in 1966.  There is lots to see in this gallery - tons of great black and white photographs, clips of old cartoons including the Silly Symphony ones, and stories from his daughter Sharon, who cofounded the museum.  Being a huge fan of the world of Disney, it was so much fun to read about the early days of Mickey and Minnie, and how Pluto, Donald, and Goofy came to be.  There's also a really cool model of DisneyLand. There was so much to see - I would think you would need between 2-3 hours to really see and read everything that's in this part of the museum.  

The temporary exhibit when I visited was "Magic, Color, Flair: The World of Mary Blair" and it was amazing. Mary Blair was one of Walt's favorite artists and did the conceptual art for Peter Pan, Alice in Wonderland, and Cinderella, and did the designs for the It's a Small World ride at Disney Land.  Her artwork is both beautiful and adorable.  The temporary exhibit costs an extra $5 on top of regular admission, but the Mary Blair exhibit was well worth it! 

The museum also has a small movie theatre where they screen a different film every month.  This month (the month of May) the film was Sleeping Beauty.  The screenings are at 130PM and at 4PM and you need a ticket from the front desk to get in to the theatre, but the tickets are complimentary when you pay for museum admission.  

Another really cute thing at this museum is the Oscar awards that Disney won for Snow White - there is one regular sized Oscar statue and seven mini Oscar statuettes representing each of the seven dwarfs.  This is in the museum lobby, where a bunch of awards are displayed.  

It's important to note that this isn't a comprehensive museum about all things Disney. It focuses on the Walt Disney's life and career and the work and films and projects he worked on himself, so you won't see stuff anything on the new age Disney stuff. 

The museum is located all the way in the Presidio. If you do decide to visit, come on a Sunday when Off the Grid does their Presidio in the Park in the afternoon (lots of food trucks and food booths and live music!).
author: Sylvia K.

description:
If you enjoy anything related to Disney you will love The Walt Disney Family Museum. And if you don't enjoy anything Disney you have no need to read this and you are soulless.

The main museum is gigantic. It starts from Walts' childhood to his last breath. Plan on spending at least 1.5-2 hours checking out drawings, watching clips, listening to audio and viewing interactive exhibits. 

During our visit with the family we also viewed the exhibit for the artist named Maurice Sendak. You may know him from the popular children's book, "Where The Wild Things Are". Plan on spending 30 mins. on his exhibit.

Each exhibit requires a separate ticket for entry. Tickets are purchased at the main building. 

There is a nice fully stocked gift shop and a small cafe to grab a light bite. 

Located at the Presidio. It took close to 40 mins. coming from the East Bay without traffic. 

Hours are 10AM-6PM. Entry closes at 5PM for the exhibits. 

Plenty of parking if you get there before noon. 

The buildings and grounds are well kept and there is a beautiful view of the GG bridge.
author: Amber S.

description: Great to know the history of Disney! This museum is animated and is great for all ages. Location is beautiful and its a lot bigger than it look on the outside. Military gets in free!! Yay!
author: Christina B.

description: Hands down one of the best museums I have been to. I am a big Disney fan and I loved visiting this place back in April! You learn the history of Walt Disney and what he went through to get to be the man we all love. We went 2 hours before it closed and it was enough time to walk through the exhibits and read everything that was on the walls or watch short clips of history. The only downfall would be the kids running around. It's more of a adult attraction that anything. I would definitely recommend this place to Disney lovers and fans!
author: Christina L.

description:
Family of 4 up for the week. Did a bunch of fun stuff but nothing beats this. 

I am going to make this brief-Smithsonian style Museum in San Francisco. Fantastic facility with super friendly staff! 

If your a tourist and want to go waist money on pier 39 have at it. If you want something with meaning-This is the place.
author: Dale D.

description:
If you are a TRUE Disney fan. You will love this place. But if you only love Disneyland because it's Disney, you will be bored easily.
I am in love with Disney because I grew up loving anything Disney, so when I found out about this place, I knew I had to come here. There is so much history about Walt Disney that I did not know. This place is so amazing. I was mind blown. Definitely a family place to come to if you want to learn the history behind Walt's life/ career. The big map of Disneyland during Walt's life is to die for! 
I will definitely come back here again!
author: Vicky N.

description:
If you are in the San Francisco area and..............you are a Disney Fan............you like to learn a little about history......................you love films of all kinds..................your an engineer..........and you're an adult.........................you will find plenty to keep you tuned in.

I really cannot understand why anyone would bring their children here.............We spent 2 full hours reading, watching and trying to figure out ---how did they do that?  By the time we went down to the bathroom on the bottom floor and saw there was more to see, we were exhausted.

There are no rides here, no characters...............just a timeline of what Disney did when, how he created new technology and entertained people for decades.

Bring Student ID if you have it, or triple "A" also gets you a discount.


I don't know that I'd go back , but this is certainly a great place to visit if in the area.
author: E A.

description:
I heard about this museum a couple years ago when it first debuted but never made it for a visit until last week. So glad I did. :) It's located at the gorgeous Presidio in the heart of SF.

If you're a Disney fan, you would enjoy visiting this museum and learning about the history of Walt and Roy Disney. You can see how Disneyland and Mickey Mouse came to be and all the creativity and passion that stemmed from this enterprise. There were so many twists and turns and failures that were woven into Disney's life...and yet through it all, he was still able to maintain his family ties and still reach success.

It was fascinating to see some of the artwork from the past, the medals, the posterboards, the black/white films, etc. I spent a good 1.5 hours inside the museum, as there were 10+ exhibits. Also, be sure to visit the museum store downstairs as there are some neat items to buy. I'd recommend this to anyone who is interested in the history of the Disney family!

Parking available right outside the museum along the street, pay at the parking meter kiosk.
author: Yonnie C.

description:
This is like a hidden SF gem! This place is so so so cool. I went on a Wednesday so it wasn't crowded at all and it was super easy to find parking. Admission is only $15 for students so bring your student ID! Before you enter the museum there is a little cafe that has hot and cold beverages as well as yummy sandwiches so you can have a snack before you enter. And I recommend doing so because there is no where to buy drinks inside. 

There are SO many cool things to see inside. From original Mickey Mouse sketches to Walt Disney's miniature collection. My favorite was seeing a 1937 Cartier Snow White & the Seven Dwarves charm bracelet in the Snow White room. 

This place will make you appreciate Disney so much more. 5 stars!
author: Christine L.

description: We took an Uber to the Disney Museum. It was nice to see and interesting, but the entrance fee is overpriced for what you get. I liked their model of Disneyland
author: Nadia G.

description:
If you love anything Disney this is the perfect place for you! It was awesome being able to learn about his whole life. I never really knew the details of his life and how he got started. His life is definitely very inspiring. From the museum you can see beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge which was amazing. Also, there are student discounts so don't forget your ID. 

The gift shop however was a little disappointing, not what I had imagined but I suppose it's like that because they want you to go to Disneyland to buy the other things.
author: Michelle W.

description:
If you are a huge Disney geek like I am, this place is for you. Uncle Walt was a true inspiration for me. It was a real treat to visit on our trip to San Francisco. 

It's not only about Disneyland and Mickey Mouse, it's about the man himself, Walt Disney. The museum goes through the timeline of his life. It starts with his grandparents story and it moves on to his childhood and the rest is history.

You will find the coolest stuff here, animation cells, Walt's personal belongings, and whatnot. I like how the museum does not sugar coat things either. They tell us about Walt's struggles and how he overcame them. 

We did the Pinocchio exhibit. It was an extra $10 or so, but I am glad we did it. There was so much to see and do. 

The Disneyland room was breathtaking. 

I look forward to returning next time I am in Nor Cal.
author: Miriam D.

description: I love Disney stuff and it was a great museum to learn about Walt Disney. My favorite part is the  mini model of Disneyland that was inside the museum. They have a special Pinocchio exhibit that cost extra. It was $20 for adult entrance fee and $15 for the special exhibit. Pretty pricey, but definitely recommend this place.
author: Carissa M.

description: I must admit, I wavered when I found out the museum charged $20 for admission. At the last exhibit, I was ready eyed and wanted to applaud. It was a historical story that tells about Walt Disney's rise to the top. Without being a spoiler, I must say there were many struggles building his dynasty that I did not know about. I actually give this attraction 4.5 stars. I took a half away because I thought the place could use some music to set the tone in each exhibit make it over the top!!
author: Angela R.

description:
If you love Disney, this is a great museum to go to. It has a bunch of history about Walt and how he made Mickey Mouse into the company that it is. It's not tally about Disney but the man behind the mouse. 

There was so much history and so much to see. If you actually read everything in this place, you'd need two days to read all of it. They have so much info on his life. They have tons of info on his family history. They go back to his great grandparents and now his great great grandkids. 

There is just so much history to him. It also make you appreciate his efforts to make Disney where it is today. 

And boy, would he be disappointed in how the company is running today screwing people over with their outrageous prices and not paying their workers enough. But besides politics, Disney is thriving today with Marvel, Star Wars on their belts. 

This museum is all about Walt and it's great.

Parking: paid parking, but lots of it

Beautiful outdoor area
author: Laura S.

description:
Being a huge Disney fan, I have the luxury of being close enough to the Disneyland Resort to visit once a month. However, I rarely head to NorCal so once I planned my SF trip, the Walt Disney Family Museum was set on the first day.  

First of all, if you are by the Embarcadero BART station, keep in mind that because of the construction, the pickup location for the free PresidiGo shuttle has moved to right by the grassy park by the Hyatt.

Secondly, do try to go as early as possible! We missed the 1:30 pm shuttle because of the change in pickup location and had to wait until the 2:30 pm shuttle. Once we got to the museum, we had only 3ish hours to browse before they closed at 6 pm. It honestly wasn't enough time since there was the special exhibit for Tyrus Wong on display which we viewed first and then we had to speed through the main museum exhibits. Luckily, we've gone to the special Walt Disney exhibit at the Reagan Library, so some things we were okay in speeding along, but there is so much to read and learn about Walt's background, his early work and his masterpiece with Mickey and Disneyland that you would want the time to enjoy at your leisure.

The Tyrus Wong exhibit was pretty cool. I was not familiar with his work or involvement with the Bambi film, so the exhibit did a great job showcasing his work, especially what he does now in his 102 years of age -- kite making and flying the kites in Santa Monica. The items that I particular liked were the toys he made for his daughters -- wonderfully and creatively designed toys made out of common household objects (like a tissue box, pringles can, those Easter Seal stickers), what a great use of resources!

The view outside the museum is also pretty fantastic. You get a very nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge when it's not too cloudy a day.

The ticket price is very well worth what you see and the museum does have parking available--albeit a $1 per hour charge!
author: Grace C.

description: It's a privilege to have a chance to see  and explore this wonderful museum,we have been to Tokyo Disneyland and Disney Sea,Aulani in Hawaii and "D" museum compliments those places,to know more about the men and women who worked for "D" genius man,museum is very clean ,interactive.Behind the building is the Golden gate bridge so we took so much pictures inside and outside D museum.Entrance to the museum is free if you have a military ID including your dependents,show your ID,the exhibit in the other building Pinochio is $10 per person ,pet are not allowed.Gift shop is small  and they have a small cafeteria.Parking is $8.50 for the whole day but if you get lucky ,some people who are leaving early will pass their parking ticket to you.Spending at least 2-3 hours here is sooo worth it.Thanks to the men and women who put their best effort to D museum.
author: Margie L.

description: Lived here all my life and never checked out the Disney Museum. Parking wasn't too hard to find but you have to pay for it - even on the weekends. It wasn't expensive but a lot of history behind the art and Walt himself. My favorite part was the miniature Disneyland! The tiny details were 'WOW'! Definitely a place to go once or to bring someone that is into Disney. They have a small cafe that serves food/snacks/drinks, but a bit pricey (as expected). They also have a small souvenir shop when ending your tour around. They also have small theaters downstairs that plays documentaries, history, etc of Disney.
author: Amanda C.

description: I absolutely loved every moment of my visit to this museum. I came especially for the Disney and Dali exhibit, so we enjoyed that vast exhibit first. Standing i front of actual Dali paintings was a once in a lifetime experience I won't soon forget. As a Disneyland fanatic the Disney museum was extra special. There is a ton of memorabilia and unique items I really enjoyed viewing. Parking was actually easy on a Sunday, and there is a killer view of the GG bridge inside the museum. The giant diorama of Disneyland was worth admission alone.
author: Cristina B.

description: This is a pretty nice museum but I didn't realize it was really focused on his life and therefore the timeline of the exhibit ends in 66, whereas my experience of 'Disney' was during the 80s and 90s. Either way it was pretty interesting to learn about his life and very well done. It isn't super interactive but there are videos and audio recordings as you go along. It only took me about an hour to get through it all, and student discount was $15. I didn't do the special exhibit and probably wouldn't go back. It is more historical than fun so I don't know that kids would enjoy it much. It focused primarily on his earliest films-Bambi, Fantasia and Snow White.
author: Marisa L.

description: This was a very interesting museum about all things Walt Disney.  I especially enjoyed the original celluloid cells they had on display on the museum as well as explaining the thinking process behind this brilliant mind. Expect to stay about 1.5 - 2 hours here. Going through the exhibitions brought back a lot of good childhood memories. I would recommend this place to anyone who is a kid at heart.
author: Kenson K.

description:
If you're looking to have a relaxing, educational, fun, and relatively cheap activity in the city, there's no better choice than the Walt Disney family museum. 

Honestly you don't even have to be a huge Disney fan to enjoy this place. As long as you're a somewhat cultured person who enjoys learning and being entertained this place will not disappoint you. 

If you're a student, a valid student ID will bring down your admission fee from $20 to $15. Parking here is great too because there's a massive parking lot across the museum with low parking fees of $1.20 per hour (you won't need more than 2.5-3 hours). 

The museum takes you through the life and family of Walt Disney going from his childhood to education to starting his own studio, the world war, his creation of Disneyland and eventually his death. 

It's colorful, educational, and perfect for people of all ages and walks of life.
author: April Z.

description:
You don't have to be a die hard Disney fanatic to enjoy this museum but it sure helps.

It's even better if you are a museum member. When you enter you can pick up a card with five trivia questions. It turns the experience into a bit of a scavenger hunt. At the end, if you answer all the questions, you get a special commemorative pin. I answered the questions and did not get a pin because I'm not a member. What a waste of time but now I know what ski resort, which ships, and what southern California county the Disney's set foot in. Very important information to know if I ever make it to Jeopardy.

The Walt Disney Family Museum is all about Walt Disney, his family, and the rise of Disney. It's really interesting to know the story how they started so simple and became this massive empire. I loved all the artwork, old school models, animation cells, photographs... It's a 'trip' and literal trip down memory lane and history. The best part was the miniature Disneyland. It makes my heart glow.

The Walt Disney Family Museum is a great day trip to the Presidio. It's even better if you go on a day of Off The Grid Picnic at the Presidio and get a coupon at one of the booths.  Save money. This place ain't cheap!
author: Rachel A.

description:
Finally made it to the museum while on our honeymoon a couple of weeks ago.  We only managed a few minutes in a couple of galleries, but it's awesome. This is a must for a Disney and/or animation buff! There is SO much history, and an interactive gallery that's incredible fun!!

The best part was Mark,  a cashier in the store, who very kindly offered suggestions and chartted us up during our purchase. He was friendly, helpful, and ended our brief visit on a high note. Thanks Mark!
author: Alfredo T.

description:
I loved this!! My parents and I came here over Thanksgiving break because we really enjoy Disneyland and we ended up spending over 6 hours here and still didn't get through everything! My dad had called ahead of time to see how long it normally takes for people to get through the museum and apparently it only takes people under 2 hours regularly, but I think that's because a lot of people don't read all the text and whatnot. I literally wanted to read and see everything, hence why it took so long, but I also think this is why I enjoyed it so much. There was so much history and the text, although lengthy, was incredibly fascinating. I sincerely do not believe that you will fully enjoy this museum as much as I did unless you read everything!

Anyway, I will be back for the rooms that I didn't get to. If you're at all interested in Disney (the man or the company), I would say go!
author: Steph U.

description:
Mark (the guy at the gift shop) Rudy (the security guard) and Jennifer (the manager) were all very nice and made our experience go from an "ok" experience to a magical one. 

Thanks guys! We'll be back soon
author: David C.

description:
A great museum for anyone to visit! Visitors learn about Walt Disney's childhood, how he got into the entertainment/animation industry, and the history of how the Disney company came to be. It's educational, interactive, and very well-maintained. The museum may appear small, but don't be fooled, there were so many things to browse through and each room had it's own story.

Although I'm not sure how crowded this place can get, we decided to visit on a weekend around opening (10am). We were able to browse through the museum at our own pace, so it made for a very pleasant experience. I loved examining everything that they had on display, especially the mini Disneyland. 

By the end of our visit, I learned so many new things about Walt and the Disney company. I highly recommend this museum to anyone, especially Disney lovers. You won't be disappointed!
author: Josephine L.

description:
The exhibits were impressive, but the supreme aspect of this attraction is the museum design, decor, and the way the exhibitions are displayed. It's absolutely beautiful. 

Stop and read the signs. They will tell you a unique history of a remarkable man. My favorite artifact was the multi-plane camera. Spend extra time learning how geniuses figured out how to do what is all done by code programmers today. 

It's actually not that fun for kids. Don't let the Disney name fool you. You will enjoy it much more without littles.
author: Matt W.

description: Lots and LOTS of info on the history of Disney! It is pretty big inside and it's beautiful. The art is amazing and you can definitely see the change throughout the years. I loved it!
author: Tammy N.

description:
I have been to the Presidio countless times over the years, yet I had NO IDEA this was here.  The Walt Disney Family Museum is the most enjoyable museum experience that I have ever been to.  

A couple notes before I proceed further, for those looking for a Disneyland-like experience this isn't for you.  For those looking for a completely "unbiased" account of the history of the Disney Brothers (Walt & Roy), do know that this museum was founded by the Disney family and is owned and operated by the non-profit Walt Disney Family Foundation.

Now aside, the Walt Disney Family Museum offers an incredibly modern, interactive and audio/video driven presentation of the Disney family, in particular Walt and Roy's youth, upbringing, rise and formation of all things Disney and it's legacy.  There are different rooms and area along the way, each one focusing on a period or important section of Walt and Roy's lives.  Each room always has text timelines along with spoken or video (in form of animated shorts, archival video or documentary footage) explaining the importance or significance moments of time.  There are also important artifacts of for each point, from early Walt sketches to (my personal favorite) a 20 foot, or so, wide model of Disneyland.

The experience of the museum really is a feast for the sense.  You can casually peruse parts or spend hours in a single room.  The museum does a good job of steering you linearly through time and you honestly feel like you are on a ride and making a connection with Walt and everything he created to the point that when you get to the section where he passes away (Sorry...spoiler alert) it really does hit you.  There were a few people in tears at this part and I myself was a little choked up.

Also on the premises are a Cafe (not great) a fine little gift shop with plenty of great things, along with exclusive Disney collectable items that which can't be purchased anywhere else.  I, personally walked away with a great mug http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Kkrxk2Uz7UGyvuVIDtfXDw/l.jpg and a DVD documentary on Walt Disney.  There is also a downstairs area with a screening room and animation room where they do special events and screenings.

Overall, I had a great experience.  I did, honestly, feel that there were a few points in Walt's life (particularly the McCarthy Witch Hunt stuff and the sometimes tense relationship Walt had with his brother Roy) that was a little glossed over and possibly a bit white washed.  But overall I walked away with a great insight and appreciation of the men who build the Disney empire.
author: Rob P.

description:
Absolutely amazing! Being an avid Disneyland goer myself, this was a real treat. There are lots of super neat exhibits, some of which are interactive!! Notable mentions would be the tiny model of Disneyland, and the huge multiplane camera they had. 

Not only was this place incredibly dense with goodies, the staff was exceptional. Shout out to Mark from the gift shop! He provided such amazing service that easily surpassed even the disney service I receive at the parks in Anaheim. Mark if you're reading this, you were the cherry on top to an already amazing sundae.
author: Allen Justin D.

description: Love this place a lit i cant wait to go back there when the they bring in there new exhibit my favorite piece of art when i was there when i seen the multiplane camera that disney did to create Pinocchio. I was super amazed however they dont allow picture taking in the special exhibit. Which sucks but over all its been great i had fun
author: Joanna L.

description: We spent 5 hours in this museum and didn't realize! We love Walt Disney and it was wonderful learning more about his life and family. For the price it is well worth it!
author: Jordin N.

description:
Located in the Presidio area of San Francisco. Lots of paid street parking around. The museum is two parts. One that details history of Walt Disney and the other being a rotating exhibit of the various Disney works. 

This museum can fill up most of ones day. So much to read and see. Plenty to learn about the late Disney. This museum should not get confused with the Disney theme parks. More about history. 

The rotating exhibits are always worth it on their own. One is certain to intrigue you. 

Good: for families, Disney fans, a whole day. 
Bad: nothing.

I'll comeback someday. Worth repeat visits.
author: Denny T.

description: I've been to Disneyland since I was 3 and it's a very special place to majority of the families. I was excited to hear that the daughter had opened up the museum. Tickets were fairly reasonable and the front desk workers were very nice. My family was the first one to enter it was very quite and soothing. It was really nice to see where everything started such as the first sketches Walt Disney had drew to the first Mickey Mouse drawn. To the mini model of the first Disneyland attraction. It's a must to visit the museum when visiting San Francisco
author: Mel W.

description: I live in LA so I have a Disneyland pass and just love Disney. At first when getting to the museum I was little hesitant of the price plus the exterior size of the place.. I was thinking $20 for this?! But once we went in I quickly was amazed and realized it was totally worth it. We were there for about 2-3 hours! There's just so much to do and see. Hands down the best part was the mini (but not so mini) Disneyland! I loved it. The family pictures of Walt and the timeline of his life was magical. The staff was great! We also got really cute souvenirs at the gift shop! It's about a 30 minute walk from the Golden Gate Bridge/7 minute drive. Totally recommend this place to Disney fans visiting!
author: Tania H.

description: This is a definite must see for any Disney fan. Everything is displayed and detailed very well and the museum is laid out in chronological order which is nice. I was hoping to see more historical items from Disneyland on display and the gift shop was very underwhelming for a Disney store. I highly recommend the chicken salad sandwich as it was amazingly delicious!
author: Corby D.

description:
There's so much information about the Disney family and Walt Disney's rode to success. It definitely was a magical experience just like being at the park! I learned so much and enjoyed every second of it. 

Getting there is no problem especially through public trans. I would suggest coming here alone or with someone who would be interested in doing a lot of observing and reading. I don't think this is something for children as there's so much and they can easily get bored/distracted. I saw a handful full of kids not interested and giving their parents a hard time lol...

I did the film portion after my trip through the museum and watch the Gnome Mobile which was pretty cool and a nice break to sit down from all that walking (I spent nearly 3 hours in the museum)! It was awesome to see everything and I appreciate that this exists. Definitely recommend stopping by if you're a Disney fan!
author: Linda R.

description:
I feel it's almost a character flaw in America to admit that I had no interest in Walt Disney, but I had a very nice experience and learned a lot at the museum. The Dali/Disney exhibit is fascinating and inspiring. Not only does it explain why each was a pioneer and how, but it also tells the story of their collaboration and friendship. The most fascinating part for me was to watch how their work changed during WWII and how the war even affected Disney's business. Audio guide is free for Dali and you can even use the provided headphones with your own iphone. Even if you don't buy a ticket to that exhibit, I recommend going to that back building where it's housed to see the gorgeous view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

The Walt Disney area is charming with plenty of video and a few hands-on experiences. There's a significant focus on his family history, his early days of animation, and the blossoming of Disney productions. 

Museum admission includes a screening in the theater downstairs. I saw Ichabod and Mr. Toad, Kids are welcome there. 

The cafe has sandwiches, soups, desserts. My main recommendation is to choose something hot! During busy times, the sandwiches are pre-made and left out without refrigeration. But also the hot stuff is just tastier. You can eat at one of the handful of tables inside or handful of tables out on the deck with a beautiful view. Of course there's also plenty of grass to sit on and eat.

Parking was easy. Granted we were there on a weekday, but we found parking right on the street in front of the museum(don't forget to pay and put the receipt on your dashboard!) and just across a swath of grass in a huge outdoor parking lot. Even the view from the parking lot is gorgeous. If you can't find handicapped parking in front of the museum, do a drop off in front and park in the lot.

As far as bringing kids, I'm glad I went with adults only to the Dali exhibit and that one is not great for young kids. The other part of the museum is more appropriate for young kids than the Dali exhibit but I wouldn't consider it a destination for young kids. I think ages 8+ would enjoy it significantly more.
author: Marina N.

description:
If you want to learn about Walt Disney, the man behind Mickey Mouse, then stop by here. Walt was not from San Francisco nor did he ever live there, but his daughter lives in the Bay Area. The staff here are very friendly and available to answer any questions you may have. Admission is extremely reasonable - should you be a student or a member of CAA/AAA, bring your cards as you will get a discount. I spent a good three hours here as this museum houses many artifacts. We learn about Walt's family background - his father was Canadian - to his last days in Brentwood. It is all self-guided so you can go as fast or as slow as you want. the tour ends with the gift shop. They had some cute Disney goods. If you're a fan of Disney, I would highly recommend a visit,

Good for: tourists, sightseeing
author: Mariko M.

description:
As a Floridian and certified Disney-addict, I give this place two Micky Mouse thumbs up.

One small warning --- this place is more designed for adults than kids so they may be bored
author: Bill S.

description: This place is boring and overpriced. It's a very low quality museum and their exhibits are a joke. I'm surprised they even charge, it should be free.  Also, expect to pay for parking. There's no free parking anywhere.
author: Nicolas C.

description:
First of all I have to mention how huge this museum is--much larger than we expected. We thought it would be a quick one hour visit.  We could have easily spent another hour or two .We ended up rushing through the museum since we wanted to have lunch in SF before and hopefully avoiding rush hour traffic.

The museum is housed in one of the buildings at the Presidio.  The setting is beautiful. I like how they kept the outside intact.  The inside is well laid out---lots of good signage, bathrooms on every floor, exhibits in a logical order with lots of hands on exhibits and videos with listening devices.  The lightning both natural and artificial was great.  So many museums are darker than they need be.  


We visited the Walt Disney Family Museum this past week using the Group-on coupons. Mr Rinky was very reluctant to go since he's never been pleased with Walt's political leanings.  

Even though I grew up in SoCal and went to Disneyland at least twice a year as a kid and teen I can't help remembering my mother's memory of our first visit to Disneyland .  Apparently Walt saw our Japanese-Amerocan family and gave us some major dirty looks.  Through the years there were some probably questionable policies regarding hair length, dress codes, sexual orientation and other policies that prevented people from entering the hallowed grounds.

There was an exhibit focusing on labor issues but we didn't examine it too closely.
My husband noticed that there was an exhibit of Disney giving testimony in an early HUAC (House on UnAmerican Activities Committee) meeting. Disney along with Ronald Reagan fueled the frenzy by implying that the labor issues were caused by Communist infiltration.  Several Disney employees were named and blacklisted.

I mentioned the above because Disney, like all of us, had good and bad qualities.

The staff at this museum was very sweet and welcoming and helpful.

We were given a map and directions.  We were asked if we wanted to see the movie of the day (free with admission) which happened to be one of my favorites, "Lady and the Tramp."

The first floor consists of cases featuring all the awards Disney had received over the years.An extensive and impressive collection.  I especially liked the Emmy with the seven mini Oscars for "Snow White and the Seven Dwarves."

The exhibits start with Disney's childhood.  Impressive films of his parents and early movies with special effects.  I forgot how Disney was talented in his own right.

I enjoyed the exhibits showing the early animated folks.  I especially liked an exhibit where you supplied the sound effects to a animated film (i.e.. turning a crank,
a "meow" machine)

We only scratched the surface--there are many exhibits here that we were only able to walk by.

The auditorium where they showed "Lady and the Tramp" was roomy but on the smallish side which actually added to the intimacy.

There is a small cafe which offers basic coffee, cold drinks and snacks.

The gift shop is small and I liked the fact that it wasn't just an offshoot of the Disney
Store with tons of clothing and toys. There were some books, DVDs, charms,
and other items.

So even though I have mixed feelings about Disney I thought the museum was
a great use of space, had well thought out exhibits and general layout.
I'm not sure if kids under 7 would like it although there seem to be hands-on exhibits it definitely is nor a "kid" museum.
author: Rinky N.

description:
As an avid fan of everything Disney, as well as a cast member for the company, I can't say enough about this experience.  I have followed Walt Disney's life since my childhood, but could never have known the full story...  This museum depicts the life and legacy that Walt left behind in a clear, concise and beautiful way.  You really start to understand and appreciate the impact this one man had on the world.  It's truly inspiring!

Plan to be there for several hours - I was there for four hours and feel like another visit is in order!  Great for families.  Very interactive and educational.  In a word, it's supercalifragilisticexpialodocious!
author: Michael G.

description:
We did the Dali exhibit as well as the regular museum. I'll review both. 

Dali/Disney exhibition:
First off, it's an additional $10 to the regular museum admission. 
I love how they did a side by side timeline for both artists starting from when they were born. And it really builds up to the moment where they become friends and coworkers. I won't spoil anything, so I'll just say that I learned a lot. I also recommend using their headsets. It has more information than what's on the board. It also adds narration to the videos throughout the exhibit. 

Walt Disney Family Museum:
They did such a great job depicting his life. And there were so many memorabilia to admire. Walt was a very meticulous and somewhat picky man, so they even had his favorite brand of food and toiletries. Then of course, they have all the things related to his life as an animator from the comics he used to draw to all of his featured films. They also have an impressive collection of all things Disneyland related. 

Overall, this was any Disney fan's heaven. It is overwhelming. They have an elevator at the halfway point so you can take a bathroom break and mental break. But I'd go through the museum slowly to truly appreciate everything he built.

Ps. They allow photos now! 

Pss. If you're staying in downtown, take the Presidigo bus. It's free on the weekends and takes you pretty much to the front of the museum.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I spent almost 4 hours exploring the main museum and the Disney & Dali special exhibit, so I definitely got my money's worth.

No matter what era of Disney you're into, you'll get lost exploring everything here.
author: Ryan H.

description: Great times! My 6 year old wanted to look, listen, and play with all the interactive displays. Last time we were here, we rushed though it. Even our 4 year old seemed pretty engrossed in some of the videos. So glad we actually got to spend some quality time and also check out the Pinocchio exhibit before it closes next week.
author: Mochi L.

description:
Really amazing! The Mary Blair side exhibit (extra $5) was really cool with pictures she had done for concept work for Peter Pan, Cinderella, Alice in Wonderland. Plus they showed a lot of her work on It's a Small World and her world travels.
The museum itself is really cool, although it gets very packed. There's clips on TV, photos, old merch, even a scale model Disneyland. It's great to experience. Lots of families.
The gift shop is really overpriced
Don't leave without trying the Chili at the cafe, it's cheap and pretty good. The Salted Caramel Macaroon was AMAZING
author: Kajal G.

description:
My mother is one of those people who loves Disney, Mickey, and Walt. It turns her back into an 8 year old, and you can see the joy just radiate from her. Her one condition of going with me to the bay was that we had to go to the Walk Disney Family Museum. 

Now this museum is owned and operated by the family of Walt, not the Disney empire, which I thought was interesting. It is also tucked in a national park that shows awesome vistas of the Golden Gate. 

The building is small, but brimming with trophy, and artifacts from Walt's life. It was a little expensive to go in, but my mother would have paid three times the cost of admission. I was not nearly as thrilled, but still interested. 

While she inspected everything, I spent my time doing a lot of reading. Walt through the years with the biography and self spoken quotes was my favorite part. Al thought I did not nearly enjoy as much as my mother, I did find some enjoyment out of learning about Walt's life. 

The model plan for the original Disney Land layout was completely captivating to me. Easily my favorite part of the exhibit. I could have stared at that thing for another ten minuets to appropriate it's detail and compare it to the Disneyland that I have walked around oh so many times. 


A good time even if you're not a Disney fan, but a blast if you have any love at all for Walt or his empire. Just try not to cry at the end.
author: Joey T.

description:
WDFM is targeted more towards adults and older children. It is about Walt Disney's life and work from humble beginnings to the success of creative curiosity. Expect to spend several hours in the main exhibit; there's a lot to go through! If you're an avid Disney fan, consider their membership as you get free admission to rotating exhibits. 

MAIN EXHIBIT
[+] multi-plane camera model in display
[+] mini Disneyland model, has a mix of Walt's ideas as well as past and current attractions
[+] theater room used for movie feature of the month (included in museum entry) and for special talks (additional cost)
[+] open studio for arts and crafts, from creating your own stop-motion video to hand painting your own cels (weekends only, 1-4pm)
[+] monthly themed Animate Your Night evening events, with drinks, photo booth, raffles, etc.
[+/-] last ticket sale is an hour before closing

SPECIAL EXHIBITS
[+] rotating exhibits that change ~6 months
[+] has featured Snow White, Where The Wild Things Are, Tyrus Wong (artist for Bambi), Mary Blair (until 9/7/2014)
[+/-] in a separate building, behind main WDFM
[-] separate admission fee

PARKING is part of the Presidio, $1.20/hr, everyday until 6pm

MEMBERSHIP
[+] options for individual, dual, family, and more
[+] can enter special exhibit hall with just the membership card
[+] discounted prices for special talks and workshops
[+] museum store discount
[+] includes free admission to affiliate museums
[-] quite pricey, dual is a better deal than individual
[+/-] if it helps, it is a non-profit organization

If you plan on visiting both exhibits, allot a day outing! It'll take several hours if you want to go through everything. Have fun!
author: Sandy T.

description:
Dream. Come. True. If you can't get to Disneyland, but need your Disney fix, THIS IS THE PLACE. I had such a great time. The Walt Disney Family Museum is at the Presidio, so you could make your visit here an all day excursion, with a picnic lunch and getting up close and personal with the Golden Gate Bridge at Fort Point after your visit. Get your walking shoes on, because the museum is big and you will want to ready and look at every single picture. 

The Museum is a timeline of Walt Disney's life, and what was so fascinating to me was learning what was going on in his personal life as all of those big Disney world moments were happening. I am a history buff, and a Disney fanatic so imagine how exciting this visit was for me. There are exhibits where you can listen to Walt, Roy, Lillian ect, tell stories, you can read original handwritten letters, view original drawings and even the Oscar Award is in the lobby for Snow White- check it out! One of the last exhibits is the original model of Disneyland *GRINS IN EXCITEMENT*. I couldn't take it, I could have stood at that model all day long! It took us about 2.5 hours to get through the entire Museum and it was so so so worth it! 

TIPS
-Halfway through, stop and get your self a sandwich at the café. They are reasonably priced and very yummy. You will need the energy!
-Goldstar.com sometimes offers half priced tickets.
-Pay for at least 2-3 hours of parking.
author: Liana H.

description:
Good, but not great.  

When I go to a museum, I want to see artifacts.  In the case of the Disney Museum, I wanted original artwork, or maybe Walt's desk or something.  Instead, most of the physical exhibits were just Disney memorabilia - old Mickey toys and such.

My favorite thing to see was the giant multiplane camera that gave cartoons variable depth for the first time.

I assume you could learn just as much about Walt from a documentary.

I actually preferred the attached Mary Blair exhibit because you could see her original artwork.  It's a temporary exhibit, but there are drawings and paintings for Cinderella, Peter Pan and Alice in Wonderland.

You can spend plenty of time reading and watching cartoons, but it's not a great place for kids.
author: Ben B.

description:
A wonderful place, right in the Presidio! This is an amazing place to learn about the man behind it all. I've been here a few times for events and to tour the space. Its exciting to learn about the younger Walt, his struggles and everything he went through to give these classic stories from his humble beginnings. There are some cool artifacts that Walt's family have curated. I am impressed with the aesthetics of the displays. There is a lot of reading as other Yelpers have stated, but it's really interesting information. 

I've also been here for events and presentations inside the theater. 
Great place, definitely worth a visit!
author: Marie P.

description: Visited with my 15 year old son and we both enjoyed it very much. It exceeded my expectations. Modern and very informative, gives a glimpse into Walt Disney's creativity and life.
author: Janna M.

description: Wow! I did not expect what was inside here. Before heading in, I understood this was a museum for the Disney Family and not a "cartoon museum." Based on that, I thought I'd see a few photos and artifacts from the family history. Instead I was treated to an elaborate multimedia display that was everything I'd expect if Walt Disney himself designed it. There are sections with interactive touch screens and immersive audio where you can listen to interviews and watch classic clips. There's a huge collection of original sketches and family history presented in a compelling and engaging manner. There's so much here and it's NOT some dusty old collection of family momentos. I was blown away by the quality and innovation of this HUGE display.
author: Dave S.

description:
One of the best museums I've ever visited! 

Extremely thorough education on the life of Walt Disney. Well done exhibits that are pleasing to the eye.. it is Disney after all. 

The building doesn't look like much from the outside, but be ready to spend a few hours here. 

$15 well spent.
author: Kenny V.

description: I absolutely love the Walt Disney museum!! I love learning about how Disney came to be. The entire museum is filled with loads of information on Walt Disney and his company. Lots of original sketches of the early stages of mickey mouse and original sketches from our favorite childhood movies :) My favorite part is always the model of Disneyland, but it always makes me miss Disneyland :( The staff is super friendly and always helpful, so I will be regularly coming back just to get a little piece of Disney :)
author: Gracey J.

description: Incredible museum for disney fans or fans of animation. Not really a museum for kids IMHO, a lot of history and information about the business and Disney's life.
author: Emma M.

description:
Nicely put museum. Just to let you know this museum is not about Disney characters, but about Walt himself and his entire journey from childhood to death. 

You really get to know the history of his clever business mind to his creative drive. The museum itself it not super huge like SOMA, but it's two floors and if you purchase the theater admission you can see the show/film. I opted out and only explored the two floors. 

I wonder if they ever change it up, but the yearly membership is only $80 which is not bad, plus you get to have a guest go with you for free each time. Admission itself is already $20 a person.

I came on a super sunny day which was nice. I parked right outside and spent $2 on parking for 2 hours. I would say 2 is the min you need to stay and you can probably stay there longer if you really take your time reading everything. 

I can now know what, who, where, why about Disney's history.
author: Minerva L.

description: an amazing museum full of wonderful information on the life of Walt Disney. they have a pinnochio art exhibit that is a separate price than for the museum but if you have time to do both, I would recommend both. The place is also a lot bigger than I expected. Also some cool artsy red chairs on the lawn outside that are chill to sit in.
author: Edward R.

description:
Took my 5 yr old daughter here for our first visit. I've been wanting to come forever and finally made it out today. You can spend hours in here reading about Walt's life and Disney in general. Since I was with my 5 yr old, I didn't get to spend as much time reading as I would have liked (there's a reason they don't charge for kids under 6!). Still, we were inside for about 1.5 hours and it was really fascinating to see and read what I could during that time frame. My favorite part was the scale model of Disneyland. My daughter said she had "an awesome time."

We concluded our self-guided tour by having lunch outside on the deck with a view of the Bay. It was a gorgeous day in the Presidio and we lucked out with perfect weather, escaping the heat of the Tri-Valley. Definitely recommend this museum for adults and older kids, as has been said before, however my daughter did enjoy herself and couldn't wait to tell her dad all about it when he got home!

Tip - it's not advertised on the museum website or on AAA's website (that I saw) but you get a $3 discount with your AAA card if you have one.
author: Nicole B.

description:
This place is a must see for Disney fans, though, as others have noted, may be a bit boring for the little ones except for certain portions. Most of the first half of the museum is about Walt's early life leading up to Mickey Mouse, Snow White, Disneyland, and his passing. There is a lot of information here that I know I wouldn't mind making a return trip sometime.

Lots of parking out front, not free. There is a gift shop at the end of the museum with some neat stuff.
author: Ryan H.

description:
In the beginning......

If you're a big fan of Uncle Walt, this is the place for you. Truly the ultimate tribute to the genius who dared to dream big, and created many childhood family memories.

Museum looks small from the outside but it's huge once inside. Lots of walking, reading, exhibits and videos.  Kids under 10 may get bored. The second half of the museum tour is probably the highlight concentrating on the movies, TV and Disneyland projects.

Great location with views of the Bay, and the Golden Gate Bridge.  Plenty of parking, AAA card discount and souvenir shop. I noticed in the downstairs lobby there was an art class folks can sign up for.  Overall visit took about 3 hours.  Good to revisit every 7 years or so.
author: Steve A.

description:
I have been dying to come here since I heard about it's inception, and it was a total and utter last minute decision to go on our way home from Palm Springs.

First let me say this, if you love Disney you will spend a long, LONG time here! The place is huge (so also wear comfortable shoes!). We arrived at 3:00 on the dot, knowing full well that the place closed at 6, thinking that three hours would have been enough time. Yeah, no. Budget at least four hours!  Our three hour stay included visiting the Diana Disney Miller gallery, which, I suppose, could be skipped if you really dislike whatever happens to be in there.

The museum is well laid out, and includes a lot of fun video and audio clips from Walt himself, which really helps bring the museum to life.  The museum is really about Walt, and the beginning of the museum covers his childhood and then works its way through to the creation of the studio to Disneyland, the World's Fair and his death.  There are a lot of neat artifacts about the various animated works, but the biggest disappointment is that a lot of pieces are copies of original documents, not the real deal.  Good copies, but it was disappointing to read facsimile over and over and over again.

Highlights include the train that once ran around the family home, a multiplane camera, and a large Disneyland diorama.

All of the staff that I interacted with or overheard interactions were very nice and friendly.

The only real downside to the museum is that I personally would not recommend it for children under the age of 9, maybe even 12.  There is a lot of reading involved, and subject matter that many kids may not be interested in, such as the strike Disney faced, and the studio's involvement with the war.  The word "family" is used to describe Walt's family, not that it is a museum oriented toward families.

Overall, fabulous place with SO much information and unique items! Can't wait to return!
author: Janey E.

description: Love this place! My kids and I thoroughly enjoyed the galleries and all the cool interactive Disney exhibits! So much detail, this museum is incredible.
author: Laura G.

description:
I'll start off by saying that I come from a huge Disney family, so my review might be a little biased. Just a heads up! Anyway, I've been wanting to come to the Walt Disney Family Museum for some time now after many visits to the bay area. But being close to three hours away, it took some planning and coordination to take the trip out there. Let me tell you though, this museum alone is worth the drive. The museum is located at the Presidio of San Francisco, just adjacent to the Golden Gate (you'll get a great view from one the exhibit rooms just FYI), on beautifully kept grounds. You can either make the choice to park in front by a meter and pay by the hour or to the rear of the building which will cost you about $7 bucks for the entire day (not bad for San Francisco if you ask me). We even went as far as walking down to Crissy Field for lunch leaving the car in the Disney lot. Anyway, the museum is incredible, even with the $20 ticket price, though I got in for free as they offer free military admission year round. The exhibits themselves offer a detailed look into Walt's life and that of his brother Roy's as well. Starting chronologically with his birth and boyhood, the exhibits progress from Walt's childhood influence on animation and art through to his very last projects of the mid sixties. They touch basis with everything from his service in France during the war, to his first feature animation (Snow White), Fantasia, his parks, the studio strike, and so much more. You can easily spend all day here, as I spent 4 hours speed reading and photographing through the museum. I will definitely be back for more. 

What were the great points of this museum?
The exhibits are colorful, and full of things to look at, not only to read.
Those include the first EVER known illustrations of Mickey Mouse with Ube Iwerks and Walt, a TON of vintage Mickey and Friends merchandise, the large Disneyland Park model (this seems to be the focal point for most people that visit), Walt's personal collection of various items from things he carried every day to items from his office at the studio, his scale model trains that he took people for rides in and built himself, and SO much more. If you love Disney, this is a must do.

My only gripes are that the gift shop is very limited in merchandise, the cafe being very small, and the exhibits are a little hard to follow or know how to chronologically maneuver through without the help of an audio guide.

Otherwise, this is one of the top museums on my list.
author: Brandon T.

description:
It was definitely very enjoyable coming here and learning about the history of Walt Disney and everything he created evolved. The museum was definitely different from what I expected going in but in a very pleasant way.

When you enter the first floor gallery, you learn about Walt's roots prior to this entry to show business. Emphasis was made on his contributions to the first World War by driving an ambulance in France (and the things he had to do I order to be allowed to go).

After taking the elevator to the second floor that's when things get more interesting. You learn about Walt's initial entry into show business. I learned about the character Alice and his first animated series "Silly Symphony" (correct name?), both prior to the creation of Mickey Mouse.

It was after reaching the point that talks about Mickey that the fun started. There were many video display showing features and such. I enjoyed learning about the origins of his fellow characters Goofy, Pluto, and especially Donald Duck (which was described as Mickey's foil because Mickey can never get mad).

After that there were galleries describing full-length features starting with Snow White, and much discussion about each dwarf (very informative). Later there was displays discussing Fantasia, and one detail I was surprised to discover was it was considered a financial failure despite its long run on the big screen.

Later a big highlight is the gallery discussing the creation of Disneyland, including a sizable model of the amusement.

Concluding the gallery are display of magazine covers and other discussion from when Walt Disney passed away. I wish I took a photo of the French magazine photo showing a very tearful Mickey Mouse.

I spent just over two hours in the gallery because I was with a friend and her young nephew and niece, but I felt I could definitely stayed much longer especially if I was to slowly read all the displays and watch all the videos shown.

Regular admission price is $20 but I bought Groupon deals earlier in the year for $10. There are often similar online deals for admission here on other sites..
author: H K.

description: Nicely organized and really interesting artifacts. there's a lot to read even though much of it is redundant be prepared to stay for at least 2 hours. Location is beautiful as well with a huge grassy area and a view of Golden Gate! DoDidn't seem very engaging for kids though, which would be what most people assume because of the name. Admission was $20 but $15 for students!
author: Angeline H.

description:
An avid fan of all things Disney, this was an immersive experience into a story that the movies and the parks don't tell you; the story of the mastermind himself, Walt Disney.

Be forewarned, if you're hoping to step through the doors and into a Disneyland-esque environment, turn around NOW! It's nothing of the sort. However, if you're fascinated with how a man created an empire with a mouse (and are willing to read... A LOT... to find out) this is an absolute destination.

It's a bit overwhelming at first, I will definitely attest to that. Your first room has movies playing, pictures of people you've never heard of before and the walls are covered in text about an upbringing of a guy named Walt that you get an immediate sense, you don't know at all. You peruse through this lobby and make your way to the next door where the second room is just as overwhelming as the first. At this point, you look back at the entrance, but you've come too far and then suddenly let yourself become immersed in the greatness of Disney.

Throughout your self-guided tour, you'll come across amazing pieces of history, from Walt's early career as a newspaper comic artist, to the first ever sketches of Mickey Mouse, into the making of the first full-length Disney movie, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, and into the creation of Disneyland, Disney World and Walt's final moments. I must confess, we had to breeze past the last few rooms due to the fact that the museum was closing, but it was truly a great opportunity to delve further into the mind of one of time's most creative visionaries. I will definitely be visiting again with a few extra hours of time on my hands (I'd plan for around two and a half to three hours if you're really into this kinda stuff).

If you're a Disney fan, and have ever asked yourself how any of it was possible, do yourself a favor and head over to the Walt Disney Family Museum. You might not leave with mouse ears on your head and a belly full of churros, but you'll have a greater appreciation for it the next time you do.
author: Michael S.

description:
If your a Disney person this place is a must go to. History about Disney and much more! A lot of vintage mickeys love it! There was a lot to see, hear, watch and learn. This is place is fun for teens and older. I guess it will be ok for younger kids, but there is a lot of reading to do so maybe they may get bored.

But I spent 2 1/2 hours here easy. So if you go, make room for this because this place will take up a lot of your day. 

But a very fun place to experience  at least once in your lifetime.
author: Stacy H.

description:
I'm not sure why the Disney Foundation decided to build the Walt Disney Family Museum in the Presidio area of San Francisco but I thought it was an educational venture while up in SF.  My cousin and I hopped on the MUNI to the Presidio.  The Google Maps bus transit feature is better than any MUNI app you'll find out there.  It calculates your route, tells you what bus to hop on, and even tells you the amount of the fare.  Cool, right?!  So for $2, Vanessa D. and I headed towards the Presidio.  We also walked down Lovers' Lane.  It's weird to do that with your cousin, but I digress.  Google maps says the walk from the bus stop is 1.2 miles.  WTH?  Sigh, a nature walk.  The walk wasn't so bad.  Although, I did get a few, "Are we there yets?" from the cousin.  Out of the forest, we stumble onto military baracks in brick.  It reminds me of Portland, well sort of.  

We purchased tickets through Goldstar for $10 plus a $4 handling fee.  Normal admission for adults is $20.  The museum was unexpectedly educational.  Things you didn't know about the Walt Disney family and Walt's personal life are exhibited in galleries.  Like how he and his wife tried for a large family but only had one daughter.  They adopted another girl, Sharon, shortly after Diane turned 2.  There's a huge mini replica of Disneyland in the main room.  There are photos everywhere and animated posters.  There are collections of Disney memorabilia of days gone by.  There are personal artifacts like Lilian Disney's 'Snow White' charm bracelet made by Cartier and gifted to her by Walt.  There's also Walt's 'Dopey' money clip on display.  The museum chronicles the life and death of Walt Disney.  

The museum is clean, well presented, and has the most comfortable benches I've ever sat on at any museum I've ever been to.  The gift shop has a lot of Disney inspired products that you might not see anywhere else.  As an annual passholder, I have yet to see some of the items for sale at the Disney museum gift shop anywhere at the Disney Parks.  You see, the Disney Foundation runs the museum and has no connection, except for name, to the Walt Disney Company which runs the parks and the massive Disney empire.  This little museum was done privately by the Disney family.  It's their homage to Walt Disney and for all of his fans.
author: Trina D.

description: If you're a baby boomer,  this is your history.  In the lobby are cases with artifacts, awards and recognitions  from around the world.  All of his Oscars are in one case - amazing.  Through the doors it start chronologically from the childhood home, to Hollywood, the pre-war years with Snow White, Bambi to post-war and Disneyland.  If your lucky you'll listen to a docent's  20 minute talk about Disney and Disneyland history. Pretty Cool.  Younger kids will skip through most of it.
author: brian f.

description:
This has been on my to do list for the longest time & thanks to a failed attempt at attending a free concert, the hubs & I ended up here. This museum revolves around Walt Disney's life from birth until death. Do plan to spend at least 2-3 hours here. Believe it or not, there is a lot to do in this museum & not all of it is reading!

You can really get a sense of what kind of person Walt Disney was through this museum. A very dedicated, passionate man who also loved his family. 

What I loved most about this museum is that it's interactive for both kids & adults! There's quizzes, videos, audio, etc. be sure to look through the window during one of the last few exhibits for a lovely view of the Golden Gate Bridge! Simply stunning. 

Also, if there's special exhibits, your admission ticket is good for all of them! I happened to be around for the Tyson Wong exhibit & he was a very important part in the making of Bambi. His artwork is very meaningful & quite beautiful. Definitely check out his work if you ever get the chance!

This is a must visit destination for any Disney fan, young or old!
author: Annie M.

description:
So I'm from LA, and in LA I live like 20 mins away from Disneyland. So being a SoCal girl and growing up going to dland nonstop, this place was just made for me! Its so awesome to see the history of Walt Disney himself and how he created the fantasy of Disneyland. My favorite part was the model of disneyland. Like there was an actual model of how Walt disney pictured dland to look like. And it really looked just like disneyland back home. So I thought that was the best part because I felt like I was at home. I also loved the quotes at the end of the museum. Like, this one man with such an extraordinary imagination can create something so big and wonderful to every child and adult till this day. Its so amazing to see the beginning and the end of his journey and how its still living on today. Even if Walt Disney isn't here with us anymore, his dream is living on. And I think a lot of people tend to forget his dream. One quote that I have always love and being at this Disney Family Museum made me really remember it. 

"All our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them." - Walt Disney
author: Evelyn C.

description: It was a journey to get here from downtown SF but well worth it. It looks small on the outside but there's so many cool exhibits inside and very interactive than you would think. It's not a disney museum but a museum of Walt Disney himself. You can really learn a lot about the guy who really did make the world a happier place!
author: Jenny M.

description:
If you're a Disney fan or just a fan of animation, you'll find this museum worth a visit. Hidden away in the Presidio, this museum was much bigger than I expected. I thought we'd be there an hour but we were there all afternoon!

It really goes through Walt Disney's entire life in pretty good detail. There are several rooms and it's organized well - everything is chronological and there are a ton of examples and artifacts and lots of information to read. Be sure to pick up the telephone receivers when they are there because many of them include audio of Walt speaking about what you're looking at.

It's much more focused on the animation and movie side rather than the theme parks but they do have a model of Disneyland that's pretty fun to look at.

Overall I'd say adults will enjoy this more than kids.
author: Holly R.

description: Loved it! Not recommended for kids. It's mostly about the history of Walt Disney, how he got started, how he created the characters, the animation, and Disneyland. There's a lot to read. It can be overwhelming but very interesting. We spent about 3-4 hours here. Inside there's a movie theatre that plays old Disney movies. Be sure to check that out.
author: Victoria S.

description: Disney did an awesome job with this place! I couldn't believe they fit everything that is there in this building. It's amazing! It was an awesome experience and I can't wait to go back. It's free for military families.
author: Patti S.

description:
NOTE!!! The movie about Dali and Disney from the current exposition 'Architects of Imagination is not playing!! I was excited to visit the museum particularly for the movie and the collaboration between Disney and Dali, but when I found at the end, after walking the complete exhibition, the centre piece of the exposition, where the collaboration between the two was based on, namely the movie wasn't screened!! I felt truly disappointed. Some Disney Character, should explicitly have mentioned or written this on the website. 

You can watch the movie, which I would save for after my visit, her https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1GFkN4deuZU

There still were some great works from both. And the explanation of the symbolism, such as the signification of the clock and the and walking in the palm of the hand, is beautiful.
author: Kikien B.

description:
My husband and I went to the Disney Family Museum to see the Disney and Dali: Architects of the Imagination exhibit (open from July 10, 2015 - January 3, 2016). I must say, it far exceeded our expectations. This exhibit would be most enjoyed by adults and older children who have a strong interest in art, art history, and surrealism.

This well-curated special exhibit is housed in a building behind the main museum and is priced separately from the main museum (and you don't have to pay for the main museum if you only want to see this exhibit). The admission price includes the use of an audio device and headphones. Alternatively, you can download the app onto your smart phone. You don't necessarily need it as most of the spoken audio is also displayed as text in each numbered area. But is nice to have, and is eloquently narrated by Sigourney Weaver. Allow yourself plenty of time as there are (if I remember correctly) 33 different stops in the exhibit.

The exhibit includes original correspondence between Disney and Dali, a number of short videos, artwork, and drawings. Some Dali paintings are originals and some are replicas. I enjoyed seeing some early work by Walt Disney himself, and there is a lot of artwork by his various studio artists. The exhibit draws parallels between the early careers of Disney and Dali (just three years age difference), both of whom were ahead of their time and dreamers in their own way. Surrealist images by Dali are shown side-by-side with concept art by Disney Studio artists who had been encouraged to push the boundaries of their own creativity; it's quite surprising how much overlap there is between their vision. The videos include clips of various Disney animations, and the dream sequence in Hitchcock's Spellbound that Dali had designed.

The exhibit presents the history behind the collaboration between Dali and Disney Studios for the short film Destino. Unfortunately production was cut short by financial troubles for the studio around the time of World War II. Some of the actual paintings and sketches developed for the film are shown in this exhibit. Destino was picked up and completed many years later by Walt's nephew Roy. All that was missing from this exhibit was the short film itself. Too bad, it would have been a culmination to an interesting and insightful exhibit. Nonetheless, many kudos to Ted Nicolaou, the guest curator of the exhibit!
author: Tracy W.

description:
When you wish upon a star 
Makes no difference who you are 
Anything your heart desires 
Will come to you...
