There's a whole lot to take in at the Walt Disney Family Museum, but the question that really lingered in my head ever since it opened a couple of years ago was..."Why the Presidio?" I wondered why it wasn't at or near Disneyland or Disney World or part of the Disney Studios. Instead, the Disney family foundation renovated and expanded three barracks buildings in the Presidio into quite an impressive series of galleries that follow Disney's life, legacy and death. In fact, the journey through the museum reminds me a bit of a ride my mom would like in Disneyland like the People Mover which is coincidentally showcased in a vintage poster. 

It's an oddly although not unexpectedly claustrophobic place. You start in the lobby where you're surrounded by all the accolades Disney won through his extensive career, including the famous special Oscar he received for "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" which included a coterie of miniature Oscars representing each dwarf. The first room you enter after your ticket is scanned spotlights his childhood and early adulthood. Then you go up a period-looking elevator where you start to see how he and his brother Roy partnered to create Mickey Mouse. There is a great wall showing 348 enlargements of a single minute of Mickey's debut cartoon, "Steamboat Willie". 

Things move quickly from there and go through the production of his classic full-length animated films, nature documentaries, WWII propaganda features, and then how he branches out to television and theme parks. Along the way, you get an unexpected view of the Golden Gate Bridge behind the barracks. His death is given an appropriate tribute as well as a multimedia room where you get a final recap of his multi-storied life. Speaking of which, none of the more controversial elements are covered here, so don't expect a personal expose. On the other side, the kiddies may get bored during certain, text-heavy stretches of the museum.

The gift shop, of course, is chock full of Disney memorabilia but nothing of the magnitude you'd see in the theme parks. Yet, for its thoughtful, thorough approach and for all the attractive design touches, the museum still left me a bit wanting. I made the inevitable comparison with the Charles M. Schulz Museum up in Santa Rosa and just feel Walt deserves something even bigger, more spacious and certainly more interactive than the Presidio barracks could afford. Admission is a bit steep at $20, but the museum is a most worthwhile visit regardless, especially for baby boomers and Disneyphiles.
author: Ed U.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  We went here with a pretty big group for the museum's version of "After Dark" or "NightLife" called "Animate your Night".  The theme for the night was Heinrich Kley (animator from Fantasia).  At $10 for entrance, it is DEFINITELY worth it.

Live music
Palm reader
Photo area (with printouts for each member of the group)
Stop motion animation downstairs (no way to e-mail or send to yourself, but bust out your phone and record the video) 
A HUGE gallery
buttons, masks, free izze drinks
passed h'or dourves
fantasia playing in the downstairs little theater

so worth it. esp. if you LOVE disney! they have maquettes which i LOVE. a miniature little disneyland from back in the day! free parking out front. the event is 7-10 which gives you plenty of time to get something to eat after some small bites at the museum. 
 can't wait for the next one!
author: Anjelica C.

description:
Anyone who would give this place one star because it's not Disneyland needs to be slapped.  Seriously?  It's not called "Disneyland 2" or "Mini-Disneyland."  You HONESTLY expected the WALT DISNEY FAMILY MUSEUM to be some flashy, ride-filled fun parade?  That's like going to a really good Italian restaurant and giving it one star because they don't have Doritos Locos Tacos.  I think you're a little off there....Oh, and P.S., check your grammar!!  

OK, rant over....

This museum is nothing short of impressive.  The size is huge, you could easily spend all day there.  There are passages and quotes to read, actual home movies of the Disney family, photographs dating as far back as Walt's grandparents, audio of Walt and his family telling stories, video displays, actual equipment used by the Disney studios, the list goes on and on.  I love all things Disney: the parks, the movies, the characters, but most of all: the nostalgia.  I visited the museum with one person who shares my love for Disney, and one person who loves history and is just OK with Disney.  When we left, the latter was the one going on and on about how great it was.  

I'd always had a great respect for who Walt Disney was, but this museum lets you really experience him as a man: both personally and professionally.  I left with a deeper admiration of him.  What stood out most to me was his drive and work ethic: he never gave up, even in the face of terrible adversity and back-stabbing people.  The other thing I enjoyed was seeing how much he loved and adored his family.  The display of him spending time with his grandson at Disneyland was beautiful.

Historical events shaped the way the Disney came to be, and they do a great job incorporating history into events in Walt's life.  You get to see how the events in the world and in his family influenced the decisions and breakthroughs he made.  It was both educational and inspiring.

The museum is visually and architecturally beautiful, 17 rooms all connected by hallways or creative use of elevators.  I loved the displays of artifacts.  The ones I was most excited to see where the first known drawing of Mickey Mouse (and all the earliest merchandise), and the actual train Walt had built in his backyard that would later be the model for the Disneyland Railroad.  

Don't bring young kids unless they like reading and history.  Photography IS allowed (not flash).  Totally worth the admission price.
author: Christy M.

description: What a fantastic museum. As a big fan of Disney and a history aficionado, I've always been vastly interested in the creation of Disney and Walt Disney's life. This place answered so many of my questions. The employees were super knowledgeable and helpful (I had A LOT of questions). The artifacts are unbelievably cool. I felt honored to be in the presence of such great history. Plus, it is located in the Presido, which is always a beautiful part of San Francisco.
author: Tyler K.

description:
This beautiful place truly makes you appreciate the amazing mind of Walt Disney. The museum is really inspiring and introduces you to Walt Disney the man, as well as the Disney creator. You learn the history of a lot of old favorites such as Peter Pan, Snow White and man other.

This is a great place to take the family or even a significant other. There's a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Parking is cheap and there's a beautiful grassy area in front of the museum for the kids!

Highly recommended!
author: Felix N.

description: A very informative museum, a lot of reading and not as many interactive exhibits I was expecting but still a great visit. The staff was very friendly. I liked the Dali exhibit, we also went there for a Talk by a Disney animator which was interesting. I'd suggest people to go but not to expect a Disneyland type of experience, more educational.
author: Ranee W.

description: This is a must for any Disney fan.  There is a ton of really interesting information and loads of memorabilia. It take a couple of hours to get through it, but well worth the effort. I can't wait to go back!
author: Jessica S.

description:
An exquisite, five-star museum experience...

Enchanting from the very first room you enter (after presenting your ticket.) The first display details the very young life of Walt Disney and is presented via three v-e-r-y clever works of (flash?) animation. 

From there, you continue following Disney's life story through various interactive presentations and artifacts.

With each new room you enter, there are details and nuances about every project Walt Disney embarked on ... including missteps and failures. You will discover facts you may have never known about previously such as the Disney company involvement with WW2 and Walt Disney's tenure as an American "ambassador" to South America.

The tour can take an entire afternoon if you allow yourself the luxury of every exhibit. If you have the time to spare, there is even an additional screening room you can visit (showing the classic Mary Poppins when I was there as the new "Saving Mr. Banks" film was due to hit theaters soon.) The museum ends a bit abruptly, the same way Disney himself died. The history here stops at year of Disney's death ... but we all know the legacy lived on.

There is a gift shop and a separate gallery for ancillary exhibitions. That gallery is usually a separate admission price and though the show being presented at the time sounded interesting, you can keep quite busy with the main museum.

Also on premises you will find the museum's cafe serving respectable (if pricey) sandwiches and drinks. We decided to have lunch there and found the soups and sandwiches to be ahead of the curve culinarilly speaking. They could use a bit more seating near the café proper, though you can find more seating downstairs and thats not made apparent enough on the first floor. 

Caveats the first: there is a good amount of walking to the museum. It doesn't seem like it but there is a lot of walking so take the time to use some of benches provided in some exhibits to get off your feet.

Caveat the second: leave any child under 12 years old with a baby sitter. Yes, this is all about "cartoons", but it really is about animation as an art form and the untethered children running around indicate this place is not for the GameBoy generation.

If you are a fan of the Disney animation from the past, or even pop culture or Americana, then you owe it to yourself to visit this tribute museum originally conceived by Walt Disney's daughter.

Since you will be on the grounds of San Francisco's 'Presidio' area, plan to visit the Yoda statue at the entrance of the new-ish Lucasfilm complex. The Yoda stature and it's reflection pond are a Yelp favorite and worth the short trip.
author: Ray B.

description:
This is the first time I've wished I had more than five stars to give - for anyone who loves Disney, this museum is an absolute must! Every exhibit is beautifully planned and designed and curated, and you come to fully understand and appreciate Walt Disney's vision and lifetime of incredible accomplishments. Each gallery keeps you fully engaged and all of it adds so much to your love of Disney animation and parks.

Likely better appreciated by adults than by kids, but I wasn't a museum lover as a child anyway. Tickets are currently $20 per adult, and 3h curbside public parking is easy to find even on a weekend morning when the museum opens. Gorgeous views of the Golden Gate Bridge from inside the museum too!
author: Cynthia V.

description:
I love a good museum!! 

I learned so much about the whole Disney family, the animation process as it was back in the day and the current process. Very informative and well laid out. My favorite part was the massive model of what Disneyland looked like when it first opened!! 

There are some cool views of the golden gate from the upper floor of the tour too- turn around and look out the window to check them out!!

The gift shop is nice (items can be pricy but they usually are at a museum gift shop so I have no problem with that). The cafe is well stocked and what you would expect. Bathrooms were spacious and well kept! I would go back.
author: Amy M.

description:
Loved this place! Thought it was very informational, and I was surprised how big the museum was. Each room was a separate story with each one of Disney's movies, and I loved seeing all the sketches and videos used during the process of making a movie.

Will be coming back!
author: Cal C.

description: The Disney museum is a great place to visit. You can learn about Walt, his family and how Disney got its start. This place does require some serious time to cover the museum. The reason is that you have to read a lot of the stories and go through all of the different exhibits. If this museum ever offered an audio tour it would be a 5 star place. We spent about 3.5-4 hours here and skipped over a few things bc we got tired and hungry. Keep in mind this is a museum about Walt and his life.
author: Paul L.

description: A must for any Disney fan! Exhibit halls were a bit hard to follow at times and the Tomorrowland "exhibit" was more of a hallway near the bathroom, but the collection is outstanding. We spent about 3 hours exploring here. The Disney Dali exhibit was worth the extra ticket fee (took about an hour) too. Note that this isn't a Disney museum for kids, littles will probably be pretty bored.
author: Katie B.

description:
Disney fan?  Go... just go.  It's truly a wonderful experience and like Disneyland, it's  something you can do more than once.  There is so much information and each room is impeccibly designed with Disney flair.  The main museum is awesome and then there are also rotating exhibits featuring other artists.  My family and I went to the Maurice Sendak exhibit this past July and it was truly impressive and heartwarming.

The gift shop is also very cool with unique items for all ages... reasonably priced, in my opinon. There's also a little cafe near the entrance which serves sandwiches, salads, desserts in addition to drinks/coffee so you can hit that up before or after your museum visit.
author: Janette M.

description:
This was truly a highlight of our visit to San Francisco.  The size of this archive is a bit overwhelming even for a Disney fan but, wow, what a collection it is.  Beautifully and thoughtfully curated with love and utmost respect to Walt Disney, his family, and his amazing colleagues throughout the various decades of his impressive career.  We were already fans of Mr. Disney and his legacy but now have an even deeper and richer respect for his achievements.  

A must-see for anyone that is even a casual Disney fan although, personally, I don't think that younger kids (under 14) would really have the patience or understanding to appreciate this type of museum that's essentially a giant biography with a ton of reading and decades old info to read/absorb.  I would highly recommended this attraction for ages 14+ and even for those that don't know much about Walt Disney; you'll certainly learn a lot and most likely will really enjoy this experience.

Our only regret is that we did not have more time because we honestly felt we could have spent more than one day absorbing all the information and visuals.  Bravo to the staff that maintains this wonderful archive on the life of a legend.

Good to know:
*The Disney movie-of-the-month on-site is included with paid admission.
*Parking is plentiful at the Presidio site but not free.
*Wonderful view of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge from this location.
*The cafe inside the museum has a limited and very overpriced menu but there are plenty of places to eat nearby or bring a picnic and enjoy the lawns on the grounds of the Presidio.
author: Tina P.

description: My wife and i are big disney people. we recently visited the museum and absolutely loved it! its a definite must for Disney fans!
author: Angel B.

description:
Favorite museum in SF? This one takes the cake. 
The location is gorgeous. I took public transportation, which is a little ways away... But the walk has so much lush greenery, it's a treat to walk instead of drive up.
Be sure to check out the yoga fountain outside of lucasarts before you get into the museum. 
The museum does a great job recapping Walt's life until death, and yes a tear will shed when you find out he dies at the end.
There is so much Disney history that I wouldn't be surprised if you needed to come here more than once for it all to sink in.
Did I mention the views of the bridge from here? Simply stunning.
author: Lissette V.

description:
For as far back as I can remember, I've been a fan of the Walt Disney Company, but now I can say I am a fan of Walt Disney, the man.

I've recently begun to fall in love with Disney all over again, so visiting the Walt Disney Family Museum was such an awesome experience for me.

I had no idea what to expect because I'd never been to the Presidio area of San Francisco, but this place is beautiful and the perfect location for a museum to honor Mr. Disney.

The layout of the museum is pretty easy to follow.  There are hundreds of photos and a lot of reading is involved, but if you listen carefully, there's audio to help guide you through as well.  Here you will learn about Walt's early years and what moved him to become the inspiration he still is today, alongside details of his personal life.

This museum is meant to highlight Walt and his achievements, and it definitely does that.  While reading the names of different people who helped him along the way, I couldn't help but think of all the "random" names all over Disneyland's Main Street.  Everything Walt Disney did had a purpose.  Everything Walt Disney did had to be just right.  He never settled for less.  He knew what he wanted.  He strived to be the best at what he did.  He became the best at what he did.

What I love about the museum are all the personal photos, the animations, the memorabilia, the awards, the handwritten notes of Walt, his personal Lilly Belle train, and of course, the miniature Disneyland of Walt's dream.  I left here with a deeper appreciation for and admiration of Mr. Disney and all that he's done for our generation and those to come.

Not everyone may enjoy this museum, but if you're a fan of Disney or a fan of animation, I'd highly, highly suggest a visit here.


Other helpful bits:
Definitely geared toward adults
Admission:  $20, but different discounts are available
Parking:  $7/day, but I'd suggest using Uber if you're out of town and staying in a hotel
author: Angie D.

description: A great series of exhibits walks you through the life and work if Walt Disney.  Largely filled with art and artifacts, there are a couple of interactive exhibits. Because of this, younger children are likely to become bored.  However, if you love animation or even fondly recall Disney films from the Golden Age of Animation, then you will find this place interesting. The museum housed many personal items owned by Disney and includes art from various films.  One of the highlights is the first sketch of Mickey Mouse.  They also have temporary exhibits that will keep you coming back.
author: Brad C.

description:
This is such a classy museum in the Presidio - yes, it's a little out there but when it's a gorgeous day with the Golden Gate Bridge shining in the background, it is so worth it.  This museum is well put together and is done in Disney classy style all through keeping you interested as you read about the history of Walt Disney and see the animation develop over the years.  There are lots of little and big surprises that tie it all together.  There is a gift shop, cafe and theater onsite too.  Plus, if you are there on a Sunday, Off the Grid trucks and booths will keep you fed across the way on the field.  

There are Presidio GO shuttles from downtown to near the museum, or you can take the 43 Muni, or you can drive of course (plenty of street/lot parking).
author: Maile N.

description: There are hundreds of excellent reviews here telling you what to expect to see when you visit. I won't add to their thoughtful and thorough (Donna H. 10/26/09) details. I'll instead focus on trying to explain how this museum makes me feel. I was always a fan of Disneyland, the place. As a child I spent a lot of time there, and the sights and smells of Disneyland were always like home to me. When I grew up and had my own kids I made sure they spent time there as well. Every time we leave Disneyland it's a hard goodbye. I hate leaving and always wish we could stay longer. Disneyland is truly a fantastic dream made real through the monumental efforts and amazing imagination of Walt Disney. The Walt Disney Family Museum pays loving tribute to the man who created so many wonders. When I visit I am overwhelmed with feelings of nostalgia. I always marvel at the beautiful design and layout of the galleries. If you love Disney, please go. You won't be disappointed, and you might not want to leave.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
This museum begins at the start of Disney...way before the motion pictures and through to his peak and ultimately to his death. It's really an amazing collection of original drawings and photos throughout Disney's life. The museum itself is also way bigger than it seems from the outside. It takes roughly 2.5 hours assuming you read through each blurb and participate in all the mini hands on activities on the touchpads. 

My favorite room contains Walt's vision of Disneyland and I am always sad when I reach the end. Right now, until February, they have a special exhibit on Tyrus Wong. It contains a full room on his work for Bambi, but what really steals the show are his vast collection of handmade kites. They are the most fantastic, beautiful works I've seen.

Aside from that, there is also a room with floor to ceiling windows with a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate Bridge. And they also have some neat workshops to check out on the weekends and a daily movie showing.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The Walt Disney Museum is not usually one of the big things you think about when you think of San Francisco...  However, it is located smack in the heart of the Presidio, within spitting distance of the big orange bridge, so it's bound to become a popular tourist spot.

Some thoughts based on my recent visit:
-Parking was free* and plentiful!  (Never thought I'd say that about any place in SF!!)
*free on weekends

-Admission into the museum was overpriced, and I even had a $3-off coupon (thanks, Google-search!).  Regular price is $20pp, and the special exhibit costs more on top of that.  

-The view of the GG Bridge was a really nice surprise while walking between exhibit rooms! (photo link: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-walt-disney-family-museum-san-francisco?select=7V16jRHZoTg-0W2O3Jj6Fw#iqpadRqvRm19m8xsiNt7hQ)

-It's easy to take graphics and animation for granted these days (computers make it much easier!), but the museum helps to teach us what a huge innovator Disney was, developing what must have been really cutting-edge stuff back then!

-The hallway about Walt Disney's passing is heartbreaking.  Nothing like seeing Mickey Mouse cry to wrench at your heartstrings.


All that being said, I have NO CLUE what this museum has to do with San Francisco... seems like Anaheim or Burbank might be a more logical place for it.  You get the whole life story of Walt Disney and his family, but I *could not* figure out why they opened this museum in SF.  Oh well, it's still a cool place to check out, so I shouldn't complain too much!
author: Chris Y.

description: Simply amazing. There is so much to see. They have two museums you can see. One is strictly for a Disney movie. And the pick and choose which film every few months. The other museum is for Walt and his family. There was so much to see in each. Every room I was amazed at what was in there. I recently wanted a film called Walt before mickey on Netflix and it explained his whole beginning. And then the museum showed the same information.  Walking through his life and his legacy was absolutely amazing. My favorite part was the last room you see before you exit. It was after Walt's death and other artist designed works that depicted his legacy. There were pictures of his animations sad and crying because they just lost their creator. It was the sweetest thing to see. What was also amazing was the diagrams they showed of disney land. They have multiple interactive stations to learn about a specific film, his partners, Walt himself. What I found most interesting was Walt's hobbies and interests. This is a must if you are in San Francisco and or a Disney lover.
author: Krista P.

description:
I try to come here as often as I can. The main museum is very nice, lot's of interesting memorabilia and innovative technology to make it all interactive (although really, what else would would you expect from something Disney?) I love to bring my friends with me when I go, and they all agree that it is great, even though they aren't obsessed with Disney like I am. One of the most breathtaking things in all of San Francisco is walking down the ramp that wraps around the Disneyland model. It is incredibly beautiful, and words can't describe it well enough.

The secondary exhibits are in a whole different building, which makes them feel special, and they are top notch as well. So far, I've seen the Maurice Sendack one, the Salvador Dali one, and the Pinocchio one. All three were amazing, and had a lot of pieces that I was shocked that they were able to acquire.  The museum workers mill around, happy to answer any questions you may have.

Lastly, there is a theater in the basement of the main building. It isn't in operation at all times, but they do really fun shows when it is. They'r usually structured around a theme, like a compilation of vintage holiday shorts or something along those lines. It's small and intimate, and you can really feel the Disney magic.

All in all, this place is great. It isn't Disneyland (my favorite place in the whole world), but it's a GREAT fix for when you can't travel there. I love it!
author: Erica M.

description:
What an amazing experience! I took the tour for the Mary Blair art exhibit and was pleasantly surprised. (Blair was an artist and animator who was involed in productions such as Alice In Wondeland, Peter Pan, and Cinderella, just to mention a few). The gallery was so well organized and the drawings and paintings left me wanting to see more and know more about this artist. I am not big on museums, more of a "speed" tour person, but between the tour guide, the art itself, and the information that was set with each piece, I truly felt engaged.   

After touring Blar's exhibit in Building 104 we went back to the main building.  This tour started with vintage pictures of Disneys family and short flicks of where he and his family came from and how his career began.  This particularly is a lengthy, but informative self-guided tour and you will want to take your time. Fill the meter up for sure. I made the mistake of not doing it. You could easily spend 2-3 hours on this one alone!
author: A. C.

description:
Great museum for the adult Disney lovers of the world! You'll leave with a ton of knowledge about Walt Disney the man, his family life, the history of the Disney brand and company, and an urge tore watch all of the classics from Snow White and the Seven Dwarves to Dumbo and Fantasia!

Definitely an adult museum though- displays, plaques, signage, and labels are everywhere and they're text heavy. There are also a lot of pictures and stuff to look at, but without doing the reading they aren't particularly meaningful.

My favorite parts were the multiplane camera and the side-by-side comparisons of The Ugly Ducking videos circa 1931 and 1939- so much progress in the field of animation and in the talent at Disney! The expansive area on Walt's vision, plan, and execution of the Disney Land theme park was also personally meaningful to me, as I visited the park for the first time exactly a year ago. 

Got my ticket at half price through Groupon- worth checking to see if the promo is still running, as the $20 regular entry fee is a bit steep.

The museum itself is large and they've done great things with the space- though it's an impressive building from the outside, the museum space itself seems even larger than the building it's in.  Street parking was available right in front for us, and they even said it was a busy day for them. 

Museum gift shop is a little lacking- some like the lack of trademark Disney merchandise, but I found that the store was terribly overpriced and had a variety of kitschy stuff that didn't have anything to do with the museum we'd just experienced- think coffee mugs with a single bird feather drawn on them, circle globe earrings, generic handmade felt stuffed animal Christmas ornaments, etc.
Would have loved to find more references to Minnie mouse within the museum or in the store.
author: Stefany V.

description:
Came here for the Tyrus Wong Exhibit. So inspirational! If you want to hear an amazing story of a man who beat the Chinese Exclusion Act and went on to become one of the greatest artists at Disney (and first Asian American Disney artist), check this exhibit out. The landscapes, watercolors, and works he made for both Bambi and Warner Bros. (classic movies such as "A Street Car Named Desire," etc.) are absolutely breathtaking. Amazing if you think about how this guy was so poor growing up he'd paint using water; his characters drying up before he could even finish them. There's also tons of stuff from his personal life -- crafts he made his children for Christmas, the fantastic kites he builds now, and even old Chinese watercolors and murals he made before starting out at Disney. 

The main Disney museum is also a must here if you're a Disney fan. (Tyrus Wong runs until sometime in February and is in a separate building behind the main Disney museum). At the main building,  you learn all about the life of Walt Disney and all his works. There's even cool videos of original footage of the artists drawing, reference models at work, first original cartoons, and concepts behind Disneyland and more. Watching these clips and seeing all the original artwork and photos brought back a wave of nostalgia for me. It is truly so beautiful. A great place to take the family- young and old alike if they grew up with Disney! I think it's about $15 for the main museum entrance and $10 for the featured exhibit. Worth every penny in my opinion.

I can see myself coming back to this place every time they feature a new exhibit! It's truly wonderful!
author: Evonne L.

description:
A short and sweet review, since I'll be reiterating much of what has already been said by previous reviewers.  

This is a wonderful museum that pays homage to Walt Disney the man, highlighting his life story, his path to become an animator and entrepeneur, and his enduring legacy.  The museum is ideal for MEGA MEGA MEGA Disney fans and animation history buffs - everyone else might be a little disappointed. 

It's easy to assume that a museum with Disney in its name will be a treat for all ages, but it ultimately isn't kid friendly.  Interactive exhibits are based more on education than entertainment, and the majority of the exhibits are text with photos.  It's like a great history book come to life.  

2 major highlights: when you reach the section where Disneyland comes to being, you see an amazing model of the park, with both original and added attractions.  As a Disneyland buff, staring at this model was like taking a quick trip to the Happiest Place on Earth, and reliving many great memories!  Another highlight was around the halfway point you enter a long glass hallway with a magnificent view of the Golden Gate Bridge.  We lucked out and visited on a sunny day, it is truly spectacular.  

So be prepared to learn a lot - this museum, while great, is less amusement and more education. 

*I Yelp today in honor of Roger Ebert, the ultimate critic - RIP*
author: Terri N.

description: Great place in a beautiful location with amazing memorabilia.  I just wish the male cleaning crew would knock and announce themselves before coming into the ladies room.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
An absolutely wonderful place.  If you're not Disney fan, it's still worth taking a look.  Walt Disney did a lot of stuff.

And if you are Disney fan, you must go see this place.  Now.
author: Jon N.

description:
OK, I noted all the Yelper comments, and understand that not all, like me, are gonna give it those five deserved stars.  Fours are OK, just to be fair and balanced.  Now, giving one star (or two) rating is just wrong.  

We were there from the opening at 10:00 AM, and stayed until they they kicked us out at 6:00 PM.  No, it not Disneyland with cute characters in costumes of Goofy or Minnie Mouse, so be forewarned.  What it is; a fantastic trip through the past, from the early beginnings of cinema, through the great depression, the war years, plus seeing the technological advances in the arts.  The history lesson is fantastic, and instead of expecting your children to be amused with scary rides and twirling teacups, use this time to educate them about how the world works.

Nough said.

PS: the smallish cafe is OK, and the gift shop varied and interesting too.
author: Marshall W.

description:
Have you ever wonder who created imagination? 
Well, think about it? Who?

I personally don't have the answer, I would assume that person was in charge 
of my life and most of my childhood memories. So, the majority of my lauding,
and appreciation, goes to two people... A Man and a Mouse!

Creativity is a hard thing to come by nowadays, so it should be lauded. 
So having a homage to the person who created "Disneyland" and "Mickey Mouse"
and various characters of Disney fame, it's only right to have a museum in his honor.

As mentioned in reviews early the museum is a HIDDEN gem.
It's pretty close to "Fort Point" It's a private museum but is worth
every penny you pay for.

You can see the details of Walt Disney's History and of Roy Disney.
The struggles and accolades, awards, various questions and quotes,
from different interviews, the attention to detail was narrative on parts
of the Disney dream, and Man dedicated to a craft to try to make people happy.

Very educational - take your time, please and revisit some of your classic
movies like "Snow white, Lady and the tramp," and even "Peter Pan."

I seriously was so engrossed with the Museum but the end...
I almost came to tears. Seriously, I felt so much gratitude for 
the innovator of imagination.

Pro-tip : Take your time at the Museum
                I personally, liked the Snow White extra footage and details
                on how they made the animated movie, but I would only
                do it once since it can be a little pricey. ;)

IF YOU ARE A DISNEY LOVER.....GO!

Thank you Mr. Disney!
author: Michael R.

description:
This review is just for the gift shop portion of the museum as we didn't have the time (or really the want to spend 20 dollars) to wander around the museum itself.

The gift shop is amazing.

Very few if any items are actually Disney and thus the commercialization which usually just slides under your radar, is shown full force to not be in effect here.

Each item in the store looked to be lovingly chosen for it's likeness to the movie it's section displays. For instance, the Snow White area had a deep red clear glass apple picture clip and Cinderella's had several small sewing baskets with removable tops, neither of which were actually related to the movie or Disney. I actually ended up purchasing the basket since it was so cute.

It really reminded me of a time when Disney wasn't a conglomerate, but  a family park with shops like The One Of A Kind Store, shops where everything wasn't Disney copyrighted and the was a little bit of everything within it's walls.
author: Meg T.

description:
The Disney Family Museum was superb. My kids (5 and 3) enjoyed themselves, my wife was impressed with the animation, and I learned a lot about Walt Disney the man. You can do the museum in two hours or make a solid half day out of it. 

We went a month prior to a Disneyland trip and found the Family Museum to be a nice juxtaposition to the Parks. You really get a sense of the workmanship that went into the pre-computer animated films. 

Finally, any review has to also talk about the location. The Presidio Trust continues to impress me with solid, quality residents on this former army base. And the museum appreciates their location, building the scenery into the exhibits.
author: Philip S.

description: We've been here on many occasions and as a Disney fan I wanted to show by virtue of a yelp review how wonderful this place is to visit regardless if you're not a Disney fanatic.The Presidio itself is a historic site.  This place is not owned by Disney and is not a Disney store. It has on display a lot of memorabilia from Walt to include a train collection. There a many activities and film to keep the kids occupied. It's a decent size worthy of a half day visit.
author: Gerald H.

description: We came late on a free day. The people who organized his memorabilia did a great job. I felt like I was really experiencing his life. It was really interesting seeing what he did. I can also say me and my bf teared up at the end. It was a great experience. I highly recommend coming here at least once in your life. Great family place too of course.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Let me just say: WOW. 

This is, hands down, the best private museum I have ever visited. I was honestly taken by complete surprise by the size of the museum, the quality of the exhibits, and the amount of time you could spend here. I definitely do not think the website accurately represents this place; I came here expecting to spend maybe an hour looking around, and we were here for maybe 3. We could have been there longer if we didn't have to be somewhere at a certain time, so we rushed through the last couple of rooms. 

There is a lot of detailed information about his life (yes, a lot of reading), but the museum also has a large number of "things" to look at. Additionally, they do an extensive job of integrating media into the exhibits. Throughout the museum, there are screens showing different clips of movies / cartoons, there are interactive media devices, little phones that play recordings to you, and more. 

My favorite part was the gigantic scale model of Disneyland that had a ton of detail and moving parts. I could have stared at that thing for 30 minutes straight. 

When I visited, they we doing a special exhibit on Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs that had a large amount of information on how the cartoon was actually made, and it was extremely interesting - this level of detail on animation was not present in the permanent exhibits. It was definitely worth checking out. 

I wouldn't necessarily recommend taking younger kids that can't read to this museum as they probably wouldn't be able to spend as much time in each room as you would want to if you are trying to experience the entire exhibit. 

There was a little snack / beverage place inside of the building where you could grab a drink and hang out for a bit at some tables. My group took a rest there between the special exhibit and the main one. Additionally, they had a gift shop with a bunch of cool things available for purchase.

If you love Disney, you should visit this museum.
author: Becca S.

description:
Wow this was an amazing museum, probably one of the best I've been to in a while. The outside is a standard colonial facade from the old Presidio but the inside has been done up very well with rotating exhibits and technology galore presenting the life of Walt Disney.

As a Disney fan, I truly appreciated the history and stories behind the scenes of the founder as well as the art and music of the works.

The Disneyland model is probably one of the highlights of the museum and brings me back to my inner child.

20 dollars for adults - totally worth it. Plan to spend about 2-3 hours here at minimum.
author: Julia P.

description: I absolutely loved this museum! I'm a huge fan of Disneyland, DisneyWorld, and most Disney films so it was a great opportunity to learn more about the genius behind it all. If your a fan of Disney, this is must see here in San Fransisco, and it's totally worth the $20 admission!
author: Brian A.

description: This museum is awesome! It's a great collection of Walt Disney's life story. He was just an amazing man and this museum gives so much respect to him.  It is nicely done by his daughter Diane who is a co-founder of the museum.  There are 17 galleries, which was much bigger than I thought.  It took about 3 hours (including time to eat lunch), but if you read everything and listen to all the audio, I am sure it will take a lot longer to complete. I wish the cafe had more variety of foods for meals.  The gift shop is pretty cool with all types of Disney items.  The cashier Mark is super friendly and amazing.  It was nice chatting with him about Hawaii.  He was so nice to give a map of  Presido, which helped in discovering the Yoda Fountain!  So funny at the end he was like "Shoots!"(I really appreciated that use of Hawaii lingo).
author: Kim O.

description:
This is a must-go for all Disney fans! We decided to visit the museum on Walt's Day, aka his birthday. It's free admission for the whole day with extended hours! We got there around 9:30 am and there was already a line (the museum opens at 10:00 am). We got the tickets and spent almost the entire day there. We left around 3:00pm? We took a break for lunch at their cafe. Don't let the exterior deceive you, because there's so much to see, read, and do! The exhibits just never end! Anyway, my favorite part of the museum was probably all the stuff towards the beginning. I enjoyed learning about Walt's earlier humble days and how he came to be. The exhibit towards the end was great as well, but less interesting since you know all about Disneyland etc.. 

Pro tip: Right after the exhibit on Walt's favorite foods and personal collections and right before you enter the exhibit featuring Disneyland, you'll walk through this hallway with large glass windows on the left. Look out the window and you'll see the gorgeous Golden Gate Bridge. Be prepared to be awed by its beauty and take out your cameras!
author: Cassy H.

description: Fun fun fun. Takes you through his entire career, and it's fascinating. Some of the old movie cameras are really cool too. We went in on impulse, and glad we did. Was a great way to spend a rainy afternoon.
author: Blondie P.

description: Simply a wonderful place to visit; you can spend hours looking at all of the Walt Disney history. We took a free Presidio shuttle from the Hyatt at the Embarcadero, and back. the museum accepted auto club and senior discounts.  Everything was presented so well, and was so interesting and enjoyable.  A real treasure!
author: Robert T.

description:
I went to this museum today and overall had a good experience. It's in the presidio so was of course nice area with beautiful - great view from the museum of the golden gate. 

The museum itself was busy. With Aaa and student id my ticket was $12. Parking $1.50 per hour which isn't bad either! 
Very historical life of Disney! To me I felt like there was a ton of focus on certain movies/ characters and some were totally left out. They have super cool exhibit of Disneyland I will post. It does kinda end abruptly with his death. Overall if you are a Disney fan I would recommend, but make sure you have 2-3 hrs!
author: Carol G.

description: Being at Walt Family Museum make me realized through his failures. Walt never gave up. He persevere and never gave up his dreams. I thank him for his vision and the ideas he brought to what our children called Disneys World.
author: Vinny M.

description:
I love The Walt Disney Family Museum! Their current show is "Magic, Color, Flair: the world of Mary Blair" (3/13 to 9/7) and "Leading Ladies and Femmes Fateles: The Art of Marc Davis."

I really liked Mary Blair special exhibition. I wish they have more! For repeaters like me, it'll be nice to have more of the special exhibition part since the permanent exhibition doesn't change items that much. 

Little addition of Marc Davis exhibition at the basement was pretty nice, too. They were showing "Sleeping Beauty" at the theater as a part of the show (the ticket includes the movie). They only show twice a day (1:30PM and 4:00PM) so plan the day ahead. 

Make sure to pay for the parking. It's not free even on Sunday. If you get caught, it'll be very expensive since it's Federal. 

During the Summer season, there's a "Off the Grid" twice a month on Sundays. You can go to the museum and have a nice lunch on the lawn, right in front of the museum on sunny days. (You can always go back into the museum as long as you keep your ticket.)
author: Mariko H.

description:
This museum follows the life of Walt and ends when he passes.

Sister is a huge disney fan and have wanted to visit for awhile. We were finally able to last weekend and we both enjoyed it. 

Located in the Presidio area. 

PARKING was easy for us to find --there's a paid by space lot directly across the building.

DISCOUNT: They are able to take multiple discounts, example: student and AAA discount can be applied. 

GIFT SHOP: One of my favorite parts of museums are the gift shops, and I was a bit disappointed in the selection for this one :(
author: Sunny W.

description: If you remotely like Disney, you'll love this museum.  Being a disney fan, i loved the history of the park and Walt himself.  Great to come with family.
author: Dj S.

description: Took the family to this yesterday. While I thought it was pricey, especially for my 8 and 9 year old kids, it was well worth it. The museum was so much bigger, had a lot more information than I could have expected. We paid extra to also tour the Pinocchio exhibit. All of it was really well done! Walt Disney was definitely a man before his time! We will certainly plan a return trip so we can take more time to view and read everything about his life. Oh, and to (hopefully) take part in the grassy picnic area!
author: Christina S.

description: This is where all the Disney memorable items are at! Kept safe and sound! At least 10 rooms filled with articles ! Trophy after trophy, western union telegrams,awards family an friends pictures. And what a man he was to work for, and with. One man that brought the world forward. Thank you for that!
author: Lynn D.

description:
I absolutely love this place !! As a huge Disney fan, I was quite excited to hear that the museum would be out in the Presidio. This is definitely another hidden gem in the city. 

This is a must see for Disney fans as well as anyone interested in the history of the Disney corporation or Walt Disney's work. It takes you through the life, aspirations and struggles that Walt Disney faced to create the original disneyland resort and the concept ideas which because Walt Disney World. From losing Oswald and the creation of Mickey to Fantasmic and beyond, this brings you back to the roots of the global giant Disney has become and pays tribute to the man who dared to turn his dreams into reality.

Original artwork, cels, props, video and audio footage accompany the tour. Additionally, much of the original interviews, quotes and photos/video are used to tell the story from Walt's point of view. The original posters and interactive displays allow guests to see how the films and characters were created. Highlights from my visit would definitely be the large model version of the original Disneyland park, original SteamBoat Willie artwork and the gallery highlighting the first Disney films.

I would recommend taking at least 2 hours to fully immerse oneself into everything the museum has to offer. Also, as this would not be considered a "kids museum", younger children may lose interest quickly. The gift shop provides wonderful souvenirs for Disney fans young and old alike and the adjacent cafe is perfect for those who want a refreshment after the tour. In Disney tradition, even the smallest details are accounted for. The walls in the lounge/restroom/coat-check are decorated with original movie and theme park attraction posters, much like what you see at the park entrances.

 The price of admission is $20 for regular adult (which can be reduced to $15 with AAA membership) but is well worth the money spent. The gorgeous view of the San Francisco Bay and Golden Gate Bridge on a nice day are an added plus as well.


- Jenn
author: Jenn Y.

description:
I have had friends and family tell me to go to this museum for years. I finally made it up to the city on Dec.5... That is Walt's birthday and they celebrate by giving free admission. After so many recommendations and all the hype I have been hearing, I still was not sure what to expect and worried it wound not live up to my raised expectations.  This museum is so well-planned, creative, fun, and informative. Four of us went together. All four of us loved it! We all highly recommend to all Disney fans, and anyone interested in the creative process of making animated films before computers.

A couple tips - for first-time-visitors I would recommend seeing the movie about the building of the museum first, before walking around. It gives a good family history, answers a lot of questions about the museum, and gives some items to look for that otherwise may seem less interesting than other items.   We went on a Friday and parking was wonderful. There is a machine where you pay, but we had no issue finding a spot.   Don't look into what they have.. Just go and be open to enjoy.   To walk around takes roughly 2-3 hours but more time could be spent, easily. 

Treat yourself to a fun, creative, informational day at the Walt Disney Family Museum.
author: RaeAnn M.

description:
Oh my gawwwwwwwd.  Being the huge Disney fan that I am, I was told this is a must-visit.

I don't want to say too much about the museum, but I loved walking through Walt's life from the moment he was born until his death and even some after that.

Each room is decorated in such a beautiful way with drawings, pictures, interactive pieces, and short movies, that you are almost transported to the exact moment in history.

The museum isn't huge, but since there is so much information to read and take in, I would highly recommend at least giving yourself a good 2 hours and then maybe 15-30 minutes for the shop afterwards.

I really enjoyed my visit to The Walt Disney Museum and would totally go back again and spend more time in each of the rooms/exhibits.  

Parking is free on Saturdays, there are a couple lots surrounding the building.

For all Disney and Disneyland fans, I promise you will thoroughly enjoy this museum!  Go go go!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
A friend and I recently decided to check out this museum in the Presidio. Fun fact: the reason this museum is here is not because Walt Disney himself had any strong ties specifically to the Presidio but because his family lives nearby and wanted to find a large amount of space in order to dedicate a museum to him--they decided that this would be a good place which is why the museum exists where it is.

It's $15 for the museum and $10 for the exhibit (when I went it was the Walt Disney train exhibit) or $20 for both. These are the student discount prices btw.

It's honestly just such a well done museum. There's a ton of history and it's just so informative and inspirational. I didn't know anything about Walt prior to this museum but after reading everything, it was just so cool getting to learn more about how inspirational of a dude he was. He was such an optimist and someone who really believed in his dreams... and I think that's really inspirational stuff. The trains exhibit was basically about his passion for trains and where it stemmed from while the main museum starts off with an insanely comprehensive overview of his childhood and family background. I was really impressed that they were actually able to get this much information about him! Anyways it was that, and then how he started animated films, some of this film history, how Mickey was created, then a section on his other films and the company he started with his brother Roy, then a mini section on trains and the creation of Disneyland.

A ton of knowledge packed into a seemingly small museum. There are also some gorgeous views of the Golden Gate bridge as well. 

tldr; really lovely museum and certainly worth checking out if you're a fan of Disney!
author: Jasmine X.

description: Excellent experience! The Museum had a lot of parking and it was easy to find.  The museum itself was very informative, and as a Disney fan, I spent almost 3 good hours at the museum.  Be prepared to do a lot of reading! Also, I would not recommend this museum for children.  We saw a few kids there and they looked very bored.  There are a few interactive exhibits, but most of the museum were pictures and drawings from the Disney family. If you are an adult Disney fan, it definitely pays to go!
author: Brian Y.

description:
At the mention of Disney, most people will associate that name with fun characters and amusement parks. But at the Walt Disney Family Museum, it pays tribute to the Disney that started it all.

The museum takes you on a journey of how it all came to be. The emergence of an empire as the result of Walt Disney's passion. You get to know Disney in every aspect of his professional life and personal life. You see his less recognizable works and the transformation of popular characters over time. There is also a section with original sketching from few classic Disney movies. Of course, not everything is glamorous. The museum shows the struggles Disney faced when he started his first company and with the Disney company. 

I really enjoyed this museum. Walt Disney felt so real to me. I loved the handwritten list for his cook when he got tired of his wife's cooking.  Or the fact that he invested his own money, not his company's, to build Disneyland because he was afraid the idea might fail. I felt that he deserved all the awards displayed in trophy room if not more. And I was especially moved by the story of his passing and the newpaper tributes as he had deeply affected the world.

Just know that even though it's called a family museum, it's really a museum more for grown-ups.
author: Marti L.

description:
As you can tell, I rarely get around to reviewing non food related places so it must be something for me to say something about a museum.  Admission was $20 each or $25 for the combo tix that allows you both regular museum admission + access to the special exhibit which was Snow White right now.  Do note that the special exhibit is time entry so you need to arrive at the set time that you choose.  

We went for the combo pack and ended up spending so many hours here, I felt like my legs were about to fall off and wish there was a monorail to bring you around.  We started off with the Snow White movie which I realized during it that I've read it as a child but never actually seen the movie so it was nice seeing it play out and noticing the differences between the book and the film.  It was a nice segway into the special exhibit as I started to notice a lot more things that I otherwise wouldn't have.  The special exhibit took about an hour to go through and is in a separate building behind the main building.  

The main exhibit spans the life of Walt Disney from the early years all the way til the end with everything you can imagine in between from his struggles, his movies, and Disneyland all across 10 areas.  It truly is a magical experience especially for adults.  

Note:  Although there were children there, it is geared more towards older children and adults who can really appreciate the life of Disney.  

So the next time you need a rainy day activity, head over to the Walt Disney Museum!!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Wow.  This place is pretty amazing.  If you want to read every little thing, watch every single video, do all the interactive gizmos... you need to allow about 5 hours.  That's how much Disney there is.  It's pretty amazing how many artifacts, original artwork, memos, etc. they have.  It's designed so that as soon as you enter the first exhibit, you forget all about the real world.  I really felt like time stood still while I was in there.  I don't want to give too much away in this review, so I'll leave it short and sweet.  

PS.  Not sure if it's a good place for little kids, they might get bored.
author: Chloe M.

description: What a cool place for Disney lovers to go! There is some great history about the beginning of Disney inside this building! Highly recommend stopping here!
author: Matt B.

description: My boyfriend took me here on a date because we're both huge fans of Disney and I must say, it was much bigger and nicer than I expected! There are two levels and it takes about 2 hours to walk through and look at everything, 3 or 4 if you decide to listen to all the sound clips, watch all the short informative films, and read all the blurbs and descriptions. If you're a fan of all things Disney I highly recommend you don't let the opportunity to come here slip. The large scale of Disneyland is stunning as well. (just don't try to take pics of it over the glass or the employees will stop you)
author: Trina I.

description:
Wow, what a great museum! I learned so much more than I expected!
An amazing man and journey.
author: Michael M.

description:
I went to this museum with a Disney fanatic.  If you, yourself, are not a Disney fanatic, at least go with one.  It makes it that much more enjoyable.  It took us about 3 hours to get through the museum (with the last hour being a speed reading through the displays) but can easily go 4 to 5 hours if you read and digest everything it has to offer.

The museum is well kept and beautifully arranged.  I learned so much not only about Walt Disney but the way the technology evolved to create what is now Disney (Pixar and Star Wars and all).  It seems like a chain of events that are serendipitous.  In any case, the geek in me loved the techy part of it.  I would've loved more interaction with the set somehow.  I would've loved to take pictures but due to copyright issues, we couldn't.  

The bridge in the middle of the exhibit overlooks the bay and it was a gorgeous day when I went.  

I think it'd be worth going at least twice, to catch anything you might've missed.  My brain was spinning from reading all the displays and my eyes literally hurt.  Still, the information made you feel connected with Walt Disney and I teared up at the end when reading all the tributes after his death.

The gift shop is expensive but offers some nice gifts to take home with you.  The food is pretty good (my friend had the chicken sandwich there.  He raved about it all day) but pricey.  Sort of like Disneyland.
author: Lynn C.

description: I am a huge Disney fan (I am an annual Disneyland/CA Adventure passholder) so wanted to check out their Walt Disney Family museum. It was an enjoyable museum located at the Presidio (the entrance to the Presidio has these beautiful towering trees along the rode towards the building structures- you would never know that you are right near the financial district with high rise buildings). The view of the Golden Gate bridge toward the end of the walk through of the museum is beautiful. I think it would be boring for smaller kids but highly recommend going if you are a Disney fan and above the age of 10.
author: Aimee C.

description: Not anything related to Disneyland, has ALOT of history, very interesting and if you have any Walt Disney curiosity this is a MUST!! It's so interactive, kids might not have the most fun since it's a lot of reading.
author: Liliana D.

description:
Wow, this place is deceptively large and FULL of stuff. Came here recently for the Snow White exhibit, which was about an hour visit alone. When I started getting into the general exhibit, I knew I was not going to be able to do both in one trip.

From what I saw, the museum is very modern, with a great pace to it. Fyi, this is definitely more an adult museum. I mean, I think all museums should be devoid of kids, but there's a lot of reading and detail that would probably be missed on the eyes of those wee ones.

And hey, did I mention the museum is situated in a really gorgeous section of the Presidio, with a great view of the bridge? Check it out.
author: Jon T.

description: Great spot to visit with older kids or adults.  The info on Disney's life is in-depth and fascinating.  The interactive content is really unique and fun.  The exhibits are very high quality and really beautifully done.  Parking in the nearby lot is easy, though note when there are events scheduled in the area.  We visited one Sunday morning and thankfully arrived to park as they were setting up Off the Grid.  In hindsight, that was great timing.  We emerged from the museum after about 2 hours and had a great time visiting the food trucks.
author: Patrick S.

description:
My boyfriend wanted to take me here although it felt more like he dragged me here, hahah. But I was so glad I came! He was giving me a preview of Walt Disney before our disneyland trip. 

The parking you have to pay for even if it is Sunday, then you enter the beautiful doors of the museum. Buying tickets are pretty simple, if you are in the military it is free excluding the train because walt Disney did serve our country as coast guard and etc! So boyfriend got lucky... Lol besides that they also have student discounts. 

It was advised to take the train first then go into the museum, they will direct you to the train and it is going through that walt has a enormous amount of love for trains and the stories behind them. 

The museum itself is AMAZING. I do not want to ruin it for you! 

The souvenir store could be a little better and the variety of the food they serve.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I'm an only child. I grew up watching Disney. Micky, Goofy, and Donald Duck were my best friends. Visiting this museum and learning about how Walt Disney animation came to be, was so mind blowing. I can hardly believe someone like him existed. He did so much before the age of 30 - what is my life?

This museum is tucked away deep in the Presidio, and its so random. It looks like a military barracks outside, as it once was. We stumbled upon it. Being a native to SF for 24 years, I had no idea this even existed. Maybe I don't get out much? It does look small and quaint from the outside, but this is a deception. We spent a full 3 hours inside, and that is with skipping a few displays and not reading every single exhibit.

My favorite part about this museum was learning about Walt's involvement in World War II, and how he helped the US create WWII propaganda through his short animation films. It makes you realize how truly monumental he was to American history and culture, other than the fact that he revolutionized animation forever. I'm also obsessed with WWII in general so that was icing on the cake for me. Der Fuhrer's Face was awesome. and hilarious.

I do agree with the other reviewers when they say this place isn't for kids, but maybe your young kids will gain a few IQ points going through this museum? It's worthwhile. Just go.

Also, free admission for military, which they don't like to advertise but it's true.

I LOVE DISNEY FOREVERRRRRRRRRRRRR
author: Angeli W.

description: If your a Disney crazy fan (like me) go here for sure. But also recommend to anyone. It was a nice place and there was so much to see. Bonus part is at the end basically where u get a great view next to the San Francisco bridge which makes for a great picture. Fun and interesting
author: Destiny J.

description: Wow!! If love Disney and you love Disneyland you will absolutely down all day here!! Amazing place for ALL ages!!
author: Mike D.

description: Hidden gem... We thoroughly enjoyed our ~3 hour tour through Walt's fascinating life.  Highly recommend this for a great day trip.  Plenty of interactive activities leave you feeling like you really knew the man and his family.  The museum aptly pays tribute to his genius and passion.  The location in Presidio is beautiful.  The staff is courteous and accessible, always with a smile!
author: Don W.

description: Great experience. We visited the gift shop first and had a man named Marc tell us great places to visit in the bay and had a great personality. Marc made us feel really welcome and I loved that!! The museum was great, way bigger than we expected. His whole life is portrayed and I loved how they divided the exhibits with sound, movies, and artifacts. We also did the Pinocchio exhibit which was very interesting to learn how the old movies were done and the development of technology to produce Disney movies. It was a remarkable find and I'm glad we went!!!
author: Morgan W.

description:
Spent a wonderful Saturday afternoon at the Walt Disney Family Museum! Like many people who probably attend this museum, I'm a Disney child; grew up on the colourful, fictional feature length cartoons and oh my - this museum surpassed my expectations! Granted I knew it was going to be about Walt, his family and his legacy, I felt it was done with that classic and warm Disney charm that makes my heart smile :)

Lots of interesting factoids, artifacts and videos from early in his career. The exhibits follow a logical flow and lots of side activities to participate in as well - this museum is a definite must see for any Disney fan!
author: Alex P.

description:
The first thing you should know is that this is a must for any true Disney fan. I'm not sure whey this in San Francisco but it is located in a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
I went to the Mary Blair exhibit, who designed its a small world and other Disney proprieties. it was wonderful and had a tour provided to go with it. The family museum is made of a couple of buildings with special exhibits in a separate location.

The main exhibit is the entire life of Walt Disney with extremely interesting displays that paint a wide scope of who Disney was, in all fairness it even takes the artist strike into perspective. 

There was also a side exhibit of art by Marc Davis who did much of Disney's female villains, it was amazing to see original artwork and cells of famous Disney animated movies. 

This is must for Disney fans.


Free coat check
author: Adolfo H.

description:
This museum is very beautifully laid out, clean, and informative. I am a huge Disney fan, and it doesn't take much to impress me with Disney memorabilia, but I feel like they could have upped the excitement factor in the museum a little bit. We all got a little burnt out at about 3/4 of the way through.

My favorite part was the miniature set up of Disneyland. It was really magical. I probably would have given the museum only three stars, but the fact that Bill Farmer (voice of Goofy) and Bob Gurr (famous imagineer) were downstairs signing autographs made my experience much more memorable!
author: Stacy K.

description: If you're a Disney fan, this is a must visit attraction. We are kid-free and enjoyed this very much, but this is a great museum experience for the family. The history behind Mr. Disney's beginnings and the formulation of his positive outlook and success he found, even in his failures, is remarkable. There were great visually pleasing pieces to this museum as well as some interesting Disney facts. This was very much about the person and not as concentrated on the Disney works.  Recommended!
author: Julie D.

description:
There is SO MUCH to see and learn here about Walt Disney and how he built his Disney empire from the ground up.  If you're a first time visitor, forget trying to see any of the temporary exhibitions and go straight for the main exhibit.  I'm the kind of person that likes to try to read every little thing, including the handwritten letters from Walt himself to family or business partners, so I barely made it through a third of the museum in 2 hours.

It starts with a history of Walt Disney's family origins, goes through his childhood and early interest in cartoons, to his move to California and first animation business ventures, and then goes on to shed light on Walt Disney Studios and beyond.  I definitely need to go back so I can see the rest of the treasures here.  It's chock-full of memorabilia, and there's even a scale model of Disneyland.  I saw some people with Disney-related clothing or pins on, so this must be like another mecca (besides Disneyland) for the consummate Disney fan.

Visit the cafe and gift shop too--  I got a great coffee table book all about Alice in Wonderland.
author: Amy H.

description: If you're a disney fanatic, this is the place for you. It's Walt's life and everything you could imagine. Although I expected it to be something like Universal Studios, there was cool mini activities and it is a museum after all... what was I expecting right? Awesome place for kids and adults as well. Loved learning about the history and the staff were really friendly. Let's not forgot about the mini disney land inside and the many different themes!
author: Vanessa G.

description: For some reason, even knowing that the name is "The Walt Disney Family Museum", I went in thinking Disney Museum, as in the parks, rather than the family.  It was actually a very pleasant surprise, and there was a lot more in there than I expected given a relatively small building.  Very interesting to learn about the Disney family and to see old sketches of how some of our favorite characters came to life.  Not a place to bring little kids, expecting for them to see a lot of Disney items, there are a lot, but more on the family and films and information on their history so probably not fun for the little ones, but good for adults.
author: Heather G.

description:
What an amazing tribute to Mr. Disney! I found it fascinating to learn about his early days, how he got started and grew his hobby into an institution.

The exhibits are nicely laid out and cleverly designed to take you through his life. The visual presentations are so well done that you can't wait to get to the next one. Although this is geared for adults, we brought our young granddaughter with us and she enjoyed the cartoons, colors and sounds. She was intrigued by the 3 Little Pigs animation which allowed us to fully absorb the entire exhibit without distraction. 

I am of the age where everyone in my class had visited the new park named Disneyland before I did in my late teens. It has always been a magical place and even the park model filled me with the same happy feeling as being there. It was an "E-ticket" ride through Walt Disney's life.  I had forgotten that we lost him far too early but his legend lives on to inspire others.
author: Suzy S.

description:
This museum is about Walt Disney's life. It starts with information about his early life and family up through his death. The museum is larger than it appears. There are 10 galleries and lots of information to read. Make sure you allow yourself at least 2-3 hrs.

My favorite part of the museum is the miniature Disneyland model, and learning more about Disney's early films. I also enjoy the view of golden gate bridge. 

The special exhibition is Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. I highly recommend buying admission to this exhibit. You'll see original artwork and explore the history behind the film. My favorite part of the exhibit was reading about parts that got cut from the film. 

After my 1st visit to this museum I decided to become a member. 
Admission is $20. Membership is $75. Membership allows you and a guest unlimited free admission which I think makes membership worth it if you live in the bay area. Plus 10% off the museum store. 


TIP - Photography is now allowed! Just no flash.
author: Nicole S.

description:
A true 'only in SF' experience for Disney fans, history buffs, and museum wonks alike. The museum boasts one of the most advanced museum multi-media experiences in the world, and it is hard to argue. It highlights and details Walt's life and life's work, certainly trumpeting the Disney glory while not shying away from detracting aspects as well (e. g., a section of the museum documenting the 1937 Disney animators' strike, etc.).

For Disney fans, unique highlights include:
* Trophy case of Disney awards including an Emmy and multiple Oscars... quite a thing for us mere mortals to stand within a couple of feet of an actual Oscar. You can also check out the Oscar for Snow White which includes seven little Oscar-ettes...
* A chance to actually stand near and get a complete description of Disney's groundbreaking Multiplane Camera, designed and first used to revolutionize animation in the '30's even today it looks years ahead of its time.
* Engine and cars from Disney's Carolwood Pacific Railroad, the 7.25" gauge miniature train Walt famously ran in the backyard of his California home - which embodied his love for the trains so prominently on display in Disney parks
* All kinds of history around Disney movies - not just the films themselves but how they were financed, the approach to color and sound, their successes and failures along with the Disney Studios over the years
* A scale model of Disneyland ca 1967 - 1970
* Documentation of early Disney efforts (i. e., Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, the Alice films, Silly Symphony films)
* and so much more...

Additionally there is a theater which shows features and special films regularly, along a separate building with rotating exhibitions which in the past have included the works of the legendary Mary Blair, Secrets of Disney's Movie Magic, A Celebration of Walt's Trains, and others.

The Walt Disney Family Museum only exists in San Francisco and its contents are (as I understand it) property of the Disney family, not the parks, so you won't see what is in here in Anaheim, Orlando, Paris, Tokyo, etc. The only advice I will give on the visit is that even though this is 'Disney' it is a museum, not a 'ride,' and not really compelling for young or younger children - in my experience. If your young children want to go be prepared to keep them interested while you are touring the exhibitions, because you will want to stay for a long time.

Highly recommended, a must see for anyone visiting The City and for residents alike. The view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the walkway between galleries alone is worth the price of admission...
author: Arthur S.

description:
If you are a huge fan of Walt Disney (the individual), then this will be the perfect museum for you!

The information that you will gain from attending this museum is very similar to what you'll learn from television documentaries, biographies and from Wikipedia.  The difference though..; is that you get to see the actual artifacts, magazines, photos, newspapers, artwork, etc., throughout Walt Disney's life.  There's always a difference between the appreciation to something that you read or saw on TV, compared to seeing them with your own eyes. As you walk from the beginning of the museum to the exit; you really do feel as though you've chronologically walked through Walt Disney's life, work and his family.

If you are interested in writing a biography on Walt Disney, then all you need is to spend a few hours at the Walt Disney Family Museum.  The main thing that I want to warn you about.., is that if your family is expecting this place to be like Disneyland, then you're attending this place with the wrong approach.  If your kids are expecting a Disney type atmosphere or the same time of fun & games like Disneyland, then your kids will be disappointed.  This is strictly the story of the entire life of Walt Disney (the person).
author: Johnny W.

description:
If you want to learn about Walter Elias Disney's life, this is the place to go. It's sort of on the pricey side, $20 for adults but just like Disneyland, it's $$$.

Pstt...Look at the Disneyland model, if you bend down & look straight through Cinderella's castle, you can see Walt Disney. COOL!!!

Walt Disney has truly left a legacy.

After coming here to learn about Disney's life, I'm going to have a Disney movie marathon.
author: Kylie L.

description:
The amount of detail put into this museum is spectacular. There is an incredible amount of artifacts from the Disney family, and nearly all are so special and crucial to Walt, his family, and the Walt Disney company. You get to see new aspects of Walt's life that you had no idea had ever happened. It was great to see those pieces that showed Walt as more of a man than a mogul. It was so fun to visit with my parents and see them reminisce with the old Disney productions and past technologies. The layout is perfect and walks you through the years from before Walt's birth to his passing. Everyone can enjoy the Disneyland part of the museum, and it's fantastic to see papers doodled with the earliest ideas behind the park.

As a side note, I whole-heartedly appreciate that they offer a student discount!

It was a phenomenal experience, and I can't wait to go back.
author: Alyssa D.

description: A must see for Disney fanatics.  It's like walking through a biography.  Very interesting and interactive.  Well done.
author: Marcos T.

description: Absolutely fantastic telling of his life and work. Has fantastic relics from Disney lore, and of walls personnel life such as the miniature train he rode around on in his back yard, and almost every Oscar and Grammy any Disney movie ever won.
author: Franklin J.

description:
AHHHHHH I hate that I have to give this 2 stars I love everything Disney but this is just not the experience I expected. So I will start from the beginning..

Parking: 
We parked, walked into the museum, and see a sign on the desk that says we have to pay for parking because it is all metered....but there were no meters. Come to find out there is a central ticketing area at the at the beginning on the parking area with NO signage and I mean they have one sign covered by an overgrown tree and nothing else.

Staff: 
Front desk lady was nice, don't remember her name but she was helpful and polite.

Museum: 
OK first off this place is HUGE and I mean you need a block of 5 plus hours to really get through everything here, but don't be fooled you will be tried by the end of it and feel like you spent the day at school because the ENTIRE museum is reading. There is a lot of visual components but to understand what they are you have to read long drawn out explanations to what you are seeing. The items in the museum were very cool but by the 3rd room, out of maybe 15, I was over it. Again just my opinion but I didn't want to spend the entire day reading on my vacation.

Kids:
I really wouldn't recommend this for kids as crazy as that sounds. You are going to spend 15$ to chase them around, asking them to be quite, and you will not get to enjoy a second because beside maybe 4 interactive stations there is NOTHING for them to really learn unless they are in say 5th grade even then a 5th grader would NOT want to do all that reading.

Price:
Well this can be swung 2 ways. If you ask my boyfriend it was a steal for $20 you can literally have a whole day of entertainment and learning. For me I say I just spent $20 to strain my brain and waste a beautiful day inside. Depends on your personality and what you like.

I was hopeful for this place but it really was a no go for me :(
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Wow. I took my mother to this because of the Dali and Disney exhibit. We bought the admission to the main part of the museum as well. The special exhibit was housed in a separate building.
