The best way to describe the exhibit is as unpleasant. The problem was not as much the contents of the exhibit, but how it was displayed. Every wall was crowded with information organized in a linear timeline. Over the course of the exhibit you see Dali's and Disney's lives intersect. The exhibit was extremely crowded, and the path very narrow, so even if I had wanted to see all of the text that was written it was impossible. People pushed and shoved to get to the next thing, and a couple of times obliviously almost knocked my 88 year-old mother over without a word of apology. We hurried though as quickly as we could to go to the main museum.

The main museum exhibit was better, but similarly linear, driven by Disney's life and accomplishments. The curator relies too heavily on timeline, and does not do a good job of story telling, and tries to jam everything Disney left behind, including every award, every letter, and every drawing that he ever did, into a space that is not really big enough. In the end, I was left wondering what Walt would have thought. I loved many of the drawings, and learning about the evolution of animation, but my favorite parts were about the animators strike of 1941, and learning that Mr. Disney was a bad guy (anti-communist informant and anti-union) during the McCarthy era. These were the only true glimmers that I got of Disney, the man. I  actually felt sorry for all of the artists who spent their life at Disney and whose drawings were displayed, in most cases attributed to "Disney studio artist," or in other cases to "Unknown." Disney made so much money on the backs of underpaid artists, and basically took all of the credit for what they did. 

My mother, who is a wonderful artist, grew up in LA. One of the best moments of attending this exhibit was when she told me about learning to draw Micky Mouse from the guy who lived across the street from her who was a Disney studio artist. She went on to author a cartoon strip of her own, and to become an incredible drawer. Thank you unknown Disney studio artist for getting my mother started. I hope that one of your drawings is displayed at the Disney Family Museum, and that I saw it today.

If you are a Disney fan, you may like this exhibit. There are wonderful things to discover through the clutter and the noise of it. If you are a parent of younger children, think twice about bringing them to this; they will be bored out of their skulls, or trampled to death. Not sorry I went to this museum, just disappointed in the overall experience.
author: Anne M.

description:
I found this museum while searching for attractions for my family's trip to San Francisco a few months ago and was very excited!  We're all big Disney fans, so it was pretty much a no brainer to check it out!

Admission is $20, but there is a $5 AAA discount - too bad I only found out after I paid! 

The museum has a lot of interesting and fascinating displays and information from when Walt Disney was born, his childhood, the beginnings of his career, and his death. At the end, there is a huge mural of all the tributes that were made to Walt Disney, and I have to admit: I got choked up.

My favorite display is right before the museum tour begins, it's a display case of all the Emmy awards the Disney company was awarded...when "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" won, they were not only presented with an Emmy award, but with 7 tiny Emmys also! That is just too cute!
author: Faye M.

description:
Last night hubby and I attended Animate Your Night with a film screening of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs in the lower level theater. 

We nibbled on small bites and purchased cocktails from the bar.

Pros - ability to focus in the various galleries with less crowds milling.  And much more serene.  

Cons - small bites catered by Dixie restaurant.  I was not impressed.
author: Shirley N.

description: This is a great place for kids and adults. My favorite is the Mary Blair exhibit. If you are an alum from San Jose State University you should support other alums from this university. This houses amazing art. If you are in the animation/illustration industry I would say this is a must see museum.
author: Jessica J.

description:
I'm more of a classic Disney girl who loves reading up on the history and back story of things, so I was really excited to visit this museum. My friend and I got a pretty good deal on Groupon though I wouldn't mind paying the regular ticket price ($20, though if you have a student I.D. you can get it for $15). 

Like many people have said this isn't the best place to take young kids. There is a LOT of reading and hardly any interactive things.We didn't go through it as meticulously as I would have wanted to since I was the only one who was really interested in reading all the long descriptions. But either way it was enjoyable for all of us. The place is set up nicely so you can make an organized walk through the whole museum. 

- You're allowed to take photos as long as you don't use flash. 
- They have bathrooms downstairs and two single bathrooms in the middle of the museum. 
- You can pay extra to view the special exhibits they might have that day. 
- There's a tiny cafe and gift shop at the entrance/exit. (We didn't eat there since they were having Off the Grid right outside. We did explore the gift shop though and they do have quite a few interesting items. I purchased a black reusable tote bag for $15).

Overall a really great museum. Might come back sometime in the future for a more in-depth visit.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Walter Elias Disney, or Walt Disney, has been my hero since I was a young boy

I have not met a single person who has not been touched personally by something Walt helped create. Whether it's a classic Disney cartoon, a full length animated classic, one of his many theme parks, a TV show or a live action movie, everyone has some sort of positive, magical memory that is linked to Walt Disney.

Personally, I have seen every full length Disney animated classic, I've probably seen almost every old cartoon, watched almost all the companies movies, been to all the US theme parks and read many books on Walt. Since I'm such a huge fan of Walt, I really didn't gather too much new information on him when visiting The Disney Family Museum. However, that doesn't mean I didn't have an awesome time, because I did. I loved watching his family's home movies that show him playing with his kids, reading his personal hand written notes to his associates, listening to what his peers thought of him and more. And of course it wouldn't be a Disney museum without some Disney magic. There are many fun, interactive exhibits you can play with that give you a better insight to how special an individual Walt really was.

The museum starts off when Walt was born on December 5, 1901 in Chicago, Illinois, moves onto his teenage years when he was an ambulance driver in the World War, takes you through all his trials and tribulations of becoming an animator and studio owner, shows you how he became the industries leader in making cartoons, movies and television, lets you see how he came up with the theme parks and ends with his untimely death on December 15th, 1966, in Burbank, California at the age of 65.  The final room, which is all about his death, is very moving. There was not a dry eye in that room while I was there, including my own.

Now, if you're a casual Disney fan, you may not enjoy this museum too much. Small children especially may find it boring. If you want to learn all there is to know about Walt, his company and the way he changed the animation industry, TV industry, movie industry and theme parks, you'll absolutely love The Walt Disney Family Museum. In my opinion, the world is a much better place because of Walt Disney. He touched so many people all over the world and this museum shows you how he did that. He worked very hard, was an imaginative genius, was a devoted father and husband and an overall magical person.

Price for an adult admission is $20 but if you're a AAA card holder, it's only $15. They also have many special events that take place at this museum like movie screenings and discussions. They do not allow cameras inside the actual museum, only the first room where all his many awards are housed.  

If you live in the bay area or are just visiting, please check out the Disney Family Museum . There is so much great information here about my hero, Walt Disney that by the time you leave, you'll know almost as much as I do about this enchanting man.
author: Craig R.

description: I'm a twenty-something who grew up watching Disney, and I thought the museum was great. Incredibly informative and professionally done. What I liked was that it wasn't super gawdy or over the top like a Disney Park.  Lots of history, artifacts, and interactive stations. I saw small children there, too, who seemed to enjoy it as well. Definitely a place worth visiting.
author: Mark B.

description:
As museums go, this is one of the most well-executed I've ever seen. 

The layout and exhibitions are very well done as one might expect from the Disney family. The location is amazing as well so I would recommend you plan on looking around The Presidio on your trip here too.
author: John D.

description:
Class establishment. Beautiful exhibits, rich in historic and artistic insight. The staff deserves particular commendation -- friendly, helpful, knowledgeable, to a person they far surpassed local hospitality standards.

I arrived a few hours early for the Choose Your Own Adventureland event, unsure whether I had enough time to enjoy the museum beforehand. At the front desk, Summer answered my questions patiently, thoughtfully, and cheerfully, helping me map out an excellent two-hour experience. She made sure I saw the Mary Blair special exhibit (which, though I'd planned to skip it, ended up being my personal favorite) and that I got a proper overview of the main museum. 

I'll return often for further exhibits and events. Thanks for a wonderful day!
author: Gregory H.

description:
The Walt Disney Family Museum was for cooler than I expected. There is another building that houses the rotating exhibits- which are great!
The main building has a detailed timeline that is very entertaining. The kid loved it and the dad loved it to. My youngest was fascinated with the old time cartoons that were running, and the adults have audio and many interesting vintage aspects to appreciate. I was most fascinated with the models and how the house of Disney survived a time of war and was helped out by Giannini of Bank of America. The story of persistence and faith was inspirational.
author: Melissa B.

description: This museum is so well done and enjoyable. The exhibits create a fun atmosphere and theme. I've been here several times and always see something new. The special exhibits are always really interesting and do a great job of showcasing whatever the content is. Aside from the content itself, the museum is beautiful and has beautiful grounds and views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Perfect for Disnerds or anyone interested in art or animation!
author: Alex H.

description:
A must for Disney lovers!

I flew up to San Fran from LA for a Dapper Day event at The Walt Disney Family Museum for the Mary Blair exhibit. 

Beautiful! Two members of my party went into the Mary Blair exhibit part which was located outside and behind the museum; they thoroughly enjoyed. Two other members of my party enjoyed Disney themed drinks from the bar as well as tasty dishes from the food trucks outside the museum. I went into the Disney Family history section of the museum. Let me tell you, you need to have some time to get through all of that! I think it was 3-4 floors of art work. From the beginning of the parents life to Walt's death. So much original art work, videos, interactive stuff, movies, a Disneyland replica, ah the list goes on! It was deeply moving. I must come back to have more time. 

The gift shop has a lot of one of a kind items and i snagged myself some vintage Mickey and Minnie plush dolls. 

The view from outside is the Golden Gate bridge and the drive to the museum is through the presidio, gorgeous!
author: Harlow H.

description: Great food and coffee to come and eat. Loved the museum and learned a lot from Walt Disney. Recommend this a lot.
author: Daniel C.

description:
This place has been opened for so long and we finally got around to visiting it.  It was free in the beginning.  We got in as charter members of the DeYoung Museum, you just have to bring your DeYoung member card. 

It's rather deceiving from the outside, as it doesn't look that big but it's pretty large inside with an upstairs.  We fed 2hrs. into the outside parking meters (gosh, it used to be all free) and couldn't finish in that time, not if you read all the displays.  I think you need 4 hours or more to explore this place because they have rooms of history on WD's life and family and how the studio started.  We had to cut out of another 1/3 or 1/2 to get out of there. There's also a shop and cafe' in the building.  

If you're a Disney fan and have enjoyed the animations in your childhood, you'll like this place.  It's a bit too advanced for small children who can't read yet but is good for smart jr. high kids and teens.  

We'll have to make a return trip to finish up and spend some time in the shop and the Presidio Visitors Center in the building next door which relocated from the Officer's Club which is undergoing renovations/remodeling.  Parking in the areas outside the museum is currently $1.20/hour.
author: Ry T.

description:
When they say "The Walt Disney Family" Museum, they mean it's all about Mr. Disney and HIS family. That needs to be clear. 

If you are thinking of visiting because you think it's good for YOUR family (with young kids) then you may be very disappointed. 

The information is all very interesting but be prepared to read a lot. 

Not a very interactive museum. I think they could have broken the museum up a little bit so that you could take reading breathers. 

Highlight of the museum is the large model of Disneyland. 

Still worth the visit. Parking is $1+ an hour at the meters throughout. Huge grassy field looking out to the Golden Gate Bridge if you'd like to picnic, otherwise there's a cafe.

NOTE: It's not there for much longer, but the Tyrus Wong exhibit was my personal highlight.
author: P. G.

description:
This museum looks small on the outside, but it is quite large on the inside. It is filled with a lot of information about Walt Disney, starting at his grandparents until his death. It talks about his struggles as an artist and then how he enhanced animation. 

It is very interesting, and there are a few hands-on demonstration to play with. There is a lot of reading, so I'm not sure if it's very good for kids. We spent a good 2.5 hours here and I enjoyed it! There are awesome views inside and out of the museum of the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Admission is $20 for adults and $15 for students. You can also get an additional discount of $5 per ticket if you show your AAA card.
author: Leslie P.

description: No words can really describe how wonderful this place is to me but, I am going to try. When you step in it looks just like a normal museum. When your in the first gallery it is nice but looks like a normal museum should. The second floor then blows you out of the water. Intense colors, music and other sounds give you that feeling of magic disney created in his work. You learn all about Disney's life, his struggles, his triumphs and his wonderful world. Hands down you just have to go and experience the magic for yourself!
author: Shelby R.

description:
i work at an art school and often i schedule field trips for my instructors and students to go the Walt Disney Family Museum. The museum has two buildings. One is the big main building while the other in the back is where they usually show their special exhibition. The main building focuses on Walt's life. You walk through his childhood, how he started the studio, the challenges the studio faced, his miniature model of Disneyland, and ending with the end of his life. There is a lot of fun stuff to see if you are a fan of Disney and the early films. 

From the outside, the museum looks very small, but you would be surprised how big it is inside and how much time you can spend in there. 

Currently, their special exhibit is about Mary Blair which I enjoyed very much. I would go again (and it's easy for me to go for free again when you are a member). The gift shop and cafe are both small and expensive, but what can you expect from a museum? They do have a small theater inside where they screen a different Disney film every month and kid (as well as adult)-friendly workshops downstairs.

In general, this museum is really a place for fans of Disney, not fans of Disneyland. I have seen a variety of ages at this museum, and everyone who comes here usually has a good time.
author: Jessica C.

description: I had always been meaning to check out the museum and learn about the man behind the mouse. I'm glad I finally did and for $20 per adult, I got to learn about what a visionary Walt Disney really was. From his birth, step-by-step, the tour took you through his triumphs and tribulations with signing up to serve in the war to escaping to LA with barely any money to try it big in Hollywood, he was constantly reinventing himself and pushing boundaries.
author: Leina K.

description:
Disclaimer: I am a huge Disney fan, so this museum would have to do something absolutely awful to get lower than four stars from me. 

This museum is a must for any Disney fan. I just got back today after getting a membership (P.S. College students: you can get a discounted membership). This museum is not run by the Walt Disney Company. The museum is a non profit created by Walt's daughter and heirs. The museum does not seem that large, but when you get inside, you realize it is huge. 

The museum tells the story of Walt's life. You start at his early life and travel through the museum all the way till his death. You travel from his early days, arriving in Hollywood, to the rise of his animation empire, to his moving on to other projects, like Disneyland. There are lots of really great exhibits, showing how animation works, a multiplane camera, a diagram of Disneyland and so much more. This museum has a lot of reading, and not that many interactive exhibits. Parents, this may be a museum you go to the first time, without the kids, just so you can take it all in. 

The museum also holds lots of film screenings, special events (a must for Disney fans!) and has special exhibits. The special exhibits are in the annex building, which has a smaller, more intimate feel. The current exhibit is the Mary Blair exhibit, which is filled with great artwork, for all those who love Mary Blair, or even those who don't know who she is. Previously they had a Snow White special exhibit, which was also very well done. 

Finally, I wanted to talk about membership. This museum has an awesome membership program. Members get in for free to the museum, exhibits and events and they also get to take a guest into the museum and exhibits when they visit. An awesome deal for any Disney fan. 

Overall I can't rave enough about this museum. If you are a Disney fan, you need to go. If you are not a huge Disney fan, it's worth going at least once in your life
author: Brian G.

description:
WHAT A GEM

I'm still baffled that SF has rights to this little wonderland and it hasn't been stolen by LA, but I'm NOT complaining!  

Came here with the parents while they were out here visiting me, and I'm so glad we did.  I learned so many fun facts about the history of Walt Disney himself, as well as the empire he built.  What a visionary!!!

I definitely recommend everyone come here  - such a hidden treasure in the Presidio.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
I had less than a full day in San Francisco  and wanted to take my little lady somewhere special, cue our visit to The Walt Disney Family Museum. I have to say, I was not prepared to be as impressed with this museum as I actually was. The Museum is two stories and literally walks you through the life story of Walt Disney from his birth to his death. They have family heirlooms of Mr. Disney including letters from his childhood, pictures of his family, etc. All his major cartoons are showcased along with in depth stories behind the creation of each. I had no idea how much shady stuff had occurred regarding his cartoons and concepts being stolen by Warner Bros, how many woman were involved in the production of many of his cartoons ,and how many times he fell flat on his face and experience gigantic failures. I thought my daughter might be bored with the museum but they have great hands on activities  such as creating soundtracks for cartoon reels. I particularly liked that certain things that Mr. Disney did such as trying to block the unionization of his workers was also shown, there was no whitewashing here. 

This is definitely not a day long museum trip but if you have two or three hours to kill and want to learn a little more about the history behind the Disney empire, I highly recommend this museum.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Wow... we went here expecting to walk through in a couple of hours but HOLY MOLY is there too much to see! We ended up taking about 3-4 hours and could have easily stayed for 1-2 more. The exhibits are chronological to Disney's life and incredibly detailed. We ended up skipping through a bunch of the late 40s-50s portion between the Disney Studios strike and the beginnings of Disneyland to try to save time since we had somewhere else to be.

It felt like we spent the most time in the room dedicated to the creation of Mickey Mouse and the room after that, then a lot more time with the scale model of Disneyland as it appeared in 1959. We really appreciated that there was a staff member posted there to answer our questions/chime into our conversation about what rides are still there and a little more history about the park. Of course, my friends and I are all early 30s and the DIsneyland model was what interested my friend's 3 year old daughter the most.

In those 3-4 hours we were there I feel like there's a lot I skipped over because I was antsy and my feet hurt, and we didn't even see a film or any specific exhibit. I could definitely go back and spend a few more hours reading all of the exhibits and information I skipped the first time!

I think, with the sheer volume of reading, that this probably isn't the best outing for a small child unless it's for a specific workshop. I can't imagine anyone younger than 15 being interested in the minutia of information presented. There's more visuals as the exhibits go on, but almost the whole downstairs is very reading-heavy.
author: Trisha F.

description:
Having been here 5 times now (yes, I love museums that much), I can confidently say that we're pretty lucky to have this kind of museum that exemplifies all of the inspiration and imagination that Walt Disney has instilled upon American history and culture.

My childhood is riddled with stories that have originated from Disney, including annual trips to Disneyland.  I've been to Disneyworld in Orlando twice, once relatively recently for a family reunion.  For all of my personal experiences ranging from theme parks, books, movies, television, music that came from the Disney camp, I honestly did not know much about the man himself.  That is, up until this beautiful museum nestled in the heart of the Presidio popped up.

One of the main reasons I continue to come back is the fact that there is so much stuff to check out here.  I would find it nearly impossible to be able to explore the entire museum and all of its contents in one visit, even if you spent the entire day here.  Most of the exhibits contain quite a bit of reading material, so you may find yourself staring at the wall while reading what seems to be a novel (this actually reminds me of some of the exhibits in the SFMOMA).

Near the end of the tour, be sure to take your time to soak in the amazing views of the Golden Gate bridge as you walk towards the finale.  I'm always intrigued by the interesting architectural design of the window panels and the white wall with TV panels.  I usually just take a seat here for about 10 minutes and give my eyes a rest from all of the reading.

And for the finale (where they don't allow you to take pictures and they actually have someone standing there to make sure you don't but I've snuck in a few here and there but just don't tell anyone that), you enter a room that contains a very cool miniature of Disneyland that is completely decked out and very detailed.  This last room itself would probably take at least an hour in itself to explore everything it has to offer.

Be sure to stop by the cafe where they serve clam chowder in a sourdough bowl, its solid!

This review is dedicated to my hero, Joe N!
author: Tony L.

description:
LOVED this experience. As a former employee of the Walt Disney Company, it's so interesting to learn about how Walt and his brother grew up, worked, found wives, and then later got into the business and then later came up with the idea of Disneyland. Very cool videos and audio sound all donated by his daughter I believe. The museum is very well designed and the walk-thru took about over an hour. My friend and I didn't expect to spend over 2 hours there, but we did.

The museum has pretty advance technology with large flat screen TVs, touch screens, and iPad, which really make the experience more interactive. 

Make sure you know the following

1) Discounts for students with ID (can be used in conjuction with the $3 off coupon below)
2) $3 discounts for adults http://www.couponsforfun.com/couponsforfun.com/CA_Walt_Disney_Family_Museum_coupon.html
3) Parking is right outside (meter)
4) Check the calendar for events to schedule your visit around activities: http://www.waltdisney.org/calendar/

We took part in the open studio hours from 1PM-4PM and painted Disney characters as part of the creativity session. We didn't take advantage of the awards tour (because it also started at the same time). Tons of Oscars and awards are displayed on the floor; it was very cool to see. 

Anyway, if you're a Disney fanatic, then you'll love it. Even if you're not (because my friend wasn't), it was an enjoyable experience to learn so much about a man who has changed our world with just one mouse.
author: Ameera D.

description:
Such an amazing museum in our beautiful city! They did a wonderful job putting together interactive and interesting information on Walt Disney's life. We were fortunate to get a half price ticket through Groupon. You could easily spend 3-4 hours looking at all of the displays. The content of the museum is really geared more for adults than kids. 

I'm really happy that the Disney family chose San Francisco and the Presidio to honor their father and grandfather. I highly recommend this as a stop for all locals and tourists coming to San Francisco.
author: Rachel M.

description:
To be completely honest, I went into this museum not knowing what to expect.  I thought it would be only for children, but that's absolutely not the case.  I was really impressed with The Walt Disney Family Museum.

It's a huge timeline of Walt's life.  I'm not quite sure how they organized it so well!  The museum is very well put-together, starting with documents / facts about Walt's family, leading on to how he became the most successful animator of all time.

The Disney community did a great job at donating to the museum.  Many of the sketches were donated personally by individuals who had previously bought the art, then wanted to give it back to Walt's family.

If you wanted, you could literally stay in the museum for 5+ hours.  There are so many things to read and listen to.  Altogether, I would highly recommend this museum for everyone.  It's really motivating to see how Walt's determination and perseverance paid off.
author: Andrew H.

description:
First off, if you're not driving, this place is a bit difficult to get to, as it is tucked away within the depth of the Presidio.  We opted to walk through the huge park, and by the time we arrived, I was so tired that I thought the street food festival in the garden in front of the building was a mirage (by the way, that festival is the "Off the Grid: Picnic at the Presidio," which is one of the better collection of food trucks/tents that I've seen).  After grabbing a bite at one of the tables provided in front of the Museum, we headed in. 

If you don't care much for Disney, this museum will give you hours of tedious walking and reading.  It looks small from the lobby, but once you've entered the main exhibits, you'll find yourself in an endless continuation of rooms that take you through the life of Walt Disney, literally from his birth to his death and everything in between.  There isn't a whole lot of interesting "stuff" to stop and stare at, but it's more like walking through a life-sized biography of the inventor of the most famous mouse in the world. 

The Walt Disney Family Museum made me appreciate the genius of Walt Disney.  This early works are actually quite remarkable and creative, even from modern day standards.  This is certainly not some guy that just stumbled upon a random cartoon character that shot him to fame.  There was a lot of work, failures, and sacrifices that went into the creation of the Disney Dynasty.  

A very interesting museum for the Disney lover, but don't expect dancing Winnie the Pooh bears or costumed princesses to entertain your kids.
author: Yujin M.

description: Walt Disney family museum is the place for any avid Disney Lover! I have been there three times and I would go again! It has so many things to look at. Make sure you have plenty of time to spend when you go there!
author: Steffanie C.

description: I'm a Disney geek like many others. But to clarify: this is not the land or walt disney world. No meet and greets with Mickey and friends. No turkey legs. Instead this is a museum about Walt Disney, his life, his family and his work. You'll see a wall of all the awards he has won. There are some snippets and clips from various short films. It's inspiring to see his impact on the world and how it all started. I was able to take advantage of a group deal and get two tickets. No special exhibits without paying extra $$ but there was more than enough for me to see. My favorite is the mini replica of Disneyland. Not exact but based off what they had envisioned - from above my eyes were able to walk through the tiny main street and through the different lands. It was fun calling out all the rides. At the end of the museum you can pick up a few trinkets from the gift shop and grab a coffee and sandwich from the cafe.
author: Samantha L.

description:
What an adorable place to go with family or friends! It's located in one of the prettiest parts of the city - Presidio and it's seriously a charming area if you don't get up there very often. 
I decided to take my mom on a whim. Admission is $20 for adults and with a Triple A discount it was about $17. 
Although a bit steep - it's just such a different thing to go and do that I recommend going. It's about 12 galleries and there is also a movie that's about an hour long. The theme of our movie happened to be Christmas due to the time of season. We walked thru the galleries in a little over an hour and I think that is very subjective based on how much you sit there and read. 
There was a TON of stuff on his early life and his family, it's crazy how much they could display but it looks like the family had a lot of mementos and information to put together.
I think the one thing I noticed which I was originally thought is this is more so a museum on Walt Disney and his life - versus Disney (overall). It's not really the history of Disney, although there is much of that history intertwined into the story. 
There is a little, cute museum shop and a mini snack cafe where you can get snacks we didn't get anything but ppl were having coffee and snacks etc. 

This isn't necessarily a place for a child because it's a lot of reading and less of Disney characters everywhere but nonethless a charming place to visit!
author: Priya S.

description:
So, I love Disney but I'm not addicted nor do I wish to visit it every year. 
Now the museum is more of the story of Walt Disney and how Disney started evolved throughout history. It has 12 galleries and it goes in chronological order of the evolution of Disney pictures and Walt. It has a lot of interactive exhibits and a lot of words. You will have many things to read and listen too. 
The 12 galleries provide you about a 2 hour tour. Their is also the special exhibit of Mary Blair when I went. It is a beautiful gallery. Spend the money.  Also we went to do the showing of a Disney classic movie. It was Cinderella. 
Do that too. 
A must go for adults. A must wait for children.  Not the best place when the kids love the pictures and the adults love the story behind.
author: Agatha K.

description: I am a Disney fan so this was a great treat for me during my trip. The museum was worth the venutre into the Presidio. They have a lot of memorabilia as well as loads of original artwork by the big man himself. I would recommend 1-2 hours to walk thru the museum. There isn't really anything to eat or drink in the immediate area so eat before heading there.
author: Vanessa M.

description: An amazing collection chronicling Walt's life and imagination. Wonderful artifacts and time well spent if you enjoy Disney and/or Disneyland. Bonus is beautiful views of the Golden Gate and exploring the rest of The Presidio.
author: Scott H.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about this museum, but I did not have as much fun as the reviews had said. I guess it might be because we did not grow up during the era that all this was happening and could not really relate to it. There was a lot of Walt's history and pictures and explanation and stuff to read. A lot to read (but it is a museum). It was nice to see the history, but sprucing it up a bit so that we don't have to read so much would have been nice (possibly an audio tour?).

Overal the museum is nice, I probably would not return unless things were updated.
author: Matt L.

description: Great place to come if you're a big fan of Walt Disney himself. Museum is mostly about his life and his achievements. Don't think it'd be a great place for kids though considering its not about Disneyland or Mickey Mouse. Although my favorite part was the Disneyland part of the museum, very cool to learn how he came up with the idea on his own and started with his own money. The area the museum is located in is also a very nice area, hidden behind the woods in a very nice community. Would be a great place to have a stroll through in the spring. Also has a cafe we didn't get to try out. As well as a theater downstairs where they show movies, they were showing Pinocchio that day. Overall a nice place to spend your day.
author: Eric D.

description: What a treasure!!  One of the finest, most well thought out and thorough museums I've ever been to.  It's like a presidential museum, but way better!  We only spent two hours (disappointingly rushed by impatient teenage family members) I could have spent an entire day or two reading and listening to all the various displays of his early career, military service, innovations, aspirations and magic Walt gave to the world.  This museum put together so lovingly by his family should be on everyone's list of places to visit in SF.
author: Shelby C.

description:
This is a wonderful museum that follows Walt Disney, his career, and the juggernaut that Disney's company became. Curious about Disney's technological innovations? About his family? His relationship (sometimes rocky) with the people who worked for him? It's all there. Like a magic box, the museum seems to be much bigger on the inside than on the outside. I do think that unless you have a kid who is interested in old tech, the history of entertainment, or so totally besotted with all things Disney that even the Mickey Mouse tschotskes of yesteryear entertain them, it might not be the place for them.

But boy, if you grew up with the Wonderful World of Color, and went to Disneyland often enough to know the shortcuts, this is an amazing place.
author: Madeleine R.

description:
Animate your night! After hours event with drinks and eateries! we've been to a few of these. and they are ALWAYS a good time. they end early enough, that if you are here on a date, you can suggest grabbing a drink afterwards and extending the night! 

had my palm read here! made a stop motion movie, AND a clay figurine.  if you have a creative side, you need to come here and act like a kid in a candy store. we always spend too much time downstairs messing around with the arts, and never enough time in the museum.  this is why we go month after month. the museum part of it is amazing too. great materials there. stills. paintings. maquettes. miniature model of disneyland. interactive things. AND they even let people UNDER 21 go.  

THIS PLACE IS GREAT and you DEF. get your bang for your buck. they always have something for you to take home. printed pictures. magnets. pins. masks. BY FAR MY FAVORITE AFTER HOURS EVENT.
author: Richard N.

description:
After three years in San Francisco, this was one of the last museums left standing that I had yet to visit. When a fellow Disney maniac, *ahem*, "enthusiast" rolled into town, we put on comfy shoes and hit up The Walt Disney Family Museum for a relaxing Sunday. 

Well by golly, I felt like the museum was the physical incarnation of Walter "Elias" Disney's Wikipedia page. His creativity, genius, passion, trials and tribulations, family life and friendships all spill out and speak to you. The exhibits have been thoughtfully created with a perfect balance of photos, letters, videos, historical interviews, original sketches and storyboards, collector's item memorabilia, actual camera and equipment that revolutionized the cartoon industry and even includes multiple Oscar statuettes, awards and accolades. Bonus points for a tastefully small gift shop that features beautiful coffee table books, art material and figurines. Since the museum was founded by Walt's daughter Diane, it's a loving nod to everything he stood for and brings you deep behind the scenes on how these classics came to life and what an indelible mark he left on the industry and the world. 

Two tips: Carve out enough time to walk through his life chronologically. The museum was much bigger than it appeared and I spent too much time reading each paragraph about his childhood and realized I was only a fifth of the way through the exhibits without much time to spare. It's also not the most kid-friendly place and more suitable for adults who heart Disney. There's quite a bit of text and historical info and young ones might get bored fairly easily (or tire out)!
author: Faith Y.

description: Went here for a birthday treat. What a great museum. From the very beginning you are intertained with lots of memorabilia. The Cafe serves gourmet foods and was reasonably priced. Will be going again.
author: Keith R.

description:
Neat little place if you like museums and Disney. This is more of a biography of Walt Disney and the formation of the Disney empire. If you hate reading or history, this may not be the place for you.

We took our time looking at each exhibit, ready a couple things here and there. It's really cool to see how the art/animation transformed over time.

You get a student discount if you bring your student ID.
author: Desmond T.

description:
If you are a Walt Disney fan you will love this museum. The exhibits were very interactive and informative. Keep in mind there is a lot of reading material. If you are the type of museum goers that don't like reading the labels you will most likely find this place extremely boring. This is also not really a place for younger children. While there were a lot of short movies and hands-on exhibits that younglings might find interesting, the majority of the museum is tailored towards adults. This museum is about Walt Disney's life and not Disney animations or characters.

Some of the layout in this museum is a bit odd. A lot of the long introductory texts were placed right at the entrance of the major galleries. That created a bit of a traffic issue. 

It took me about 2 hours to go through the entire museum but it was a bit rushed. I had to skip over a few of the more popular exhibits as the lines are often long. I will budget about 3 hours if you plan to see everything in greater details. The best part in the entire place is the miniature Disneyland.

The $20 entrance fee is a bit expensive. I was also quite disappointed that no photos were allowed inside the museum.
author: Mona W.

description:
Is amazing 1 of the best things i did on my trip it was my first time in San francisco and one of my things to do in my bucket list, it has everything all the live is there, Awards/Paintings/ pictures / etc you name it. The Gallery is so organized mom went as well i was so excited just to see her face she was a little kid again it was awesome the story , the end brought tiers to my face just seeing the pictures and drawings when he pass away the sad cartoons etc, you would have an amazing time here. It has a really nice view of the Golden Bridge as well to take pictures. The coffee shop the have is good and the Gentleman that was working is extremely polity and so nice, everybody is love this place can't war to come back and bring all my family 

This is A MOST DUE when you visit San francisco
author: Jessica M.

description:
Disney is rolling in his grave!

As a HUGE Disney fan, I am appalled by the fact that the museum does not allow double or triple strollers.

I am a mother of multiples (twins), and many of us depend on our double strollers.  If attending by oneself, it would be physically impossible to carry twins through the museum.  Would they rather have toddlers running around like crazy, rather than restrained quietly in their stroller?

They previously had  "no stroller" policy, and have since changed it to "no double strollers."  Well, sorry - some of us DO have more than one child!

Disney wanted his parks to be " a place where children and parents can have fun TOGETHER" - this stroller policy is extremely discriminatory.  I understand that this is a museum, and not a theme park, but it should be accessible to all.

The museum itself is wonderful - but it is heartbreaking that a single mom of twins, or triplets, or even a mother/grandparent/caregiver with children close in age would not be able to attend due to this ridiculous, discriminatory, elitist, and heartless stroller policy.
author: Tiki G.

description:
Walt Disney came to California with $40 in his pocket, exactly the same amount it'll cost for you and your sweetheart to spend a day wandering through this surprisingly large museum.  

And i think its worth every penny.  No where else will you get to see the treasures from the Disney empire all in one location. 

There's a feeling of awe looking on the first sketch of Mortimer "Mickey" Mouse.  There's a sense of amazement in seeing drawings of story scenes you remember as a kid, with deleted scenes you never even knew existed.  

You can get lost staring down Disneyland's Main Street at a Bird's eye view while your destructive side imagines stomping around the replica of Disneyland as Walt imagined it.  Scaled at 1/187, it is incredibly detailed, and amazing.

You get to see the other side of the empire as well.  There's a whole section dedicated to the war propaganda that the studio dedicated all of their work to.  It's quite a thing to see Mickey and Donald calling on all patriots to rally for victory.  There's even some eyebrow raising nude Disney Pinups, drawn by the studio itself and sent off to soldiers on the field.  

Somehow when I looked down at my watch, three hours had gone by.  I'd recommend this to any fan of Disneyland, and Walt Disney (although, I think kids might get easily bored, so ditch them at Crissy Fields nearby to chase seagulls).  Also, photography beyond the entrance room is not allowed, so you'll have to check the camera in.
author: Lam N.

description:
I decided to come here at pretty much the last minute on my last day in town, and to be totally honest, I didn't expect a whole lot, given the brief description on Fodors.com, but I was extremely surprised. The exhibits, as others have already mentioned, are laid out chronologically starting from Walt Disney's birth, and the "timeline" continues up until his death just before the completion of Disney World in Orlando. Special exhibitions are held in the annex behind the main building and are just a few dollars more.

This is probably one of the most enjoyable museums I've ever set foot in, not to mention well arranged and thoughtfully designed. I was extremely pleased with my decision to come here and would definitely recommend it for any fan of history, pop culture, or Disney-ana.
author: Ryan E.

description:
$20 each adult is pretty steep. But it was a good 2 hours before we left so I guess we got our monies worth.

The building is beautiful and the muesum is larger than you think.  Going through the history of Disney from the start to the really sad end.  I personally don't like where they ended the exhibit.  It was really sad and kind of bummed me out.  Would have been nice to see something hopeful, like what "might" be in the Disney company's future.  

My favorite part was Mary Poppin's exhibit and the miniture view of entire Disneyland. 

There are 2 levels.  If Level one is crowded skip it and go up to Level 2 and see it on the way down, but before you walk the spiral down to the miniture Disneyland. 

Don't eat there its a rip off - way to pricey and it looked like airport food.  
If you go before january 3 2012 park in the large lot and NOT on the street.  The large lot is free UNTIL Jan 3, 2012.  The street you still have to pay. 

It's a great place to see the history and if you love anything Disney you'll love this. 
Not a great place for little toddlers because its nothing like Disneyland and its a MUSEUM!
author: Erika G.

description:
IT'S A BIG WORLD

This is a such a huge museum. I arrived here at 10am for the Mary Blaire Show. Then left at 2pm. I really enjoyed it. However, I was kind of caught off guard that it was so expensive. Although, I guess if you really love this stuff it isn't so bad. You could literally spend hours on hours in here if you wanted to and make your time worth the cost; Just soaking it all in. Reading every tid bit of information this place crams in is amazing. 

My favorite installation must have been the film viewer that allows you to cycle through each and every cel to take a really close look at the animators notes and subtle changes in the character performance. 

If you plan to make the most of your visit. I would highly recommend eating a big breakfast so hunger doesn't disturb your vast excursion midway through the museum. My friend and I left because of hunger. Not because of boredom. I was also visiting from Los Angeles; I had things to do and Philz coffee to try.

Depending on who the next featured artist is. I will definitely be back.
author: Christopher M.

description: I really wasn't sure what to expect at this museum but I have to say I was really amazed. There was so much interesting information on Walt Disney and his family. The layout and the design is very impressive. I really liked the model of Disneyland. I am looking forward to going back to see the Dali exhibit.
author: Paul D.

description: Excellent museum. Has something for everyone. Great collection with interactive displays. You cannot leave this museum feeling inspired and in awe of the man who created this vision called Disney World.
author: Evelyn G.

description:
A must for anyone who has ever adored anything at all Disney. 

It was an amazing journey through Walt Disney's life. What an inspiring man who captured true imagination and manifested it throughout the world!

This museum was a lot more impressive than I thought it would be. Very organized and of course creative. 

As mentioned in other reviews, there is a ton of reading! Not for kids who are looking to be entertained or need activities. There are a few hands on exhibits as well as audio narrated visuals. But other than that, its a 17 room, detailed timeline about the Family of Disney and Walt's journey to making Disney a household name.

I left enlightened, grateful and excited for another trip to the Magical Kingdom!
author: Earlene C.

description: I loved this museum! I may be a little biased because I love Disney, but it was awesome to see the beginnings of Walt and how the Disney empire started. We went to the Disney and Dali exhibit first which took about 45 minutes. After that we went straight to the actual museum and had about 2 hours before it closed. The only regret I had was I wish I got there earlier to spend more time at the museum. If you really want to read and look at everything I would have allotted 3 hours for the main museum. There was so much to read and see, kinda had to rush towards the end. This place is a must for any Disney fan!
author: Erika E.

description: I was skeptical about going to this museum - it was not easy to get to using mass transit and it is fairly expensive at $20 per person. The first room or two I was even more skeptical as the information seemed to be info I could get from Wikipedia. The rest though? Blew me away. It made me realize how much of a patriot Walt Disney was, how smart he was technically when it came to his knowledge of animation and film production, his entrepreneurial decisions including his failures and lots of footage from his earliest drawings and cartoons. Overall, a very enjoyable and thorough museum that is geared towards adults willing to do a lot of reading, but I still felt it was overpriced at $20 per person.
author: Dan E.

description:
If you love history and grew up on Disney, then this is the place for you. I expected a tiny little museum, but 2 1/2 hours later I was still following the path - family, the early days as a cartoonist, a dream in Hollywood, movies, television, the theme parks, extras, and today.

I had forgotten that Walt had talked a lot about the process. You don't think about that during the weekly television shows. So, it was nice to hear his narration and of other people associated with him. There is even a little section dedicated to BofA and the strike.

The only thing I can add since I'm already raving, is to opt for all day parking in either the front lot or the side lot. Street parking in front of the museum is only for 3 hours, and it'll take you that long to go through the museum and any extra exhibits occurring. Next time I'm staying for the movie, which changes every month.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Janice O.

description: When I first moved up to the Bay Area, I made a trip with a friend to the Walt Disney Family Museum. I had no idea that it was here! The museum is incredibly extensive. I was so interested that I started off by reading everything. That was a mistake! Several hours later, I was dying to sit down and have a drink, but we were only half way through! There is a ton of information. I could easily go back again. Keep in mind that this is a museum, not an interactive play space. Its better for adults who can appreciate the history.
author: Kari G.

description:
great for Disney freaks like me who would like to be further enlightened on the history of the man behind the magic and how it all began. I love everything Disney and if youre a fan like me then why WOULDNT you come here? never hurts to learn new things. and when its about Disney, it makes it 10x better.

different levels, different rooms , different stages of Disney during its fascinating evolution.  

i wish a single adult admission wasnt $20 though. seems steep. or maybe im frugal. but then again it is Disney...
author: Renalen C.

description: Great for Disney fans, not so great for smaller kids.  It is a museum and even though there are interactive elements, there are more lithographs and reading involved then you might expect.  It is beautifully done, but it's more about the process and journey of Walt himself.  They also have Disney movies that you can see in their theater for an additional cost to your admission.  The special exhibits are in a separate building and are typically really interesting.  There is a gift shop and a cafe that has a very limited selection.  It's worth a visit if you're interested in a special exhibit, otherwise it's more of a one time visit kind of place.
author: Kristi G.

description:
I love love this museum. I'm a big fan of Walt Disney and museums so that's probably why. The museum is huge, there is so much information to absorb. I learned so much about his life and the advances of his animations, it was amazing. 

This museum made me admire Walt Disney even more than before and every room I walked into I got goosebumps. 

If you're a Walt Disney fan and in SF, (it's right next to the Golden Gate Bridge) it's a must see!
author: Kimberly X.

description:
Came here on Walt Disney Birthday, which the admission was free. Usually it cost, $20-25.

When we entered, there was a café on your left and the admissions office on your right. Got tickets and started the tour. 

Started out the history of his birth, videos, audio, and showed a lot of antique stuff around the whole tour. Very inspirational if you liked what Walt Disney did and how he had a success with Disneyland. There was 2 floors that gathered his cartoon work and Disney films. Towards 2/3rds of the museum, there was a view of the Golden Gate Bridge and begins your way towards how he got his idea of the famous Disneyland. I don't want to spoil the whole museum for you, but it's a must. It really brings you back to your childhood memories of watching Disney's films and Disneyland.
author: Gen M.

description:
The museum is really nice and you cannot get a better location than the Presidio.  I have been to the museum on a weekday and weekend.  The weekday of course is less crowded but when you buy tickets they do give you a start time to go through the place so people are staggered.  The first part of the museum is about Walt Disney and is entertaining enough so you want to look at everything.  The second part is the most fun when it gets into the animation, hands on exhibits and and Disneyland and world history.
The cafe and nice and the prices are not as bad as you might encounter at actual Disneyland.  The coffee is good and there is water for free.  The cafe has a pretty good variety of ready made hot and cold sanwiches and salads.  They are ready made though so ask about ingredients if you have any allergies.  I could not get a sandwich because it had onions in the spread.  There are also pastries and canned soft drinks and bottled water.  They have plenty of seating inside and outside.
What I was disappointed about was their small theater.  The screen was small and seating was very uncomfortable.  The rest of their facilities are so nice and designed to be Disney standards that when we saw the dinky theater it really does not do the rest of the museum and the movies that are screened there justice.  At least you can see just the movie for $7 and do not need to pay for the museum admission.  If you get the museum admission, the movie admission is included.  Check to make sure the movie did not change or the time is still correct day of on their website.
When you're done there and it's not too dark, walk up about half a mile to see the Yoda statue at Lucasfilm!
author: Casey T.

description:
I love the art and history of Disney so this is my kind of place, it may not be that interesting to small children, but an older children would enjoy it as long as they are interested in how Disney movies are made. 

First off it's a little hard to get to, at least for me since some if the current construction is blocking or covering the signs that help guide you through the presidio (where I've never been) and my gps kept wanting to take me to the dowtown Montgomery street not the presidio one, but after we found the place, it is a lovely location. 

Second know what you want to see and tell the receptionist everything, they don't seem to volunteer information. I didn't understand the special exhibits/movie are all separate fees because white on orange is hard to read in the board. I eventually saw the Mary Blair's exhibit after some back and forth, there is a Marc Davis exhibit somewhere that is still a mystery and I never found it, but ran out of time anyway, since I was lost in the presidio for 2 hours driving in circles earlier in the day.

To fully enjoy and interact with just the main museum you need at least 2.5-3 hours,and the special exhibit probably at least half an hour to an hour and then there's an hour and a half movie if you like, so you could easily spend the entire day there. Though be warned the café is expensive, but so are all other museum cafés, so that's nothing new really. 

We were pleasantly surprised at the size of the museum, but they could use some more security through telling people to get off their phones or stop talking so loudly. We happened to be around a few parties of loud talkers, and they weren't talking about the exhibit, which was annoying. We spent extra time waiting them to move on, but kept catching up to them.

Also don't be tricked into taking the elevator down at the end of the war movie stuff, continue on the path to see awesome miniatures disney collected, a great view of the golden gate and a disneyland model. (It's all ramped). 

I would return, especially to check out the special exhibit with more time.
author: S. D.

description: Went here for the first time a couple weeks ago.  The weather was poor outside but inside it was all forgotten.  This is a great museum to learn about the man behind Disney.  There are lots of old letters, recorded conversations, and photos to show how the Disney empire was created.  They say it takes 2-3 hours but at the 3 hour mark I was only about 1/2 way completed.  I'm one of those people that reads and listens to everything.  Luckily I went for the membership.  If you are there with a friend and seeing the extra exhibit it is only $20 more for a membership.  So basically go twice with a friend and it pays for itself.
author: Tom T.

description: Loved it! Took me back and educated us too what was happening innovation wise during my childhood. The Mary Blair exhibit is fantastic!
author: Lee M.

description: I never heard of this place until we found the bichirs at the hotel so we went to see what was there and this place was very interesting for all ages. I'm 26 and not to much into Disney but Walt had a very interesting story and there is a lot of cool exhibits there. I recommend you go and see for yourself.
author: Dustin H.

description:
This was a pretty great museum, but definitely more for adults than kids. I saw a bunch of kids that looked pretty bored through the whole thing. 

I would describe the museum as mostly reading with some audio and visual enhancements scattered around to keep you interested. I'll be honest, I got pretty tired of reading about 1/3 of the way through. I think if they had more seating near the reading I wouldn't have gotten so tired. We spent 3.5 hours to get through the museum, so leave yourself some time!

The museum definitely gets more interesting as you go (probably because it becomes more relevant). Of course you have to accept a little bias in story telling, given that it's made by the disney family (I recall reading several accounts of less-than-friendly encounters with Walt...). My favorite parts of the museum were the full Disneyland model, the origin of animation, and the 360-viewed disney clips.

Tips: 
-Definitely don't miss the incredible floor-to-cieling windowed room with a Golden Gate view!! 
- Remember your student ID to get $5 off (otherwise it's $20 for an adult).
-Even if there's a line to get in, it all spreads out later so don't panic.
-Closed every Tuesday...plus some other days, so look at the website.
-Parking in the lots right across from the front doors is $1/hour, and I would say 3-4 hours is more than enough time.

Overall: If you like disney stuff, definitely worth coming! I learned quite a bit about the disney family and origins of the company. I did get a little restless at some points from all the reading, but you can always skip ahead to the visual stuff if you want!
author: Brad M.

description:
I am a big fan of Disney but the museum was not overall that fun for me.

The beginning part is about Walt's history, growing up, and there's lot of reading. This part I recommend just zooming by. It gets more interesting when you hit Snow White and Bambi. It's somewhat interesting - I would like to have learned more about the movies themselves, but I guess that's why it's the Walt Disney museum.

The special exhibit was on trains, which I actually found really boring. There was also a gallery of Mark Davis animation, which had a lot of his drawings. I'm sure he contributed a lot to Disney animation but that was a quick zoom by for me as well.

Overall, I would recommend it to fans of Disney and/or museums.
author: Derek M.

description:
Is this place worth the $20 adult admission price? I say NO!

I think even if you are a die hard fan of Disney, this is just not a place to go.  When I went walking through the exhibits I felt as though it was a tour of wikipedia and google images for the name "Walt Disney." I'm not saying I know exactly what wikipedia has to say about Walt Disney, but it felt like I was just going through one giant encyclopedia, that had a few videos to make it seem like it was something special.

I guess I expected this to be epic, and it was such a letdown. For $20 per person, I expected  a lot of interactive pieces and there wasn't much. Ultimately, I came out of the museum feeling unhappy, which is sad because Disney is supposed to be uplifting.

I did not go to see the movie they were playing "Alice in the Wonderland". but I believe I would have had to pay extra to see it. I believe they give out discounts to AAA members and students, among some others, but only a couple of dollars off.

Overall, you can skip this museum and save your money to go somewhere that is more worthwhile.
author: Mona H.

description:
Excellent adventure!

Another fantastic place to bring out of town guests and the like. 

The Presidio setting is amazingly beautiful and the WDFM sits in a row of amazingly stunning brick buildings.  

Upon walking up to the building entrance, a docent invited everyone inside and instructed the person buying the tickets to stay in line.  There are plenty of upholstered benches inside or wooden benches scattered around outside to wait and relax until your volunteer buys tickets. 

While waiting, walk around the foyer of the inner entrance to the museum.  There are plenty of things to see including the Oscars awarded to Walt Disney and/or company.

Once you have your ticket, you go to the north end of the foyer, where a docent scans your ticket and you enter the life of Walt Disney awaiting a "train" that will take you from Kansas to Hollywood. Enjoy!

I loved it!  The docents are extremely knowledgeable. So much information!

You really have to visit here at least once if you are interested in the man or his ideas.
WowZa!

The Mary Blair exhibit was also excellent! Her artistry is featured in the "It's a small world" ride and other Disney animations.

It was a long day and very interesting!

I would not recommend this place for children unless they are enthralled with Disney history and facts. There are some interactive things for children to enjoy with an adult 
but the guided tours may not interest them for the duration.
author: Rebecca B.

description: Spectacular museum!!  I has tears in my eyes on the way out.  Plan to spend 2-3 hours to soak everything in.  What an amazing man Walt Disney was. You will be inspired!!!!
author: Marsha S.

description: If you are a Disney fan and into history, you will love this place. I went here with my friend who was visiting that is both of those things. She loved it. I thought it was ok. Honestly I was kinda bored. She is military so got us in to see the disney museum for free and the Dali exhibit was $10. The disney museum is usually 20 each so we would have spent 30 each. That would have sucked. Go with someone in military!
author: Ginger K.

description: The Walt Disney Family Museum is in a great location.  The museum explains the life of Walt Disney very well.  From his awards to his childhood life, you can spend hours at the different sections of the museum.  There are movie clips of how Walt Disney worked on the different Disney movies.  There is a lot of reading at various displays.  The gift shop is ok and the cafe doesn't have much food to eat.  I ended up eating at a bowling alley near by.  I highly suggest visiting this museum no matter how big of a fan you are of Disney.
author: Brandon L.

description:
I was expecting the Disney museum to be hyped up a bit, as most museums are, but being an avid Disney fan, I decided to drive up to San Francisco for a day and check it out. It was definitely better than I ever expected! The museum had everything from Walt's life, including his drawing before Mickey Mouse, the designs and history of Disneyland, the techniques for his animated features, ect. And never have I seen to many artifacts and the history labeled next to everything. 

Worth the drive and the price, however there's a lot of reading, which might be boring for certain people. I suggest going if you're a die-hard Disney fan (like me), or you want to learn the history of Walt Disney and the Disney company. This place was amazing, for sure 5+ stars! :)
author: Ali M.

description:
The Walt Disney Family Museum features so many excellent displays that it is easy to spend hours learning all about Walt and his creations that we all enjoy so much. Walt's Trains features several operating model trains. Don't miss the fun of that exhibit.

Be careful with parking. Some web posts have incorrect information about parking permits. You must display the permit that is purchased at the parking kiosk on the dash, even if you are paying to charge an electric vehicle. A $7 full day pass is inexpensive compared with getting a $75 parking violation. Since violations are handled by the federal United States District Court, there is no online citation protest.
author: Mark Z.

description: This place is amazing! The location is not hard to find, just be aware of co aren't street traffic prior to entering Presidios area. But once you are in that area it us much calmer. The museum itself has a lot of detailed information about Walt Disney, his family, and of course all his work before he created Disney and then of course tons of pictures and readings about Disneyland and the creation of Disney world. I would highly suggest younger children not be brought to the museum. This museum has a very calm and quiet environment due to everyone reading and listening to interviews from Walt Disney and the animators. Children will be bored and when too loud they distract others. It took about 2.5 hours to go through entire museum. I highly recommend this place especially for any hardcore Disney fans such as myself and anyone interested in learning more about Walt Disney.
author: Andrea M.

description: I got in during the free day (Walt's birthday I believe) with a group of friends and very little time to finish touring the museum. Sadly, we believed the museum to be very dry and similar to the first room, which was all about Walt's family history. We barely got to see the good stuff and man, there was a lot of cool stuff about the history of the company and the animations made. I loved the fact that there were interactive exhibits and information about the how and why of his creations. Seriously awesome. But, I probably wouldn't pay the admission on a regular day so I'm glad I came today.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
Have I mentioned yet that I am a huge fan of almost everything Disney? Welllllll now you know, + so like any true Disney fan, I made a trip to the one + only Walt Disney Family Museum on a recent trip back home. Yes, I do find it odd that the Walt Disney Museum is in SF (rather than somewhere that Walt had actually lived or worked) + hidden in the Presidio of all places, but hey, all the more convenient for me!

We pulled up to the unassuming brick building http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0LOx2_t8mUQ8zB_JY5pBHg?select=wSiyMVmkA40_Psx1_31uiw on a weekend afternoon + only knew we were at the right place by the small signs along the lampposts + on the front grass http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0LOx2_t8mUQ8zB_JY5pBHg?select=3ojo6iKwP25sAi7j8OsNAw. It wasn't crowded, surprisingly, + to my relief, the fellow visitors around us were mostly adults so we didn't have to be concerned about infants or children disturbing the experience.  

The museum, itself, consists of 10 galleries that chronologically follow Walt Disney's life starting from his family's genealogy in Europe to his passing away + the legacy that has followed. You begin the journey in a waiting room full of awards + Oscar trophies until it is time for your timed-entry group to enter the first gallery on the first floor. Here is where you see a glimpse of Walt's childhood + modest upbringing in the Midwest before taking an elevator up to the second floor to follow his early career + hardships as he ventured west before finding success with his now-famous beloved cartoon, Mickey Mouse. Continuing through the growth of Disney's thriving business in film, merchandising, + then eventually his theme parks through the decades, the exhibits then begin to spiral down http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0LOx2_t8mUQ8zB_JY5pBHg?select=grefdG7z1lnSH7wy4Jz4hw to the last 50 years of expansion of the Disney empire.

If the story of Walt Disney's life is not inspiring + admirable enough as it is, the layout + presentation of the museum will wow you for sure. Each gallery contains countless amounts of original artwork in the form of drawings, model figurines, film clips, etc as well as actual personal correspondences, photographs, documents, + memorabilia with captions, quotes + stories that explain the meaning behind each piece. Passing from room to room brings a refreshing new experience as the interior decor embodies varying themes + color palettes beautifully complemented by creative wall + freestanding installations, light fixtures + the architecture.   

I went with my family on this visit, + we probably spent a little over 4 hours there in total as we were taking our time admiring everything in each of the rooms, watched all the video clips, + of course, made a visit to the Museum Store gift shop afterwards. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0LOx2_t8mUQ8zB_JY5pBHg?select=EX4q7ne0jxKMqRKG51Bosw Highly recommending for all Disney fans who are of age (I'd personally say about at least 10 years old?) to patiently appreciate the detail + artistry in this peek into Disney's life. In a few years, I would definitely like to come back to visit the museum again!  

Admission is $20 for adults, $15 for seniors (65+), $15 for students (must have school id) + $12 for kids (6-17).
author: Janelle Q.

description: Anyone who appreciates Disney will have a good time at this museum. It was very cool to see the history of the mind that started it all, the man himself Mr. Walt Disney. Not only did this museum talk about the Disney family, but also the art of early animation and film and how Walt was a man like no other. The museum had many interesting artifacts and displays, but also interactive areas as well. So worth the visit for any Disney fan!
author: Karissa C.

description: What a great museum! It was informative, engaging, and moving. Give yourself a few hours to fully enjoy the experience. The museum offers an in-depth history of Walt's life and career, with very interesting toys, video clips, and artifacts. There is also a really neat model of Disneyland. If you are a Walt Disney fan, you don't want to miss it!
author: Rebecca V.

description:
I don't visit museums.  Although I appreciate art I don't go to museums at all.  THIS ONE was an exception.  This is a fantastic museum in a beautiful historic building located in the Presidio showcasing the life of the man himself, Walt Disney.  We spent about 3 hours here and I loved every minute of it.  The exhibits were insightful and I enjoyed watching all the video clips throughout the place, especially the ones of his family trips & vacations.  Upon entering, I'm thinking "okay, It's an adult museum".  But then it moves to stirring up the little kid inside of me.

There are some exhibits where the kids can get hands on playing fun like trying to play along to the Steamboat Willie cartoon, with headsets on, but don't count on more than a few.  My 6 year old immensely enjoyed banging and playing along with the cartoon, although she found herself a little bored because I wasn't moving on fast enough -- I just wanted to read everything!

I also found myself in tears towards the end of the exhibits realizing that Walt Disney's life did come to an end, and I wasn't the only one in the room in tears either.
author: Emy B.

description: Big museum with very thorough information about Walt Disney's inspiring life.  You come here for a long life story about Walt Disney.  You will learn a lot with the detailed information.  You will get to see some of his drawings and animations, his videos, his letters, lots of pictures with him and the people he met in his life.  My feet grew tired but I enjoyed the experience.  It was lovely.
author: Bena W.

description:
Speaking as a parent and as a primary grade teacher, this place is not for young children. It may sound like a great place to bring the kids but do everyone a favor and wait until your child is a bit older. 

The museum is located in the Presidio, one of the most beautiful places in San Francisco. If you come on a weekend, parking is plentiful and free so that's definitely a plus. Ticket prices are pretty expensive (if you aren't a member nor plan on becoming one) - $20 for an adult general admission. We got the combo ticket today (general admission + special exhibit admission) which was $25. If you buy the special exhibit admission separately it's $10 so you save $5. FYI, you cannot apply your AAA discount of $5 when you get the combo since it's already discounted. 

The museum is very big and in depth. It's best to go when you have a few hours and are not in a rush. There is a lot to read and appreciate (that's why it's not great for young kids as they will look around and be bored really quickly). In the middle of the museum (as you are walking through) there is an entire wall of glass that gives you an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. 

The special exhibit going on right now is Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. There is a lot of the original artwork on display and definitely worth paying the extra $5 to go and see if you are at the museum. One of the employees told me that it is so popular that it may be traveling after April 14th when it is finished at the Walt Disney Family Museum (as opposed to being in storage).

If you have to use the restroom, go downstairs in the main building. There you will get to see all the retro posters advertising the different parts of Disneyland (Tomorrowland, Fantasyland, etc.). 

I grew up in Southern California and have been to Disneyland numerous times but I love that I got to truly see how it all started with Walt Disney. What an amazing man to have influenced the world with the way that he did.
author: Connie W.

description: A great way to spend a couple hours on the Presidio. I enjoyed learning about the life and inspiration of Walt Disney, LOVED the first known drawing of Mickey (I felt I was in the presence of history), and was sad in the RIP Disney area. Beautiful museum,  beautiful stories.  Probably better for adults rather than kids.
author: K H.

description:
Absolutely 100% pure magic. (One tip-- be sure to pace yourself if you're low on time. It doesn't look like it, but there's like 4 floors of amazing content. )

In this museum, I learned that one of my all-time favorite, most inspirational people in the universe had a granddaughter named "Tammy".

My name is Tammy.

WORTH EVERY DAMN PENNY.
author: Tamara S.

description:
What an amazing way to spend a day!! 

I didn't even know this museum existed until I saw posters around SF advertising a screening of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs to celebrate the 75th anniversary of Walt Disney's first feature-length animated film. This place is a treasure. From entrance to exit, the museum manages to be cozy, educational, and accessible. The exhibits are multimedia, featuring original drawings, story boards, photographs of the studios, movie clips, musical scores, and collectible Disney items (including a Snow White charm bracelet by Cartier). If you want to take a peek, interactive galleries are here: http://www.waltdisney.org/interactive-galleries#. It's interesting to read about Walt's humble beginnings, his passion for his art, and his faith in animation. His exuberance and enthusiasm are contagious; he's one of those guys you wish you could have known. I was inspired by his vision, a world in which visual art and music unite in a unique, original way to inspire ideas and emotions. Nothing like it had existed before him, and there has been nothing like it since. 

There is a short film worth watching on the creation of Fantasia; Walt describes how artists were asked to listen to music by famous composers such as Bach and Tchaikovsky, and drew what they felt and saw when they closed their eyes. What was born from these creative, inspired sessions were eight animated segments many of us remember from childhood, including The Sorcerer's Apprentice. The concept drawings are fascinating, as is hearing the story behind the story. 

We were lucky enough to get into the 4pm showing of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. I loved it as a kid, but never saw it on the big screen. What a treat! It is amazing to see how much animation has changed over the years. I have a new found appreciation for the beauty and difficulty of drawing each frame by hand, the camera work required to give depth perception, and for the artists who spent their lives sharing their gifts with us. Go with kids, friends, or go alone - you will not be disappointed.
author: Ray J.

description: This place is fantastic. Located in the Presidio. It's a comprehensive history of the Disney family and the origin and growth of Disney Studios. Rich in detail and explanation. Plan for a long day. We got thru the early years up to World War II and then skimmed the rest. An amazing place.
author: Karl S.

description:
I actually didn't know that the Walt Disney Museum existed until I saw a Groupon-like deal show up in my inbox a few weeks ago.
