I made it up here recently and I was very impressed on how they compiled a lot of Walt Disney's early life from his parents and family to how he met his wife.  I also enjoyed seeing his pioneering visions when he entered into the animation field of work.  He truly was a great innovator that was ahead of his time.  From Steamboat Willie to Snow White and then subsequently Disneyland, all of these great ideas came from the active and brilliant imagination of Walt Disney despite many trials and tribulations over the course of his career.  

Overall, this museum is worth visiting at least once for anyone who has grown up with Disney and want to know who the man was and how he created the cartoon and animation genre.  As some Yelpers have mentioned, the museum tour ends with Walt Disney's death so there won't be anything in there with Pixar's footprint on there.  I'm glad that I came here to see the background story of the Disney name but I'll unlikely be back here unless they add a new exhibit or wing within the museum.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Day 3 of MWLAWMBF:
This was easily one of my favorite museums that we went to together. As much as I want to say that I enjoy hanging out with my boyfriend's friends, I like exploring museums on my own. Reading things at my own pace, watching the videos, various other things. 

I learned so much about Walt Disney going through this museum. You learn about his successes and failures and this difference that he made on various different people and the animation industry itself. The videos itself were amazing. You learned about Walt and you felt like he was talking to you in some of them. He was talking about his career and what he did. 

It's a great place for Disney lovers and learning lovers alike. You can also see how business savvy Disney was - taking risks and having them pay off substantially. Everyone loves the classics and he was the one who created them. You can see all the awards that he has won, but also the impact he made on people. 

I would have given them 5 stars, but minus one star because no pictures allowed inside the museum. I mean I get it; it's all copyrighted and stuff, but really I wanted to take a picture of the cool model they had of the original Disneyland. AWESOMENESS TO THE MAX.
author: Nina Y.

description: I am a huge Disney fan so when I came to San Francisco, I knew I wanted to visit. I feel that it is geared more towards adults with the history of his family. You get a great look into Walt's history and how Disney became the Mecca it is today. We also visited Dali and Disney exhibit which runs til the end of the year. It was a bit crowded so it was hard to read everything and the exhibit was very small but interesting.
author: Amanda T.

description: Very nice establishment with a lot of interesting artifacts about Walt Disney. It definitely sheds a light and insight on the man that I never knew before. It's sort of out of the way in the Presidio area of town. If you're you're relying on public transportation it's sort of a pain. The $20 price is fair but definitely on the high end of value. We went through the museum later in the day and the staff hurried us along unnecessarily so trying to get us out of the museum. Unless you're a HUGE Disney fan or looking for an indoor activity as we were it's down the priority list in the city
author: Jude W.

description: I think you have to really appreciate Disney and its name to appreciate this museum. I love Disney and I found this museum and the history it contains inside amazing, however my family and found it extremely boring. Then again they don't like Disney ): If you're tourists, it's definitely a must to come here! It's good for kids, and you'll only find a Walt Disney Museum here in SF. And it's very close by the Golden Gate Bridge, Crissy Field, Fort Mason which is next to Fisherman's Wharf and the Marina, and Geary Blvd, where you can find about a bajillion restaurants, and and the list just goes on.
author: Yvonne N.

description: Wonderful Visit! We are from Atlanta, GA and members of the high museum they have a reciprocity program where you can get in to other museums across the country for free and since we are visiting San Francisco we noticed that the Walt Disney Family Museum was on the list. I was amazed and so ecstatic to discover this gem! It was truly a wonderful museum and display of the brilliant man Walter Disney! Please, please, please do not hesitate to visit this museum! Carve out at least 2-5 hours so that you can really read and enjoy all of the artifacts! Don't forget the free movie in the theater each month as well!
author: Lauren W.

description:
I am a huge Disney fan, so this was definitely a fantastic visit.

http://shiawaselife.com/2013/06/20/museum-magic/

^^ That's my full post, with pics, but in general, here's the nitty gritty:
- Allot at least 2-3 hours to walk through and enjoy the exhibits
- This museum is all about Walt Disney's life (the highs/lows) and is NOT Disneyland, go in with the expectation of discovery and you'll enjoy it.
- Fun gift shop!
author: Krissy M.

description:
Being a Disney fan I thought it would be fun to go to this museum and see what its all about. I took one of my friends with me who loves Disney as well and we were in awe of the place because of Walt Disney's history. This place wasn't really what I was thinking it would be, it's no Disneyland or anything but it really is nice to learn about Walt Disney. The section about Disneyland was my favorite, where they even had the first model of the Autopia car!! I wouldn't bring a 5 year old to this Museum though, I would say someone 12 and up would enjoy it. I wish it was explained more or that we could go on a tour, but its nice that its self guided because you can take your time. We spent probably 2 hours here in the morning. 

Its in the presidio, so don't get lost!!
author: Jaimie M.

description: Nice place. They were a little weird about taking pictures though.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Being such a Disney fan, this place is pretty awesome.  It's an awesome museum that traces Walt Disney's life, all the way back to his lineage.  You get to learn a lot of how Walt Disney started, about his family, and how it became the empire it is today. 

Just remember:  there are no pictures allowed (there's people that walk around and enforce it) and it really isn't a place for kids.  A lot of the museum is reading and fact-learning, so if your kid can handle that, then go for it! 

It definitely makes you appreciate what Disney has done, and the magic  he bought into our childhoods.  

Oh and FREE PARKING IN SF?!  That really IS magical!
author: Mary N.

description:
I will admit that I was a bit disappointed with the museum as it didn't fully meet my expectations. With that being said though, my expectations were likely incorrect (my bad), and it's actually quite solid for what it is. And to get this out of the way, I thought that there would be more focus on the artwork and sketching, or at least the development of that skill throughout the years. Not so much, so again, my bad.

It is a great look at exactly what it advertises itself to be: a museum about Walt and his family. Each section is wonderfully curated and quite a bit of interactive sections that allows you to not just stare at the walls to glean the information behind the Disney family. 

The museum itself is also deceptively larger than it looks as it's planned in a manner that allows them to utilize the most space possible. This goes back to my statement of them curating it rather nicely and mixing the different styles, artwork (when applicable), along with the growth of Walt's business and his family.

Oh yeah, and for the pin traders, they have some amazing pins there.
author: Shauna S.

description: Wow! What a great experience!  Everyone was nice and informative!  It was also really refreshing to see Walt from a different perspective.  I would go again!
author: Paulie B.

description:
I've been wanting to visit for a while now. Truth be told - I'm not a die-hard Disney fan. On a recent rainy day, the Manpanion and I were looking for something to occupy our time. Tip: Museums are a great place to go to on rainy days. Be warned: A lot of people know this!

There were two major exhibits going on: the permanent collection, which is in the main building, and the Snow White exhibit, in a neighboring building. Tip: You don't have to go to both. You can choose one or the other. Since we didn't realize this, the Manpanion and I ended up getting tickets to both. 

We hit the Snow White exhibit first. It took about an hour to get through. I really enjoyed reading the history behind the film. I had no idea the impact it had on filmmaking and animation. The exhibit showcases how the characters were designed and how the story was adapted from its various versions. It'll definitely give you a new respect for the film!

The permanent collection is much longer and I highly recommend that folks give themselves about three hours to get through everything. You don't really understand the magnitude of Walt Disney's contributions until you see this collection. It's quite detailed and there are so many components that it's easy to get lost and overwhelmed. While I enjoyed it, I'm definitely going to come back and see all the things I missed out on the first time around.

Another cool discovery is that they have a theater where they screen select films. You have to check the schedule to find out more info. After seeing the Snow White exhibit, I'm definitely going to come back to watch Snow White in the theater there. Also, don't forge that there's a cafe and a bookstore!
author: Joanne R.

description:
This museum is surprisingly well designed, the quality of artifact, interactive exhibitions, are absolutely jaw dropping. I noticed they used tons of big flat screen TV, big touch screens, and iPad! Which probably explains the rather expensive admission price.

It also takes advantage of the prime location, there is a whole section of stunning glass wall to give you 180 degree panorama view of gold gate bridge and san francisco bay, breathtaking!

There is also an open studio on the first floor, where visitors can do some wide varieties of very unique crafts, you can even make some movies.

After looking through the exhibitions, I come out with tremendous respect on the dedicated,  hardworking, visionary Walt Disney, who is truly one of the kind, no wonder he can build the extremely successful Disney franchise.

The only minus is that everything in the gift shop is expensive. Oh well.

You probably need a whole day of uninterrupted time to go through all exhibitions, better make it two day trip if possible, it's really that good.
author: Hong Z.

description: I was here with my cousins that came to the City from back East, it's informative, delighful, feel like a kid again going here.
author: Amy B.

description:
For my 100th review, I wanted to celebrate one of the best museums I've ever been to in my entire life. If I could give this museum, 10 stars, I would.

Any Disney fan will LOVE this museum. Pure and simple, this museum highlights Walt Disney's entire life, from his upbringing to his financial struggles, as well as his artistic accomplishments in the most interactive and creative way yet.

From the exterior, it seems like this museum is just like any other boring museum. BUT IT'S TOTALLY NOT. Wow, I haven't had so much fun reading beautifully crafted texts and playing with all the different instruments and touch-screen monitors inside.

The best part of this museum is the miniature re-creation of Disneyland and definitely the glass view of Golden Gate Bridge. On a sunny day, you'll get awesome pictures of the beautiful bridge.

The staff inside are REALLY friendly and are willing to help you navigate through all the crazy exhibits. My favorite exhibit is one of the earlier stages of his animation career.  I've learned so much about Walt's career and struggles from this museum. He is truly an inspiration for adults and kids everywhere.

A MUST-VISIT for anyone visiting San Francisco or the Bay Area and anyone who loves animation!
author: Vinky I.

description:
This museum is gorgeous, informative, and there is no other place like it.

The highlights for me included seeing Disney's Oscars (including the one he got for "Snow White" with 7 ll' statues..one for each dwarf!), and cameras he used to create his magic. Oh- and the exhibit on his visions for Disneyland were also something else. His life and career are fascinating, and this museum did such a fine job telling s about it. 

Beautiful museum in beeeeeaaaaauuuuuutiful Presidio. Aren't many better ways to spend a weekend afternoon!
author: Molly M.

description: Got to this place (The Walt Disney Family Museum) today. This place is as good as it gets and I would give it a thousand stars if I could.  My aunt from Illinois and I decided to check out the Mary Blair exhibit for an extra $5 (worth every penny and then some).    This Museum is clean, classy, well organized, informative, entertaining, enchanting and educational.  We spoke to several employees today about various questions. Every person we interacted with was friendly, helpful, informed/informative and really seemed to want to provide top-notch service.  I am an absolute fan.
author: Maggie B.

description:
I came here on a weekday and did the Snow White exhibit as well as the museum. 

I lived near Disneyland for a few years and definitely enjoyed my annual pass there for a couple of years, so I was already a disney fan going in. I will admit that I have always been a bit wary of how corporate it seems, but this museum made me remember the magic of disney.

As a 20-something I grew up on Disney, but never appreciated it's revolutionary qualities. This museum shows the history of Mr. Walt Disney and how he worked his way to create the Disney empire. This didn't happen overnight or very easily, he risked a lot and put it all out on the line in order to see his dreams come to fruition. 

I really respect Disney more than I did before and appreciate how he transformed the movie experience.
author: Maggie F.

description: Love this place. As a lifelong Disney fan and Bay Area resident, it's shameful that it took me so long to visit. If you are a fan of Disney history at all, this is a must-visit. Tons of information on the makings of the Walt Disney Company, on Walt Disney's humble beginnings, and if you have any sort of inclination to learn about the world of animation and its origins, you NEED to come here. Be warned - if you're a huge Disneyland fan and are expecting to get a Disneyland-like experience here, that's not what you'll find. You'll recognize the design and technical elements like you'd find in the park (as expected), but there is only one large room dedicated to Disneyland. The museum focuses on Walt Disney and his family, and ends with the creation and development of Disneyland (including a model of the park which is INCREDIBLE), and Walt Disney's death. I became a member on my first visit and have already returned. Great experience!
author: Jessica S.

description: Wow. Anybody who loves Disney and grew up watching the films will appreciate this museum. I really loved going through the different exhibits, seeing the childhood and past of Walt Disney and then also how his drawing matured through the years and how Disney played a part during WWII with designing cartoons and drawings during wartime. I really loved the view of the GG Bridge along one side of the museum. My favorites were probably seeing the Snow White section as well as the mini Disneyland. A beautiful tribute at the end to the life and work of Walt Disney.
author: Ellin C.

description: Great family day, with inspiring insights into Walt's genius, topped by an afternoon viewing of The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh, all included with the price of admission. For a few extra dollars, we enjoyed a simple lunch in their deli of Walt's Favorite Chili and our family favorite Caesar Salad.
author: Mary S.

description:
Fabulous. Inspiring. Touching.

Decided to become an annual member for the first time. Went with my family for all of our first times and I can honestly say this is the ONLY museum that not a single one of us said "I wanna go now." If there were more levels and floors to this museum I would not be disappointed.. 

It is really inspiring to see how one man made such a difference in millions of peoples lives then and now. There is a beautiful view of the golden gate bridge from this museum. Photography is NOT allowed in the museum.....only in the entrance where you can see Walt's awards, including his customized Oscar for Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. 

If you want to really take your time and take in all the magic around I would suggest going with Disney fans and children that will be okay with sitting, standing, reading and just viewing. This is not a discovery museum so it was very annoying to see children trying to climb fixtures and such. 

Worth the time and money. Don't miss out.
author: Kimberly M.

description: I'm not a disneyphile but I found this to be really interesting. I'm definitely more of a history buff than anything else and this was just a fascinating piece of modern history. I didn't know how many things Disney had his hands on. He was definitely the Steve Jobs of the 20th century. It was a great business/history lesson. Even though it wasn't as interactive as, say, Disneyland, there were videos, sketches, memorabilia, murals, etc. that was just exciting to see and read about. For the price, it was quite awesome. If anyone can let me know why it was in SF, that would be helpful. Didn't see any connection between Disney and the city. It's also a great location with plenty of parking.
author: Anna S.

description:
I am a huge Walt Disney fan so when my boyfriend got two passes to the museum, I was so excited.  I have read much about the man, himself and everything that is Disney oriented.  My grandmother was a childhood friend of Walt and his sister back in Missouri.  Every few years, I head to Disneyland for vacation every since I was little.  Disneyland has fond memories for me.  

Anyhow, I did like the layout of the museum and the experience in itself was enjoyable.  The displays were educational and there was much video footage throughout.  My favorite exhibit was the small scale of Disneyland with actual moving parts.

 But there were a few reasons why I did not like it.  First, this museum lacks hands-on exhibits.  It involves mostly exhibits with reading text.  This would be okay if you wanted to just spend hours learning about Walt Disney through text.  But in a way, I was hoping for an amusement park like atmosphere with a fun and interactive way to learn about this amazing person.

Second, you are not allowed to take pictures while in the museum.  And yet, there is a picture book you can buy in the gift shop, although it is not cheap at $34.95.   Still, people often want to take pictures of their family and friends or even take a picture of themselves to prove that they were there.  But taking pictures is not allowed.  That sucks!

Third, the gift shop items are pricey.  It is actually cheaper to buy merchandise at the regular Disney Store or better yet, at the nearby Disney store outlet (AMS) which is open at a nearby shopping mall for a limited time.  For about the price of a necklace I had liked at the museum gift shop, I was able to buy a Disneyland hat and charm bracelet for about $10 less at the outlet!

Fourth,  I did not like that fact that not everything is included in the museum admission.  The new Snow White exhibit admission is separate from the museum's admission.  I am a huge fan of the Snow White movie but I would have to wonder with the lack of information I found at the museum regarding this Snow White exhibit,  if it was worth paying another $10 to go to it.  Personally, I think that there should be one straight admission fee that covers all exhibits and events at the museum for that day.


Pros:
-great place to learn about Walt Disney
-nice layout of the museum

Cons:
-lack of hands on exhibits
-no taking pictures allowed
-gift shop items are pricey
-not all exhibits are included in the general admission
author: Irene S.

description:
It was beyond incredible - like stepping back in time 109 years and reliving life alongside Walt. And even though like the Titanic I know how the story ends, I still cried uncontrollably during the final 20 minutes - and I'm not ashamed to say it. I was there for five and a half hours and was never bored once. The artifacts, video and audio clips, the history - it was well worth the time. 

The opportunity to hear Walt's voice and see his image in video could only be matched by seeing in person artifacts such as original furnishings from the Disney apartment above the Disneyland Firehouse; the actual Carolwood Pacific engine #173, the tender, and several boxcars and gondolas; the incredible scale model of Walt's Disneyland; personal effects that once belonged to Walt and Lillian; dozens and dozens of awards and honors bestowed upon Walt from around the world; and, the heartwarming quotes from Diane Disney Miller throughout the two-story museum. 

Walt Disney has meant a lot to me in my lifetime and has been an inspiration, role model, and icon for me. This experience was the closest I'll ever get to meeting Walt and his family now that all of his immediate family with the exception of Diane have passed on. 

Thank you WDFM for making my dream come true today. I will definitely be back - even if you don't change a single thing!
author: David F.

description:
Beautiful and unexpected.
Another amazing Presidio destination.  A wonderful day for any Disney fan who wants to experience the magic without any of the amusement park madness.
author: Truth Mama B.

description:
I enjoyed my visit to The Walt Disney Museum situated in a historic brick building (once a barracks) on the main post of San Francisco's Presidio.  This museum is great to visit if you are really interested in learning more about the life and career of Walt Disney.  

The museum's large collection is mostly composed of Disney's early drawings, photos as well as personal correspondences showcasing his trajectory and accomplishments in animation and live-action films.  Additionally, inside this 40,000 square foot museum, you will also find historic memorabilia such as Disney's Oscar award statues, interactive galleries, listening stations, 114 seat Fantasia-themed theatre, and a 14-foot model of Disneyland.
author: Lupe M.

description: $20 a person + extra $5 per person for 'special exhibits' + parking for boring exhibits + crappy cafe = highway robbery by a corporate family who already has plenty of money.
author: Rebecca S.

description: What an amazing tour of Walt's life.  I am a self confessed Disney World fanatic and couldn't wait to visit.  This place does not disappoint.  starting with Snow White and Seven Dwarves Oscar and continuing with all the interactive exhibits, the original Lilly Belle and amazingly detailed model of Walt's Disneyland - we spent about three hours exploring the museum.  The last gallery is incredibly touching as the world said goodbye to Walt.  In talking with the docents I discovered that the museum encompasses about 20% of the Disney family's collection, but the museum is huge.  I will definitely visit again, feeling that I could spend more time reading and viewing.
author: Robert H.

description:
The crowds have subsided.  A visit to this museum is quite enjoyable, no waits for the interactive displays.  Comfortable seating is well-placed for viewing the various exhibit projections.

There's apparently a ticket discount for Wells Fargo account holders, although the staff may be unable to figure out how to apply this.  

Parking is free on Saturdays (sorry, I think I'm getting obsessive about parking when in SF), and very available and tree-shaded behind the museum.
author: Mutant O.

description:
Any Disney-Lover would love this place! But it is not good for kids. There is a ton of reading in very small print. The layout is beautiful and this museum really takes you into the thoughts and ideas of Walt Disney.

He was a very creative man who did encounter defeat but pushed through every challenge. This was very neat to see how Mickey was thought of and drawn out.

The price is $20.00 per person, a little up there for a museum but if you are a student, have an updated ID that way you only have to pay $16.00.

There is also a cafe here for a quite lunch or quick breakfast. 

I would recommend if you have extra time in San Fran but if you don't I wouldn't make this one of the major things to go and see.
author: Victoria C.

description:
YES YES YES I LOVE THIS PLACE!

It's just as magical as going to Disneyland! Or just as magical for the price tag of $15 :p I was having Disneyland withdrawals like the crackhead I am, and decided to hit up the museum. 

General Admission: $20
Student  Discount: $15? Awww yisss.... 
They also have senior discounts.

You can also buy a yearly pass. The yearly pass is valid for an ENTIRE year and DOESN'T expire at the end of the year. You can choose to buy the pass after you purchase the one-day ticket if you decide to come back, they take off the amount you already paid for. The info desk also told me that you can return with your ticket stub within 30 days (I think) to purchase the yearly pass and still get the amount you already paid for taken off. How nice is that?

Exhibits start off a little slow, and it builds after that. They did a GREAT job with each individual exhibit room. It's like the factory for how the magic happens, it's just wonderful. 

Excellent decor and i would LOVEEE to be able to purchase some of the vintage Alice in Wonderland posters but none were available. The giftshop is ALSO full of wonders! I'm not a giftshop person, and this is probably the only giftshop I've gone crazy in!

Everything is so lively and so creative, a must visit for all diehard Disney fans!
author: Azn B.

description: This is a beautiful new museum in the Presidio chronicling the family history and life of Walt Disney.  It is an absolutely beautiful venue with stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge.  They have amazing photos, and the story is very well laid out.  We spent 2 hours here, and I certainly could have spent 5 here (we were with a group, so we had no choice).  I want to come back.  I loved learning about Walt's beginnings in Chicago and Kansas City, and his starts in animation.  The model of Disneyland is also amazing.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. 

I don't even live in SF, but I bought a membership so that I can go whenever I want. There are so many things that I learned and the visuals were so fantastic, it was nearly impossible to conceal my squeals of delight as the 10 year old in was coming out. 

Its in presidio, which is a beautiful place to be and its nearby the golden gate bridge so  you can swing by and take some tourist-y pictures right after!!
author: Jenn C.

description: As a huge Walt Disney fan, I really wanted to like this museum but, ultimately, found it to be a big disappointment. Too much of the museum was just photographs of Walt's early days and a lot of reading. The crowds surrounding each exhibit made many of the readings difficult to get near so, basically, you are left looking at a lot of photographs without any sort of explanation or context to them. The best parts of the museum are at the end; a big model of Disneyland and an animatronic Tiki Room bird. Also, if you are using public transportation, this museum is quite difficult to get to.
author: Gary B.

description: Ill be the outlier here.  Was very disappointed. First i will admit that coming to a museum about a cartoonist/film producer/empire builder wasn't high on my list but i tried to come with an open mind and heart. There is definitely a lot of information, gee whiz technology, and great staff. So why the low rating you ask? Simple, overload! There are a lot of audio and video exhibits. So much so that sound from one bleeds into the next.  Even when u are standing in that magic spot where speakers are directed right at you, you can still here multiple adjacent exhibits.  I found it really really hard to focus and enjoy the presentations.  Gave up after 30 minutes. Others in the my group seemed to really enjoy it though.
author: Marcus K.

description:
Awesome history of Disney, the man. While Disneyland makes up a big part of his life, there is a fascinating history. Self-guided. Takes between two to three hours especially if you watch all the video clips and read the fascinating stories.

If you are a fan of old fashioned Americana and self-made success, this is a great experience. 
 
Rent a bike for the day and see the whole Presidio.
author: Philippe H.

description: I went today to the 5 year anniversary Free day and it was amazing! I really wasn't expecting much, I didn't know what to expect. I didn't think I would end up spending 7 hours there! Yes, that much to see! I found myself whistling to the snow white song and feeling like I was a kid again watching old cartoons. They also had a special film with the family telling the story of how and why the museum was built. It was very informative and touching. There are really cool interactive pieces. Very cool for adults, and some fun for kids too. Get ready to READ alot if you really want to know about Walt.
author: Karen T.

description:
If you're like me, you've grown up on Disney movies but probably still don't know much about the man or the story behind the great company.  Well, the Walk Disney Family Museum will fix that for you.  It is a museum mostly built for adults but is still interactive and fun!

You walk thru rooms of memories and come out with a better understanding of how difficult it is to build an empire.  My favorite parts were the wartime stories and what they did to survive when so many others crumbled.  I'd tell you about it but, it's better if you go yourself!

For me, it was prolly only a one time adventure but I have other friends who have been there a couple of times already.  

Might see ya there.
author: Susan D.

description: This is a beautiful tribute to Walt Disney! There are so many Galleris to view his life from childhood to his passing away. We spent hours looking at everything & the small extra price for the Pinnochio Exhibit was absolutely
author: Julie E.

description: I recommend going to visit because it's a non-profit(not run by the Disney Company) that still tells you the honest and accurate truth about Walt Disney. It also has a huge model of Disneyland that Walt Disney wanted Disneyland to be like! It also has some of his own personal stuff too. I was a volunteer there, I try to go more often but it's to far away from where I live so I haven't been there in a while. All the people who work there are really nice.
author: Samuel B.

description:
I'm not too much of a Disney fan but I really enjoyed this place! The only issue I had with it was that there was so much to read!!! Totally not a place to bring your kids cause they'll get bored before you can read the first placard in the room. They should add some kind of interactive section to distract the kids so the adults can quickly enjoy the museum.

Lots of history about how Walt Disney built his empire. I loved it but it does get exhausting. Glad they have the elevator half way through the museum so you can take a break to look at the gift shop below or get some coffee and a snack. 

The gift shop lacked Disney merchandise though. I was really disappointed that most of the stuff they sold wasn't Disney brand. Basically only the keychains had the Disney Museum logo on it and everything else was just Disney-esk stuff like random fairy books and jewelry. I was looking forward to buying something that said I went there but nothing piqued my interest. 

I didn't see a parking lot. Parked on the street in front of it where there's limited parking. Go early. AAA discount to get in for $15 too.
author: Karen Y.

description:
One blustery day, the Canadian and I decided to venture out into the Hundred Acre Wood known as the Presidio.  

"Where should we go?  Are there museums to explore?" he asked.  
"Let's go to the Walt Disney Museum!" I exclaimed.
"Why there?"  he asked.
While I can't remember my official answer, the reason was that I wanted to show him my unhealthy obsession with all things Disney early in our relationship so he could run away before we really started to like each other.  

Suffice it to say that while he tends to mock me at every available moment about said unhealthy obsession, he's stuck around.  Bonus points for him.  

Like others have mentioned- this is really a museum for adults.  While some of the younger generation will recognize Snow White or Mickey Mouse, it's the adults who will appreciate clips of the Silly Symphonies or cast photos of the original Mickey Mouse Club.  

Truth be told, I love that museum.  Sure, there were parts I skipped over because it REALLY gets into Walt Disney's life, and there are a ton of recorded interviews you can listen to, but it's an inspiration that a man with his background became one of the most influential men in all of media (and has the most Oscars to boot- trivia question.  Look for the one for Snow White- they are original Oscars, and they are all on display).

Parts I loved- the whole Disneyland section...for obvious reasons.  Particularly the little replica.  Also, although I almost cried, the part at the end when it covers his death was very touching.  

If I ever need a Disney fix, I'll come here.  It's well worth it.

One tip: Don't bother taking a cab out there- your cabdriver will not be able to fathom that there is a Montgomery Street in the Presidio, and will keep trying to take you to the Financial District.  That was the most painful cab ride I've ever experienced, although I did get a good tour of SF.
author: Pam S.

description:
What an amazing experience at this family museum. I remember writing a paper about walt disney when i was younger and this place really brought back memories.  My favorite was definitely stage 9 as they called it...Not really your typical disney place for kids for i would think just plain exhibits the young kids would find this place fairly boring..but there are lots of plasma screens that play endless cartoon clips that might keep them entertained. The model of disneyland 1/2000th scale was pretty cool.
Overall great experience, a must see in the Yay area ...well done 5/5 judochops!!!

M-I-C....see you real soon!  K-E-Y....why? Because we love you.....M-O-U-S-E.
author: Dustin G.

description:
My friends and I spent a good 2-3 hours here just being wrapped up in the entire life path from Walt's birth to his last day on earth. Very inspiring and gifted man who did so much for the world. I felt like we went through a time warp in each room you go through. If you love anything and everything Disney-related, you'll definitely enjoy learning and experiencing the life of the creator of all things magical. Glad we finally had the chance to visit! It's as close to "Disneyland" as you'll get in the Bay Area. :)

And last, but not least, you have to visit the gift shop of course! The Presidio is a great location as it has spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge and ocean.
author: Bria S.

description:
I remember seeing the Walt Disney Family Museum in the Via magazine and told myself I have to come here. I came here recently and loved it. The museum is all about Walt Disney's life history and his career. Their display consists of videos, readings, and audio. I wasn't expecting a lot of reading but all the readings were interesting that I couldn't stop. My favorite exhibit was at the end where they had the miniature layout of Disneyland. I wished I could've taken a picture because I was so amazed by it but no photography allowed. I wished I shrunk so I can go take a tour of Disneyland and maybe ride the rides. Haha. I really enjoyed this place and the price was so worth it. 

The museum is really clean and parking is free.  They do have a cafe after you finish the exhibit. It is operated by Wolfgang Puck Catering. They have healthy organic items like sandwiches. They do have a museum store too which have tons of objects related to Walt Disney. I walked out with milk chocolate, postcards, and a paint brush pen.
author: Janice V.

description: I see a lot of people saying if you love Disney you'll love this place on here and that is just not the whole truth. The truth is if you love Disney and have a want to learn everything you can about Walt and his history this place is great. If your like me and just love his movies, love going to the theme parks but your interest in Disney really stops their save your money. Now to be fair if I could have gone at my own pace this place would have been ok but i was with two people who were enthralled with this museum and what would have taken me about 30 minutes took them well over 3 hours. In the end I would have had a much better time if I had spent the price of admission on a Disney movie at my local theater.
author: Omer H.

description:
As I trekked across the presidio with my heavy backpack, in transit from the MUNI stop near the Lombard gate, I couldn't help but think that I was embarking on an adventure.  Maybe it was the absolute stillness of the morning, or maybe it was the labyrinthine path my iPhone had drawn me in order to reach my destination.  Either way, the day was resonating with the spirit of Walt Disney.

But seriously though, finding this museum is like finding a hidden mickey;  You have to do your research and work for it.  That's why I'm not docking points for its remote location; in fact after the glorious view of the Golden Gate bridge you get from the middle of the gallery, how can you not reach catharsis?  Any frustrations I may have had were whisked away by the glorious views, the cavernous 16 room exhibition floor, and the faint whispers of Tchaikovsky.

There are so many things to love about this museum.  From the sheer depth of information that you probably did not know, to the plethora of Disney artifacts, I was filled with an actual sense of wonderment that I hadn't felt in a long time.  I geeked out and learned about how to use a multiplane camera, watched Walt interact with animatronic dinosaurs,  and lost myself in the entire room dedicated to Disneyland with it's phenomenal scale model of the entire park.  That, and a gift shop full of merchandise that you probably haven't ever seen in the Disney parks.  

I already had a mountain, no Matterhorn of respect for Walt's creative genius, but after learning about his hardship, his selflessness during the war to contribute to the cause, and his fearlessness to innovate despite a world of haters, I was smitten once again.  

This is one of those museums that will excite your children, and regale your folks.  It truly is for everyone, and I simply cannot wait to go back.  Bravo.

5 Stars.
author: Drew M.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed this museum!  There were so many insights into Walt's life, his early struggles and his eventual success. A great place if you're a Disney fan, but also if you are a student of entrepreneurship, personal fortitude and visionary endeavor. Fascinating!
author: G M.

description:
Stop me if I'm saying something that isn't true- Anyone who has ever been a kid still loves Disney today! We have to admit it- we're all grown adults with a life long affection for a mouse! Anything and everything that encompasses the name 'Disney' brings a smile to our faces. The cartoons, the movies, the characters, the theme parks- It's only fitting we give thanks to the genius himself who created it all- Walt Disney.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0LOx2_t8mUQ8zB_JY5pBHg?userid=-4BEUkLvHQntN6qPfKJP2w

Visiting this museum, two things will become unbelievably clear. First, how much influence Walt Disney has had on our culture and entertainment we enjoy today- And two, how much love and happiness Walt wanted to spread across the world to people like you and me. The museum is a journey from Walt's very early family life, his military years, his first adventures into cartooning, all the way up to the creation of many characters and movies we know today. I have a feeling that this museum was done better than some presidential museums. 

I love taking pictures of places I know I'll be Yelping- however taking pictures in the museum is not allowed. I guess it's better that way though- I wouldn't want to spoil some of the awesome things you'll be seeing in here! A lot of previous Yelp reviews suggest that bringing kids here is a no-no, but if you're kids can appreciate Disney(and can stay QUIET in a museum) then I say go for it! 

Bring a student ID and save $5. If you are lucky enough to be a Bay Area resident- the Walt Disney Family Museum is a must see local attraction. If you're a tourist reading this review deciding whether this museum is for you- It's a little out of the way from all the other downtown SF tourist attractions, but it sits right next to the Golden Gate Bridge and Yoda Statue http://www.yelp.com/biz/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilms-hq-san-francisco#hrid:-Z_eJKTOcVohlivHPNyKgA/src:self

5 Stars- Magical, Inspiring, Great place to go.
author: Greg G.

description:
This is an amazing place to see for Disney fans. All the stories about Walt and his childhood, his passion for animation and how the whole thing turned into the global empire of today.
There are so many amazing things to see inside (Mickey's first appearance, how they made Bambi move so lifelike, the different camera's they invented for the animators. It's just a blast. We spent almost 4 hours there this weekend and we still missed a ton.
I would have given 5 stars, but there is so much reading to do that young kids will miss out on some experiences,
author: Greg S.

description:
Being a HUGE Disney fan, I'm surprised I hadn't heard of this plac euntil one of my friends suggested we go here!

Student admission was $15, which was all right, seeing that we ended up spending 2.5 hours wandering all of the galleries. The museum does a wonderful job of tracing Walt Disney's family history and career advances. Sprinkled between each informative gallery are huge pictures, videos and interactive displays that create a fun visual break from all of the history.

While this place would probably not be a good place to take kids (they'll get bored!), it's a must-see for any older Disney enthusiast.
author: Lucy C.

description:
If you are a "Disney Fanatic", you will like this place for the collectables and history. A really nice place to learn about the man and his passion.

Kids may find it a little boring because it is a museum, but there are plenty of videos and cartoons to keep their interest.
author: J T.

description:
This is a nicely laid out museum with a lot to learn. The rooms are constructed in interesting ways that make it feel interesting and varied. The vast majority of the museum is photos with signs to read or short videos on the wall. It was very interesting to learn about Walt's early life, as well as his career. 

I was visiting with all adults, and the one thing that surprised me was that this place is definitely NOT a good place for kids. It is a museum about the Walnut Disney Family, not a family museum about Walt Disney. It is entirely geared towards adults, with very few interactive activities and lots of reading. It was  a pretty busy day, and there was only one couple with a child there, who was getting obviously antsy after just a short time in the museum, because there really was nothing to keep their attention. After a few minutes, I heard one of the parents say they were going to go wait in the car with the kid.
author: Kristen C.

description: I absolutely adored visiting the Walt Disney Family Museum! Went with a party of 6 and it was wonderful. The museum contains so much of Disney's life, work, creative process, and more; I learned much more than I had expected to. The interactive audio tools for kids are great. My favorite part of the museum was the miniature model of Walt Disney's vision of Disneyland, it was so interesting to see all the attractions that still exist today and what had been originally planned. As a child of the early 90s I admit to hoping there were some displays about The Lion King inside; there aren't any, but I learned a ton about the older works of Disney than I previously knew. The museum also has a cute little gift shop (I recommend picking up some pins!) and cafe with delicious Ginger Beer. Being located in the historic Presidio was an absolute bonus for me; the buildings have a lot of history and are beautiful to walk amongst. I highly recommend taking some time out of your day in San Francisco to visit the Walt Disney Family Museum.
author: Paige P.

description:
This place was fantastical! Beautifully and thoughtfully designed and costs not spared to bring an extensive and gorgeous museum to the Presidio. My only complaint is that I was exhausted after 2 hours of reading and perusing this great monument to the life and accomplishments of Walt Disney. There was sooo much crammed into this museum that I got a little tired of it after a while, but don't let that deter you from checking this place out. 

The design was the best aspect. Beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge. High tech features. Interactive displays. It really couldn't get much better. My fav was the room towards the end dedicated to the building of Disney Land. The miniature model of the Park was AWESOME!!! I couldn't take my eyes off of it. I'd go just to see that room. And yet you get soo much more.

I highly recommend if you have at least a half day to dedicate to this. It's just great.
author: Krista S.

description:
I love all things Disney!  I've grown up with the movies, and have visited Disneyland during an insane amount of family vacations growing up and presently as an adult.  

So naturally, I've always wondered about the background, the  r e a l  background of Walt Disney, this mangnificant person who helped to contribute to so many great memories for me as a child.  This museum is a true testimony of proof that if you have a love and passion for your interests can truly reach your dreams in life.  

I had the opportunity to visit to Walt Disney Family Museum with my good friend Johnny W. this past Valentine's Day since we both share a huge love for all things Disney. 

Upon entering the museum in the Presidio, you are first visually stimulated by the abundance of various awards and recognitions that Disney has earned over the years including the actual Oscar's that the Walt Disney company has won.  

This museum is not a  museum for kids looking for the colorful Disney characters and waiting in line to get their autograph and pictures taken. But it is instead a "Story" of Walt's backgroud and life as a small town farm boy to being one of the world's most influencial characters himself, in conquering the entertainment and travel world.  Afterall, Walt Disney was first and foremost, a Storyteller.   

The museum is chronologically laid out starting with the humble beginnings of his family prior to their immigration to America, and concludes perfectly with Walts final projects in the making, and a tribute to his life with various newspaper articles, Telegrams of fans who express their sympathy, and cartoon drawings depicting the pain and loss that the world has encountered with his death.  I found this exhibit of the museum to be the most touching.  

We all know of his movies and his parks throughout the world, so there's no need for further explaination here.  But to me, it was visiting this museum that put a deeper meaning to the entire Disney empire that has contributed so much Happiness to my life over the years.

P.S. - Pictures are not allowed anywhere in the museum, as the staff scope you out like starving hawks.   But despite this sour note, my love for all things Disney continues to grow.
author: Cass J.

description:
We went to The Walt Disney Family Museum on Sun 2/21/10 because we had an afternoon to kill & it was rainy.

It's not very far from the Golden Gate Bridge in the Presidio.

FREE parking in the parking lot right across from the museum.

The museum is huge inside- 10 Galleries, budget at least 2-4hrs to see everything.  Noticed the Cafe first, then the two ticket takers.  It's $20pp for adult.  NO AAA discount - I asked.  Senior citizen is 65yrs old & $15.   No photography, no food & drink, allowed in the galleries.

Begin by looking at all kinds of awards.  Neat was the Academy Award w/ 7 mini Oscars next to a regular size Oscar for Snow White & The Seven Dwarfs.  Then give the person your ticket to go in to the galleries on the 1st Fl.

Lots of  stuff about Walt Disney's parents, his wife, 2 daughters, grandkids.  Pictures & videos.  Lots of videos about his life early years: moving to Chicago, Kansas City.  Laugh-O-Grams - his 1st animation studio, went bankrupt, then moved to Hollywood.

Gotta take an elevator to 2nd Fl.  Lots of stuff about Mickey Mouse, Snow White & the Seven Dwarfs, Bambi, Pinocchio, Fantasia, Multiplane Camera, The trip South of the border, Post war movies, Disneyland.  Cool model of Disneyland w/ some moving parts.

Museum store: many cute items.  Postcards 75c, Mickey Mouse Cup $11; magnet $6.50, Pin $6.50-$11.50, charm bracelet $13, butterfly necklace $70, etc.

Cafe: drinks $1.50-$3.25, soup $3.25-$4.5, sandwiches $6.50-$7.50

Bathrooms: Lower Level separate bathrooms & 2nd Fl had 2 unisex/handicap ones.
author: Ann L.

description:
This is hand's down, one of the BEST museums in San Francisco. I am a huge history buff and loved learning about the man behind the company. There is so much to look at - from the first drawings of Mickey Mouse to family pictures and possessions to a mini model of Disneyland.

I watched all of Disney's films and shorts as a kid and this made me super nostalgic as well. Imagine learning about Steamboat Willie, Snow White and Fantasia all at once. 

The museum is surprisingly large, but laid out well, and takes you from beginning to end of Disney's life. It took us about 2 hours to walk through.
author: Sara N.

description:
museum-great museum and very detailed history of walt disney's life and how the animation was done. the special snow white exhibition was great as well. got lots of work and video references to see.
cafe-nice coffee and i enjoyed their pumpkin cheesecake :)
gift shop-got variety of things to buy, even products from tokyo disney too!
author: Ru C.

description:
Three things about this gem:
1. Well design exhibition
2. Inspirational story of Walt Disney
3. A beautiful view of a certain SF landmark

Make sure you have 2 to 3 hrs to walk through the entire museum. 
I enjoyed every single minute while I was in there.
author: Maggie Z.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect before I visited, but I can now say that if you are any kind of a Disney fan this is a must see! The history, photos, videos and memorabilia are put together in such an interesting way that you are drawn in immediately. We took our two teenagers and they were never bored, which is the true sign of a good museum!

Parking was ample and easy to find behind the museum (even on a weekend). There is so much to see that I'd recommend visiting half the museum, then taking a break before continuing. When we entered and they said it would take a good 2-3 hours I thought they were joking, but you will be there for at least that long. There is a small (but pricey) cafe in the museum, and another a short walk away (which is closed on the weekends). The views from outside the museum are beautiful, and there is a glass wall about 2 stories up inside with amazing views of the bridge so be sure to bring your camera. The brochures say "no cameras allowed," but we were told they are allowing them as long as you don't use your flash. The gift shop has a lot of interesting things that you won't find at a traditional Disney store or in the parks.

Like I mentioned before, if you enjoy Disney cartoons/films/parks you won't be disappointed with your visit here. In fact, I would strongly consider going again because there is so much to see.
author: Monica D.

description: This museum is a must see for Disney fans! Not only did I learn a ton about the Disney family themselves, but I learned the hardship and background of the Disney lifestyle that I've grown to love and adore so much. It will make you appreciate and envy the mind that Walt Disney had and show you the growth and potential the Disney company has. I was amazed by the different rooms and just how much rich history was brought to this place. My boyfriend and I randomly bought a groupon for two for one tickets to this place and thought what the heck? We weren't let down, my favorite part of the whole museum was the room dedicated to the makings of Disneyland and their small mini model of the park. They have a cafe located below the museum if you need to get a quick bite to eat and a gift shop with old and new Disney character gifts of your choice. I would say it takes about 2-3 hours to get through everything, and once you're done here you have the beautiful area around the museum to explore! Loved my visit here :)
author: Jayme N.

description: I enjoyed the visit in this museum. It is so informative and interactive. You won't get bored visiting this place. Staff are very friendly and accomodating.
author: Gilda T.

description: Absolutely wonderful. If you are a fan,  This is a must see and do. You gain a much higher appreciation for the amusement park, the animation, and Disney himself.
author: Georgina R.

description: Job well done from an ex CM! Remember this is a museum on Walt's extraordinary accomplishments and not Disney as a company. Super location with gorgeous views as well. After your done here, go check out the officers quarters just up the hill. SF's first structure!
author: Bruce N.

description: Forgot how awful pinnochio movie was. Our seven year old needed to leave after about a half hour in and the two adults kept giving each other the "that's just not right" look!!
author: Sue K.

description:
What a great museum!  It really does take 2-3 hours to go through it all.  

The museum starts with Walt Disney's family history and eventually takes us to how Mickey Mouse all began.   It's fun to see how it all started and how much work goes into the creation of the animation.  The museum showcases early drawings, the equipment used, clips of cartoons and movies, and a really awesome detailed model of Walt's vision of Disneyland.

I don't think you have to be a Disney fanatic to enjoy this museum.  Go check it out!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I'll be honest -- I was super excited to visit The Walt Disney Family Museum, because I am a BIG fan of all things Disney.  Sadly, it was not as awesome as I had hoped.  

That being said, there were some VERY cool moments in the exhibit.  For starters, seeing every award Walt Disney won (Emmys, Oscars, Grammys, Golden Globes, etc....) was very cool.  I also enjoyed seeing some of the original Mickey sketches and storyboards for Snow White.

I also really enjoyed the overall layout of the exhibit.  It's very 'hip' and high tech and flows seamlessly.  Big A+ on layout.

However, this is a museum that focuses on Disney's LIFE, not Disney's CAREER.  If you're looking for lots of unique Disney (Studios) artifacts, check out the special exhibit at the Ronald Reagan Library instead.  Or visit the Disney Studios Archives if you can.  

Is it a nice museum?  Yes.  

Is it worth going through once?  Sure.  

Are there some cool, 'exclusive' things you won't see anywhere else?  Uh-huh.

Something cool to do if you have an extra hour or two and you are in the area?  Sure.  

Will I be back?  Probably not.
author: Kyle O.

description: This is a great place to go to with your family. If you love Disney this is the perfect place for you. My daughter loves Art and Disney so this was a great opprtunity for her to see all the great art work of Disney. I never really knew about his life and how he got started. He definitely change the world. Who doesn't love Disney? You will surely enjoy your day here if you plan to visit. Museum is clean. My most favorite is the very last room where in you'll get to see the miniature Disneyland. You even have the view of the Golden Gate Bridge and five minutes from the museum  is the Palace of Fine Arts. I surely recommend this place to everyone. If you have AAA you'll get ten percent discount.
author: Arlene S.

description:
I'll preface this by saying I'm not a fan of Disney. I grew up in Orange County, where Disney is a big part of the area, and eventually got burnt out on anything Disney. I wasn't expecting much from this place and was a bit turned off by the $20 admission price ($15 for students). Man was I surprised.  It is beautifully put together with a extensive amount of items on display. They mix visual, audio, and pieces wonderfully. We only had an hour and a half and figured it would be enough time. We had casually browsed about half of the museum before realizing we had already been there for an hour. I want to go back and really explore each part of it, giving myself plenty of time. 

If it wasn't so expensive it would be a 5 star review.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Very cool museum that goes through the life of Walt Disney, with a lot of artifacts from his early work. You'll get to learn the entire history of Disney up to Walt Disney's death. The earliest known sketches of Mickey Mouse can be found on display here. You'll get to see the evolution of the company as it goes through its humble beginnings through the major strike, the WWII era, the beginning of Disneyland, and so on. Lots of interesting information. The flow of the museum is great as well - you're led in one complete direction without having to go back and forth.

Also, at the time of our attendance, we were able to check out the Snow White special exhibit, where they displayed a lot of the sketches and other artwork from production of the movie.

The only thing about this place is that there's no photography allowed. Understandable for a place like this.

Very neat place and lots of neat artifacts from the early Disney years. If you're a Disney fan, this is a must see.
author: Francis F.

description:
This museum is world class, just like Disneyland itself.  of course, there aren't rides here but you do get the context and history behind Disneyland and also all the animated Disney films and cartoons.  The museum has displayed everything in a wonderful and thoughtful way and also added interactive elements to make learning fun.  It's great for kids and adults alike, especially history buffs and those who are interested in animation or all things Disney.  I liked how the videos were framed in lovely picture frames so it seemed like they were pictures but there was movement and speech.  I also liked the spectacular view of the Golden Gate bridge (more on that later) as well as the model of Disneyland with moving parts.  The wall of Oscars and all the awards that Disney amassed was pretty incredible too!  The museum also shared some of Walt's failures such as his first picture company going bankrupt so I liked that even though he had failures, he was able to pick himself up and stay true to his vision.  My favorite part though was the special exhibit featuring Mary Blair's artwork.  Mary Blair was the artist behind Alice in the Wonderland, Peter Pan, Cinderella, and It's a Small World.  She also illustrated many little Golden books.  It was great to see all her work in one place and it would be very inspiring to a budding young artist.  There was even a sketch book where kids drew pictures of what they enjoyed in the exhibit - I was amazed at the talent!  this special exhibit is in a separate building but easy to get to if you follow the decals on the sidewalk.

I think we spent 3 to 4 hours here - and towards the end it was information overload for me.  I would probably recommend coming on two separate occassions so you can soak everything in.  The unexpected bonus was the $20 million view of the Golden Gate bridge through the wall that was made entirely of glass to afford a complete view of the bridge.  Wow!  I grew up in SF but the bridge just takes my breath away and I can take a ton of pictures of it and still not get bored!

Entrance fee is $20 for adult, and $15 for students and seniors.  Special exhibit is an additional $5.  It's pricey but definitely worth it.  Unlike some other local museum which has a fabulous location but not enough content to fill it's space (and I won't name the museum), this place has both a great location and a wonderful exhibit with substance.  It's a true local gem. i took a ton of pictures - pictures are allowed BUT NO FLASH!!!  Also, the museum staffers are very nice, friendly and polite - I think it must be part of the Disney creed, and made the visit even more enjoyable.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Disney was like crack for me when I was a kid. Couldn't get enough of it, was the family afficianado when it came to knowing all the insider information about Disneyland Park, followed the early history word by word in books and memorized the lyrics to every song up through Beauty and the Beast.

Oh, but wait, this isn't about my obsession with Disney. This is about the Walt Disney Family Museum and how awesome it is to finally have the inside glimpse to the area of which there hasn't been much public knowledge: Walt, his family and how innovative, intelligent and determined he was to succeed in the risky business of animation. I will admit that it starts off a little dry, being centered in the early 1900s and moving up through his birth, which is a bit harder for the youth to really relate to. But it weaves a story, much like Walt believed in doing when he was creating films, and had me hooked by the second room. Once you were able to see his early drawings and publications, well, the crack phase starts to kick in. 

This is definitely a place to take anyone and everyone touched by Disney, who will be have the patience to read a lot and really spend time with the exhibits. Geek kids and adults of all ages....just not your sugar high, ADHD kid. Oh, and its a bit pricey, which is surprising since Disney makes billions a year. Guess it's the same business thought processing as movie biz to make money.
author: Alita M.

description: I had a good time coming here but I found myself kind of walking through rather quickly. I stopped and looked at most things but mostly just browsed a lot and watched the videos. Very educational for sure and very beautiful. I loved the first videos of the museum, of his life growing up, and I loved the Mickey Mouse room. Even if you do just browse through the museum like I did you still learn a lot. I couldn't believe when we got to the final part of the museum when they talked about his death and his legacy a woman behind us actually asked her boyfriend why there was a wall of sad depressing paintings. We really couldn't help but walk out of there laughing.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Went for the first time, very impressed with the layout and exhibits, not to mention the views of the Golden Gate bridge. Went to the 1:30 screening of Dumbo, cool to see on the big screen.
author: Chuck M.

description: How can you not give Disney five stars! Uuuhhhh mazZZZING!!! Located in the beautiful presidio of San Francisco, it gives an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. They do let you in for free with Military Id! My friends and I went on a Friday afternoon & it was pretty busy. Like other reviews, there is a lot of reading! They do offer some interactive and listening sections but you will find yourself reading thru most of it. This museum is dedicated to Walt & his family and how Disneyland come to but it is still awesome. So many things to look at, read it's almost overwhelming. My friends and I spent a solid two hours inside and loved every second of it. They have an awesome miniature display of Disneyland that I can look at for hours. Towards the end it's rather sad during Walt's death, but of course it feels like magic throughout. We went inside the gift shop but didn't buy anything, the prices are pretty expensive. Overall it was an awesome experience and I would come back if I get the chance. Best $20 I ever spent!
author: Drea O.

description:
I didn't really know what to expect since the website wasn't fully functional before I went to visit.  In a nutshell, its about the life and history of Mr. Walt Disney himself.  You basically get a glimpse of Walt's life from the start to the end.  This isn't a place I'd bring the kiddies since its more history than anything else.  The kiddies would probably start getting restless.  I saw a teenager who was bored to death, but her mom was having a great time!

There is a really cool mini version of Disneyland, but unfortunately pictures aren't allowed inside.  There were employees everywhere, so I wasn't going to risk getting yelled at.  The only spot you can take pictures is after you exit gallery 8.  You get a gorgeous view of the Presidio and the Golden Gate Bridge.

Tickets are $20 and can be purchased in advance online.  There is a parking lot right across the street, and its free!
author: Patra I.

description:
Did not know what to expect, wow we spent the whole day here. Not a real good place for kids though. Allot of reading! Well worth it!
The life of Walt Disney in this museum reads like a book from start to end including the screen with rolling well deserved credits at the end.
author: Frank C.

description: I didn't exactly get to check out the main exhibit of the museum during my visit. I checked out the special exhibit -  Mary Blair since it was going to close soon. That alone took about 30 minutes or so. Nonetheless it was still interesting to look at the all artwork that Mary Blair did for some of the Disney movies. I would definitely make another trip back here to check out the main exhibit!
author: Cathy T.

description: A beautifully curated museum. I went specifically to see the Mary Blair exhibit and it did not disappoint. We even got to watch Peter Pan in their awesome movie theater after we checked out the history of Walt Disney himself. Whether you're a resident of San Francisco or visiting from out of town, this museum is worth your while.
author: Katie S.

description:
We visited in January but never wrote a review. 
We had a wonderful day and visit. I would recommend, but if you want to see all exhibits plan on staying the full day. A lot of reading and watching movie clips, but all worth it.
author: Mary F.

description:
Such a wonderful museum! It's really a unique view into the life and wonders of Walt Disney. 

This museum's design is like walking through a story book, it's very well thought out and organized. I've been here twice, one with my company after a conference to unwind, and then again with my boyfriend. 

Be prepared to spend  a few hours walking through. There's SO MUCH to see! In all honesty, I can go back and be amused all over again. It's great to have such an awesome place to visit in SF.
author: Marisela R.

description:
Fantastic, especially if you are a fan of Walt Disney! Broad museum with a lot of information, interesting exhibits, and a knowledgeable/friendly staff.

I drove up to San Francisco from L.A. just for this museum and it was well worth the trip. I will definitely return soon!
author: Julia S.

description:
This is a wonderful museum. An amazing collection of the works and life of Walt Disney. We also enjoyed the Mary Blair special exhibition as well. This was held in the building directly behind the main one. Very educational and highly entertaining.

The staff was friendly, the interiors and displays were modern. The gift shop (for which all museums should be judged) was excellent. Outside, there was plentiful (paid) parking and a lovely view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Highly recommended for families, lovers of art, and fans of Disney films and Disneyland.

Tip: Don't forget to ask for their AAA discount rate.
author: Glenn S.

description:
This place is amazing.  If you are a fan of the old Disney movies, you will love this place.    

It is located in the middle of the Presidio.  Its in a amzaing location with the bay nearby and isolated from the city.  Its in a old brick building.   And when you walk in you entered the life and imagination of Walt Disney. 

Wow is all I have to say, its a wonderful museum.   First you enter into the early life of Walt, a humble life, to a cartoonist, and then to the development of Walt Disney company.  There is lots of pictures, short videos,of his life and of his work.  There is a lot to see and absorb.  You view the characters, story development, and then to the development of Disneyland.  I spent about three hours in this place and was absorbed by story of Walt Disney.
author: Richard G.

description: You could literally spend hours and hours inside of this museum, especially if you are a Disney fan.  We ended up buying the membership but if you buy the day pass it is reasonably priced at $20 per adult.  There is so much to see and a lot to learn about Walt, the man, even before he became famous.  The bathrooms are super clean and make sure that you visit the gift shop for some cool souvies on the way out.  Some are overly priced but some are fairly reasonable and if you get the membership you get 10% off.  If you go on a Sunday there is a picnic in the park event right across the street with food trucks and vendors offering a large variety of items.  The feel of the location is worth the drive to the Presidio.  Parking is on the street and reasonably priced.  If you can make a day of it I would recommend it because it was relaxing and beautiful.
author: Karen R.

description:
This is definitely a historical museum. You learn about the history of Walt Disney and what his company was when he originally started it. There are about 14 rooms and I would plan a good two to three hours to be able to read/watch everything. DON'T COME AFTER 4PM IF YOU CAN HELP IT!!!! The museum closes at six and the employees will start to rush you at like 5:15. If you want a pleasant and enjoyable experience I would plan to get there either when it opens at 10 or in the middle of the day or early afternoon. 

They show movies, sometimes there is one at 11 then the others are at 1:30 and 4pm. I think you can look up on their website what movies are playing but it is included in your ticket price so thats a nice bonus if you want to see a Disney Classic. 

I think that this museum is more for adults but on the weekends they have more family/kid friendly activities like open studio where you can do an art project (like animation) and kids are more than welcome to those classes. Otherwise I think your kid may get bored if they are under the age of 12. 

Because the museum is located in the presidio it took me awhile to find the place. There are TWO Montgomery Streets in San Francisco and that is super confusing, so when you put the address into your gps, make sure you go to the Presidio and not downtown! You have to pay for parking, but I think it is because of the museum being on government property and they don't really get a say in it. It is something like $1 per hour or $7 for all day. I would say to just get the $7 parking because that is pretty darn cheap for the city and then you don't have to keep running outside to fill the meter. 

Some of the highlights for me were the oscars in the lobby, the silly symphony room, the war propaganda (super interesting!), and then this huge model of disneyland! I am a huge Disneyland fan, so this was really neat! You are allowed to take pictures which was awesome but they tell you no flash and when you are at the disneyland model they get a little upset if you put your camera over the glass to take a picture (I was able to snag a couple before getting caught!). 

Overall, I think this a fantastic museum! I just got a student membership and it works great for me because I like being able to take a friend with me to the museum to show them some of the great things about Walt. They have a number of membership levels, mine is the basic so I get myself and one guest in. It's a great deal too because it gets you into whatever the special exhibition is! Most other museum memberships I have I still have to pay for the special exhibit, so that is a major plus. I know they have a membership where you can get three people in or something like that, but it was just out of my price range! It is worth it, especially if you plan on coming more often than not. Also, they let you apply your tickets to the membership, so say you want to check out the museum before getting a membership they will let you use those tickets for a membership, so that was a bonus for me! 

I would definitely schedule time if you are ever in San Francisco to see this place!
author: A.J. C.

description:
Once upon a time, in a far away land, a baby named Walt was born. 

Little did the world know, he was going to be one of the world's most influential and innovative man. 

Even though the name Disney has become synonymous with princesses, family films and of course, Disneyland, leave your stereotypical thoughts of Disney at home.  For this newly constructed Walt Disney Family Museum pays homage to Walt Disney's life.  He was only 65 years old when he passed, but no other man has accomplished what he had.  Although it looks unassuming from the outside, this is a 2 story museum which has 10 galleries depicting his family history and his life here on earth.   So, you think that's boring and it seems to cater more to history buffs, but I give credit when credit is due.  There is no other museum like this.  It's highlighted with 21st century touches:  there are HD TVs displaying filmed artifacts or narrating his work.  This makes for an easier learning experience if you're not into reading all those information plaques.  There are interactive audio handsets at some stations and touch screen monitors which allow users to browse through antique documents.  

The galleries are extremely detailed.  You'll find cherished documents such as original drawings of Mickey Mouse, a wall (on the 2nd floor) with Steam Boat Willie's frame by frame stills and cameras used by Walt Disney in his various productions are randomly placed everywhere.  For those interested in animation and special effects, there is a Schultheis Notebook (the notebook of the special effects man of "Fantasia")  under glass but there is an interactive display for that.  

Needless to say, this museum caters more to the adult crowd or children 10 and up.  There are stretches where it's boring, but I loved Gallery 9 which has the miniature scale version of Disneyland.  The model is lovely to look at with its lights and moving parts.  It just brings back memories of when I went to Disneyland. Also, in this gallery, younger patrons will probably appreciate the model trains on display.

I didn't partake of the food in the cafe, though the prices are expensive for the small portions.  You've got the usual salads and sammies, cookies and other pastries.  Mini-cupcakes are $2.50 each. 

Some people mentioned that there are not enough restrooms on the second floor, they're right, so go to the restrooms at the ground floor (where the theater is,yes you can buy tickets for the movie showings here) which has more stalls.  

I was lucky enough to snag preview passes, but don't fret, the museum opens this Thursday, Oct. 1.  Tickets are $20 and it's timed entry, so buy your tickets in advance.  There are plenty of parking available in this area and take note that on the ticket stub it says that strollers are not allowed in the museum. The no photography rule was also enforced and they watched us like hawks. For more info, visit www.waltdisney.org

If you visit this museum, be sure to heed my advice and you'll live happily ever after.
author: Janice C.

description:
Locals, add to your list of SF museums to visit! And allow *at least* three hours. We spent an hour and a half on the gorgeous Mary Blair and Marc Davis special exhibits, and had only a hour and a half left to visit the main exhibit, where we could have used another hour (and we also barely got to look at the Oscars in the entrance hall). 

The special exhibits are beautiful with mostly drawings and paintings, a few cartoon clips, and some tablets that enable you to flip through text from original journals displayed nearby.

The main exhibit is a rich and overwhelming mix of clips, quotes, audio, telegrams, photos, merchandise, etc. that takes you on a journey of Walt Disney's life. The exhibits included difficulties and mistakes as well as triumphs. By the end, while I did not know much about Walt Disney before going to the museum, I was so emotionally invested that I could not help choking up while reading the sympathy messages about his death. 

The journey also reflects the American story of this time period, and the reminders at the beginning of each room about other major events in film history and American history helped highlight these links. I particularly appreciated learning about the evolution of animation, with clips from other early 20th century animators.
author: Emily S.

description: I love Disneyland but this museum was just ok for me.  I am glad I came here on Groupon deals instead of paying the regular price admission.  This museum is definitely more catered towards adults so if you have little ones I will not suggest you bring them here.  The only interesting thing for kids to do here is the art studio they have downstairs which lets the kids paint any Disney characters they want.  Both of my kids had a really good time doing the art, but other than that I can tell they weren't that interested.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
If you're visiting San Francisco, check out this reasonably priced tour. For more details, see Evenbrite link: Walt Disney Family Museum (Shuttle Tour and Admission)

http://brownbagwdfm.even... 

Tickets include Shuttle ride from the Hyatt Regency, 5 Embarcadero Center (Drumm St.) Adults $25, Children $19. Duration: 9:30 am - 3 pm, Return to Hyatt around 4 pm.

Summertime fun and you'll appreciate Americana history of a man who made Mickey Mouse so loved.

Keywords: Brown Bag, Presidio, Shuttle, Tour, Walt Disney Family Museum

Also check for reasonably priced Eventbrite Presidio Tour: 

http://presidiobrownbagtour.eventbrite.com/
author: Josie W.

description:
There is Disney magic at this museum.  My wife and I love this place and as Disney fans it was wonderful to learn and appreciate more about Walt.  
This place is a must see for Disney followers.  There are different special events scheduled.  We saw a 1965 Wonderful World of Color TV show about the tenth anniversary of Disneyland.  Before going check the Museum website for themes and show times. Two hours is the very minimum for a visit.  The cafe has well made prepared sandwiches and salads.
author: Arthur N.

description:
