Should be more correctly named "The Walt Disney Biographic Museum".  This is a great place, but is not good for families with kids under 15 years old. 

Superb displays, informational film clips and historic artifacts of Walt Disney.  Sort of a walk through "Behind the Music"

WELL WORTH $20 Admission.  Also, leave your cameras in the car, no photography allowed.
author: v v.

description:
I didn't even realize this museum was in SF but glad I went. Located in a picturesque spot in the Presidio with great views of the Golden Gate near the end of the tour. 

Note this museum is about the life of Walt Disney the person, which of course covers early Disney films, Mickey Mouse and Disneyland. It's a self guided tour ... Best to lay expectations beforehand especially if you planned to bring kids (not recommended). On the other hand, for those interested in history and behind the scenes and filmmaking techniques, it's a fascinating experience.
author: F. P.

description: Had an amazing, nostalgic little day trip! It felt really great paying a visit down memory lane. The exhibit layout is very nicely organized following the fantastical life of Walt Disney, and by the wrap-up (though bittersweet with remnants of slight sadness) one feels- well, at least I felt, so grateful to have lived out a childhood in which the great Disney played part!!
author: Lauren Y.

description: As a long time Disney Fan, this has been on our bucket list. First we went to the Snow White special exhibit and were a bit disappointed as it just seems there should be more.  However, we were happily impressed with the magnitude of what is in the actual museum.  They recently started allowing photos and I could not get enough! It was well put together, focused on all points of his life, and covered the good and the bad. There were a lot of quotes from Walt or his family that told the story, a very nice touch! We went on a Saturday so parking was free on the street and it took us about 4 hours to fully experience everything and that included a lunch at the tiny cafe.
author: Jeanne C.

description: very educational... as a Disney fan, it was a must do! it's A LOT of reading... i probably need to go back since i just couldn't read through everything in the given time... but i definitely learned A LOT about Disney... I'm a bigger fan now!
author: Gloria L.

description:
When you look at the Walt Disney Family Museum from the outside, it seems like a very unassuming brick building surrounded by the beautifully iconic Golden Gate Bridge and Palace of Fine Arts.  No fireworks, character greetings, rides, or theme music.  However, stepping into the exhibit is a whole new world (haha, see what I did there? ^_^)  In true Disney fashion, this museum impresses with its scrupulous attention to detail... from the architectural path that leads you through the deceptively small building, to the devices you use to hear sound bites, to the strategic placement and design of seating.  At $20 for an adult ticket ($17 with a discount, and as low as $10 on Groupon), you can immerse yourself in the life of Walt Disney, the man.  I spent about 3 hours there, but you could probably spend more.  To get the full story of his life, a lot of reading is involved, but it is balanced with realia, videos, sound files, and a few interactive displays.  Because of its more informative nature, I imagine younger kids would get bored very quickly, so consider carefully before shelling out that $12 for the youth rate (6-17 years).  

Side note: go on a holiday to park for free! I went on President's Day and was pleasantly surprised when I saved on parking costs.
author: Amy T.

description:
This is a must see museum!  I was amazed it was so big and soon realized that I would be spending several hours here as I wound my way through the entire exhibit.  My three hours here were truly time well spent! The museum is spotless, well organized and honors an individual whose creativity, talent and vision earned him a place in American culture and throughout the entire world.  I learned so much about Walt and his family that I never would've known had I not learned it here.  Of course, I also learned a bit about animation, film, story writing, editing, sound, color, etc...  and how Walt was ahead of his time in implementing all of this into what would one day become Walt Disney Productions.  

The museum lays out Walt's life in chronological order and one can truly see him not only as a creative man with a futuristic vision, but also as a family man and friend to all those who knew him. The vast array of personal letters, photographs, and voice recordings throughout the exhibit greatly impact his life story and ultimate success.  He never forgot those who helped and encouraged him along the way.  He also dealt with failures yet persevered because he believed in himself and his futuristic vision.

Although his life ended abruptly at age 65, he's allowed countless people around the world to enjoy his many creations through his numerous films and Disney amusements parks, and will continue to do so with future generations.

A must see in the museum is the display of Academy Awards (Oscars) that he received for his many films.  In fact, I learned that he received more Academy Awards than anyone else in history!
author: Rob L.

description:
I bought two tickets from Google Offers and since the deal was about to expire in a month, I decided to have a family outing. We had lunch in Redwood City so we headed on the 101 to go to San Francisco.

The place is near Crissy Fields so the drive to the museum had beautiful views on a Sunday afternoon. Thankfully it wasn't too overcast.

Adult tickets are $20 so I basically paid half with the Google offer. Kids under 6 are free and you get a discount if you're a student. They tell you that there is no photography or video recording in the galleries so I took a picture in the lobby and the outside of the museum.

It's a self-guided tour between two floors of galleries of memorabilia of Walt Disney from his birth up to his death. It was fun seeing all the excerpts of the cartoons I saw as a kid. There were so many things to read about his life, timeline of events and recordings at every station. It's a fantastic history of the creator of Disneyland and Mickey Mouse. It was neat to see a replica of Disneyland on display.

My husband and I enjoyed our time there. I think we arrived there about after 3pm and stayed till almost closing time (6pm). It's amazing what they have at the museum that you can spend your day there.

There's also a small gift shop and a concession stand. I bought two books for our son to read at bedtime when he's a bit older, a packet of chocolates for a coworker and a magnet, which is pricey since I spent about $60. 

Outside of the museum, there is a black and white picture of Walt Disney with a bunch of Mickey Mouses and you can put your face to take a picture. 

If Google Offers didn't provide a deal to the museum, I wouldn't have known it was at San Francisco in the first place. If you haven't been and you love Disney, it's something to check out.
author: Jenn D.

description:
What an awesome memorial to Walt Disney!  I loved the fact that they honored the people who helped contribute to his success, and how all aspects of his career was covered, good and bad.  The coverage was very thorough, and well organized.

Some may say that the admission price of $20 is kind of high, but there are coupons on the city guide app, and students get $5 off ( always bring your college Id with you! )

The neighborhood was a little under construction, so the bashing sound of the black tarp across the street was a little annoying, but overall a very pleasant neighborhood.  If you plan good, you may catch some legends lecturing.  I was fortunate enough to catch a background animator from Pixar giving a lecture.  It was free with admission.  

I took a cab to the location, however I would recommend taking the bus.  It's dependable and runs all day.  It cost me $15 to get there, and $2 to get back to my hotel,  need I say more?  

Overall, I would strongly recommend this museum to anyone into motion arts, animation, illustrations, and all things Disney.
author: Shari P.

description:
PROS:
- There are many hands on pieces which made it fun.
- Train-themed elevator, where Walt talks to us. Pretty cool.
- Gallery 9 was fun, only gallery worth looking at for the children.
- Lovely gift shop. Prices aren't too pricey.
- You really get to learn the history of Walt himself.

CONS:
- No photography allowed except for gallery 7.
- Must arrive/enter to according time on ticket.
- Once the museum started getting good, there was a fire drill and we had to evacuate the museum with no accommodations. Going through the whole museum takes at least 2 hours or more, and this made it longer.
- Not enough tables and chairs for people to eat at the cafe, so my boyfriend and I ate outside on the porch where there were chairs and tables as well but it was still nice.


This is museum is usually interpreted as a family museum that parents can bring their children but the reason why it is called a family museum is because Walt's family created the museum in honor of him.
author: Jessica R.

description: We had no idea this was here, we stumbled on it on our way to the Golden Gate Bridge. A memorial to the awards and events of Walt Disney's life, the majority of the information is given during the guided tour for $20/adult. There is a lobby area with plenty to look at, and we just did that for a lack of time.
author: Mila G.

description:
This is a great place to visit for those Walt Disney Fans. Not a great museum for kids though. If you're going to visit, you should for sure take at least 4 hours to explore the place. We only saw 1/2 of what we wanted because we were going to be late for our dinner reservations.

If you do go and you have limited time, skip most of the beginning and go towards the end of the exhibit for a great visual display of Walt's work. There's a great model of Walt's idea of Disneyland. It's definitely a must see! Don't forget to take a picture with the famous Oscar and the 7 little dwarf Oscars in the front entrance of the museum!

Definitely going back soon.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Disney and everything related to his empire occupies a weird place in my mind.  While growing up, as a russian six year old, ive heard my parents talk about far a away place called america, which to me was about as real and tangible as anything i've heard in a fairy tale or read in a childrens book. Until, that is, i watched my first disney cartoons featuring mickey mouse, and other characters, those must have been classics from the 30s or 40s but to a 6 year old me they were new, different and exciting, and finally gave a tangible image to this place i've heard my parents talk about. So until about 10 years of age i was pretty fascinated with the idea of disney, and disney themed parks, and cartoons that company produced. Then i got over it. Then i came to the US, and found it totally weird that adults get totally excited about trips to Disney land.

Fast forward to the WWWDD YEE.  Not really caring too much about the company i arrived to the museum and went thru the exhibits, which are by the way expertly put together in an awesome setting.  The volunteers are friendly and pretty knowledgeable and overall the museum is really cool, even if you're not a disney fan.  My favorite part of the place was the first 3 galleries that detail Disney's early life and exploits.  While pretty light on the controversial topics the exhibits do acknowledge some of them - such as for example Disney's father's socialist leanings. All in all the museum is pretty cool.
author: Oleg H.

description:
One day last year while watching eye on the bay they had a quick segment on the Disney Museum opening up soon in San Fransisco. Being a huge Disney fan I knew I had to attend quickly. 

The next day I mentioned it to my boyfriend and off we went to San Fran. The Museum is located off the embarcadero so it may get confused with another location downtown sf that has the same address only a different zip code. So if you're heading here make sure your zip code is correct. 

One we arrived we were greeted at the front desk by a very friendly girl. We showed her our SJSU student Id's and received our student discount which I think was a couple of bucks off. Once we received our tickets I was eager to enter! Let me tell you, they spent years making the museum and the work showed! I was amazed on the detail.Disney never fails to amaze me with their art and creativity. They definitely brought it with the decor, history, and props. 

I do not want to go into to much detail as this museum is a hidden gem since not too many people I've come across are aware its there. I will leave the rest to your imagination and try out this great destination. 

*Accept credit cards.
author: Evangelina B.

description:
I looked at the info based on review and it states:
Good for Kids : No 

That is soooo true. There is so much reading, not a lot of interaction with the museum and its more on history.

I enjoyed myself at the museum and I can see why it would take some people 2-3 hours to run through it. It took my girlfriend and I 1 hour to go through the whole thing because we were too lazy to read everything. Well... She was too lazy, I actually wanted to read some of it.

No photos are allowed passed the start of the museum. My favorite part was the scale model of Disneyland in the eyes of Walt himself and the very ending where theres a room full of screens. Amazing.

I would recommend this museum to anyone who is a Disney fan and remembers the OLD Disney. Come here to reminiscence.
author: James N.

description:
Love this hidden gem at the Presidio!  I would recommend it in general but especially if you are looking for inspiration. Pretty incredible to look at where Walt came from and what he created. It is easy to imagine if you don't know his story that it all happened easily but really get to understand just what a visionary he was and how hard he worked to create what he did.  

Plan 2-3 hours for this place even though it is not that big.  There is a lot packed in there.
author: Laura P.

description: This place was really neat.  Kinda like being at Disneyland but no roller coasters you can ride or costumed characters.  Inspiring to learn the story of Walt.
author: Mark M.

description: I only set aside two hours to visit this place and it wasn't enough time. I went pretty much right when it opened and was able to find parking right in front. If you're not familiar, the area is super nice. In a park, right near the water. And on the day I went they were having an Off the Grid event with picnicking and food trucks. It's a pretty happening place. The museum itself is in this pretty and modern looking mansion also. I had brought a groupon for admission. It's just for the regular museum and not the special exhibits. I didn't even see what the special exhibit was or where so I didn't feel too bad for missing it. Oh and they also show Disney movies here (included with your ticket) though I didn't see where the theater was. It was Lady and Tramp the day I went but unfortunately it was playing in the afternoon. So usually I'm not a museum person. I like museums but they don't hold my interest for very long.  But being a Disney fanatic, I found myself stopping to read everything and poring over all the pictures and artifacts. I pretty much did this till the halfway point (second elevator) and I realized I had to leave in about half an hour. And I think the second half was even more interesting than the first half. Well maybe Disneyland's history, maybe not (spoiler alert?) Walt Disney's death. Lots of videos and audio clips and some interactive stuff as well. That miniature model of Disneyland was one of the coolest things in there. So the second half, I just read all the really big signs and glanced at the all the pictures. So I guess this means I'll need to make a second visit. Haha. Pictures are fine, just no flash. And like all Disney employees everywhere, everyone was super friendly and helpful. Not too kid friendly either as it's not super interactive.
author: Alison W.

description:
Amazing, amazing museum if you're a fan of Disney!  At first glance at the house-looking facade,  I thought it would be some cheap thrill kind of museum that I would be in and out of in an hour or so (that's what I put into the parking meter*); not so!    This museum is amazing for the fact that held my attention for that time period and I still wanted to stick around and see more.  I was intrigued with all the history that was presented. The subject matter, Walt Disney, being a corner stone of a lot of my childhood, kept me interested.  
The exhibits begin with a family history room because this place is named the "Walt Disney Family Museum" after all.  This was a bit dull to me, but you could start seeing the inklings of Walt's animation.  What captivated me were all of the shorts that they showed of iconic Disney films.  Some exhibits were even interactive.  A lot of exhibits had earpieces which resembled old telephones which you could place to your ears to hear the history of an exhibit in audio.  A lot of detail was put into this museum.  It truly is a hidden gem because I don't feel that if you were intent on coming here, most people wouldn't venture into this neighborhood.  
I especially loved seeing all the short films 
Prices range from free (children 5 and under) to $20 for general admission; $15 for students (w/ valid ID's) and seniors.  There was also an additional $5 fee if you combine it with your general admission fee to see the special exhibition, which is currently Tyrus Wong, best known for "Bambi".  It is $10, if you want to view just the exhibition.  
Also, there was a featured Disney movie of the time, and when I visited, it was "Mary Poppins".  Be aware though, you can't just show up and expect to get a seat.  You have to inform the ticket sellers that you wanted to view the movie and you are issued a ticket.  The two showings were at 1:30 and 4:00pm.

*As I mentioned, there were parking meters, if you're driving here.  It costs $1.25 per hour.  You can pay in increments of $1 or .25.  I don't know who enforces the parking out here, but just a heads up.  This tidbit will be reminded in paper form at the sales desk.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
This place is deceiving. Outside it is a cute, small house that calls itself a museum. But trust me, it will take you upwards of 4 hours to get through!

Each room is packed, really tightly packed, with information. Everything here is information. Each sound bite, each wall panel, has so much detail to be read. Each room also has some form of interactive feature. I wouldn't be surprised if it took someone an hour to get through each room if they read every sentence.

And it keeps going. It's a lot. I don't think its actually very child-friendly (toddler age, probably up to 10). There's a lot of detailed reading. Even the aspects of actual Disney animation are very historical and detailed. I think it's a really, really gorgeous & well made museum - even though I could not get through every bit of information, I appreciate their dedication to quality and information.

But really  - it will deceive you. You need half a day!
author: Allyson D.

description: Id rather go to Disney land. For the price i did not think it was worth it. I enjoyed learning about them coordinating the sounds to the film.
author: lesly l.

description:
Nicely Done!  Great place for adults who grew up watching Disney but not really fun for kids.  Don't be deceived by the plain brick building, inside is very modern and surprisingly big! There is a lot to see if you take the time to read through each exhibit.  You can easily spend 3-4 hours here.  

This not an amusement park or play area for kids.  If your kids are under 12 they will probably not enjoy it.
author: Ethan C.

description:
This was one of the best museum's I had ever been to. I would say this is more for the teenager and up. My 16 & 19 year old cousins enjoyed it as much as the 30-50 y/o in our group.

The $20 ticket was well spent, however with a AAA card it gave us an additional $5 off 4 people! There is a coupon in SF guidebooks too for $2 off each admission. Parking was very reasonable $1/hr and the lot was accessible.

It was all about Walt Disney and his rise to the brand. I was thoroughly impressed with the artifacts & memorabilia as well as the interactive displays everywhere. It was very well sought through, executed and had a wonderful flow to it all. 

This is going to be a "must visit" for everyone coming for a visit to the Bay area as well as family & friends who live here. 

It makes you want to come home and re-watch all his movies as well as take a trip to Disneyland.  

I've come out with a higher level of admiration for a man who I already thought was ahead of his time. It has forever changed how I will  look at another Disney film,, all for the better. 

Thank you Disney Family for sharing this with us.
author: Danie G.

description: This is a fun place to visit once. It is located in the presidio. It is something I recommend for ages 10 and up just because of the history. Please don't expect a Disneyland experience because you will be disappointed. It was interesting learning about the history of Walt Disney and his family.
author: Zakia R.

description: This is not Disney museum.  It is the museum about Walt Disney and his Family. The museum is nestled in the beautiful presidio neighborhood. Exhibition contains chronologies of life of Walt, with characters from yesteryear.  Also, toward the end, dioramas of Disneyland. Very extensive and detailed. Lots of reading materials.  We were there for 3 hours, but could have been easily more, if the museum was not closing for the day. Galleries are spacious and easy to maneuver.  Beautiful GGB view from one of the hall way window. Cafe space and offerings limited.  General Admission $20.  Special Exhibition may be extra, depending. NARMA member.
author: Naomi T.

description:
W.O.W.

There are no words to describe how amazing and comprehensive the Walt Disney Family Museum is. It is definitely a must-see for my fellow Disney-nerds, or anyone who's interested in animation, cinema, or American history.

Admission for the museum is $20-$25 for adults (depending on whether you decide to see the special exhibits), and I'd allot a good 2-3 hours to get through everything. Even the main lobby is a spectacle in itself, with displays of all of the awards Walt Disney won, a replica of the living room of the Disneys' apartment on Main Street in Disneyland, and paintings and portraits that hung in the Disneys' house. Once you leave the main lobby, expect to be immersed in room after room dedicated to the life and history of Walt Disney, the Disney family, and the Disney company, from the time even before Walt was born all the way up until Walt's death. The whole museum is extremely interactive with visual displays, audio recordings, and movie and music clips playing throughout, including a ride up to the 2nd floor in an elevator tricked out to look like an old fashioned train car complete with a train "conductor" (as a nod to Walt's fascination and interest in trains). To many, the highlight will be near the end with the miniature replica model of an embryonic Disneyland.

To be honest, I don't know how much children (say under 10) will enjoy this museum. There is very little on the movies that kids will be most familiar with, as the museum focuses mainly on the earliest Disney movies (Steamboat Willie, Snow White, Pinocchio, Fantasia, and Dumbo), and even then, approaches them more from the perspective of how it impacted the Disney company, and filmmaking and animation in general. There are some neat parts that go into how sound, music, and colour was added to the films and plenty of imagery from the movies to ooh and aah at, but I don't know how much a kid will appreciate listening to a sound clip of Walt speaking to his banker about financing Snow White. Plus, the museum is deceptively large, so props to any kid who can make it through the whole thing without getting tired!
author: Stephanie T.

description: Yes, yes and yes to the Walk Disney Family Museum.  So much information and interesting stuff to see; I don't feel like I even conquered a fraction of it on my first visit.  VERY friendly staff - how Disney of them!  The Disneyland room was outstanding, great interactive displays everywhere and they don't sugarcoat the weird stuff that went down around the foundation of this empire.  I wept at the end where they cover the death of Walt - something about all those pictures of crying Mickeys really got me.  And you get a bonus view of the bay from the top - quite outstanding.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Admission fee of $20 was a bit much, but there is a student discount. You can easily spend the whole day here, especially to milk the worth of the entrance fee, but we had some time constraints and finished the museum in about 2 hours. Also a tad out of the way from any nearby public transportation so definitely drive or taxi your way here.

I wasn't sure what to expect because the reviews were pretty vague, but I'm still glad I went. This museum focuses more on the life and influences of Walt Disney. It may be boring for the kids, as it's less hands-on and more about looking at old photos, reading history tidbits, and watching film clips that show the evolution of his characters. But as a huge Disney fan, it was enthralling, seeing how he poured his whole life into his vision and ultimately changing the world one film at a time.
author: Jess C.

description:
My cousin, friend, and I ended up going to the Walt Disney Museum on Monday after finding out that the DeYoung was closed on Mondays (and also a lot of the other museums in SF), and I'm glad we did because the Walt Disney Museum was great.

The museum is located in the Presidio which makes for the building, area, and views from within the building all gorgeous. Aside from the museum area, there is also a cafe (catered by Wolfgang Puck) and a store. The cafe is decent (and pricey) with salads, sandwiches, soup, chips, and coffee/drinks - we ended up having lunch here since we rushed to the museum before getting the chance to eat. The store is also pretty cool filled with Walt Disney Family related and some movie related gifts (definitely not stuff you'd find at the Disney Store).

The museum area is great - very clean, organized, and good looking exhibit displays. Like others mentioned, the first floor is slightly boring - it's all information about Walt's family history and childhood - great information, but I do remember thinking "hopefully the rest of it gets better."

The rest of the museum is great and I enjoyed it a lot. You'll see everything from the works of Walt before starting Disney and through the time of his death. The exhibits are very informational (lots of reading!) and I liked that every description was accompanied by some sort of visual. This came very useful when the museum referred to Disney films I had never seen or heard of - glad to have a visual/video reference. 

If you come here, you'll learn a lot about not only Disney, but also topics like animation techniques, color, etc. Be prepared though - I was definitely not mentally prepared for so much information (if you want to learn, you're going to need to do a lot of reading), and got pretty tired by the end. But nonetheless, great museum. Now I want to go and watch all the Disney classic cartoons!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Hit this up for the 2nd time in 2 years and I had just as much fun as the 1st!

Entering the Presidio is beautiful in itself with the sweeping green grass and historic buildings. The museum is nestled in between these communities and you already feel excited by the time you walk in.

The arrangement of the exhibits are logical and chronological and takes you from Walt's family up until his death. They go into extreme detail about his life and take you to places you didnt know existed in the life of Disney. It's fascinating to see what inspired him and what brought him to the point where he created such an amazing legacy.

The museum itself succeeds not only in wealth of information but also presentation. There is movement and sound at every turn as exhibits combine text, pictures, video, interactivity, sound, and unique presentations to really engage you and keep you moving through his life. You can tell incredible thought went into the design and it really does make the experience that much better.

I can say that this is the first museum that I actually saw EVERY SINGLE exhibit as you did not want to miss any part of this fascination journey. I guarantee if you have any interest in Disney or its parts you will not be disappointed by this museum!

It is definitely not for kids and I didn't see any the two times I went. The price is a little steep but for what you get you will believe it is worth it.
author: Joe C.

description: This is an ABSOLUTE MUST SEE for Disney fans! It not only illustrates Walts personal life before during and after disneyland, but also the birth of everything Disney, from life situations causing the creation of our beloved Mickey Mouse and even how his name came to be to the paint blending of the colors used in the movies how his cartoons and how he revolutionized cartoon making to be more life-like...this place, to go through EVERYTHING will take about 4 hours....so be sure to plan time accordingly to see it all! BEWARE...the end is a tear jerker!
author: Jennifer F.

description: We decided to visit this moving gallery of the world's amazing man Walt Disney.  From beginning to end, his legacy continues for many generations.  Of course it has a cute gift shop and cafe operated by Wolfgang Puck Catering with local organic ingredients and kid-friendly selections.  Animation was his life and work, inspiring!  This exhibition hall is breathtaking, and it embraces the unique surroundings and natural beauty of SF.
author: Christine R.

description:
I loved this museum so much on my first visit that I became a member!
I've taken many friends and family, and my 6 year old niece loved it too.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Beautifully done. Came here to fill an hour and two hours quickly flew by. Could have stayed longer but ran out of time. Now I want to go home and watch some old Disney shows!
author: Corinne G.

description:
I just recently visited this for the second time. I really enjoyed myself each time, and I will confess to not being the biggest Disney nerd. The first time I was able to visit here with "The world's biggest Disney buff to not work at Disney" and even he was learning new stuff. The second time I did my best to take on that same role.

It takes me about two hours to see everything here, and that is skipping over a lot of the reading material. They do a good job of having variation from exhibit to exhibit, thus keeping your interest level high. As everyone raves about, there is an excellent view of the Golden Gate Bridge at one point, and my favorite was the model replica of Disneyland. For anyone who has ever even seen only one Disney movie, I would have to recommend going here.
author: Chris B.

description:
My wife and I loved this museum.  We are both fascinated by Walt Disney after taking a class in college about him.  This was a must during our vacation to SF.  The location in Presidio was nice as it made us visit a section of SF we probably would have passed by.  We loved the area, it was beautiful.  Upon entering, there was an impressive display of his awards including a display of Academy Awards.  

The set up of the Museum was well thought out.  It was in chronological order from birth to death in pretty great details.  We were amazed at all the pics, drawings, etc they had in the museum.  We took around 2 hours to view the displays and probably could have taken more time to completely digest all that was included in the tour.  

This museum was nothing short of fantastic if you are a Disney fan.  For $20 dollars, it was well worth the price of admission.
author: Joel G.

description:
Amazing place to visit, I had no idea the adversity Walt Disney faced or did I know much about the history of his personal life, truly a must visit museum.  Anyone that would give this place a bad review clearly has no appreciation for what is required to be successful and build a great company.

Wayne Gorsek
author: Wayne G.

description:
My boyfriend and I spent an entire afternoon here on a recent trip. There is tons to read and look at. My favorite part was getting a glimpse of Walt Disney the father and husband. It was also very inspiring seeing how many times he failed before he built the empire we know today.

If you have a half-day to kill I highly recommend this museum.
author: Meghan S.

description:
This is a beautiful museum with a lot of high quality installations, all focused on Disney (during the life of Walt Disney).  You won't find a lot of your modern favs (Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, etc.) as a result.  But you do get a good historic perspective of Disney and Disneyland.

They say you need 2.5 - 3 hours, but I think 1 - 1.5 is fine.  I think they are priced a bit higher than they should be ($15 per adult would be more fitting (versus $20)).  Otherwise - well worth the visit.
author: Brian K.

description: Was an amazing experience, you got to learn about the history of Walt Disney and his family. Along with some interesting facts about Mickey Mouse and more films. Found out plenty of things I didn't know.
author: Daric C.

description: Simply the best! Takes you through Walt Disney's life and creations. Fascinating!!! We are so fortunate to have this family museum right here in SF!
author: Cindy L.

description: This place has a really nice gift shop. Lots of neat stuff for all of us Disney fans. When we were there it wasn't crowded. Didn't get to really experience all they had to offer, but just it's location alone makes it a nice place to visit! It's in the Presidio and being able to see the old barracks and grounds brings lots of imagination to mind, just thinking of the soldiers who once passed through these grounds. Really a very well kept and clean place.
author: Dave F.

description:
my fiancé and i are disney fanatics. we moved from so cal to nor cal and had to give up our disney annual passes, so we though we'd visit the museum in SF while we had the chance. the location is amazing.. you get to see the golden gate bridge right out of the window. 

the museum itself has a lot of reading-- i definitely wouldn't recommend this place for kids since it's not really an interactive museum. it's mostly about walt, but has a good chunk about disneyland and how it came about. there were so many things that i learned in this museum. 

there is ample parking, the museum store is adorable and has a lot of hidden gems, and the place is very clean.
author: Kim M.

description:
This is a MUST-SEE in San Francisco. But don't take the kids. It's really a high-tech, multi-media, interactive, state-of-the-art comprehensive look at the life and innovations of a man who was Steven Jobs before Steven Jobs even put on a pair of mouse ears and sang along to the Mickey Mouse Club theme. I've written an extensive review here:
http://leftcoastcowboys.com/2011/11/26/whos-the-leader-of-the-club/

Bonus, the Mezzanine sports one of the best views of the Golden Gate available and the parking is easy at this location in the old Presidio.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Tips for an enjoyable experience: 
*You may purchase timed tickets online although because the museum is not very crowded you can walk up to buy tickets too 
*Free parking in the lot directly in front of the museum 
*Play area for kids while the adults are enjoying the museum 
*Prepare to spend at least 2 hours here 

If you are a Disney buff or fanatic, then the Walt Disney Family Museum is a place that you should go and learn more about Walt Disney pre: Disneyland/Disneyworld. The Museum talks about Walt's life as a child, his days as an animator, how Mickey was his saviour, and how he was a risk taker, a dreamer, and a true Imagineer. The Museum also shows him as a family man, a business man, and an optimist-how Mickey and Disneyland is really an extension of one man. I'm not going to lie, by the end of the exhibit, I was crying. 

The exhibit is interesting and historical and details a lot about his personal life and how everything intersected. The exhibits are sort of long and not suitable for children as it's mostly reading and looking at memorabilia. 

The price is a little steep for a Museum ($20) but I can say that overall I enjoyed learning more about the history of a man that I admire (I mean I did write a 7th grade report on this man so I'm a little biased). 

Great for a Disney buff but could be a little boring for someone who's not.
author: Betty C.

description: Establishment is actually really nice and well kept. Except the museum is really well not all that exciting. I was expecting alot more artwork and alot less fluff. For every panel of artwork you see theres about 500 signs with paragraphs about Walt's life. Not to mention theres a huge section dedicated to how Disney workers went on strike, how is that visually interesting at all? Beats me? The place wasnt bad but I wouldnt come back, MoMa is definately more interesting and at the same price too.
author: Jini Y.

description:
It's a great museum. I guess I'm more into the new Disney stuff than the old Disney stuff. A lot of the stuff in there had the old Disney stuff, which are it less interesting for me. 

It makes sense why we can't take pictures, but I just wished I could. The museum was very organize. It's amazing to see how much Walt Disney have done for our childhood. 

It's for sure a must go, at least to see what Disney is all about. The area is beautiful to walk around too.
author: Mo W.

description:
The museum is so informative and set up really well! I am a huge Disney fan so I love learning all about Walt Disney and his visions. 
The museum is set up to walk you through Walt's life, starting with even before he was born, showing how his parents met. It then moves on to his early life and how he got his inspirations and how he used technology to his advantage and it ends with his death; however, his visions never die. Throughout the whole exhibit there are original drawings, movies, and interactive activities. 

My suggestion would be to go earlier in the day because it takes you a lot longer than expected. The first time we went, we went to the last entrance time which would have given us 2 hours to do the exhibit but we barely made it half way through. The second time we went, we went in the morning (which was also less crowded) and finished in about 3.5 hours which it didn't even feel like it!
author: Thea M.

description: This museum is so worth the $20 admission fee.  It shows the history of Walt Disney,  from his family's background (originally from Ireland) through his war years, marriage, early animation career and all of the classic Disney films and of course Disneyland. Plan on spending at least a few hours,  especially if you plan to read asked look at all the information. A wonderful secret that you must explore when visiting San Francisco.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I was very impressed with the scale of this museum. From his birth to his death you feel like you really get to know Walt. What was interesting is the museum does not shy away from scandalous topics and public criticisms of Disney, but gives a fair balanced perspective on the events that took place. I'm not going to lie, I shed a couple tears at the end of the museum because you walk down this animated hall where famous people are talking about the impact he had on their lives. It's the idea that when you die you would hope people would have nice things to say about you. 

The only draw backs I could find were they do not allow photos in the exhibit hall. Bummer but I understand. Also I would have easily given this museum 5 stars if they gave a discount for Disneyland annual pass holders. 

I truly had a magical experience at the Walt Disney Family Museum and can't wait to come back!
author: Aaron L.

description:
As a former Cast Member of Disneyland, a lifelong Walt enthusiast, and overall Disney fan- I knew I had to to get to this museum.  I had happy to say, this did not disappoint. However, this is an experience for ADULTS. This is purely about the life of Walt and his accomplishments, not  just about Walt Disney World or Disneyland. 
 
I loved seeing the original concept art for Mickey Mouse, the Oscars Walt won for Snow White and the 7 dwarfs, and the multi level camera. I got to see all his many awards, sketches, concept art,  the original saddle from the old TV series Zorro, the original plans for Disneyland, and even the  full Disneyland model.

I loved that this really focused on the man and not the parks, Disneyland was mentioned at the end, but it was the main point. The museum is owned by the family and not the WALT DISNEY CO., so I found refreshing not to be bombarded by the typical Disney franchise.  

It is really well done and really entertaining. Everything flows really well together and I never found myself bored. 

I spent around 3 hours there, but I am a Disney fanatic. 

I highly recommend visiting this!!
author: Danielle E.

description: Very neat museum. My kids, wife, and I all enjoyed it greatly. There are interactive exhibits that the kids will enjoy, and educational exhibits for the adults.
author: William M.

description:
I like museums and always try to visit at least one on each trip. The Walt Disney museum is one of the best museums I have ever been to. Pricey, but well worth it. First the location is awesome, The Presidio! You get an amazing view of Golden Gate Bridge too during the tour of the museum. 
Secondly, the decor and attention to detail is amazing, very Disney. And best of all, it's about Walt, who is one inspiring and amazing. They tell his complete story andthere are so many things I learned about him that I didn't know before.You can easily spend a couple of hours here and not realize it.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
A hidden gem in the Presidio. I expected something much smaller, but this place manages to tell the whole story of Walt's family from the late 1800s on, plus the history of the Disney studio and theme parks. Exhibits are expansive & detailed, with lots of interesting artifacts, plus audiovisual materials around every corner.

A fitting tribute to a creative man and the hard-working people around him.
author: Dave R.

description:
If you admire Walt Disney for what he created for the world, this place will amaze and move you. It's as much an emotional experience as it is one both nostalgic and historic. When was the last time you went to a museum that had a proper pacing, where someone could spoil it for you if they revealed the surprise ending. This is such a museum.

I'm really proud to have this museum in our city.

More in my review for the Yelp Elite Event that occurred here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/what-would-walt-disney-do-yee-walt-disney-family-museum-san-francisco#hrid:3bxaXvd3wxMGtSEu7gE4mA
author: Keane L.

description: More than you can possibly imagine! Allow at least two hours to get through the main exhibit. Covers the disney family and company history end to end. Even if you are not a Disney fanatic I think you'll find this museum fascinating! Easy access and easy parking are a plus.
author: Mike J.

description: If you've ever been to Disneyland or grew up with the classic animated films, then this is a museum you must visit. Beautifully designed, it provides a look at how Walt Disney went from an okay cartoonist to a force in entertainment. Tons of information about his family and business. There are no "rides" here as one man asked when I was there. So it's not really appropriate for very young children.
author: Jon K.

description:
It was ok.  It certainly didn't blow me away, but I enjoyed learning about the history of Walt Disney's life.  The best part was watching some of the old cartoons on various screens throughout the museum.

I wouldn't bring kids, and an hour is long enough to see it all if you aren't trying to read EVERYTHING.  If you like to read, count on 2-3 hours.  If you are a fanatic, I am sure you can figure a way to spend 5 hours.

The museum is well built and has some great views of the Golden Gate Bridge on a sunny day (see photo).  However, photos are not allowed inside of the museum.

The Disney movie(s) they show are operated separately and require an additional $10 per person.  The cafe and gift shop are ok...nothing special.  Overall, I was hoping for a lot more since the "Disney" name is attached.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Attention parents - this is not an amusement park but a museum. There are lots of things to read and view that will not interest your 3 year old.  The family background and company history is fascinating. I enjoyed seeing the technological innovations and progression of animation. I would have enjoyed it more if kids weren't rolling around on the floor crying that they were "bored."

Such a gem for out of town guests.
author: Kim W.

description:
I made this account just so I could write a review for this place.  Absolutely amazing!  I walked into the museum expecting to get a little glimpse into Walt's life and came out feeling ultra-inspired by his courage and the love that he had for his work and the world. I went with my boyfriend, who isn't a major Disney fan, and he had equally as great a time as I did! 

As many others have already commented, the Walt Disney Family Museum is a lot bigger than it looks.  2-3 hours isn't gonna be enough time if you really want to immerse yourself into all of the awesome exhibits.  I was here for about 3 hours and had to rush a little in the end because the museum was getting ready to close.  I'm definitely coming back here to get a closer look some time. :]

Being in the museum was like being in another world... I nearly collided with people at least 5 times while reading all the little plaques and whatnot because I was so  focused.  This museum is definitely more adult-oriented.  Be prepared to read when you get here... and be prepared to read A LOT.  My eyes were exhausted by the end, but it was way worth it.  It was so interesting to learn more about Walt's personal life outside of his career.  Just looking at the stuff he left behind for his family, you can tell he was a wonderful husband, father and friend-- just another reason to love and worship him even more.  By the last exhibit, my eyes were welling up... I had to try very hard not to cry.  You'll know what I mean after you've seen it. ;)
author: Amy H.

description: Beautiful museum & what a view of SF!! Must see :) for Disney fans & for those who will come to the mouse side!
author: Denise S.

description:
If you're a huge Disney fan. You have to go to the family museum. It's a must. I don't think you can call yourself a true fan until you do to be honest. There's just so much history to absorb it's actually quite overwhelming. At least for me it was. Even though a good portion of this museum is very hands on and interactive (lots of touch screens and games to play) i do not recommended this for children. Not only is it not the environment for kids.. I personally don't think they would appreciate it since they're so young. So this is definitely a trip to take either without the kiddies or maybe wait until they're older. Overall as a museum it's a great place. I learned a lot (most of it I already knew but still...). You get to learn the real story of Walt Disney and his life. There's just a lot to take in, so wear comfortable shoes if you intend on getting your monies worth by reading and interacting with every station. I would say it would take you at least 3-4 hours to go through the whole exhibit if you're a fast paced/average reader. So get there early!! Personally, I would say the best parts of the whole museum would be the giant miniature (contradiction?) replica of Disneyland. The attention to detail.... wow. Breathtaking! As well as the final two rooms of the exhibit leading away from the Disneyland room. I think I spent the most time that room, MORE TIME THAN WITH THE REPLICA! It was a lot to take it. I won't spoil anything. But.. it was definitely tugging the strings of my Disney loving heart...

Overall, I'd say it's worth. You should at least go once in your life. Why not?
author: Allie A.

description:
I'm so happy we went here.  This is located in the Presidio and was easy to get to via the bus system.  The day we were there the weather was beautiful so the walk  through the Presidio was especially nice.  

The museum was a great experience.  It mixed the personal and business life of Walt Disney.  I walked away knowing a lot more about the man and how he built his business then I did going in.  There was a discount coupon in one of the SF Visitors guilds that we took advantage of - but - I would have been happy to pay full price as I thought it was worth every penny.  We spent several hours and I think you could spend more if your inclined. 

I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in Walt Disney, his life and how he built his business.
author: Drew M.

description: Had my cousin here Santa Barbara last week from April 2, 2014 - April 6, 2014 we decide Friday April 4, 2014 to come to The Disney Museum I didn't expect much from what the outside looks like and we are both Disney fanatics I was real surprise so amazing of Mr Disney himself growing up and the making of his Amazing Parks it was so beautiful & very interesting & educational I just loved everything and all the paintings in the exhibit just Gorgeous I loved every bit spend 2 1/2hrs and the view of the Golden Gate Bridge just Beautiful I Love Love Love Mr Walt Disney and the Amazing work he created for all to see from the beginning of Mickey Mouse to Frozen and all the Disney Parks throughout our World
author: Barbara L.

description:
Having seen all of the amazing reviews on Yelp, I was expecting to really enjoy this museum. I usually like museums, and I think Disney is okay (although I'm not a huge fan). The tickets were more expensive than generally expected of a museum ($20 per adult) but the reviews were so great that I decided to check it out. We had a group of four people, so this was $80. The location is in a really nice area to walk around. Walking around the museum and the nearby national cemetery was actually my favorite part of the visit. They also have a very nice porch area and the facilities are clean and new.

Now for the actual museum experience... 

I have never seen such a text-heavy museum in my life. There were paragraphs and paragraphs of information EVERYWHERE with very few objects that were interesting. It honestly reminded me of reading a book of Walt Disney's life. It was sort of like information overload. Also, the museum was pretty busy so it was hard to find space in areas that I did find interesting. The overall experience was just too overwhelming, and we basically ended up running through the museum and not learning very much at all. 

I can see how someone that is very interested in animation might enjoy this museum and take the time to read everything so they can follow along. Sadly, I'm not that person and the museum felt more like a chore. So much reading..... I would recommend that (if you're not an animation junkie) you check out the Legion of Honor instead.
author: A. N.

description:
A new museum with a surprising wealth of artwork. A great date if you're both Disney fans (the man, not the brand). The Disneyland room is really something to see--as is the awards gallery before the museum entrance.

Free parking!
author: Laura F.

description:
Fantastic museum, extremely well done. We learned a great deal about Walt and his brother, Roy--and the brilliant entertainment empire they built from the ground up. I was particularly impressed with Walt's resilience in overcoming many business challenges to achieve the success he enjoyed.

Bravo!
author: Don B.

description:
I'm not so much a fan of museums, but this one is an exception! It is absolutely phenomenal! However, it may seem like a museum targeted to children but I think adults, or young adults, will actually appreciate it more. 

It is basically a museum showcasing Walt's remarkable life and all his creative works in ten different galleries. It will take you from the beginning, when he was born, when he started, his first creations, his struggles during the depression and the war, his accomplishments, until the very end of his life. It is very interactive, but there is also a lot of reading. But what is amazing about this museum, is hearing his own voice in a lot of the showcased materials. It is like he was personally telling you the story of his life. He is such an asset in the film industry, most especially in the cartoon animation. He is a man of courage, dedication and passion. You will definitely be inspired after leaving the gallery. 

I suggest though, that you plan to be there for at least 2-3 hours. I only had an hour to visit the galleries and it was not enough. I want to come back another time. 

But oh, one more thing, I lolove the view of Golden Gate Bridge inside one of the galleries. I was astonished. And I think aside from the view, I liked gallery 9 the best!!! You'll find out why.

This whole experience just makes me want to go to Disneyland again. Or better yet, Disney World!
author: Abby M.

description: Disney always does it right. This is such a great display of the Disney family and Walt's life. You smile. You laugh. You point things out to others. You take your time. There are new exhibits. There are things you would go see time and time again. They have a replica Disney Land in the museum which is super cool. We got to go to the Mary Blair exhibit which was really well done. Everything is great about the Museum honestly. I can't wait to go again. Admission is $20 and the special Mary Blair exhibit was an extra $5. We spent 3 wonderful hours in the Museum and I cannot wait to go back!
author: Mary F.

description:
This museum may be one of the only things with the Disney name that isn't  for kds. It is whole heartedly an exhibit for adults that my wife and I felt honored for the Disney family to share this with all those who come to see it. 

I knew much of Walt's story already, or so I thought. From beginning to end this museum keeps your interest and gives you several methods to absorb all the info available. I laughed, got a little misty eyed, and felt a great sense of joy after viewing everything there was to see. 

Walt Disney was a true Aerican hero and entrepreneur.
author: Kirk J.

description:
Came here 2 years ago and Loved every minute of it! 
surprising interactive. With short videos and animations for viewing
Reminded me of many characters i forgot about over the years.
you get to get into the mind of a genius, Walt, and learn about the history
or his creations from Mickey to Disney World.
Sad that he didn't get to see his last project, Disney World, come to life.
But if there was an award (maybe there is), 
he should get TheMan of the Century Award
The replica Disney Land is a dream, I wish I had it for myself!

Disney forever!
author: Lynn T.

description: Alluring, fascinating, disney attraction with a gorgeous backdrop of the Golden gaye Bridge. good location too! I enjoyed my stay.
author: Nicole S.

description: This museum is so wonderful. It starts from the beginning of Walt's life with family heritage and earlier projects, and goes all the way through Disneyland creation and after that. They have an amazing model of Disneyland as well. I would say this is definitely designed for adults and would not recommend it for children. There is a lot of reading involved, and no hands-on child friendly activities.
author: Maddie P.

description:
Quite a wealth of information about Walt Disney's life and his impact on building the Disney company.  The museum shows an honest look at the highs and lows of his life and work.  Quite an engaging museum for everyone, and you can spend anywhere from 2 hours for a quick overview to an entire day if you are a huge Disney fan and still not see everything.

Quick tip: since it's a look at Walt's life, the last room with all the tributes when he passed is very touching, and if you sit and read lots of them, you are likely to cry.  Trust me.  I watched it happen to multiple people.

If you live in the area, I encourage you to join the museum, as the extra events really cover a gamut of interests and ages, and are more reasonably priced than the extra events at some of the bigger name museums in the city.
author: Elwood B.

description: If you have any interest in Disney I think this is worth your time. Give yourself a couple of hours to get thru the 17 rooms. The exhibits are a good mixture of audio, visual and reading. Gives you a great sense of the creative brilliance of Walt Disney from his childhood days to the creation of Disney World. Worth the time and money
author: Dave C.

description: Great museum! Well organized, highly detailed and extremely entertaining for anyone who is a fan of Disney. Expect to come out more educated on this iconic entertainer and have a pleasureful adventure in the process. Enjoy!
author: Jason P.

description:
I honestly didn't think I'd love this museum as much as I did. It's in a rather unassuming building, it doesn't even look like it could house something of this caliber seeing as it used to be an army barrack (I think?). 

This place is pretty damn amazing.

I think that sums it up. Lol. Just kidding! I'm pretty sure you Yelp kids expect more from me. And more you shall get. 

First off, this is definitely more of a history of Mr. Walt Disney himself and how he created his Disney empire rather than the story of Mickey Mouse. His story is pretty interesting and I read everything! I don't think I've ever read that much at a museum ever! So be prepared to read and rest your eyes the night before! Given that, do note that it will take 3-4 hours to get through the museum, took me and my friend around that long. They stamp you at the door though, so you can go out and give your eyes a rest before you go back in. Not that there's much in the vicinity to rest at/on. 

Their exhibition design is amazing! Like mindblowingly awesome. All the displays be them animated or still images are cool. They find ways to make it cool. Even the biography of Walt Disney's early years, might sound boring to you now as you're reading me type about the topic. The animations make it 48392048329x more interesting. 

The gift store is cool too, I wanted to bring EVERYTHING home. But little ole me on my designer's salary can't afford that. So I settled for some cutesy postcards since I'm sucha sucker for museum postcards and fresh graphic designs.

I thought it was pretty cool to see the man behind the mouse and what he went through to build the empire he did. Younger kids might not enjoy the museum as much so I don't really recommend that just because of the sheer amount of reading. It does get tiring reading everything and I didn't sleep enough the night before. But it's definitely worth going to!
author: Constance C.

description: My husband and I visited the Walt Disney Family Museum during a recent trip to SF. Somehow despite being big Disney fans, we had never heard of the museum before arriving in SF. I am so glad we were able to experience the museum! The life story of Walt Disney is truly fascinating and we spent over 4 hours exploring the exhibits. So much history with exceptional detail. We were very impressed. After exploring the exhibits, we watched Mary Poppins in the theater. Overall we had a fantastic time and highly recommend visiting the museum if you're in the area.
author: Tasha I.

description:
Being an animator, I guess I'm a bit biased...but this museum really blew my mind. There is something so fascinating about seeing the life of such a legend in my field. I can't imagine that there are many children on this planet that are not familiar with at least a few of Disney's classic characters. The museum talks about the beginnings of Mickey mouse and the beginning's of the Walt Disney studio. All of Walt Disney's accomplishments are significantly more impressive when you get the full perspective as to where Walt came from and how he built his empire. Nothing stopped him, he thrived despite his downfalls...and created some really innovative filming techniques that took animation to a whole other level as an art form as well as validating it in the competitive Hollywood world of film with the wild successes of Mickey Mouse in Steam Boat Willie, then onto Snow White and Pinocchio. 

The museum has old character sheets, character models (sculptures the animators used as reference while animating,) old posters and a wicked cool model of Disneyland that lights up and the rides actually move & work like the real thing. There are also old filming rigs such as the Multi-plane Camera & their immensely complicated compositing machine that helped them create films like Mary Poppins where the animated characters interact with the live action actors shot on film. Now-a-days those film treatments are easy to come by. That wasn't the case back in Disney's day. He didn't let that stop him. He hired people to engineer a machine that helped him combine the two mediums together with a very convincing result, especially for that point in film history.

It was really interesting to see family pictures, to get a background of such a hero in the animation world. Thank you, Walt Disney Museum for doing justice to such a great figure in the history of film and animation!
author: Kristin G.

description:
If you are a person who is interested in learning about the successful people in history, or just want to re-live a piece of your youth, this is the place for you.  

Just to make sure you realize, this is a museum dedicated to the Family of Walt Disney, not a family museum.  We say some kids running around who were not very interested in all of the exhibits they have here, but the experience is much more geared to adults.

It amazing how they integrated technology into everything in this place, and I loved hearing about how the Disney family grew up.  They talk about Walt's first failures and the huge risk making Snow White.  

This is a must see for many people no matter guy or girl, young or old, just not kids.

One drawback is there is no photography inside the museum, but if people were popping pictures all over the place, it would not have been as enjoyable.
author: Brett M.

description:
The life of Walt Disney told chronologically from birth to death.  There are 9 galleries,1 of which focuses on Disneyland.
So cool.
So Cool.
It is the history of the first 65 years of the u.s. filtered through the life of an american visionary....and told in many different ways,memorabilia,video,displays,technology.
It is absolutely compelling.   And,even though there is only one Disneyland gallery????It is a wonder.  From Walt's train to a wonderful model of the park, it is just a beautiful museum....with an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
CHECK IT OUT
author: DAVID G S.

description:
Wow! Loved it. Easily spent 3 hours there.. may have spent a couple more, but had reservations to get to. 

If you like Disney this place is for you. Learn how Walt and his family started it all. Amazing!

The breathtaking views of the Golden Gate Bridge are a plus too!

Not so much for kids... there are a couple interactive games/quizzes but not enough to keep a kid captivated for 3+ hours!
author: Kelly B.

description:
This is a very beautiful museum, in a re-designed historic building, with many high quality installations, quite a few on video. The family has established this museum to honor the life of Walt Disney, and as a result, expect to see exhibits that cover his working life (about 1914-1966). Don't be fooled that this is for children; it's not. Unless you have a really exceptional child, this is really for high school age and above. Because of his particular influence on our lives, people in their 50's and 60's will likely find it particularly enjoyable.

There is much to learn about creativity, the history of animation, the importance of music in film, the ideas that inspired Disneyland--a great variety of themes. It took us about three hours to go through the exhibits. We found the staff to be uniquely qualified--well informed, welcoming and outgoing. Good little museum shop, too. 

The Presidio is a stunning (though isolated) location. The Golden Gate views from inside the museum are eye-popping. There is a decent little sandwich and salad cafe inside the museum. Alternatively, there is an adorable French bistro, called La Terrasse, only about a block away.  

Except during rush hour (when a special pass is required), there is a free bus (PresidiGo) from the Transbay Terminal,  with another stop by the Embarcadero BART station and another at Van Ness and Broadway. Definitely the way to go! Find the schedule at http://www.presidiobus.com.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I never bothered looking through the reviews here, but I may be in a small group of guys to actually review this place.  This review is a little overdue since I went here a while ago, but I can still recall my visit like my first ride at Disneyland (Star Tours!!).  

I mainly chose to go to this place because of my girlfriend.  What girl doesn't like Disney?  Not all, but a majority do.  OK, let me correct myself so I won't have to "update review" this one.  Mainly girls and kids like Disney stuff.  

The drive to the museum you'll pass through some really beautiful views that you'll want to stop and just gaze for a while.    

The theme of this museum follows the life of Walt Disney, the creator of Disneyland and the father of Mickey Mouse.  It is a self-guided tour filled with fully detailed and very descriptive media covering every phase of his life.  It starts with his birth and ends with his death and the legacy he paved through the company he created.  

This place has some major underrated awesomeness.  You can easily spend the whole day looking at the Walt Disney memorabilia, reading excerpts about moments in his life, and recordings they have at every station with a different focus on him.  As someone fascinated in history and origins of people and events, I really enjoyed my time there.
author: Arnold T.

description: This museum is so worth the $20 entrance fee. Give yourself at least 3 hours to visit it, but that still isn't enough time to see everything. We visited it woth my two kids (4 & 19 mos old ) and eventhough we stayed for three hours that was in a rush because they were getting tired. It's not for young kids! But awesome for adults and older kids.
author: Ale B.

description: This museum was even better than I expected it to be.  I went here for the first time on Saturday and was disappointed to find out that I would not be able to see the whole museum in one visit because there is so much to see!  So much cool memorabilia, interactive displays, and great video and audio.  The folks at the front said it would take 2 hours, but 4 hours later I was only through the 1940s with 20 more years of stuff to see.  We had to leave to feed our growling bellies, but I will definitely be back to see the rest.  Plus, parking is free!
author: Sherrie Rose M.

description:
Certainly worth a visit -- but something about the 'brand' of Disney might shift your expectations. However, there is something here for people who enjoy the history behind things. 

This is not for kids, I'd say. This is an interesting document of Walt Disney and his family.
author: Sharon M.

description:
the lovely super yelper, Mel V invited me here after winning a family membership at a yelp event. Growing up on Disney, I was excited to check out the history of Walt Disney's life and career. 

The museum itself is very well put together. There are many interesting things too see and hear, and the personal history of the man along with the marriage of art and science to create the animation was very fasciating to learn about. I found the end of the museum tour a bit odd, though. without giving too much away, I felt (and I have a feeling I'm not alone here) very sad, where as if they had chosen to shift a few features in the musuem around, that feeling could have been avoided.

Overall though, if you are a Disney fan, an animation enthusiast, or you just want something for the whole family to enjoy, I recommed a visit to this museum!
author: Caddy M.

description:
I LOVED this museum.  The exhibits cover Walt Disney from beginning to end, going through family aspects as well as his work throughout his life.  Every room is packed with information.  I spent at least 3 hours here trying to read everything and look at all the photos and drawings.  This is well worth the $20 (or $15 for students!).  The whole place inspires a lot of emotion and nostalgia.

If you are a Disney fan, you will enjoy this museum.  Just remember, no camera's allowed!
author: Kristiana A.

description:
Definitely a hidden gem! Exceeded my expectations...actually I really didn't know what to expect when we got here. This museum was located in the Presidio with a stunning view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

I think hearing the word "Disney," most people automatically think of amusement parks and Mickey Mouse. This is a museum dedicated to the man himself, Walt Disney. Definitely not a place suitable for young children since they'll probably be bored out of their minds.

If you're a Disney fan, you'll definitely enjoy this museum. There's different rooms/sections that breaks down each stage of Walt's life. It takes you through his beginnings--history of his family/parents, his siblings, where he was born, and what he was like as a child. It then talks about how he got into drawing/animation/cartoons. The next section brings you through his early adulthood--joining the military, his continued interest in drawings/animations, his marriage. Then you're brought into a room where it's all about Walt's move to California and how he got into the industry.

Of course there is a whole section dedicated to his whole genius behind what we know today as Disney. They actually have real originals of when he first sketched Mickey Mouse. It also delves into his award winning animation films, such as Snow White, and all the hard work that goes into making one of these films.

Last, but not least, there's a whole part dedicated to Disneyland. Definitely a way to end it with a bang. There were lots of exhibits, art, awards, models, and replicas to look at. Also a lot of text to read. If you're like me and you're a slow reader, but have to read EVERYTHING, then you'll definitely be spending a good amount of time here. 

Even though the museum isn't that big, my husband and I spent about 3 hours just looking at and reading through everything. We absolutely loved it and thought it was time and money well spent. It was very informative and gives you a new appreciation of Walt Disney...he's THE man!
author: Karen C.

description: Disney fans beware! This museum IS NOT about the Disney company but rather about Walt Disney the person. As such, you will find yourself learning about his childhood and looking at the jewels he bought for his wife and kids. Even worse, the exhibits end after his passing away, so no Lion King, no Little Mermaid, no Beauty and the Beast and no Aladdin. Heck, even no Jungle Book! I felt it was a waste of time...
author: Norcloud S.

description: I have been to museums all over America and Europe and the Walt Disney Family Museum is by far one of the most beautiful I have ever seen.  After one visit we became members because we knew we would go back.  The highlight for me is a hand-written note by Diego Rivera about Walt Disney's contribution to the art world.  I agree with the other commenters that this is a museum for adults and/or older children, not really for young kids.  The museum is a biographical journey through Walt's life and contributions.  What a life he had!
author: Hilary H.

description:
The Walt Disney Family Museum is unique in that it is operated by the Disney family not the corporation so many of the memorabilia is very personal. There is an entrance level with gift shop and café along with display cases of Walt's life. The most impressive is the case with all of the Oscars. The main museum is on the upper level and takes you though Walt's life from beginning the comics to the beginning of the animated movies and the development of Disneyland. There are many interactive displays that will really engage the kids. As you work our way back to the ground level there is a wonderful model of Disneyland - very impressive.
The museum is also a conference center with a very nice hall on the lower level that has a variety of events and lectures.
author: John O.

description: Why don't more people know about this place? Besides knowing and enjoying all of Walt Disney's work, it really is cool learning about his roots and journey before Disneyland and all those movies. It really makes you appreciate his work even more...if that is possible. He really is a legend
author: Judie H.

description: Was better than I expected. About a 1-1/2 activity walk through. The view of the Golden Gate Bridge is fantastic
author: Jaseon F.

description: Been to this museum at least five times. Still my favorite museum not only in the Bay area, but also in the States. The entire experience was intimate, sincere, and genuine. The finale and the room showing the news pieces and cartoons around the world regarding Walt Disney's death was extremely moving.
author: Vivien S.

description: Loved it. Don't be put off by reviews that call it a "darling little museum" or some such thing. It took us an entire day to get through it. Interesting info about Walt Disney and his family, the many risks and nay-sayers who challenged his ideas, and family treasures. Obviously a labor of love. Many interactive exhibits, though the first rooms are pretty much walk-and-read. I would not take young children to this museum, though they seem to have lots of special things to do for school field trips. I did think the price was a bit high ($20 museum; $5 special exhibit if you did them together), but the museum is well-cared for. They're doing something good with that money. And surprise, surprise, the Main Post parking area at the Presidio is about the only place in SF you'll find a decent price for parking: $7/day. Fun visit. I recommend it.
author: Sherrie S.

description:
ALREADY A FAN!!! I Can't flipping wait for this to open in August 2009. I will buy a lifetime membership right now.  The two things that made me  choose the path I am on right now are Disney and Star Wars.
Man-O-Man-OH-MAN!!!!


Edit: So it looks like October 1st 2009 is the opening date! Consider me in line already.
author: Lou Z.

description:
Wonderful place
The views are great and so is the museum
Worth the price of admission
author: Greg G.

description:
"we have a disney museum??" said my older cousins from the area. This place is a relatively new museum in the Presidio areas of SF. I'm not from around but I heard that there's a Star Wars Museum nearby as well. 

I'm a huge fan of Disney. It was really cool to see Walt Disney's imagination run wild. My favorite was watching how the different tv series and movies come together. It really makes you want to go home and watch your whole collection again!

student price with id: $15
definitely worth it!
author: Melissa P.

description: Incredible. They have done an amazing job. Spent over two hour here just for the main Disney part of it. They do have rotating exhibits that I will need to come back and see. It is located right in the heart of The Presisio. Amazing views. Great addition to SF.
author: Meredith O.

description:
I'm not totally sold on the idea of a museum dedicated to one man. I don't think Walt would be sold on this either, but let's face it, the man's rags-to-riches story is impressive and worth exploring.

I can't oversell the presentation of this material enough. It's very engaging, eye-catching, and I've never seen anything this well done in a museum. I love the mix of static with animated frames. The motion graphics are beautiful. The Disneyland model is amazing.

Definitely well worth the trip.

You can take a short stroll, through the Presidio, to the Palace of the Arts from here.
author: Jason L.

description:
If you're an ultimate Disney fan...you MUST see this museum.  It's all about Walt's life and how his imagination and passion changed the lives of all Disney-lovers. =D  The place was more extensive then I thought it would be.  There are two floors filled with different exhibits and artifacts.  The creativity that went into making this museum was very impressive.  There are even activities you can try!  The employees were also very helpful, considerate, and friendly (reminded me of being at Disneyland!).  I enjoyed this place a lot and so did my dad and brother..we stayed here for about 4 hours! =D  This is a must see for Disney fans.  

(There's also tons of parking..huge plus!  )
author: Kristen T.

description:
If you ever wanted to know everything there is to know about Mr. Walt E. Disney, then this is the place to go. 

The museum is, in true Disney fashion, very clean and with ample parking (I know, what? Ample parking in S.F?). It's location in the Presidio makes it ideal. Parking is free and directly across from the museum, which already gives it three stars in my opinion. 

When you walk in, you are immediately greeted by a friendly volunteer docent. The docent is glad to take his or her time to make sure you are familiar with what you are about to experience. 

We purchased our tickets in advance for the 11:30 tour. We arrived at 10:30 and they gladly took us in an hour early. Of course this was on a very quiet Wednesday morning. Saturday may be more crowded and you may have to stick to your ticket time. The lobby has many displays to keep you busy while you wait. They also have a cafe and gift shop. (What Disney place would be complete without a gift shop?) 

Again, in true Disney fashion, you are treated as their special guest as you explore all three galleries presenting the life story of Walt Disney. The layout of the museum is very well done. It has many videos and displays that will have you reading and listening with interest. You will learn not only how Walt got his start but also what propelled him and motivated him to continue his legacy of fun and laughter that will last for many generations, if not forever. 

I would have to warn parents that this museum is not for small children. There are not too many interactive exhibits and there is a lot of reading. They may be amused by the cartoons and short videos on display but I fear anyone under the age of 10 would be bored quickly.
