The museum does have a small theater that shows Disney films for an added price. I saw some parents coming to the museum just to take their children to the theater. I mean, how cool is it to have your child still be able to see Silly Symphonies, or Peter Pan on the big screen? 

In short, if you are an avid Disney fan you will love this place. If you are just a so-so Disney fan, you may not appreciate paying the $20.00 to read about Disney's family life, business life (including mistakes he made), and so on. 

My favorite gallery was the last gallery that contained a miniature layout of Disneyland park. I will not spoil it for you but lets just say it almost had me in tears and did have me in goosebumps with a walk down memory lane. 

And that's what Disney is all about after all.... making wonderful memories. :)
author: Jules P.

description:
Really made me want to go to Disneyland right after I left here!

A museum dedicated to the life and legacy of Mr.Walt Disney chronicled in 10 beautifully presented exhibits.

The first thing you notice about the museum is that you can tell there's definitely the 'Disney Touch' throughout the place, but it's a very subtle presence. There's so much detail, but not too overwhelming. I think my biggest advice is not to devote too much time to the first room where they discuss Disney genealogy. Once you get on the elevator, that's when all the good stuff starts (Mickey Mouse) 

Like what others said, I don't think little children will appreciate the museum that much. Some of the kids I saw looked bored as hell. Maybe if your kid is 12 and has been to Disneyland a few times, maybe then they will like it here.

Be sure to go to the bathroom on the bottom level and check out the old school posters of Disneyland attractions.

Another fine establishment in San Francisco! Does anybody know why the museum is in the bay area?
author: Jeffrey L.

description: The building looks musky. Entering the doors it's like entering a new world. The place so colorful and nice. Even he bathroom. The people are so enthusiastic. Everything looks nice.
author: M L.

description: Was in the area for a conference and we came acoss the museum. Was not sure what to expect but was happy and surprised. We spent 4 hours viewing all the museum had to offer. A gem hidden in plain site and well worth the time and admission. Adults and Disney fans will love this place.
author: Maria S.

description: Don't skip the gift shop. Fantastic SF souvenirs. This is a museum for Disney Fan. I became a member because I left it is a good place to bring out of town guests and to enjoy the presidio. Plus, you get a movie and classes with your day admissions.
author: Lina M.

description:
I had to pick a place to visit for a final presentation for my California History class, and surprisingly my professor approved this museum!

This museum has so much information! You can easily spend 3, 4, or 5 hours reading and looking around. I learned so much about Walt Disney's background history and all of the hardships and successes he experienced to build Disney into what it is today.  There are tons of fascinating information and I guarantee you will leave with tons of new and amazing information and a greater appreciation and respect for Walt Disney.

This is not kiddy friendly. The name of the museum may seem like it is because it says "family museum" but it's mostly reading about the history. There are some fun activities, but if you brought a kid to this place, I'm sure he or she would get bored after a while. Something to consider if you were planning to bring your kids here.

I really recommend this place to anyone, but especially Disney lovers :)
author: Sachiko K.

description:
For my husband's bday last week, he wanted to see the Impressionist exhibit, but it was Monday & the De Young is closed. So, went to Yelp to fine highest rates museums that were open on Monday, and this was it. And what a lucky stroke--we LOVED it!! Our 20-year-old's comment was "now I know more about Walt Disney than I know about my GF"!! The whole family DID enjoy it (so "family museum" not a misnomer!), but Steve & I did especially, because we lived through the latter part of Disney's career, remember all the classic films from early releases, remember Disneyland opening, the resurrected Mickey Mouse Club & Wonderful World of Disney (then Color) on TV. 

This gave me a much fuller appreciation for what a creative genius and visionary Walt Disney was, his relationships with his brother, wife & daughters, his family history that contributed to his creative integration of music, how much personal financial risk he took to realize his dreams, and--amazingly, the critical role played by the Giannini's of Bank of America legend, back in the days when they were a true local SF institution.

I'm pretty detail oriented, so loved spending about 3 hrs there (tho 1.5 would have been enough for the kids).
author: Laurel L.

description:
H
O
L
Y

M
O
L
E
Y

This is as good at it gets.

So it's not movies and special effects.  It's a very exhaustive chronology of the life of him and of his family.  The story includes the very early years of his struggle to break into the world of animation and into Hollywood.

It's a VERY intense multi-media experience.  Be prepared to do a lot of reading and a lot of listening and a lot of viewing.  It's borderline "overload" but VERY engrossing and VERY interesting.

Have I gotten TOO carried away?

Well, I was blown away.  The quality of the presentation is phenomenal.  The mixture of printed material and videography is done splendidly.  There is so much to watch and learn.

Don't rush.  They say give yourself two hours, but we spent over four in there.  As my friend Curtis says, "Its just AMAZING."

To be honest, I wasn't very enthused about going in, but it didn't take long for me to become totally absorbed.
author: Ken B.

description:
A nice place and set up. This place can be a little tricky to find since it's located in the old presidio and surrounded by what appears to be vacant buildings. The place is a self-guided tour of the place as you are taken through the life of Walt Disney during his up and down times. Staff here estimate the tours to take about 2-3 hours, but if you're a real Disney fan, you'll want to set aside maybe 4-5 hours.

Although "Disney", this place is geared more to adults, because there is mainly just A LOT of reading as you go through all the displays. There is, however, a neat area in the museum where they explain how they used to make the sound effects in their animated cartoons. To help children (and even adults) get a hands on experience, they have set up a little game where you follow along a "sing-a-long" type of video as you play the various instruments.

The cafe does not have much to offer, so I suggest you grab something to eat before entering. I did get a better understanding behind the history of Disney and enjoyed the place.

Overall, a place where any Disney fan should visit at least once to learn the history behind the man that created the Happiest Place on Earth.
author: Robb J.

description: Amazing look at walt disney. well worth it - took about 3 hours.
author: Michael S.

description:
Had the pleasure of coming here for a Yelp event and was pleasantly surprised.  The exhibits were described to us as "state of the art" and they were just that.  Each room had numerous well-conceived HD multimedia displays.  Really beautiful high tech stuff.  We didn't have enough time to read everything but it was fun to get nostalgic over old childhood friends and get a glimpse into the genius mind of Walter Disney.

The Presidio is an absolute bitch to navigate-- I made the mistake of following Google directions and got totally lost.  My advice is just to look at a map; there was a much easier/more direct route that Google decided not to tell me.

The museum also has a spectacular view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the surroundings in general are pretty nice.  A good place to take an out of town guest who's already done "everything" in SF.
author: Kristin P.

description:
I came here the other weekend with the boyfriend during a SF play day. Here are my thoughts: 

Pros: 
(+) Very detailed, great storyline of Walt Disney's life
(+) Educational - I had not seen some of the movies and short films which Disney created, and for the movies that I had not seen or heard of in a very long time, it was a great walk down memory lane (like the Three Caballeros)
(+) Overall cool exhibit - lots of old Disney family photographs and home movies, Disney memorabilia, telegraph messages between Walt and his brother, etc.
(+) Towards the end there is a miniature replica of Disneyland. Can you say awesome?
(+) Easily spent about four hours in there, if you want something interesting to do that will last you for a while, definitely go here.
(+) They were also holding a special Snow White exhibit for another ten bucks or so. It was pretty neat as well, shows lots of the original drawings and sketches used for the movie
(+) Also the museums provide a neat history of the development of movie and filmography
(+) Great location in the middle of the presidio with a great view of the Golden Gate bridge

Cons:
(-) The museum exhibit ends when Walt dies, and it ends really sad. They show a bunch of Disney characters crying. I left the museum feeling sad. 
(-) There is a LOT of reading in this museum. For someone who likes to look at things (like pictures, exhibits, movie clips, etc.) I got really tired of reading after a while. 
(-) We went on a weekend which makes it understandable, but it was very crowded in there. Sometimes I'd have to pace around for a few minutes before being able to read a placard because some inconsiderate baffoon would be standing in the middle of the way.

Also, neither a positive nor a negative point, but Yelp is right - this place is not good for kids. This is a museum of the Disney Family and their background and involvement in the Disney legacy and movie industry. Plus, your kids probably like the newer cartoons and Pixar, neither of which are involved in this museum. 

If you are a history buff and interested in Walt Disney's life and history, I would definitely recommend going!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
The Walt Disney Family Museum should be called the Walt Disney Adult Museum. (Or the "Walt Disney Family" Museum - as it is about Walt Disney and his family but is definitely not designed for a family with children.)  As an adult, I enjoyed it, but the kids that were there, especially younger ones you could tell were bored.

The museum is located in an area of the Presidio in SF that is beautiful.  It has a huge grassy area, great view of the bay, and plenty of parking (and free parking on weekends).  

The museum focuses on Walt's life.  There is very little about Disneyland, and nothing after 1966 as that is when Mr. Disney died.  It is much less interactive then I thought it would be.  About 75% of it is standard plaque displays, and you are reading information.  About 20% is audio, mostly where you pick up a headset to listen.  The remaining 5% was some videos playing, and one hands on activity where you see how sound was created for Steamboat Willy.   I took my time going through it, and it took me about 3 hours.  

It is nicely laid out in chronological order with lots of pictures, and as I mentioned above, text-based things to read.  Of course, everything is pretty much "pro Disney" including the brief information about the 1941 strike (which is attributed to Communists).  

If you are interested in Walt Disney as a person or the older Disney movies like Bambi, Dumbo, and Snow White, then you should enjoy a visit to the museum.  But leave the kids at grandma's when you go, or you will most likely spend the day listening to your kids tell you how bored they are.
author: Renee R.

description:
Probably the worst way to spend $20. Unless you are really into the history of walt disney, his origins, and  how he created the disney empire, there is not much to see here. I was quite bored the entire time and this place is definitely not good for kids. They also do not allow cameras or cell phone use while in the museum. The only thing that I thought was cool was the miniature disneyland replica. Avoid this place and head over to the lucas arts studio (http://www.yelp.com/biz/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilms-hq-san-francisco#hrid:7vSgWfY76hcTDJ79o6zp7Q), golden gate bridge (http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bridge-san-francisco#hrid:j3ZsLZCFPQ-wZCJQczlJNQ) or palace of fine arts (http://www.yelp.com/biz/palace-of-fine-arts-san-francisco#hrid:ca-cYw32mV6suB0ClB4b1Q) instead.

If you actually want to go here, they offer a AAA discount of $5 off for up to 4 people.
author: Robert Y.

description: A must see for Disney aficionado.For  Kids under the age of 18 not so much. Some interactive exhibits but it would boring for the average kid. My 21 year old liked it so much we left him there and picked  him up later
author: Russell H.

description:
Add this to your list of must-sees in San Francisco and plan a day exploring the Presidio and area surrounding the Golden Gate Bridge while you're at it. This museum is a one of a kind experience that allows the visitor to learn about the vision behind the Disney empire that we know it as today. However, don't expect to breeze through this museum in a short time. It would be easy to get lost in discovery for 2-3 hours. The Walt Disney Family Museum isn't huge so to speak, but it's filled with detailed information, movies and images. But let me start at the beginning...

Hidden within the Presidio, the Walt Disney Family Museum celebrate the man behind the mouse in a renovated historical building overlooking the Golden Gate bridge. It's a tranquil and beautiful setting before you even step foot inside the museum. Tickets for non-members are $20 but it's worth it.

Upon entering, you're welcomed by a cafe, gift shop, ticket counter and walls filled with Disney's endless awards. And that's just the beginning. The museum wraps around and you don't really realize what you're walking into until you're there. The first room is dedicated to the early life of Walt beginning with his parents history, where he was born, where he lived, what his parents did, etc. Each room is like a timeline of his life and the best part is that it's narrated by Disney himself. They have several pictures, artifacts and videos with Disney's voice in the background, I won't go room by room, but it's definitely a historical masterpiece of information and pictures. Slowly but surely you start to see Disney's progression from small cartoons with Alice Comedy Company which ultimately led to the creation of Steamboat Willie, aka Mickey Mouse. Then the Disney fun begins. The rooms start to transform into each of Disney's magical movies such as Alice in Wonderland, Snow White, Bambi, etc. After walking through several rooms with the history of each movie, you enter a room with a ongoing reel of all of his movies. It's pure perfection with the combination of state of the art imagery, movies and original artifacts. 

So now you're asking Disneyland. Me too. Luckily, an entire room is dedicated to the creation of Disneyland and it's as magical as the theme park itself. They created a special model of what Disneyland looked like at the time of Walt's death. It's amazing to see how so much of the park is the same today. It also talked about Walt's final projects and his final days. 

This museum is one where a description won't do it justice. It's one where you must visit yourself and make it a day by packing a picnic and enjoying the Presidio while you're there!
author: Lindsey D.

description:
I am yelping ONLY about the WD Theater part of the museum only. I just hope yelpers with kids will catch this tip before trying to catch the film.

I learned that a kid's movie (Peter Pan since you asked) was playing at the theater at 4pm. We raced across the city (from mission) at 3:30 to get to the Presidio. I'd called around mid afternoon to ask if I should purchase tickets in advance on phone or online, and was told "(pause...) no, just come before the movie."

ok. So we arrive at 4:15 panting :) and the theater folks look really surprised when we try to pay for the movie. Then theater folkperson says "Oh, sorry, no kids showed up for the 4pm show, so it's not playing today." So - if this isn't clear, we were there to see the show and were told it couldn't be played for us and that we were too late. Then they said: "Next time you should call ahead and let us know you're coming and then we'll know to wait."

?! My issue is not the customer service - I'll spare the messengers. 

My recommendation: Call in advance to reserve a spot for the movie. If you are more than 10 mins late, call in advance and let them know you are coming. Most of all we were so sad. It was PETER PAN!!!
author: Shanta J.

description:
We are huge Disney fans and really enjoyed our visit to the museum. We learned a lot about Walt's early struggles with his business, which was interesting to learn about. Seeing the actual drawings produced by Walt was amazing. The gift shop offered a few original t-shirts, pins and key chains as well as, many other unofficial items. Our t-shirts for adults were $22 plus tax.

This museum is located on the Presidio grounds which are riddled with history, and well worth exploring. You can ride the Presidio bus for free which will take you to the Golden Gate Bridge and into downtown SF. We took advantage of these services, they were really convenient. 

LucasFilm is located in the Presidio too, and you can visit their front lobby to see true to size replicas of Darth Vader and Boba Fett, and see the Yoda fountain located in the courtyard as you enter LucasFilm's lobby area.

The museum offers a AAA discount which saved us $5 per adult ticket.
author: C. B.

description:
I grew up in Southern CA and went to Disneyland ALL THE TIME.  I was  also one of the many college students who had a job there every summer.  This museum is basically a showcase of the Disney Family including old photos, home videos, and interactive media that featured Walt's work.  I was surprised to see all the Oscars displayed out front including the one he won for Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.  So cool!

I really enjoyed watching old videos of the animators and hearing Walt tell his stories.  There's also a HUGE miniature Disneyland display that lights up when the lights are turned down.  

This place is a must-go for any Disney fan.  There's lots of nostalgia and they do a great job focusing on Walt Disney's creativity, vision, and ingenuity without it feeling like the Disney Store or propaganda.
author: Nina L.

description:
Thought this place would be amazing by all the good reviews, but I was highly disappointed. I love museums, but I'd never come back here again. Not a kids museum, mostly reading and watching with a few interactive displays. If you plan on reading every piece of writing, watching all the videos and listening to all the little telephone voices then come early, you will need the extra time. The location was beautiful and the museum set up was nice. I was told it was called "The Walt Disney Museum" so I was expecting something more kid friendly and exciting. "The Walt Disney Family Museum" is more history of disney (the person), film and animation, not so much focused on the charcters. 


Oh and there is no photography allowed in the museum and since I love pictures, that was kind of a downer for me.

Not worth the $20 admission
author: Alicia L.

description:
As many other reviews have pointed out, this is a MUSEUM - there are some kid-centric displays but overall it's really more targeted to adults. That said, I loved it. I've always found DIsney to be a fascinating company, and it was great to learn about its evolution. This place is also a lot larger than I expected; my feet were pretty tired by the end of it so be sure to wear comfortable shoes!

The only reason I won't give the museum 5 stars is because I was a little disappointed in the customer service. Maybe I'm biased, but when the Disney name is attached to something, I expect Disney-caliber service. Don't get me wrong, the employees were friendly on the whole, but I expected more.

Tip: If you know when you're going, be sure to buy your tickets online in advance!

Value: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Ambiance: 5 stars
author: Shannon B.

description:
If you're a history buff who loves biographies, this would be a good museum to look at particulary how one becomes so successful like Walt Disney who built an empire that still exists today.

There's alot of reading and can be daunting to get through but I enjoyed looking at the old family photos of Walt Disney and how they spend together as a family.  

Definitely not for kids.  Overpriced for a 6 year old which is my daughter 's age who was looking for the Disney princesses in the museum.  The walkway of glass where you see the Golden Gate is breathtaking which leads to a spiral walkway with a view of miniature Disneyland.
author: Salena M.

description:
Beautiful museum ! Not really for children.
My recommendation is to have headsets and give everyone a condensed version.
Tried to find a comment box, but none
author: Kris M.

description:
I guess depending on how you read it, the name could be misleading. Is it the "Walt Disney Family" Museum? or Is it the "Walt Disney" Family Museum?

I suspect it's the former because anyone under the age of 16 would probably not find this very fun or interesting. Not a good Family Museum if the kids are bored out of their mind.

In any case, I think the Museum itself is beautiful. There's such a huge variety of things to look at. As you walk through the museum, it's also a nice historical lesson in the art of cartoons.

If you're a huge Disney fan, I'm sure you'll love this place. If you're just a casual fan like myself, you probably won't be able to share the same appreciation in some of the artifacts.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
This is review is for that b$#*h that sells you the tickets.

I came here last Saturday and before I bought my ticket I asked if they give military discounts. The lady replied "well are you active duty?" I told her no but my husband is while trying to show her my military i.d. She said "we only give discounts to active duty members, not there families."

Well I get home and check online turns out anyone in active duty, veteran, OR THERE FAMILIES get in for free.

 Well thank you so much..
author: Chelsea W.

description: More for adults than kids. Strollers not allowed past lobby. Still its very interesting and we loved it.
author: Kasey S.

description:
Loved it!  For anyone interested in animation or has ever watched a Disney film, this is a must-see site.
I found it to be very inspirational as well as educational to see how Mr. Walt Disney overcame the many obstacles in order to live a life of innovation and passion.  Will want to visit again some time as we went there later in the afternoon and ran out of time towards the end.
author: Jessica L.

description: Phenomenal. The stuff that they have here is great but the presentation was also very good. I was expecting a somewhat boring museum but that wasn't the case at all. And holy crap, is that Disneyland diorama awesome. Overall, i highly recommend this place to any Disney fans.
author: Alex B.

description: It was pretty cool. There wasn't a lot of people so it was a bit chill. We enjoyed learning about Walt Disney and his family and his success. It was quite cool. There's a lot to see with lots of pictures. Eventually we just went through it pretty fast. It took us about 1.5 hours to go through the whole museum but we did speed up a bit and not look at every single detail. If you are the type that wants to see everything, then it'll probably take about 3 hours. $20/person + $1/hour for parking on weekdays. I loved the mini Disneyland model towards the end of the museum.
author: Nari L.

description:
This is a stunning museum!  The exhibits were breath-taking, I especially loved the "Silly Symphonies" exhibit.  It brought me right back to when I was 6 years old seating on my Grandmother's floor, staring up at the TV mesmerized by "Ferdinand the Bull" or the "Grasshopper and the Ants" or, my favorite, "The Old Mill."

If you are a fan of Walt Disney this is a must-see!  The museum is broken down into periods of Disney's life from childhood to his untimely passing.  It was interesting to see his ups and downs, perseverance, and eventual rise as the creator of "The Happiest Place On Earth." Not only does the museum highlight Disney as the entrepreneur but also as a family man and loved employer.  It goes without saying, you'll probably learn something you never knew about this American icon.  

However, I would caution those with kids, if you're expecting "Disneyland" this isn't it...it really is a museum and it takes a while to look through all the exhibits so be prepared for restlessness in your youngsters.
author: Amber G.

description:
First of all, it upsets me to see people giving this place low scores because they obviously don't know what a museum is. Why don't you do some reading about the place before going? It's non-profit, it's going to be pricey. It's the WALT DISNEY FAMILY museum, not the MICKEY MOUSE museum; it's Walt's life from beginning to end. Right there you should realize that it's most likely not a place for little kids. Someone said you could do the museum in an hour if you don't like reading everything -- then what's the point of even going? It's hard to swallow that ignorant people like that were even able to find the place or even know how to setup a Yelp account.

Now that I have that out of my system, I can begin my review. Disney enthusiasts beware!!! Give yourself 3 hours or more to see the entire exhibit -- I'm not exaggerating. I went in twice giving myself 2 1/2 hours each time and I STILL haven't had the chance to read everything. You are overwhelmed with so many amazing facts about Walt and his life!

The staff are incredibly courteous. They are always letting guests know that they'll happily answer any questions about that content. I've overheard some of the conversations guests have had with them and you can tell they are real Disney enthusiasts which is great to know.

I learned a lot about Walt's life and everything that lead up to the creation and success of Mickey Mouse among other amazing achievements. There are some items in the museum I couldn't believe they had! Early sketches, really old merchandise, and much more. I must warn my fellow Disney enthusiasts one more time: the ending will make you cry.

There's a nice little gift shop at the end with lots of great goodies. Next to it is a little cafe as well. The museum even has a little theatre downstairs where they show all kinds of classics. Today they were showing Lady and the Tramp. They also have various events going on throughout the month so check their calendar. On Valentine's Day I saw that they had some kind of wine and movie thing going on -- pretty sweet, huh?! An excellent place to bring a date -- you have a marvelous view of the Golden Gate Bridge. I've been twice so far and I'll be coming more often. Maybe I should become a member?

P.S. $20 regular admission or $15 with student ID. Parking is free and there's tons of it in their lot. Have fun!
author: Jonny A.

description:
Note: I'm not a *HUGE* Disney fan so this is a review from the 18 to 24 demographic who just happen to like going to museums.

I came here with a co-worker and we made it to the last entry time at 4:45 PM. I can definitely see why the museum has chose to put an hour and fifteen minute buffer before close (where most museums cut off at about half an hour prior to close) as navigating the exhibit space takes a great deal of time.

The WDFM is in a very scenic location, but it IS a hassle to get to. Public transit drops you off about 5 minutes away but only if you are in a part of the city where the 43 Masonic or 29 Sunset is nearby. 

Occasionally you can take the "Presidigo" from the gate, but that depends on the time of day and the shuttle driver.

Now, as to the actual museum? It is a very INFORMATIVE museum, with lots of old relics, photos, and excerpts about Walt's life. It felt very old time-y in the first gallery; senior groups must LOVE this place. I felt a bit uncomfortable with all those vacant flapper eyes starrin' at me from the video screens.

As an animation geek and illustrator, I got a kick out of all the production art and sketches you find further along into the galleries.

We also played an interactive musical game where you try to replicate the soundtrack from Steamboat Willie.

I was still feeling overwhelmed when we got to the back of the building, where you can use the restroom (Nicest restroom ever. SERIOUSLY, it was immaculate). Following the restrooms there is a large glass wall, with a great view of the GG Bridge and the floor is done up all shiny and modern. Then you get the coolest part, which I won't spoil totally, but the theme is EPCOT. Super cool model city in there. 

After that the museum gets a little creepy, with the white walls, crying Mickey Mouses, political cartoons-- everything following Walt's Death. We made our way out after a few minutes of that. 


I might come back, but I'd want to go with a Disney Enthusiast who would get more out of the trek to the Presidio. Or just to use those nice, nice bathrooms.
author: Adora S.

description: Awesome!! Love this museum! Learned so much about the history of Walt Disney and it only made me love Disney more. Great place to visit for the family. My kids had a great time looking at all the exhibits especially the mini-Disneyland. So cool!! I want that! Don't remember the price for admission just decided to join as a member. Regardless of price, just go. So worth it. It is located in the Presidio with fantastic views. The whole experience is as close as you get to Disney magic in the Bay. Parking was across the street and it was free.
author: Julie H.

description:
The Disney musuem in the Presidio was far more enjoyable than I thought it'd be, and this from a nonfan of the big D.  

Check it out, it's actually quite well done, with fascinating info on the early history of animation!  Too, more kid-accessible than some if the Yelp reviews led me to believe; my 6yr old was really engaged and enjoyed it much!
author: Ali S.

description:
Came here for a Yelp Elite Event. Loved going through the museum. Wish I had more time. It was nice to see the history of Walt Disney's Life. I especially liked seeing the hand drawn images (early Mickey, too). Boy, has he gotten prettier. Also, I liked the explanation of the multi-plane camera, and the model of Disneyland.

I need more time to go through the museum store too and try more goodies from the Wolfgang Puck Cafe. I can def. see spending hours here.
author: Anita C.

description: This was one of the best museums I have been too!!! Definately plan in spending 2 or more hours there, we were there for 4. There is lots of fun stuff to see. Plus special exhibits depending on when you visit. Well worth the $20 a person to get in, plus they let you take photos which was awesome. I agree with other reviews that this is more for older children and adults. Lots of history and fun facts though.
author: Heather P.

description:
Once upon a time in a land not so far away

A princess lay bored in her castle one day.

"Woe is me" she crooned and let out a large sigh
"If I have to sit at home all day I simply will die"
And just as she was about to give up all hope
A voice called out across the slimy sidewalk moat. 
And there to her great surprise
Stood a handsome knight.... with dreamy eyes.
Before she could think, she was swept off her feet
Her new beau assured her she was in for a treat.

Over bridges, through forests, they quickly traveled across the land
The journey was much quicker than they had planned.
Plenty of parking for the horse and carriage
The princess didn't notice, she was busy day-dreaming bout marriage. 

"So tell me princess, what do you know of your family history?"
"Sadly dear prince, it's quite the mystery." 
"Ah well then have no fear! That is why I have brought you here.... I believe this museum will help make things clear."

A small 20 dollar fee 
sent them off to learn all about Grandfather Disney. 
Exhibit after exhibit, information packed onto each floor
So much to learn, discover, and explore. 
Hours were spent with the man, the movies, and the mouse
They felt like honored guests in Disney's house. 
The princess was happy that she now knew
How her unique and great family grew. 

Walt Disney was a man who should be admired
His life and work left the Princess inspired.
His legacy reminded her life isn't as complicated as it seems
And that you should never give up on your dreams.

The day came to a close, it was time to go
Satisfied, they left the museum with hearts aglow
Riding  off into the distance, they filled the air with laughter
Smiling, the princess knew they were headed to happily ever after. 

:)
author: Caroline J.

description:
Some advice:

1) Do not be fooled by the woman collecting tickets who says there are only two galleries on the first floor and the upstairs. Sounds like there isn't much right? WRONG! There are SO MANY ROOMS! Especially upstairs!! So, give yourself some time to look through it. My sister and I took 2 hours and we ended up having to rush at the end because we had to make dinner reservations. 

2) The more "interesting" stuff is at the end...well at least for most people. I was completely fascinated by the first few rooms because I love learning more about Walt Disney. My sister was upset by the fact that we wasted so much time in the first rooms and didn't get to really look at the end. What's at the end? More information on Disneyland!!  The beginning is the history, then about his career progression and then finally Disneyland and Disney world/epcot plans. 

3) This is not really for children. There are parts they will find entertaining but overall it isn't really geared towards kids. Plus, how are you supposed to enjoy it if your kid is constantly pushing you from room to room. I think other patrons would also be happy to have you leave the kids at home. I heard a couple people say (in response to a particularly annoying child), "Ugh, why do people bring kids to these things?"

Look at the yelp pictures and you'll see that they feature a mini mock up of Disneyland. This of course isn't the actual Disneyland you see today but you can see some old rides that they used to have!

Look up directions cause getting to this place can be tricky, especially for tourists!

Overall I loved it! It is kind of overwhelming how much Disney was able to accomplish and how unbelievably creative he was.
author: Jessica F.

description: I was ready for this to be a really FUN place, and it was, but not the "fun" I expected.  Get ready for A LOT of reading.  I was a bit exhausted by the end of it and found myself skipping occasional parts because of all the text there was to read.  I enjoyed learning about Walt though - what a guy!  There could have been more things to watch considering he made films but, for $20, it was amazing value for money.  Definitely check it out, but be prepared to spend 3hrs in there - I did!
author: Lauren M.

description: The museum is almost all drawings! I got bored real quick. Lacking "Disney magic"
author: Bridget O.

description:
I'm a huge fan of whatever Disney. So when the opportunity for a free admission came my way, I had to take a look. The museum features the history, the tribute of Walt Disney himself and the empire he built. The place takes one to the journey from the very beginning to the legacy that still lives on. There is so much to explore here...go see for yourself. 

The museum is located in Presidio of SF. Beautiful scenery. Plentiful parking.
author: Dee T.

description:
If you are entrepreneur in a creative field, this is a mecca location.
The ups, the downs, the bankruptcy  letter, the memos to staff, to affiliates... it's all here!  Read Read Read every morsel!  :)

Get some!
author: Dan M.

description:
Wow. I think, absolutely one of the best museums in the Bay Area. Heck, California, USA.

While I am a Disney fan, I felt this museum had something for most people over the age of 13 or so. Whether you're a creative, a film buff, a historian, a techie or a Disneyphile, there's at least a few galleries, if not all, that would entertain and hold your attention.

I loved the wonderful details in the exhibits which follow the life of Walt Disney, showcasing his highlights and even a low-light or two. The amount of thought in creating this journey for the viewer is pretty neat when you realize that the museum is truly and thoughtfully designed for you, the visitor. 

***Warning: Minor Spoilers Ahead***

The beginnings of Walt's life is a simple narration from an old recording of his voice but is elevated by a lively animation. And just below the LCD screen, a little train quietly chugs by in a long, horizontal, glass window. Lovely! For those hard of hearing - like me - there's closed captioning available at many of the stations. 

As a whole, the space is well-designed, guiding you into the different spaces chronologically. There's still freedom to move organically (and sit here and there.) The galleries are warm and inviting and it's a fully immersive environment to support the gallery content.

There's always something to play with your visual, hearing and tactile senses. Recordings from those associated with Walt (adding great personalization) are available and galleries with different medias to explore: videos, phone handsets, techie hands-on stations, short films, photographs, ephemera, original concept art, collector's items, maquettes, replicas, models and more. There's originality like visiting a mini-projected Dick Van Dyke hanging out on an Optical Printer - and he'll explain to you about that Disney-invented technology.

Not only is the content and technology diverse but the manner in how they draw you in can be sincerely surprising and inspiring. I ate up a lot of time viewing a library of digital imagery that encompassed a vast number of subjects. They've projected an interactive interface on a ledge that allows you to choose topics spanning from A to almost Z. For Mary Blair fans there is a satiating amount of work showcased in the form of digital imagery (under several different subject headings) and original concept art. 

Another highlight is the 20 ft diameter model of the original Disneyland. You approach it first from an ariel view and then are able to get closer and peek into it at an eye level if you're okay with crouching down. If you look into Tomorrowland they even drew in the detail of Mary Blair's original murals that once lived there.

There's lovely thought in adding emotion to the galleries, like the announcement of Walt Disney's death. A carefully designed display is built, honoring how one would have heard the news in 1966. I think because of this, many people are surprised at how moved they are when encountering this section (as some of the Yelpers here have expressed.) And as you are carried along after hearing and reading about his passing, they symbolically and elegantly remind you that Walt's legacy lives on. 

For a detailed listing of technological specs and gallery subjects, you can read up here:
http://www.e-architect.co.uk/san_francisco/walt_disney_family_museum.htm
author: Thanh T.

description:
I've never been a fan of Disneyland and all the walk-around characters.  But as a lover of animation (and member of ASIFA-SF), I like this place so much, I became a member.  This means I can bring a guest for free, get into certain exhibits and screenings for free, and get (small) discounts on certain events.  Unlike Disneyland, it's more quiet, and more history-oriented.

I've been to fabulous exhibits on Snow White and Maurice Sendak, and I just heard about an upcoming exhibit of Italian animator Bruno Bozzetto, who has created some wonderful films worth learning about.

The staff is very friendly, and the atmosphere is breathtaking.  You'll be glad you came here.
author: Guillermo G.

description:
I am amazed by how many self-identified Disney fans are unaware of this gem here, not in Southern California where the company is based, but here in San Francisco.

This museum is somewhat exclusively about the man. The first official gallery is about his childhood. It takes you chronologically. Do not expect to see information about "The Little Mermaid" or Pixar. The museum reminds attendees that Disney(R) was not always the billion-dollar juggernaut it is today. Walt had triumphs like Mickey Mouse and Snow White but also failures, and failures that would later be considered successes.

The museum attempts to tell Walt's story through as much of Walt's words and images as possible. There are dozens of televisions and telephones throughout the museum with the voice of Walt and his family and artists. 

The museum is laid out beautifully. There is a lot of video, original artwork, props, models, and collectibles sure to make the biggest Disney salivate. In addition, the museum displays many of Walt's personal effects, home movies and photographs. My favorite parts of the museum are the walkway in which viewers are inundated with animation from post-WWII, and the gallery highlighting Disneyland, with an impressive animated model of the park, television, and the World's Fair. Many guests skip over the display of a large special camera towards the end of this gallery. Be sure to pick up the receiver and watch a miniature Dick Van Dyke explain it to you.

I agree with another attendee that this is not a Disneyland attraction. Although there are a lot of familiar characters and interactivity, some children may find it boring. There is a lot of information to soak in here that will likely educate even the most informed Disney fan. Depending on how much you want to soak up, it is possible to spend hours here reading and looking. The museum costs $20 for the average adult. It behooves one spend a lot of time for this price.

On a personal note, one of my favorite Disney artists is heavily featured throughout the museum. This is Mary Blair, best known for the flat, colorful, graphic, playful work that inspired much of "Three Caballeros" and "it's a small world." I enjoy seeing her original work, the bottom floor inspired by IASW concept art, and prints of some of her pieces in the museum gift shop.
author: Amanda H.

description:
What a great museum! We spent three hours here & could spend even more.
This isn't a museum of Disneyland or Disneyworld, but rather Walt Disney himself. And he is interesting enough to spend time learning about. This museum showcases the different opportunities he had or made to become the well-known man he is today; including many personal stories, pictures, awards and even home movies.
This museum is clean, the staff is friendly and the location is in the Presidio.
A must see!
author: Kathy S.

description:
I was totally taken in by this place. It goes through the whole history of the man we mortals know as Walt Disney. One thing you find is that Walt and the Walt Disney Company are impossible to fully distinguish from one another.

The whole museum flows similarly to a Disney attraction. Your preload area is big and bright and adorned with little bits of eye candy. Just like a Disney attraction you can also see the gift shop from the preload. 

Biggest thing to note: no pictures allowed! Yeah, this comes from aforementioned fusion between man and company. The Walt Disney Company has nothing to do with this place and, therefore, makes no money from it. Since they are not making any money from your memory making excursion, you must keep your memories the old fashioned way. Between your ears and behind the eyes.

The museum starts with Walt's story from before he was alive and ends, kind of morbidly, with his death. It is packed with artifacts and multimedia displays. Many of which come from the Disney family or the Disney Company vaults. The big finish before the total bummer (death bits) is a classic Disney move: giant model of Disneyland.

For more animation minded folk: you can skip virtually the whole first section and the last section. The gooey middle has your fix. Spend time with Oswald the Lucky Rabbit. Mickey's older and way more awesome brother. He will buy you beer if your underage (that cool).

Do not take kids. Please. If your kid sucks (be honest with yourself here okay?) and has more in common with Victorian glazed bricks keep them tied to a tree out back. This place is for the older set, both in mind and vintage. However, they do run a movie series here and it could be the only time you or your child(ren) will see a  Disney classic on the silver screen.

The gift shop is sorry. Nothing of value or interest really, but it is not their fault. Again, since Walt and the Walt Disney Company are stuck like glue, they can only sell Disney stuff that the Disney Company approves.

Despite the negatives, you run into kindred walking through and I spent an hour talking with a dear old lady that was a secretary in the Ink & Paint department in 1956. Free bonus material! Go, see, experience, and curse your family if alzheimer's runs in the family, because your memories are all you get of here.
author: Mitchell M.

description:
This is definitely the first museum that I've been to where I looked at and read almost everything.  I was there for a little over three hours and had to rush through the end because my stomach was growling from hunger!

Be forewarned that this museum is truly dedicated to the life of Walt Disney and is not really meant for kids, as it is a ton of reading.  Everything was really interesting and I was just amazed at how much stuff the Disney family kept from the old days.  I really loved the gallery dedicated to Steamboat Willie and the synchronized music game was a lot of fun although I sucked at it.  It was so cool looking at all the pictures that they drew in order to produce 1 minute of the cartoon!

Seeing how much Walt contributed to animation (from the first black and white cartoons to creating full movies in technicolor) really makes me admire him that much more.

It was so easy to lose track of time in that museum.  Even though it was a lot of reading, I was nowhere near bored.  Definitely plan to spend a good four hours or so there to really go through all the galleries.

WARNING: prolonged exposure at the Walt Disney Family Museum can result in catching the Mickey Mouse fever, so be prepared to start planning a trip to "The Happiest Place on Earth" as soon as you get home!  ~ I know I'll definitely be putting my Premium Annual Pass to good use, haha ;)
author: Katelynn L.

description:
pretty informative museum about the life of walt disney, which makes me want to check out some autobiographies on his life now. there is a ton of reading in small print, so it's not really a museum for kids. it was pretty informative though with a ton of things to look at. the model of disneyland in the 60's was my favorite part of the entire museum.

also, after coming here, the siblings and i planned a trip to disneyland. see you next week disneyland!!!
author: Melanie C.

description: Came here with a Travel Zoo coupon and paid $10 per adult instead of $20 each. Then paid an additional $10 each for the Snow White exhibit. I liked the Snow White exhibit more than the regular museum part. It was more interesting I thought. In Disney fashion, it was more interactive and fun compared to a regular museum. They had the Disney magic in there from the flow of the rooms to the music and colors and videos in each area, to cool looking historical toys and memorabilia. And at the end, they direct you to the store. If I didn't have the coupon, it would have cost $30 instead of $20 to visit this place, which is a little steep I think, which is also kind of in Disney fashion. :(  We parked outside along the street for only a dollar or two.
author: Vivian L.

description: Museum was fun and informative. Disney's innovations and drawings are nice to see along with his history.  Presido was beautiful and windy/colder.
author: Troy M.

description:
If you are from the bay area, you must, I mean you MUST check this place out! I know there are people still out there that love disney's cartoons. What most people neglect is the man that created it. This man is incredibly talented and this museum gives him the full validation. I had a great experience. It took roughly 2+ hours to go through the museum, and it was well worth the time. Don't forget to check out the restrooms downstairs, extra exhibit and the gift shop.

$20 admission 
$15 if your a student
Plenty of parking space
author: Johnson B.

description:
Review No. 7 

* _______________________ 
*[                                                   ]
*[                THE WALT               ] 
*[                                                   ] 
*[                D I S N E Y                ] 
*[                                                   ] 
*[                F A M I L Y                ] 
*[                                                   ] 
*[                MU SE UM                ] 
*[_______________________] 

Eric W.'s review of the preopening of The Walt Disney Family Museum not only depicted precisely the whole picture of this amazing event of Walt Disney's vision, genius and life. I can only add that on October 1st, if you should go to the opening day to check out the Learning Center and the Auditorium which was not open and the security guard informed me that it will not be opened until that day. 

Wolfgang Puck is the food master for the small, very small Cafe (6 tables for seating of 4). Not all the food was available, mostly snacks. The salads displayed (The Fall, Mediterranean, and the Beet Salad) were delish but very small and expensive. The baby cupcakes were $2.50 each!!!!! Bring your own and eat outside where they have a couple of tables. No food upstairs for the Museum viewing. 

If you're in the creative field of painting,drawing, animation, architect, etc. - you will looooove this museum! My brother is an architect and a life member fan of Walt Disney. He was salivating and ohhhhh and ahhhhhhhs I thought I had to get him a resuscitation kit.
author: Marian G.

description:
Very nice, tasteful museum. Definitely for adults. I asked a docent how long one would need to really absorb the best of the museum and she said four hours. After seeing the museum, I'd say that's pretty accurate. I, however, only had about one hour there, and I had a great time anyway. 

They have hundreds of cool old awards and art deco trophies. Also sketches, letters, photos, tons and tons of artifacts from his career and personal life.

Mostly, I wanted to see the big Disneyland model, because some movie modelmaker friends worked on it. It's cool! I could have spent half an hour just checking out all if the little details. Probably even cooler if you've actually been to Disneyland. (Yes, I KNOW.) 

If you're interested in Walt Disney himself, do set aside some time to enjoy this place.
author: Karen Z.

description: Pretty cool place if you're into the life of Walt Disney and his early work. Personally, I wasn't too fascinated about everything in there but I'm not going to deny 5 stars because it had nice, well-organized galleries. It worked like a time-line. The Disneyland model and Ugly Duckling clips were the best. Great location and parking. Don't forget your student ID or AAA for a discount. :)
author: Allyson L.

description:
Located in a remodeled building in the Presidio with stunning views of the Bay and Golden Gate Bridge, the Walt Disney Family Museum is more of a history and celebration of Walt Disney, the man himself, and not necessarily of the Disney corporation. Parents should bear this in mind when thinking about taking the kids, as those looking to catch a glimpse of Selena Gomez, Zack and Cody, and London Tipton paraphernalia will be sorely disappointed. Also, be sure to inform the little ones that there are no rides or a giant Pooh or Mickey strolling around the premises.

What we are treated to is a stunning collection of original drawings and inspirations of the incomparable Mr. Disney. It should be thought of as an educational experience rather than entertainment. The museum is broken up into about 10 rooms, each representing a certain phase in the development of the vaunted Disney brand, starting from the birth of the man who would become a legend, all the way until the day he took his last breath. As mentioned, any Disney related items post-Walt are not included, unless he specifically had a hand in it himself.

The best thing is that, unlike the actual Disneyland, parking is free and abundant. The exterior of the buiding is very non-descript, with no mouse ears or any of that pizazz and neon you would normally expect from a Disney production. You would never even know what this place was without checking the small sign up front.

My favorite Yelper and I were invited to a special "soft opening" on 9/20, so not everything was fully functional, but it seemed about 90% complete. We spent a little over two hours, but one could easily stay much longer, as we didn't necessarily take the time to read every single capsule or play with the interactive kiosks. We already had more than enough to keep us occupied. The normal rate is going to be $20, which is the typical of museums of this ilk, but for those on a budget, can be somewhat pricy, especially if adding up the costs for a family of 4 or more.

Here are some of the highlights and general observations:

Totally out of this world awesomeness:
-Miniature replica of the original Disneyland, which is set up at the bottom of a long winding staircase, giving you a bird's eye view of all the rides and attractions. Even more impressive is that a few of the set pieces actually move, almost like an elaborate model train set. For the enclosed buildings, the roof has been removed to give a peek inside.

-Allotted time slots for visitors. This helps a great deal with crowd control, especially since the layout is set up as one long queue instead of allowing everyone to roam freely. The ushers are also very polite and helpful, sporting the popular blue and gold Disneyland unis!

-Collection of original marketing memorabilia. It's been said that in modern times, pop culture icons are oversaturated, appearing on everything from lunch pails to underwear to silverware. Heck, this isn't anything new. It all started back in the day with one famous little Mouse.

-Actual frame by frame cells from the original animation. It takes at least 700 frames to produce less than one minute of video. Credit is also given to Walt Disney's associates and fellow animators, who were just as integral in the creation of characters and movies.

Could use a little work:
-Only two unisex bathrooms on the second floor for this huge facility. Even on a preview day, which was likely not to full capacity, there was a line at least 3-4 deep. I don't want to know how it would look on a holiday weekend when things are in full swing.

-Gift shop is rather disappointing. I did walk away with a cool Mickey Mouse mug featuring raw animation sketches, but that was probably one of the few nifty things I saw. I'm not sure what type of licensing agreement they have with Disney itself, but there was NONE of the normal stuffed animals, magnets, keychains, pens, etc. you would find at Disneyland, or even the Disney store at Any Mall, USA. Instead, there is a plethora of random, non-Disney related items, such as bracelets, earrings, art books and drafting pencils. I guess this is intentionally done to further separate the museum as a place of learning rather than entertainment.

Upon leaving the Walt Disney Family Museum, one can't help but be awed and inspired by the genius of Mr. Walt Disney. This was a man with a vision and unwordly talent, but above all, the determination to make the world better place. From all accounts, he has succeeded in his quest with flying colors. However, as great as he ended up being, the museum makes a point not to immortalize him, instead pointing out his failed business ventures when starting out, and his struggles when first arriving in Hollywood dealing with upscrupulous distributors taking advantage of his unbelievable skills. The rest, as they say, is history...

Come witness this amazing history for yourself starting October 1, 2009!
author: Eric W.

description:
i am a BIG Disneyland fan!!! I love  disneyana but i'm not that hardcore to subscribe to D23 or go to conventions. the red brick building is unassuming as with all the buildings in the presidio . once you walk pass the glass case containing all the Oscar awards Walt Disney won especially the Snow White and the 7 Dwarfs with the mini Oscars WOW!!!  
the museum is very modernistic with the interactive features  making it an all sensory overload of pictures and sound. there is a lot of things to read and I took my 6.5 year old son who wanted to run & climb the displays. it's not a good place for young children b/c there's a lot of stuff I couldn't read b/c I had to keep an eye on him. My favourite thing was the miniature Disneyland with moving parts one word AWESOME!!!I would recommend as other posters to spend at least 2 to 3 hours to look and READ everything. wear comfortable shoes and bring something to drink & snack for later. they have a gift shop and café with Disneyland prices HIGH!!!

sadly i found out Walt Disney's daughter Diane recently passed away. I learned she co-founded the museum. I can see the love she put into the museum: it is a beautiful wonderful tribute to her father.
 there is a  letter toward the end of the tour about her father's passing that brought tears to my eyes and other people who read it. thank you for this beautiful museum a testament of the wonderful imagination of her father!!!
author: Jo K.

description: It was a really interesting experience to see the history of one of the world's most loved animators. I'm a big fan of Disney but didn't realize how many times Walt had to re-invent himself and and his art. The building that the museum was made in was  really cool as well.
author: Stephen S.

description:
On this past Sunday I met up with a Disney friend from LA and two of his good friends for what turned out to be a very full day at the Mecca of Disney geekatude, the Walt Disney Family Museum. I thought couple of hours and then lunch and then home to relax the remainder of the Sunday afternoon away. I was wrong, we got there at 11, broke for brunch (word to the wise, avoid La Terasse, it's barely passable, that review is elsewhere) and then back to the museum until closing time, 6pm. 

I neither saw everything nor absorbed everything, but what I saw was truly, truly amazing.  The WDFM is a project not of Disney in Burbank (though I am guessing some items shown are from Disney Burbank and I suspect the Disney Archive, too), but many personal items courtesy Diane Disney Miller and Disney Family. The mission, in a nutshell, is to bring this story back to the beginning and show who Walt Disney was and what he accomplished. They succeed in this 110%. 

The WDFM is beautifully laid out in a repurposed building in the Presidio and comprises 10 galleries encompassing Walt's life, his achievements. In the lobby are the awards (including the very cool Snow White special Academy Award which I never thought I'd see, it's really quite huge). 

In the lobby, before you enter the first gallery is a reproduction of a portion of Walt's apartment at the Firehouse in Disneyland. The lamp was on, but as my Disney geek friend commented to me, they should have had a photograph behind the window showing the view down Main Street behind the sheer curtains. I agree, that is one cool touch they could add. Anyone listening? 

You really do need to pace yourself, the mind exploding stuff increases with so much incredible stuff as you move from gallery to gallery. It is all beautifully presented. I would really recommend this to be a 2 day trip. 

I had the real pleasure to make my first visit to the WDFM with my friend who is a real Disneyphile and this made the experience extra super special. He has so much knowledge and we spent what had to be a full 90 minutes looking at and examining closely the Disneyland model, alone. That was mind-bending, the Disneyland of my childhood. The model is amazingly detailed and to get the story behind some of the things shown in this model was a real treat. Let me mention here the WDFM staff are super friendly and all do seem to realize they work in a very special environment. 

Do not miss this when you come to SF. So many of the exhibits are very interactive and fun. Not merely geared to the kids, it's for the kid in all of us. Extreme nostalgia factor. It's all laid out beautifully, designed fabulously. The attention to detail in the presentation, is so great, loads of little touches. In gallery 5, Fantasia, Pinnochio and Bambi, there is an animator's table reproduced, on the desk is a radio, of course the narrative is coming from the radio. Awesome little details like this are sprinkled throughout. It was, quite simply, one of the most exciting museums I've ever been to. 

My special moments of geek, the display from the Ink & Paint Department, a wall of bottles of Technicolor cell paints from the studio. Still bright as Technicolor! To stand above and at the multiplane camera (in the gift shop, we got to push buttons, nothing worked but it was SO cool) there is a background painting from Bambi on the glass (I'm sure a repro, but the effect is as if the camera would be working right now). To see some original Eyvind Earle (sp?) concept art on Sleeping Beauty and Mary Blair concept paintings on Peter Pan that were just astonishingly beautiful. Again, the model, the model of Disneyland. 

A special moment of geekness for me, on display an AtomMobile from the Mighty Microscope from the defunct Monsanto Adventure Thru Inner Space (it was my favorite ride as a young kid, might have had something to do with it being cool in there, but I was and still am a science geek). Also, in the Disneyland Model among many wonderful things, Adventure Thru Inner Space back where it belongs.  

Then, you are hit in the gut and brought back to reality as you come to the end of Walt's life. It was quite sobering, emotional and affecting. You are brought fully to the realization of how much Walt Disney did and what a creative force he was. The last room is what I would call a slice of heaven to ease you out of the shock of Gallery 10. A fabulous looping video of Walt, quotes by and about him and photos of so much work he produced and inspired. I'm paraphrasing, but the quote from Rolly Crump summed it up for me. "He called us His Geniuses, but we were inspired because he believed in us." A great way to end the day and a great summation of who Walt Disney was. 

Photography is NOT allowed.   Awesome, not to be missed if you know or love anything about Disney.  This brought it all home to me.
author: Donna H.

description: Not for kids. About Disney's life and career. The cafe food isn't that good and it's very expensive (and I live in NYC so I know expensive food).
author: Molly E.

description:
I too am not a Disney fanatic and am pretty turned off by the current Disney empire that dumbs down and vanilla-ize anything it touches-and there's now a Disney resort in Hawaii-i.e. Aulani--a supposed recreation of a Hawaiian paradise--really Disney?  Is that really necessary?  
But... I've always been very fond of the Disney classics and wanted to take my 13 year old daughter to see what I thought would be some cool sketches of some of his original creations...We found this and a whole lot more.  I was very impressed to find a truly excellent museum that was very well laid out and very detailed without being dry.  Wtih each room we entered I went one direction and my daughter another --both stopping along the way to point out exhibits of interest.   For such a compact space it packs in alot but there's a lot to be said about Disney's contribution to animation, cinema, American culture, etc. etc. 
And they couldn't have chosen a more gorgeous location -- the views of the GGB are stunning.
author: Shaki S.

description:
The Walt Disney Family Museum tells two histories. It provides visitors with an in depth, creative and cool walk through the life and imagination of Walt Disney himself. At the same time it also lays out an interesting educational look into the early years of animated shorts. 

This museum is chalked full of interactive exhibits allowing visitors that opportunity to hear audio commentary for early illustrators, employees from the Disney studio color lab and actors. There also exercises in matching music to character and sound effects to soundtrack. 

Intertwined in the history of Disney's empire, is the story that is the birth and growth of Disney's own family. Lilly Disney and the couple's two daughters along with their families are all represented here. It is really a touching tender and intimate look at the man behind the far reaching Disney culture. 

Some of the most memorable points of interest for me: 

- Disney Studio's work during WWII -- some of the signs and poster art displayed are entertaining! Image Donald Duck warning bugs to stay out of the victory garden and Mickey Mouse throwing gunk in the der Fuhrer's face!! 
- The expansive model of early Disneyland! It's amazing how much of the original is still there! 
- Video footage introducing, "It's a Small World." 
- Video explaining animatronics used to manufacture a display where Abe Lincoln appears on stage and gives talks to visitors at the NY World Fair and during the early days of Disneyland. It is positively creepy!! We're talking Honest Abe giving talks from the grave!! 
- A photo of Mr. Disney with the first two children to ever enter Disneyland. 
- An entire wall (and it is a long wall) of editorial cartoons and telegrams expressing the grief and sadness over the Mr. Disney's death. Very touching!! 

This museum will make you nostalgic for your childhood, inspire you to use your imagination and touch your heart. What an amazing legacy!! 

NOTE: Despite the Disneyland connection and the great vestige to childhood, I do not recommend taking young kids here. Our kindergartener had a very hard time holding attention or interest. Many of the topics were technically and emotionally beyond his grasp. Our eight-year-old however, was fascinated by most of what she saw.
author: Kristine D.

description:
I am giving this a single star for misrepresentation. It should be called: Walt Disney Family HISTORY Museum. While the museum itself is well done, the collection is simply a chronological history of the Disney family and Walt himself. Which, as it turns out, is not terribly interesting to the toddler/pre-K set.  Couple this with the NO stroller/NO touching policy (but in a few designated areas) and you have the recipe for a less than joyful experience.

At bottom, the museum is better suited for adults and older children. The median age on our outing was 60.  Most of whom seemed to be having a lovely time.
author: Ryan R.

description: 2 hours is not enough if you want to know the whole Disney story.  You'll feel like a time traveler as the museum is set up in such a way that you actually feel you are being transported through different eras.  Feelings of nostalgia abound if you've been a fan of anything Disney over the years.  Walt Disney's personal story is interesting. He had very little growing up.  He did have tremendous creative talent, drive, ambition...he took chances and did not give up after failures.  You have to admire him.  The museum is housed in a beautiful building and of course the grounds are gorgeous.
author: Bleep S.

description: This museum was great! It's very informative and provides all the answers to any questions you've ever had about Walt Disney and and anything disney. This is the perfect place to go for fellow disney lovers!  The gift shop was cute, but i felt that the souvenirs were way overpriced. But.. i guess with the name "disney" on it.. it has to be. Parking was pretty good.. $1 an hour.
author: Mertani G.

description:
Woot! Preview passes? Makes me feel like a regular VEEE-EYE-PEEEEEE!!! :) 

Liked that the museum was not too crowded and also liked that it wasn't TOOO HUGE. I was pleasantly surprised though, that they managed to fit sooooo much about the beloved Walt Disney and his craft inside that little bunker building at the Presidio. There were a few kinks here and there, but for a soft opening, I thought it went fabulously well. I loved learning about the earlier Disney productions and hearing more about the man behind the magic. Some real sketches were also available to see as were collections of Mickey Mouse paphernilia, including the "Mouse Getar" HAHAHA...the precourser to Guitar Hero? :)

The entire museum was well laid out but there was so much to see! I did get teary eyed at the end, where it has some info on Disney's death - how could i not? Definitely a great man, who led the way for animated cartoons and film, and definitely a pioneer. 

There's plenty of parking and a cafe as well. The gift store was alright - seemed like a total mishmash of random items...the only gripe i really had was the bathrooms...only two single unisex bathrooms at the 2nd level. Didn't know if there were any at the bottom, but didn't seem so. 

Regular priced admission is about 20 a head (I think)...people who really want to learn about Disney will have a great time here. The exhibits are fun and interactive and definitely kid friendly. Be forewarned --- if you don't like museums or aren't really a museum person, you probably won't like it here. 

Overall, 5 stars to learn about a great man and his art that affected generations! :) Love!
author: Linda C.

description:
After seeing a write up about this museum in the Chronicle a few months ago I put it on my list of things to do the next time I ventured into San Francisco.  This museum is dedicated to the I whole life of Walt Disney and it truly does take several hours to get the most out of the exhibits.  I would say it is more of an adult oriented experience since it covers his early life and his business dealings extensively, though certainly there are exhibits that kids would find interesting.  I also enjoyed seeing the special exhibit on Snow White though wasn't expecting a track to an outlying building to view it.  Again, it was interesting to see the production notes on the artwork and the final cells from the film, but kids might give it a yawn.  On the other hand, the ones that were there seemed to be having a good time so who knows, depends on your kids tolerance for non-interactive entertainment.

My only complaint, and its not really the museums fault, but following the directions on their website I ended up getting lost because of some street closures in the Presidio.  Overall it was worth the trip and, like almost any location in The Presidio, the views of the Golden Gate Bridge are not to be missed.
author: Nolan H.

description:
The place does not look big, but boyyyy does it take awhile to get through all the exhibits if you take your time. My fellow explorers and I were there for about 3.5 hours. We didn't read every single description, but we did take our time to at the least browse each display. The last exhibit was definitely the best exhibit. The lighting, the spiral passage down to the first level, wonderful! I also liked this one station where we could play a game where we match a tune to the animation. I was dancing while playing the game. There were a few interactive stations, but most of them were just for looking/reading/observing. Some displays have audio phones/headphones/speakers for you to listen to. Do not forget to stop by the multi-plane camera section to listen to the audio. It's a short audio clip, but that camera is RADICAL, DUDE! If you are a fan of Walt Disney-any level type of fan, there is no doubt that you will enjoy this museum. Unless you just dislike museums because you think they're boring, this museum should fulfill your interest in Walt Disney.

Don't forget your student ID for student pricing. Drop by the gift shop on your way out!
author: Anna S.

description:
Likes: I thought this would be boring because the place looked so small but it turned out to be very interesting to learn how Disney, Mickey Mouse and Disneyland came to be and how it developed over the years.  I liked it.

Dislikes: no pics allowed
author: Karen M.

description: If you are a fan of the man, or even if you are a bit skeptical of his foresight and courage, then this museum will eliminate the doubt about Walt Disney being a true pioneer in American entertainment.  Things we take for granted today, theme parks, animated movies, character merchandising, never existed until this man paved the way.  Imagine everyone in your closest circles telling you your greatest dreams will never work, that they will ruin you.  What would you do?  Disney forged ahead, and in room after room you understand how innovative and ahead of his time he really was.  Tons and tons of archival video and audio, replicas of Disney attractions and memorabilia, and the most poignant stuff has nothing to do with the movies and parks.  It has to do with the family that inspired Walt to create Disneyland in the first place.  Pictures, video and never before seen home movies of Walt Disney, as always, acting like the big kid he always was. Telegrams tell the not-so flattering story of Disney's animators strike and the fights with the men that tried to ruin him and his brother financially.  There is very little sugar coating of Disney until the very end where his death is reflected upon by quotes and cartoon snippets as classical music plays softly in the background.  There was a lot of love put into this museum, and the attention to detail shows in the pieces collected, the knowledge and helpfulness of the staff, and the importance with which this museum memorializes a man that for better or worse, changed the shape of pop culture forever.  If you enjoy anything Disney, movies, theme parks, cruises, then you will learn more than you thought, but you will come away with a much better appreciation of the risk-takers that were Walt Disney and his under-appreciated brother Roy (without him, Walt Disney World would neither have had a name or kept the vision of what it is today).  Not for young children, but for the kid in all of us, this is a must see attraction in San Francisco.
author: Marc S.

description:
I feel it is only prudent to qualify this review by stating that I am a huge fan of the Disney Parks and have read countless books on Walt Disney. So if those facts give you reason to shrug off my five star rating and look for another opinion by all means please move one. 

However, this is one of the most impressive museums I have ever visited. In fact the Walt Disney Family Museum might be more enjoyable for people who are rather indifferent about Disney. 

If you are a fan of the Academy Awards and have never seen a real Oscar you need to visit WDFM. This is the only place in the world where you can see multiple Oscars and the infamous Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Oscar that Walt Disney received for his ground breaking work on his classic feature length animated film. 

If you are a fan of the history of animation then WDFM is your Mecca. You get to see the evolution of animation from crude flip books to full color stereophonic productions. 

I fully expected to see a lot of drawings and old photos of Walt but I was pleasantly surprised how much of the museum was dedicated to the technological side of animation. There is a Foley setup where you get to try synchronizing sound effects to Steamboat Willie. And best of all there is a full scale multiplane camera on display that is almost two stories tall. Definitely a major display for animation geeks and historians. 

The last few galleries were my favorite part of the museum. I was in awe of the scale model of Disneyland. It was about 20 feet in diameter and had so much detail that I spent at least 20 minutes looking at it from every possible angle. It was particularly fascinating because it wasn't a model of a particular time in Disneyland's history but a representation of what Walt envisioned Disneyland to grow into. Seeing some of the old rides like the Flying Saucers and Adventures Thru Inner Space was really neat. 

The museum ends with a very touching display of political cartoons depicting the world's reaction to the Walt's death in 1966. Growing up in Orange County I always thought Walt was a local hero but seeing how the rest of the planet reacted to his passing really showed how great of a man he was. 

Allow plenty of time for this museum. We spent a little over three hours inside and I know I could go back tomorrow and spend another three hours looking at things I missed. And leave your cameras at home because photography is prohibited.
author: Britt W.

description: Wanna do something different in the city, then try The Walt Disney Museum.  I've been to the Presidio few times and didn't realize this museum existed until recently.  The museum gives you a rare look at Walt Disney's journey to his success and look at some of his early work.  In addition, the theater plays non-stop old Disney flicks.  Great place for kids and those that are kid at heart.
author: Sunny C.

description:
Okay...so this wasn't quite what I was expecting. And, I know my parents were not into it and didn't have the patience for reading and learning on their day off.

That said...this museum is really state of the art, and you get to see what a genius Walt (and Roy) was. 

You can buy tickets online, and it takes at least 1 hour to move through this 2-story museum. 

I'm really not sure how "kid-friendly" this museum is....
author: Misha F.

description:
The Best Museum I've Ever Been To
But enough about me. You should come here if any of the things below apply:
-You love Disney cartoons and movies (never thought I'd be dying to come home and watch Son of Flubber)
-You're interested in the art of cartooning
-You love beautifully planned flow in a museum as well as interior design (what I"m guessing was custom made blue terazzo with sparkling pieces that remind you of Disneyland fireworks)
-Amazing interactive design thrills you. The way the designers coupled motion cartoons with still displays...took still photos and animated them old style. all blew me away.
-Stories of success, failure, luck, and hard work inspire you.
-American history interests  you.
-You are the least bit interested in creativity and innovation in film making.

I could go on...but just go. It's so worth the $20.
author: Susie W.

description: Not really for kids unless they LOVE Disney and want to learn the history of the Man himself and his family. My fiance and I love Disney and can not wait to go back to museum again! The Snow White special exhibit was OK, it would be great if thats your favorite Disney movie.
