But the museum was great so informative and we learned so much about Walt and Roy and the kingdom they created.
author: Melissa B.

description:
A few things could be improved, but overall a really cool place! I wouldn't recommend taking young kids in to see it because it's mainly the history behind Wald Disney Studios, where most things are behind the glass and can't be touched or played with. 

This place is something that needs to be experienced! If you are a Walt Disney fan, you will like it!
author: Kate P.

description:
This museum reaches a *presidential* level of detail! A veritable pantheon of evidence is produced to frame Walt Disney as the most important master storyteller of the 20th century.  You will most certainly leave this museum feeling a little dizzy and wondering if you missed anything, with that song "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf" stuck in your head for the rest of the day.

I echo the sentiments of other reviewers that this museum will probably not be completely enjoyed by younger visitors.  This place is best enjoyed by people bewitched by the cult of Disney (the man himself, not necessarily the corporation & its often not-great output of today) and is definitely a must-see for folks who love Hollywood history.  Through Disney's story you can also learn a lot about the golden age of studio filmmaking - from those early experimental 'let's try just about anything' days to the struggles of staying afloat during WWII all the way to 'how do we get them back into the movie theater?' vibe of the 60s. Anaheim Disneyland fans will ooh and ahh at the perfect little replica of the park as it was the day it opened.  

Set aside an un-rushed 3 hours to really enjoy every corner of this museum, and don't expect a lot of signs in the Presidio to show you the way. We wandered around on foot until we finally bumped into some folks who work in an office in the Presidio - only one of which seemed to know the museum even existed!  BF and I discussed afterward that it's slightly tucked-away location is just fine by us - we liked browsing the galleries without tons of pushy excited Disney-freak tourists to elbow through.  (I say Disney-freak in the nicest of possible ways.)
author: Sherrie G.

description:
Better then I ever imagined. It does a beautiful and very informative job and showing the life at one of the greatest minds. Each room is very unique and displays more information then you could ever read. The only problem is a few of the rooms have too many audio features going at once and it's hard to focus on one.
Make sure you pay attention in the elevator. It's a very special and very Disney way to go one floor!
author: Pat D.

description: I was in awe after going to this museum. I was inspired and touched. I had doubts about this place when I first heard about it, but I was astounded as I walked around. This is the best museum I've ever been to and I may never go another one that will top this place. If you have the time, definitely go here with an open mind and be prepared to be amazed.
author: Eric K.

description:
****Please understand this is not a "Disney Museum", but rather a museum dedicated to the life of Mr. Walt Disney, the father, the husband, and artist.****

I had the pleasure of visiting this place prior to its grand opening. I took the family and kids to check it out on a fine Sunday afternoon. The wait to get in was not long at all and while the staff is still green, they were very knowledgeable and helpful in answering questions. 

The museum is divided into 8 different sections and prior to entering the first section, you'll find yourself in the main lobby, surrounded by Mr. Disney's numerous Awards and Accolades. As you venture through the building, each room devotes itself to one specific period of Mr. Disney's life, beginning with his childhood. 

The first room is all about the Disney family history, wedding certificates, baptisms and the like. As you journey on, you'll interact with recordings of Mr. Disney via telephones or other various modes of media. When you get to about the sixth section or so, you will notice the amazing contraption engineered by Disney studios to create life like camera work. This was best explained in Bambi where the camera almost "walks beyond the trees". 

Towards the end, before you walk into section 7, there is a hallway with one side comprised of windows...on a good day, you can see an AMAZING view of the Golden Gate Bridge and parts of the Presidio. Follow that hallway down and you'll see a miniature replica of Disney world, learn of the trials and tribulations in building the magic kingdom and all the modern technologies placed into Mr. Disney's dream world. 

The last part was the saddest part of all as we go through the death of Walt Disney. You leave the place feeling utterly somber. 

When you are finally done with the tour, you can complete your visit with a stop at the gift shop. 

Overall, the kids really enjoyed the (limited) interactive play but the older folks really appreciated the historical value which is really what this museum is about. Personally though, I think the kids would have much rather gone to Disneyland and the Museum would be best for teens or older.
author: Monlia W.

description: I would recommend that you plan at least 2 hours of time in this museum.  Also - children under 10 could become easily bored due to requiring a lot of reading.  Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of interaction with videos however if you want to fully understand the brilliance that is Walt Disney, you will need to read a lot.  Leave the little ones at home.
author: Joe M.

description: I was excited to finally check out the Walt Disney museum, but I think the $20 admission fee is a bit high, especially for a family hoping it will entertain the kiddos.  First off, there is A LOT of reading involved- bring your reading glasses!  This is a museum about Walt, his life, family, and the history of his career and the Disney company.  I was hoping to see more Disney stuff actually, and I think a kid would too.  My impression after I left was that it was historical and interesting, and my boyfriend or anyone else interested in the production of film would also like it a lot.  My interest began to fade out towards the end but was piqued again with the Disneyland model which was really cute.  Again, I just didn't see the kids really having themselves a ball at the museum itself, except I did see them enjoying the hands-on activity room where they had some projects set up for them.  Honestly, I think this was the only place kids seemed most interested and engaged.  I think the Walt Disney museum is more something that my grandfather would have loved if he was still here.  The older generation of visitors I saw really seemed to be the ones who were enjoying it the most.  I think this museum would make a perfect outing if you have grandparents visiting and need something quiet to do in SF where there is not a lot of walking involved, is handicap friendly, and lots of history on the legendary man Walt Disney.
author: Alexandra P.

description: Walt was The Man, but yeah, don't forget your AAA discount.
author: Tully C.

description:
I am a huge Disney fan, always have been. This museum chronicles the life of Walt Disney from the human man, not the mogul or corporation we all associate with the name  "Disney" (come on admit it- when you hear the name, you think of the company, not Walt).

This museum houses the answers to every conceivable question you could ever have about Walt- his family- his life (I had always wondered where the name "Disney" originated) and more. We were in the museum for 2.5 hours and we will need to go back because we sort of rushed from the 8th gallery through the 10th.

I am super happy that the Presidio was chosen to house this fountain of knowledge and information. Most of the galleries are narrated by Walt himself and it is very cool~ it gives him an immortal air (let's face it, would you trust anyone else to take you through the Disney families History?). This is WHY the museum needed to be separate and apart  from the parks- this was the DISNEY FAMILY HISTORY (and it just happened to INCLUDE DISNEYLAND not the other way around). 

Although there are many interactive stations that are fun for everyone, and there are plenty of cartoons around it is appropriate for families however I am not sure I would bring someone under 7, because there is a lot of museum and they get bored after about 1 and a half hours (but hey! If your child has the attention span- they will have a blast).

The next to last gallery is Disneyland (and you thought that was all Disney did- shame on you!). It is breathtaking with the actual model Disney used to present to the banker's to fund Disneyland ("Walt's Folly- my butt, I wish I had a folly half as popular!).

The last gallery, is the radio announcement of Walt's death and the outpouring of support to his family. I got weepy and my sister dragged me through with the promise of the gift shop.

The gift shop is great with a good balance of all priced merchandise, and the cafe's coffee smelled great. All in all, I can't wait to go back.
author: Hanna C.

description: This place was pretty cool.  It was very interesting to see how Disney really came to be.  Took me about 2 hours to do the whole thing, and I probably could have stayed an extra hour.  Everyone who works here is also extremely nice.
author: Jason D.

description:
I love Disneyland and anything Disney, so when I learned of this place I went with 3 of my friends. We're all students so the ticket prices were somewhat steep but with my AAA card, I got $5 off per ticket for all of us. But I would pay full price to visit. 

SO AWESOME. At first you don't think there is a lot to see but give yourself 4 hours to relaxingly go through and read all that you want. Animation and how Walt Disney came to be is a magical experience in itself. It just get better the further you go into the exhibit. I would recommend this for adults because there is a lot of reading and I think children would get bored.

VISIT!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Lot's of flash, not much content.  Tickets are expensive and so is the cafeteria.  I love Disney and it's too bad no photos are allowed. Some rooms are a bit small, I had a hard time hearing some of the audio displays. Lots of attention grabbing graphics, pictures, posters, globes but with little substance.

Try to see it at least once though in a few weeks after the 'I collect everything Disney" crowds have calmed down.
author: The C.

description:
My husband and I went to this museum  last week, expecting a pleasant but perhaps dry "historical" museum about Walt Disney -- boy, were we wrong.  It was fantastic.  One step inside reminds you that the Disney folks do things so beautifully.  (By the way, this museum is not from the Disney entertainment corporation -- it is run by the Disney Family Foundafion.)  The decorations and presentations were beautiful and clever and done with a lot of entertainment and wit.

We did not have advance entry tickets, by the way.  We showed up on a weekday afternoon in summer and had no difficulty getting in.  There were a few people wandering around but there were no crowds at all.

We were impressed that upon entry, you go up an elevator to the top level, and then as you make your way through each room (following Walt's life chronologically) you wind down a gently sloping path and end up down at the first floor again.  No steps to go down, never a sensation of having to climb up or down stairs.  It felt effortless and seamless.

The exhibits were wonderfully animated so even if you are not the type to scrutinize exhibits and read the descriptive cards, you get a clear and entertaining story of how Walt's life unfolded ... Most often, from Walt's own lips as he talks about various events.  It was great fun to see the original papers behind the Disney mark on animation and television and movie history: early Micky Mouse sketches, the letter Walt wrote to Julie Andrews about her playing in Mary Poppins, etc.  

We LOVED the model of Disneyland  and could have looked at that for hours. It's delightful.

While I think this museum is more suited to adults, there is much for kids to enjoy and the animations will keep them interested.  There is a small cafe where one can buy fruit, simple snacks and drinks, and a lovely porch with chairs and tables outside.  There are also, apparently, different films and events featured from time to time that may require special ticketing.  None were running when we were there.  Parking is free and abundant.  

It was a well-spent 2 hours and $20, and we came away with a new understanding of how profoundly Walt Disney affected animation, tv and movies, the theme park industry, and our popular culture.
author: Diane H.

description:
Good Stuff about the museum:
- Great Museum!
- Great Location for a museum!
- Lots of Parking for FREE!!
- Its a tribute to Walt Disney that everyone born since 1920's can relate to. Guess that just about includes everyone.

Bad Stuff:
- Not very much stuff for little kids under 5 yrs considering its Disney.
author: R J.

description:
I can't believe it wasn't sold out on opening weekend. 

As a museum, this one is fantastic.  Like the Picasso museum in Paris, this one tells the story chronologically and gives you both the how and why Disney did things.  If you have read a good Disney biography you may find there isn't a whole lot of new info, which is surprising since the museum was put together by his family.  Regardless, the story is well told with a bounty of artifacts.  I was particularly struck by the earliest known drawing of Mickey Mouse.  

My complaints are petty.  The staff wear purple uniforms which would be right at home in a Disney park, but this is not a Disney park.  Others have complained that some rooms in the building were small.  I didn't really notice or mind.  I did notice that the museum sort of ends with a whimper, though.  You leave the largest gallery through a small, nondescript door into a small room that is the final room and that's it.  The subject and content of the final room is moving but the physical space is not.  For a showman like Walt it seems a bit anticlimactic.

If you are a bone-fide Disney nut-job (like me) you will be very happy and satisfied.  If you are even slightly interested in Walt Disney, the parks, the movies, or just eager to learn some history, this is a great place.
author: Benji N.

description: A fantastic place to visit for any Disney fan.  Please note that this is not an amusement park, and is focused on Walt Disney the man.  There are displays which kids will enjoy, but it is a museum and expectations should be set accordingly.  I would recommend a minimum of 3 hours to see all of the gallerys.  Make sure to check their websites calendar for potential lectures and special events!
author: Dave B.

description:
A YEAR LATER I STILL REMEMBER THIS MUSEUM!  This is one of the best museums anywhere in the country to give people a real feeling of what a famous man like Walt Disney was like.  It's personable and full of wonderful interactive exhibits, and it tells you things you really want to know!  I went to Disneyland when I was 13 and to see the models of how it was created were amazing.  It's absolutely worth the price and the gift shop has things you won't find elsewhere.  My son was blown away by how good it was, so even though they say it isn't for "kids", if your child is smart and savvy and doesn't want something that talks down to him or her, this museum is perfect!

We haven't been back to the West Coast since November 2009, but for sure the next trip we're going back to Walt Disney Family Museum again.  It rocks!
author: Linda Gramatky S.

description:
Great venue if you are interested in learn more about the Disney Family and how the Disney empire first got started! Really takes you through from the beginning (Walt's Childhood sketches of Mortimer Mouse) to the amazing colorful fast action cartoon world of today! 

Highlights include:
- The Walt Disney Family Train
- Theatre playing various Disney productions downstairs (extra $)
-  Interactive stations for children to provide the sound affects to their favorite cartoon. 
- Every Disney Oscar and other Award displayed in the lobby. 
- Many of the exhibits are video based or narrated by the voice of Walt Disney. 

There is a Wolfgang Puck cafe on property serving gormet lunch fare and goodies. There isn't a whole lot of options in the Presidio. I reccommend venturing out to The Marina for lunch instead.

Overall it's a good museum! May not be the most interesting for small children as it is focused on the family and the building of a legacy. But there are children's activies throughout and lots of clips for them to watch. Enjoyable afternoon for sure!
author: Marissa P.

description: I've been to a lot of museums and I had no expectations going into the Walt Disney Family Museum but coming out I was blown away.  I think we spent 3 hours in there when we really could have spent the whole day.  The museum is very large and spans Walt's entire life.  It was great to see his humble beginnings and how he revolutionized his trade and the movie industry (and amusement parks) as well.  He was a brilliant man with so many talents.  This was a great memorial to him and I look forward to heading back to learn even more about him.
author: Blake B.

description:
This place is quite the treat. I ordered tickets online and printed them out at home and we showed up in the morning right during opening time at 10AM. We got our tickets scanned, hand stamped for re--entry and then we were off into the world of Walter Disney. 

This place is really a biography of Walt Disney himself and from the first room to the last you get an experience of what his life was about. There's a room that describes his ancestors and how they came to be, pictures, everything. Then it goes into the life of young Walt, and how he came to do what he did. In different "sections" you get to watch interactive videos with Walt Disney himself narrating what is going on. 

You experience the rises and falls of his career and then how films and songs came to be. Then everything slowly pieces together with his vision of Disneyland and how he became inspired with it.  All along the way, family pictures and candids of him and his family are framed on the walls. One thing that really cracked me up was a list of his "favorite things to eat" that he wrote down and gave to his housekeeper to prepare which apparently was later found in an old magazine in the housekeepers' quarters.

Although I came here with my girlfriend, not a lot of conversation took place. That's not necessarily a bad thing, because we were both fixated on all the exhibits and reading the articles that were attached to each. A lot of reading is to be done here, and to capture it all, may take more than just one visit, but even if you do just come just once, you'll leave with an appreciation for the man who let us know that you're never too old to have a heart like a child
author: Derrick L.

description: This cool museum  is amazing. I have been here twice and still feel like I need to go back cause I missed something.  The history of Walt himself is the visit. If you love Disneyland you would love this museum.
author: Zeb S.

description: What a pleasant and interesting museum! Wasn't aware of it until a friend suggested a visit for a planned weekend in the City. Walt's family life and professional life are presented by his daughter in a loving and interesting series of galleries full of memorabilia, photos, and very well done multimedia presentations. If you grew up in the 50s and 60s, a significant part of your entertainment and play will be remembered. Not for young children, but teens and adults will find it engaging and truly inspiring about how a very talented and determined Walt Disney put his stamp on everything related to his company and built an entertainment powerhouse from very modest beginnings. Plan on at least 4 hours and spend time in the details - it is fascinating and enjoyable.
author: Mike K.

description:
A great place to spend the afternoon learning more about the brilliant creator of Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, and so many Disney movies.

Women - don't wear heals, as there are 10 rooms to go though and this takes 3 hours if you really soak everything in.

If you have kids and you think this is the place for them, I'd think again and rush to the last 3 rooms to maintain their interest and keep them from crabbing-out.

Like many others, I really took my time in the first couple of rooms taking it all in - once you go into the elevator to the next floor - it is like the entire museum has exploded with amazing things to see.  I was shocked, happily so, as I grew up in SoCal and went to Disneyland SO many times - growing up on EVERY Disney movie, book, that my parents would take me to and buy.  A huge treat, and something I will definitely take guests visiting SF to see.
author: Jason I.

description: What a surprise!  The name of the museum doesn't do justice to the quality and breadth of the exhibits.  We went to see the special Mary Blair exhibit that will be running until September 2014, but there was so much more.  This is really a museum for anyone who is interested in the intersection of art, technology and entertainment, or just who remembers with affection the Disney classics, or perhaps who is a fan of the man himself and wants to know more about him.  Then there is the setting: Beautiful views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Crissy Field.   The museum really is a gift to San Francisco.  (And the city should allow them to have some free parking spaces at their lot.)  Go!
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
I am a Disneyphile.

"But Disney is representative of a corporate behemoth which stifles creativity in the name of sanitized art catered to the lowest common denominator and justify it by the bottom line"

Get over yourself, Gertrude.  It's Disney.  Do you feel bad when you eat a chocolate Santa?  You do?  Oh...you don't eat chocolate because it's bad for you.  Cool..go plan your next low-investment/high profit margin rave that is neither licensed nor permitted under current zoning regulations.  Don't forget to sell $3 bottles of water, not pay taxes or permit fees, pocket the proceeds and then bitch about why the economy is so bad.

Going to keep reading?  Feel that burning situation in the pit of your stomach?  It's called reality.

Disney is one of the original rebels.  An amazing risk taker who got screwed many times by people who profited off of his vision because he was too romantic to hire an attorney to read  contracts.

I've read many biographies on this guy.  A lot of them were insightful and provided new information.  Some of them could have been written by anybody who had read others or had a decent internet connection.  Some of them were outright fabrications (I'm looking at YOU, "Hollywood's Dark Prince").  

What surprised me here was how much of this exhibit is relayed in Walt's own words.  The mystery of the man appears to be based on protective custody of footage and voice recordings.  But this museum is funded by the Disney family.  They have that footage.  They have those recordings.  And they use them here.

One walks from display to display and gets to hear Walt's own voice and watch interviews where he explains where he was at, where the company was at, where society was at, when it happened.  From Chicago to Missouri, to Kansas, to World War I, back to frikkin' Kansas (and bankruptcy) and then to Hollywood.  He talks about how he lost his (and Ub Iwerks') creation Oswald the Lucky Rabbit to Mintz (along with Iwerks) due to poor business acumen.  He talks about how he lost out on a year of profits due to Pat Powers' (Cinephone) unethical business practices.  This guy got steamrolled by corporate thefts more times than any small technology startup out there and he kept going.  He kept true to his vision because he believed it could be better.  It also sort of explains why the Disney empire is so protective of their property.

You rebels still reading?  When you give up and cut your hair in order to get that job you just took the step Walt wasn't willing to.  Go back to planning that next rave now.  I think there is an abandoned factory in the outer mission that you might be able to swing a deal with.  Please pick up the broken glass before you start charging people a $20 'donation' to go take drugs and dance.

Back to Walt.

So you get the idea that he narrates a good portion of his visions nascent years.  He narrates perhaps 70% of the entire museum tour.  Many of the original "Nine Old Men", Walt's inner-circle, are interviewed  as well as inkers, animators, and family members.

The displays are amazing.  If you're the type of person who could spend a year going to the Smithsonian and standing in awe at original sketches and artifacts from history this place will leave tears in your eyes.  Shut up.  I know Karate.  Most of the displays are related to the business of Disney, but many are related to the man himself.  Everything from watches to letters.  One of my favorites was a display of Walt's beloved miniatures collection.  My least favorite exhibit was some stupid interactive 'hot spot' projection display where you touch an image projected on a Formica table and it brings up something or other.  Perhaps I didn't give it enough time, but it was jumbled, confused, and way too random for me.  My absolute favorite display, the one which got me in trouble with Museum staff (how many of you saw that coming?) was Walt's miniature, ridable train.  According to the guy who chastised me soundly, this was not a reproduction...this was the actual train Walt got in trouble from Lilly with at his house.  According to some, this was the train that provided one of the inspirations for Disneyland.  A ride Walt had installed at his own house.  Yeah...I spent some time 'looking' at that.  The other display that truly took me aback was the scale model of Disneyland.  I could have done without the not-to-scale haunted mansion and pirates on top of their respective buildings, but I'm in real estate and like scaled models.  This one is pretty frikkin' awesome.

It is spendy.  Disney spendy.  I can do without that part, so reality does rear it's ugly head at the ticket counter and the gift shop.  I disagree that it is geared toward children: it is geared toward the curious and Disneyphiles (of which I saw a few).
author: Pikea M.

description: If you love the genius of Walt Disney, this place is for you. Don't bring kids unless they like to read. I could only get through half the museum before my brain got too full. The building is beautiful and in a beautiful location. The gift shop is awesome. They have a lot of neat things in there. The only thing they could improve on is the cafe. I was not impressed, so we went elsewhere (HIGHLY recommend Tacolicious). Can't wait to come back!
author: kira d.

description:
I love Disney so much.  I grew up with it and know almost everything there is to know about it.  I love everything about it.  Everything was cool.  We were told that we could take pictures of the trophy room, but honestly I was too in awe at everything there was.  This museum is for Disney lovers.

This museum was so great, I even learned a little bit about the Disney Corporation I never knew about.  It was viewer friendly and the only gripe that I have if anything is that there were whiny little kids when I went, and the museum ended on a sad note that I thought would be better at the beginning, and Walt's letters are more than a little difficult to read (because of the handwriting).  But other than that it is a great thing to visit and anyone who is a Walt Disney fan will love this museum.  They have awesome things (whether they are replicas or real things I don't care) like the ambulance that Walt drove to one of the classic Atopia cars.  

It was heaven on earth everyone must visit!  Go now before its too late!!
author: josie c.

description: We all know the legacies of Disney; Disney Land, Disney World, and movies.  But, how much do we know about the man and his family that started it all?  I suppose you could find a documentary on the History Channel or the Learning Channel, but nothing bits the walk through history of hands on interactive displays.  You get a glimpse into the creation and influences into the mind of the creative genius that Disney as we know it today.  Definitely more geared towards adults and older children (teenage).
author: Michael D.

description:
after years of hearing about this museum i finally made the trek into the city for a day to take in this awesome place. thanks to yelp i got my ticket for $10 instead of $20 so that was extra sweet.

from the outside this place doesn't look like it has much but once you get inside you will see that this place is really huge and has so much to offer. i saw they had a wolfgang puck inspired cafe but i decided to pass on lunch here since they only had a couple of basic sandwiches and snacks. the gift shop was alot of fun as they had pretty much everything you would expect with walt disney and his work but everything was so overpriced as you can imagine. the lower level consisted of restrooms and a theater where they showed featured disney classics but i decided to pass on 101 dalmations and stick with what i really came for. i decided to head on into the museum and get started and right off the bat an employee told me that pictures were not allowed inside the museum. oh come on! this is a big reason why i came and how can you not go to a place like this and not take pictures? anyway i headed on in began my self guided tour inside the life of a pure genius and living legend.

the museum has 2 floors and each floor has so many different rooms that play out the life and death of walt disney. if you know anything about walt disney and what he did for the world you would be truly amazed by each and every exhibit in this museum. you can expect to see items from his childhood, private life, early animation, feature films, the characters, awards, interactive displays, disney collectibles and of course everything disneyland. i was really impressed with the huge detailed sculpture of the disneyland park as it made me feel like i was actually there in the moment. this place is huge once your inside and your guided by walt disney's voice and even get to watch clips and full length movies and cartoons. i have to say i was really impressed with every thing i saw inside but i really loved seeing some of walt's favorite foods. he loved jello and canned chili but he really loved his gravy. also if you look in the exhibit around war time you can even see a poster the disney animators did for the troops and yes these pin-up girls are nude. this was very cool to see and the last thing i expected to see in a place like this. i was loving every minute of this place so much.

i enjoyed everything the museum had to offer and is a great and rare behind the scenes look you just can't get anywhere else. i must admit i ended up leaving the museum with just around 50 pictures with the flash off of course and i'm so glad i took pictures to remember this time i spent reliving my childhood and learning more about the man behind that famous mouse.
author: Scotty D.

description: Any true Disney fan must go to this museum to get a fuller picture of Walt Disney's genius and vision. This was one of the most creatively designed museums I've ever been to and all the exhibits were interactive and engaging. Make sure you allocate at least 4 hours to get the full experience.
author: Kelli S.

description:
First of all, this is NOT a great museum for most children. We took a very bright 7-year-old and there just wasn't too much that kept him occupied. Although there was a neato Disneyland scale model and some cartoon clips that had him semi-interested, we had to keep our visit at about an hour and fifteen minutes because his attention span just couldn't hold out. Another warning: this museum is really about Walt Disney himself, and there really isn't much information about any Disney-related projects that occurred after Walt Disney's death in the mid-60's. 

All that said, the museum was quite engaging and an interesting examination of the creative process. Say what you will about the current Disney empire, the guy really did take some risks and make some real creative leaps. For some reason I'd always thought that Fantasia was made in the 1960's (kind of a psychedelic thing) -- it was actually released much earlier; no one had really ever done anything like it before. 

I especially enjoyed seeing how "one thing led to another" -- for example, the Disney live-action nature documentaries were actually an offshoot of research that was done for "Bambi" -- in order to get the characters of Bambi as "animal-like" as possible, the artists studied live animals and footage of live animals; the footage later provided inspiration for the live-action flicks. 

Probably my favorite part of the museum was a clip of about 20 Disney artists sitting in a circle around a live deer, trying to get a feeling for what real deer do.  How much work and study they put into these 90-minute cartoons! 

Be aware that the restroom and eating facilities are limited.
author: Jen C.

description: Anyone who is a fan of Walt Disney or Disneyland, needs to make this museum a stop. It has all of the awards and honors Walt had been given during his lifetime, memorabilia from his life, as well as insight and memorabilia into both the films and theme parks. Well worth the price of admission.
author: A Z.

description:
Inspirational life choices and artistic philosophy found in readings.  

Great design, in that videos are placed throughout, so smaller children can watch while you read.  

It can take hours to get through, and you will want to return more than once.
author: She F.

description: Ditto what everyone else said!  This place is great!  I admit I was a little hesitant to go because when I hear "Disney" I picture the toy store at the mall and themeparks.  But as others have written, this is a history of Walt, his family roots, how he got into the business, his successes and challenges.  There is tons of material, tons of exhibits with original art, artifacts, photos, and media; by the end we felt the $20 admission was well worth it.  We also visited the Mary Blair exhibit which was an extra $5 and wonderful.  Plan to spend at least 2 hours, more if you plan on watching a movie.  By the way, the day we were there we didn't think to confirm movie times when we bought tickets, and we found out later there would be none today due to a private event.  Seemed like something they should have told us when we bought tickets, so be sure to ask if that's one of the reasons you're going!
author: Annie P.

description:
Randomly discovered the Walt Disney Family museum during a quick trip to San Francisco. I've worked for the company for several years so was thrilled to get an inside look at the life of Walt. 

First off, this isn't really a museum for kids. There were definitely families there but the children looked bored and just kinda ran around. The museum is half dedicated to the life of Walt Disney (childhood photos, his personal sketches, family videos, telegrams he sent, etc.) and half dedicated to the founding years and evolution of The Walt Disney Company from the 1920's on. 

There were HUNDREDS of original sketches, pieces of concept art, animation cels, etc. along with vintage products (ie: lunch boxes, figurines, watches, etc.), camera equipment, original movie posters, etc. I think the coolest part of the entire museum was a miniature, to-scale replication of Disneyland from when it first opened. 

We only had about 2 hours to spend but I could have stayed a whole day. An absolutely stunning history of Walt Disney - a must see for anyone interested in the man and the company.
author: Erin O.

description:
First off, one thing is important to understand.  This is the "Walt Disney Family" Museum, not the Walt Disney "Family Museum".  It was commissioned by his daughter, who lives in Northern California, apparently as a tribute to her father and his works.  His early interests and ongoing vision throughout his life comprise the message.  

It is really not child-friendly, but for those who appreciate a sense of the history of animation or of Disney himself, it is a remarkable presentation of his life and works.

I visited with my wife, our son and his girlfriend, all fans of Disneyana to varying degree.  Personally, I found the influence of his creativity on other areas of cinema, media, technology and popular culture to be a revelation (despite what I thought I knew beforehand), and gained a new admiration for the man and what he endured during a career that spanned two world wars and beyond.  

There is definitely a lot of reading material throughout the exhibit, and one can spend the better part of a day there if you so desire.  I finished in around five hours, but if you skip some of the mutlimedia exhibits and are judicious about what you read, you may be able to do it in two.  Again, this is not really a kids' museum.  Rather, it is more of a well-stocked testament to the life, family and works of an icon of the 20th century whose legacy lives on well after his death.

If you are interested in the development of animation or in Disney himself, this is well worth the admission fee.  Diane Disney would be happy you enjoyed it.
author: Jeff B.

description: Great place!  Location is wonderful.  A superb dedication and collection of a lifetime of memories to a innovative, creative thoughtful man.  A must see of any Disney Fan!
author: Nancy M.

description:
Made our first visit to the Disney Family Museum with our college-aged son and his 80+ grandmother. All of us enjoyed the interactive exhibits and spent 3+ hours wandering through the galleries.   There was so much to see there that we'll need to make another visit to view in detail all of the displays that we didn't catch the first time around.  I agree with other posters that this is a museum, not an amusement park, so most children 12 and under may not enjoy it as much as we did.  Allow ample time (at least a couple hours) to enjoy the museum.  You could spend at least 4-6 hours and still not see everything. The museum is definitely worth the admission price if you're interested in Disneyanna!

We should also mention that  the staff was very helpful and lunch in the cafe was great!
author: Brenda H.

description: We went with small children and had an awkward experience. There is a little kids studio area where they can do crafts. We went there first and found it very nice with kind staff. But when we went to the main exhibits I wasn't sure what the story was. I was with two three year olds who were very excited by many of the exhibits and would shout things like "dumbo!" and "Mickey!" And point excitedly at the scale model of Disneyland - "Wow! What is that!????" They were very happy and excited, and yes, louder that I would like but hey, kids love Disney. We just happened to be visiting at the same time as two grumpy women who gave us the stink eye at every opportunity and continually told our children to be quiet. When I told them to please stop they snapped "This isn't a kids' park!" Okay, point taken. But given that my children were happy and excited - not bratty or tantruming or climbing on the exhibits etc. I did not understand why their behavior was so inappropriate. This is, when you get down to it, a museum about a man who made children's films and cartoons. But if you have toddlers who may show toddler-like enthusiasm over things that were made to appeal to them, this may not be the best place to spend your time.
author: Honor R.

description: A visit to the museum brings back lots of great memories of watching Disney movies and the old television shows with my parents. The nostalgia aspect might not appeal to young children, but I was right at home.
author: Michele M.

description:
love love love love

had 2 pay for parking but area was very gorgeous and museum BIG. took us many hrs to see. altho disappointed when realized this is not "Disney Vault" 

a lot of reading but very nice i cried at the end when he died
author: Rhonda G.

description: I'm sooooooo not a museum person, but I loved Walt Disney's story, Disney World and Land, and watched most if not all of the Disney movies.  All I can say about this museum is WOW!!  What a fantastic collection of items!  It all starts with a great assortment of awards that Walt won (including about 20 Oscars which was an amazing display in itself!).  Then you go through a door and the story of the man behind the mouse begins.  It literally starts with his baby picture and goes through his young life and up to his enjoyment of drawing when he served in the military.  After that, it takes you through his life as a fledgling cartoonist and the different ideas and businesses he tried to start.  Some failed, he got ripped off a few times, but he never ever lost his smile or the enthusiasm he had for his art and craft.  When he arrived in Hollywood and not one single movie studio would hire him, he was undaunted and opened his own studio.  This museum has pictures, movies, memorabilia (my favorite part...the tin toy Mickey Mouse's from the 30's) and telegrams/letters and that's just for starters.  I never saw a collection of such amazing items from anyone and in addition, it included items and stories about his wife Lillian and his daughters, Diane &  Sharon.  It was a true biography.  If you are expecting to take your kids there to have them dressed up in Princess outfits and your boys to don Mickey Mouse ears, take a flight to Disneyland.  This is NOT interesting to small children and honestly, I can't see young teens enjoying this either.  It's for a more mature audience wanting to see Walt Disney come to life via a bioigraphical museum.  I say GO!!   You will really enjoy it.  Prepare to spend 4 hours in there.  We did and I bet we only read or saw 60% of the items we could have read or watched.  You didn't know where to look first as there was so much memorabilia.  Terrific way to spend the morning or afternoon.  Snack bar too, at the end, if you get hungry.  For the price of $20, we learned so much.
author: Sandra P.

description:
I was able to attend before the Grand Opening on Oct 1, 2009.  I arrived on 9/19/09 with some family and friends. It looked as the entire muesum was open.  They were able to offer free preview tickets to the Presidio residents! Considering the amount for tickets ($20 for adults, $12 for Kids, Don't quote me on this), it saved us a bundle.

One has to remember this is the Walt Disney FAMILY Museum.  The museum starts by explaining the ambitions of Walt and the interest he had for animation.  The path of the muesuem takes you through the Disney Family's life.  There are displays of the animations itself but the focus is on the family.  It is not necessarily a place for kids under 8, IMO.

However, we had a bunch of kiddies with us, some enjoyed it, others had no idea what was going on. There is a model of the entire Disney Land park which was cool.  A miniture train that Walt had created was also on displayed (which I believed showed the true fun side of Walt).

I never knew how OLD some of the cartoons I grew up watching, really was.  I grew up in the 80's, who knew my favorite cartoons were from the 30's!!!

Interior Design was great.  The staff is even better! No cameras though...
author: Eddie C.

description:
I was in San Francisco for work, staying at the Hyatt Regency Embarcadero Center. This was down in the financial district and when a meeting was canceled, I hoped in a cab and $21 later I was at the Presidio at the Walt Disney Family Museum. And another $20 later I was looking at black and white family portraits of Walt's ancestors in room #1. 

The museum may not be a part of Disney Corporation, but the sticker shock is eerily similar.  There is however, complimentary coat check in the basement, next to the women's restroom - convenient!

The exhibits are largely interactive and interesting to an adult audience. I saw a group of young school children being hurried through so perhaps they have special tours and activities for children. Mostly, on this Wednesday morning in early December, it was adult couples - a mix of Baby Boomers and Gen Xers. It took me about 3 hours to tour the museum and I didn't know about the theater so I only explored the 10 rooms, the cafe and the gift shop.

Unlike a typical Disney-fan, I had no plans and no idea what to expect. I was largely pleased with my visit. The one thing I wish I had mentally prepared myself better for was that this is NOT Disneyland or Wald Disney World. I knew I was going to a museum, but I was going to a Disney Museum, so I thought. Basically I was expecting Cast Members - friendly, outgoing people who are ready to answer questions and be helpful. The staff were instead bored, over-educated museum staff. I actually don't know their education, they all just seemed like they had masters degrees from expensive universities in comparative religion and women's studies and were really disappointed in the turn their lives had taken. Anyway, if you want a cab home - you have to beg one of them to #1 look at you, #2 listen to you, and #3 call a cab for you. Good luck!
author: kristine m.

description:
Want to give this museum 4.5 stars. 

First, we are not Disneyland or Disney fans. However, some of Disney's works, including "Fantasia" and a slew of lovable, ageless, iconic characters deserve esteem.  

After reading other reviews that this was a great museum for adults, we took the bait.

What a thrill. In fact, while their interactive portions offer entertainment for children and adults alike, overall the entire museum could well just be for adults. The museum provided plenty of background history on Walt Disney, his family, the business from startup to success, and the "making of..." aspects that were undeniably fascinating.  Also give them credit for acknowledging the labor disputes that occurred at Disney. How many other museums gloss over or never bother to mention the 'trying' points in a company's history?  

While the $20 adult admission may deter some, there are occasional offers.  We went earlier this year on a yelp summer offer for half off.  Goldstar also ran a promotion recently for Sunday and weekday admittance.  

The small cafe was buzzing and packed...we didn't try it, but since the Presidio does not have many other dining options around, it's a smart idea for them to have an onsite cafe.  

Gorgeous interior with plenty to keep one engaged.  What's great is they also offer multiple (2-5) stations for listening to audio segments, or the interactive exhibits...so no lengthy waits.
author: Ye W.

description:
when i told BF we had to visit this museum during our SF trip, he laughed, saying I'm silly for never wanting to go to Disneyland, which is 2 blocks away from his house, yet willing to drive 6 hours for a Disney museum. sighs.. i guess I'm just that weird. what can i say?

regular admission for adults is $20, but since we had our student IDs, and i'm an AAA member, we got our tickets for $10 each. not bad.

the first thing i noticed, and liked about this place was that it was very clean, talking SPOTLESS clean. the floor was made with sparkling tiles, i couldn't stop looking down, mesmerized. even the bathroom smelled nice, whaaaaaaaaaaaa? 

ANYWAY, the setup was very well thought out and easy to follow. for every photo, there was captions to explain and help you get a better understanding. there were also short films and many collections of his works. what stood out the most to me was miniature model of Disneyland, amazed me as i never realized just how big of a land it was. made me wonder if i really have seen it all or still missed out on some.. 

the gift shop was nice, but of course, everything, TO ME, was overpriced. but then again, it's Disney.
author: Anh L.

description:
As per the star rating, this is as good of a museum as it gets!. The layout is easy to follow and keeps your interest. The exhibits are each good individually but you also get to experience the overall experience that demonstartes what a original creative visionary Walt Disney was. 

Use the AAA discount and although the Disneyland diorama is beautiful I think that younger children will be bored. If you really enjoy Disney & like to read, you will need about 3 hours or so in the museum. It's a great way to spend the day!
author: Alisa S.

description: Fascinating, amazing and most of all inspiring.  Not just one word can fully summarize the experience of touring the Walt Disney Family Museum. Set against the beautiful backdrop of the Presidio and the San Francisco Bay, it is a must see for Disney enthusiasts touring the Bay area.  I would say that little ones up through teenagers might find it boring. But as an adult who really appreciates the genius of Walt Disney,  I loved it.  Be careful on what day you go.  The museum is closed on Tuesdays of all days and allow at least 4 hours to really cover the material.  Otherwise, you'll feel rushed.
author: Michael H.

description:
Totally not what I was expecting!  in a really good way though.  Walking through made me nostalgic.  I want to go home and watch all the old Disney Movies again!  Oh and it made me want to go to Disneyland and Disneyworld!

The best was the miniature model of Disneyland!
author: Derek F.

description:
I grew up a child of the 80's and have a soft spot in my heart for Walt Disney's animated classics. But you don't have to be a huge Disney fan to appreciate the museum. It showcases Walt Disney, his family life, his entrepreneurial spirit, and persevering imagination. You can see personal family photographs, original stills, and interactive exhibits that demonstrate the process and technology of animation at the time. This isn't Disneyland, meant to razzle and dazzle, but rather a look into a man who started a cultural phenomenon. 

The museum is housed in a renovated military barrack in the Presidio, with the beautiful backdrop of the GG bridge behind it. Gotta love my city.
author: Sonya Y.

description:
The museum is very interesting and is a definite must-see while visiting San Francisco.  The museum has wonderful displays and the information about Walt and his family is amazing. My family spent 4 hours, and did not see all of the displays.  

I could not give the museum a higher rating however, because we weren't allowed to experience the museum with my infant grandson in his stroller.  Strollers are not allowed, so we had to trudge him through the museum in his car seat.  (He was asleep.) The viewing areas are certainly large enough for a stroller.  I could see limiting their use during peak hours, but the day we were there, we  were often the only visitors in the rooms.

I would have to say that the museum would not be interesting to anyone younger that 18.  You would pay $15 for a student, and I'm not sure that they would be interested.
author: Cindi P.

description:
As a young boy, Walt Disney the man was very much a part of my life, coming into my home every Sunday evening on the Wonderful World of Disney. He was like this wonderful Uncle who you felt you knew well. He was a boyhood hero and inspiration to me. I ended up working my way through college at Disneyland in the 70's and his memory was very much alive then.

Mention the name Walt Disney today and it seems that  most people think of the company and brand that bears his name, and maybe the statues in the theme park, but rarely do you hear much about Walt Disney the human being and that's just sad, because there is much than can be learned from his life. He was one of the truly great and defining figures of the 20th century.

For me, walking through the museum is like walking through Walt Disney's life. You learn about Walt the master storyteller, brave entrepreneur, and pioneering innovator. You learn about Walt the son, brother, husband and father. As his life unfolds in chronological order,  you get a sense of who he really was, warts and all. The myth becomes very real. 

I'd suggest planning to spend at least 3 hours exploring the museum.  Younger children might become bord, but even an inquisitive 10 year old should find much to hold thier attention. The signage outside is very limited to preserve the historical integrity of the Presido, so you'll need to keep your eyes open to find the museum. Dining options inthe Presido area are very limited, but there is a small restaurant in the musuem. 


I'm very much looking forward to returning. What a great new addition to San Francisco!
author: Brad H.

description:
This place is wonderful.  Enjoyed the lay out of the museum. Loved it.
Don't miss it.  It's a must.
author: Michelle L.

description:
WOW ~ I've never knew one person can have such a fulfilling life! After coming here, Walt Disney has been an inspiration to me. His life story is representative of the quintessential American Dream. 

Be warned though, there is almost too much information to soak in. After 3 hours of reading, listening, and looking at his life story, you might be mentally and physically exhausted, and still not be finished with the tour. Also, might not be the funnest places for little kiddies, but great for teenagers or older.
author: Regan C.

description: This museum is a lot to take in all at once, and requires a lot of reading.  Personally I wouldn't take children younger than 10 who don't yet have a good grasp on reading.  I also wouldn't recommend this to people who aren't already big fans of Walt Disney, as I don't know how interesting it would be to them.
author: Catherine C.

description:
just shy of a 5 it's a 4.5

i love disney and all disney related things. i've been wanting to check this place out for a while and was excited when i saw that an elite event was going to held here. score! as we were driving through the presidio towards the museum we saw an awesome vistapoint to take photos (mental note to go back after). there was lots of parking and i thought to myself i hope the inside isn't tiny.. i was pleasantly surprised about how big it was inside. 

there are 10 galleries and all of them were great. i loved all the info, photos, sketches, etc. it definitely took me back to my childhood days of watching disney movies which i love love loved! as i made my way through the galleries i thought to myself i didn't want it to end.. i need to go back and take my time walking through everything.. 2 hrs was just not enough.. in one of the last galleries there is a model of disneyland "the happiest place on earth!" i loved looking at it and all the details was pretty awesome. once you exit the last gallery there is a theater near it and a special exhibition. the theater was nice but there wasn't a movie playing when i stepped in to check it out. =/ hopefully, next time! also, i loved all the vintage posters downstairs where the bathroom is. btw, the bathrooms are really nice too. 

just writing about this make me want to visit again soon. =)

ps. in gallery 8 there's an awesome view of the presidio and the bridge so make sure you have a camera handy. its also the only gallery you are allowed to take picture in. 

so what are you waiting for.. go check it out!
author: Raquel T.

description:
must see if you're a Disney fan. cover's Walt's life and accomplishments. i was impressed with the amount of artifacts on display, from marriage certificates, passports, to paints and equipment. it also has one of the three surviving multiplane cameras. 

not so much for kids, but most rooms have some sort of interactive display that'll keep them busy for a couple minutes. 

has a little cafe with sandwiches/salads and drinks and of course a gift shop.
author: david a.

description: One of the best museums that I have been to!  It was great and gives you a very detailed story of Walt's life.  We went kinda towards the end of the day so we were rushed at the end.  I would definitely visit again - you could spend the whole day here.  All of the staff members were really nice.  They have a great little gift shop and restaurant on site.  On the weekends there is free parking.
author: Joshua J.

description:
The museum is housed in a beautiful building in the Presidio with spectacular views, but even on a Saturday afternoon we found a parking spot right in front. The museum tells the life story of Walt Disney. As such, the first third (or so) of the exhibit is devoted to Walt's childhood and early adult life. All the things you typically associate with Disney such as Mickey, the animated films, Disneyland, etc. don't appear until you reach the second floor. Even then, much of the focus is on Walt's family life and career. This is a museum of Walt Disney the man not Disney the entertainment empire. Because of this focus and the nature of the exhibits, I think many children would find it dull, at least for the first half. There's a lot of reading to be done to fully appreciate the exhibits and artifacts. Maybe there are docents for children's groups? Otherwise, I wouldn't recommend the museum for children under 10 or so.  As an adult, I found the museum very interesting and educational. My favorite parts were the elevator ride cleverly decorated to recreate Walt's train trip to Los Angeles and the huge model of Disneyland. (I want one!) My only real complaint about the exhibit is how it ends. There's a room about Walt's death and it's all very sad then... nothing. End of tour. How depressing! OK, so there's one last room with some video screens and a couple of quotes about Walt, but really that room should be devoted to the legacy of Walt, perhaps with a summary of all that Disney has done since, so visitors leave on a positive note rather than a downer. It seemed rather an odd design choice to me. The museum also contains a nice gift shop (not as overly "Disney" as you might expect) and a small cafe/snack bar. There is also a movie theater that shows Disney films, but it costs extra. 

Definitely recommended for adults and older children. I'm glad San Francisco has this!
author: Niels H.

description:
I was a little skeptical of a Walt Disney Museum with the word "Family" in it and based in San Francisco. Turns out Disney's daughter lives in Napa or something.

Anyway, my skepticism was blown away...well as soon as I located the place. I don't know the Presidio that well and despite Google Map directions I still had some trouble.

The Museum is pretty spectacular, clean, and shiny inside unlike your average museum. Hours and Hours of stuff to read so despite it being a "Disney" Museum it is probably a little too much history for young kids.

Many cool things inside where I have to go back now. All of the awards that Walt won internationally as well as all of his Oscars! Super cool. The museum attendants are really knowledge about the history and exhibits. I particularly liked the cartoons from WWII, the wall covered with drawing illustrations that depict how many drawings it takes to make 3 seconds of animation, and the amazing miniature model of what Walt's vision of Disneyland was supposed to be like.

No photos allowed inside :-(
author: Mike T.

description:
This place is no Disneyland, be aware of that.I wouldn't bring young kids here- they're gonna be disappointed, except for the model of the park.  It is a real museum, more about the life of Walt Disney. I came here with the wrong expectations, but for someone who really wants to learn more about Disney and the early animation/film industry- this place rocks. There's A LOT of text to read, films to watch, things to listen to, and artifacts to look at. 

It might not be the most entertaining place, but for a Disney aficionado this place is heaven. I wish they would get rid of the old ugly Presidio barracks and build another Disneyland... but why is this museum located in San Francisco?
author: E. R.

description:
interesting but not essential. 

it's clear the disney family spared no expense on this place, as it's a high tech and beautifully designed/laid out space, but the content is just ok. maybe because i am not a super huge disney freak? i went because i had a free pass.

the best part was the sparkling path leading to the miniature disneyland model at the very end of the museum, and the model itself. overall i had decent fun looking at disney's oscars and learning about the development of his craft. makes you think about how insanely heavy disney's influence is on...well, most things! 

and the people that work there are creepily JUST LIKE the ones at disneyland -- they are always smiling and in your face, telling you pleasantly where the restrooms are and (at this place anyway) to turn your cell phone off. weird. yet oddly comforting when visiting a disney-related joint.
author: Sally R.

description: hank god for for this venue untouched by the hands of Michael Eisner. Are you a purist? Do you ever wonder how a legacy is created, what it looked like at it's most humble beginnings? This is should be on your short list of seeing true genius that has infected generations and will be a brand that will outlive many more to come. Disney had the insight to understand the human condition that few marketers will ever see and the product he was marketing was himself.
author: Steve S.

description: This is one great museum experieance. Total adult experience not a kid thing by any means, the few children I saw there were Bored! Plan on a good 4 hours as this is not a quick experience, much to read and view absorb, comprehend, and discuss.
author: Miller S.

description:
I enjoyed this museum very much it was very informative. it's not just based on Disneyland. It is indeed the history of the Disney family and Walt himself. You really get a feel of how Walt had a passion for drawing and art in general. He was man with a vision and put it on paper and brought it to life There is so much to see and read that 2 to 3 hours is needed to visit this place.

I was amazed with the Disneyland model that they have inside the museum very detailed and it almost like you can see yourself walking down mainstreet. I would have to say this was my favorite part.  

I was also impacted by the last part of the museum where all the newspapers ran there interpretations of Walts death and how the nation mourned his passing.

The only downside was someone pulled a fire alarm and we had to evacuate the building. When we got back inside some of the Audio Visual stuff was not operating and took 40 min to come back on.
author: anthony e.

description: Wow. There's a lot of stuff here. Exceedingly well done, but it is a lot to digest in one stroll. I say visit a few times and take it in doses. Fascinating stuff, even if you aren't a fan.
author: Jon J.

description:
I agree with the other reviews - this place is not for children. I went on a weekday and it was a beautiful day outside, which means the view of the Golden Gate Bridge was amazing. Parking was also a breeze at the lot across the street. It was nearly empty and you pay with a credit card at the machine (it does not accept cash). I don't remember the exact rates, but I do remember it was really reasonable. Like a dollar an hour or something like that...

I paid $15 for admission (with the student discount) and I think the price was just about right. I spent over three hours there and enjoyed it. I read pretty much all of the displays - starting with the awards and keys to the city in the lobby area before the ticket entrance. 

I LOVE everything Disney and learned a lot visiting the museum about Walt Disney's life and the creation and growth of Disney the company. 

The reason I give it 3 stars is because I would not go back again. The food selection and prices are a bit high and the items in the small gift shop are definitely overpriced. I also found the people who work there to be a bit unwelcoming - maybe I expected the usual Disney demeanor...
author: L H.

description:
What an amazing place. I am not going to review the exhibits in the museum because there is so much and it is all GREAT. A truly complete journey of the life of Walt Disney from pre-birth to passing. Amazing. 

Plan on spending ALL DAY here, you will need to if you truly want to see everything. 

They now allow you to take non-flash pictures inside now which is great in some places but the light levels are low and most of the lightibg is in a direction that is not conductive to taking pictures. But some of it works which is better than before when you could not take any pictures inside.

I was also very surprised to run into Walt's daughter Dianne who was VERY nice. We talked to her for a few minutes and even took a picture with her. But she was VERY nice and we saw here walking thru the museum talking to kids and other families. Such an unexpected treat and a great memory.

They do have a small food area with even a smaller eating area. You really have no options in the area so you are forced to scope out a table and all huddle around it to eat. But the food is not great- I had a salad that was turning brown and the wife had a sandwich that was soggy and also old. Kids had the chili that was greasy... its rare my kids say no to chili but this was one of those times.

The gift shop is somewhat disappointing and is what is keeping this from a 5 star rating for me. I am a huge Disney fan and like to get things with the name of the location on them. I want to have a shirt with the museum logo on it more than a random Disney design that could have been purchased anywhere. The selection of logo material was horrible. They had one shirt in long sleeve that had the true logo on it and it was only in size small. When I asked if they had more shirts with that logo on it I was told it was discontinued and they were trying to get away with the logo with Walt's face on it. WHAT? I had to settle for the logo with Mickey on it, not bad but not what I wanted. We did pick up a magnet, a pin and a key chain with the Walt logo on it as well as other items that said the name of the museum on it. But a bigger selection of logo material is desperately needed. I was really ready to spend a few hundred dollars on this stuff but only spent around $90. It was really the only let down of the day (was not expecting giid food do that part was not a let down lol) - granted not a major let down, but still.... I want more WDFM logo merch!
author: Mark P.

description: Finally San Francisco got a museum that is famous. I love the Walt Disney Museum. Instead of going to Disneyland to find out about Disney I can just go here.
author: Ronald N.

description: Today was my first visit and I loved it! The museum is laid out well and feels much like you are walking through Walt Disney's biography.  His story is fascinating and is told through many different methods- plaques to read, short films, memorabilia, etc. If you are a Disney fan, you will love it here. I loved the mini Disneyland set, so awesome! The museum is mainly for adults as it includes quite a bit of reading. Although, I think it would be a nice place to take an artistically inclined teenager. It is a very extensive tour of Walt Disney's life, dreams and accomplishments in a museum that is not overdone or becomes exhausting. Everything is well presented to maintain interest. Parking is easy and right in front of the building. You will spend about 3 hours minimum on your first visit here if you are a Disney fan.
author: Mistress E.

description:
We were warmly greeted at the door by museum staff with a welcoming smile! Upon entering I gave quick thought to membership, since it offered return visits. My husband and I joined, and after having experienced the wonderful museum am happy we did! We plan on returning to visit the theatre, and monthly planned events.
Set in the beautiful Presidio area, The Walt Disney Family Museum is a jem. It offers a glimpse into Walt Disney's family life and features a beautiful display of original work. It is truly amazing to think of the number of people that have been touched by a single person, in such a happy and memorable way. 
The gift store is nicely done, and I enjoyed the quality items offered. The bathrooms were spotless, and the views are nothing short of spectacular!
My husband and I will return again, and again. Thank you!
author: Robin G.

description: I thought it was great! They have a room that resembles the animation studio room in california adventure and the layout is very unique. I especially enjoyed the movie and the mini layout of disneyland. It was great and as much as people say it isn't for children, my daughter enjoyed it as much as i did!!
author: Deanna W.

description: Had a great time at the museum.  Took our 11 & 12 yo kids.  There is a lot of reading, but a decent amount of interactions and presentation styles.  Made for a pleasant 2-3 hours.  Probably wouldn't have been as good for younger kids.
author: Kyle O.

description: Great exhibit and lots of interesting artwork and information to look at. The museum is very clean and staff are friendly. Museum was definitely bigger than expected, and took about 2.5 hours to go through, and that's without reading everything.
author: Annie H.

description: Good museum, not necessarily for children though. Found the entrance fee a bit price!  and the gift shop isn't impressive,  especially for disney...
author: Caroline D.

description: Not so much for kids but better for adults who have patience to read!! Mainly exhibits and drawings &posters. Good two hours! Great parking
author: Veranna N.

description: The Walt Disney Family Museum contains a comprehensive history of Walt Disney's life. It's definitely not Disneyland/Disneyworld, so don't go there expecting that. I also wouldn't recommend going with children under the age of 10 (unless they enjoy reading a lot) or with people who are not interested in Disney. I really enjoyed perusing the galleries and learning more about Walt Disney. My favorite part was the small scale version of past/current Disneyland, so neat! There were also a few interactive portions which were fun. Everything felt like it was thoughtfully included in the museum, as if someone who cared very much had collected everything and put it in it's place. The museum shop has tons of cool things - I wish I had more room in my suitcase to buy more! Definitely a must visit once in your life for any Disney fan.  Note: no photography allowed once you enter the museum galleries.
author: Amanda Z.

description: I don't consider myself a Disney fanatic, but I found this museum absolutely fascinating. You really feel apart of Disney's rich and emcompassing history, rather than just being a spectator looking in. I would recommend for adults and kids 10 and up. The little guys will probably get a little restless before you reach the end - and the end took 3 hours for me to reach, the best 3 hours of my 2 days in San Francisco!
author: Sean R.

description: I can spend hours here. I've been going ever since I was a kid and still enjoy it to date. They keep finding ways to make it better, every year i have more fun than the year before.
author: Mary S.

description:
Why the one star - to warn those who think their children will also enjoy the museum. I honestly thought the "Family" in "The Walt Disney Family Museum" stood for all families, but once inside  it became clear it meant the Walt Disney Family, more like a shrine for Mr. Disney.

All of the other reviews are very favorable and rightfully so - for adults. I enjoyed this remarkable museum for the same reasons cited in the other 140 plus reviews. However, for the two six year olds that accompanied me (the reason for going) were bored from the very beginning. The description on the ticket provides a strong hint as to how children are going to respond to this place - "no cell phone, no photography, no strollers, no backpacks, no food and no beverages - the only 'no' missing was no children.

Yes, I know what you're thinking, "hey dummy, it's a museum, what did you expect." Well...what I expected is the same magic a child feels when visiting Disneyland, or watching a Disney movie, or wearing a Disney costume, what I didn't expect was a museum as serious and as strict as the Louvre. Actually the Louvre permits photography, video, strollers and cell phones like most other museums. 

The two girls did find some entertainment value in the barrow stools that lied in front of a small movie screen. Resourceful as children are they turned the stools on their side and straddled them like a horse which only lasted 30 seconds when an employee asked them to stop.  Children six and older are charged $12, money that would be better spent on a Disney movie. 

If you want insight into this wonderful and remarkable man who has entertained us during our childhood, the museum does that and more, but leave the children at home, with the sitter and some Disney movies.
author: Larry S.

description: Always love Disney Animated Movies, seen how it's in production, and their history it's amazing, my son certainly love the trip.
author: Nicole L.

description:
If you are interested in understanding WHY the greats of this world do what they do then you will definately enjoy The Walt Disney Family Museum.  
I won't go into detail about the exhibits as these other Yelpers have done so thoroughly but I will add that what impressed me the most was the absolute engrossing theme of it all.  Each "chapter" of Walt's life is covered in the various rooms and each room has a distinct feel to it.  My favorites being the True-Life Adventure section, the SPECTACULAR Disneyland section (literally made me gasp when I walked in) and the somber and perfectly executed final room commemorating Walt's death and the world wide reaction to it.
I did work at Disneyland for a long time, and was involved in Disney University and Training for a stint so none of the information was new to me, but I was still engrossed with the detail and the cutting edge technology used.  
I can say without hesitation that The Walt Disney Family Museum is the most spectacular and innovated museum I have ever been to!  GO!
author: Bill J.

description: This is the quintessential exhibit on the life and times of the great Walt Disney. One should budget at least four hours to profit from the experience.
author: Laurence B.

description: I'm not going to say a whole lot here except that this museum is really worth going to.  I was quite impressed throughout.  I did not know much about Walt Disney and what he was all about and left knowing lots of him and what he has done.  Remarkable many with dreams that became reality despite all the obstacles in his way.  Lots to learn about the history and development of animated film.  Great for both adults and kids.  Free coat check and parking.
author: Don J.

description: I didn't quite understand the connection to San Francisco and the Walt Disney Family, but the Museum is a real winner.  If you are a fan of all things Disney, this is a must see.  Free Parking at the Presidio can't be beat either.  I thought we might spend a couple hours browsing through, but we were there for nearly five hours, that seemed to fly by on how well this is done.  It starts out very simple and as you continue to progress from room to room, gets more and more complex and bigger and better culminating in a scale size view of Disneyland that is wonderful to look at at all angles.  Even the elevator ride from one floor to the next is themed so the guest experience was well crafted at every stop.   Includes a couple of movie options, one made for the museum and the day I was there a showing of Nightmare Before Christmas.  I can see a Pixar exhibit coming in the future as a special exhibit - not necessarily part of the Disney family, but part of the Disney company and in the "hood" so to speak, so would be interesting to see a special exhibit.  No trip to a Disney attraction would be complete without a gift shop, and this one has some items I hadn't seen anywhere else.  Well worth your time.
author: Steve A.

description: A must see for Walt Disney fans and anyone who has any interest in the life of this legendary hero of animation.  T he museum is well designed, informative and  visually very pleasing.  Best of all, since it is located in the Presidio, there is cheap parking and views of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Ani K.

description:
It's magical! A little bit of Disney heaven in the middle of a state park and so close to my house can only mean all plusses everywhere.

From the outside, it's unassuming and that's deliberate, otherwise, the Presidio trust would never okay the WD museum to be built here...it completely blends in with the other barracks, with only a sign outside to tell visitors that it is the Walt Disney Museum.  But once you enter inside, it's definitely going to be an experience. The lobby houses tons of Disney's awards (I believe that they have more in storage but not all are on display). They had the famous Shirley Temple presentation of the 7 mini Oscars behind glass, as well as Disney's furniture from Disneyland that he had used in his hidden apartment. The shop and cafe area are also on this level. If you're a museum member, you get 10% off on the merchandise.

There's 3 levels, the main level explains Disney's childhood years, and it has really cute cut-out animation with Disney's own voice telling his childhood stories, and there's a real cool Red Cross ambulance from WWI. You need to ride an elevator up to the second level, and the elevator decor is supposed to re-enact the inside of the Santa Fe train (don't pull on the shades, they don't move).
On level 2, is Disney and his brother's efforts in Hollywood. Please do listen to the old-timey phone sets, Mr. Disney voices his stories again on those phones. The next rooms are the Mickey years (ooo...Mickey's original merchandise wall!!! Ewww...original stuffed Mickey is ugly!) the Silly Symphonies room (ewww, original Donald has no pants! hehe), the Snow White/Bambi/Pinocchio/Fantasia rooms were beautiful. I really like seeing the workers' commissary menu (who knew you can get filet mignon for 15 cents??? And butter milk??)

The section for the union strike and the war years were informative, and the true life series along the wall with the Golden Gate panorama view was cool, but the gemstone of the museum is definitely Disney's Disneyland area. You see Disney's Lily Belle train and the progression of Disney's Land, then the piece de resistance: a miniature of the entire conception of Disneyland.  If you look straight through main street through Sleeping Beauty castle, you'll notice 2 tiny figures: it's Walt Disney and his child. The park also will go from Daylight to night time...NICE!

The latter parts are the tv shows, the live action movies and then the really sad room: Disney's death...(my friend always runs past this room cause she doesn't want to see the sadness). 

The lower level houses a theater, workshop rooms, a free coat room, and an art gallery. 

Free parking outside, and sometimes if you're lucky, you'll meet Diane Disney Miller...the wonderful lady behind her father's museum.
