author: Pauline L.

description: An amazing place to really learn about this genius and all his many unknown innovations. Well put together highly recommend.
author: Sean T.

description: This was a great find on the suggestion of local family.  It is very different from your typical museum in that it doesn't only showcase the art of Disney, but his family history and history of the Disney legacy.  They also had a special exhibition from Tyrus Wong with whom Disney collaborated with on Bambi.  While I wasn't familiar with Wong before today, his art and kites (yep the flying kind) were just beautiful.  It made for a great activity on our last day in San Francisco this trip and I highly recommend it if you are an art or a Disney fan.  Plus, it is located in the Presidio, now a national parks area and it is just beautiful with loads of sidewalks and green space.
author: Jeaux B.

description:
Finally went here on their one year anniversary and i loved what it had to offer.  it was simply Walt Disney's life in a museum.  It's a place any true Disney fan will love.  It's like going on a journey through one's life from start to finish and observing everything they did.  it's fabulous to look into Walt's life and see how he took care of the things he kept and is now being displayed in one sacred place and luckily it is in Northern California where its not "so LA" that it might get into all that Hollywood glam if it was there.  so it's here in a place where it can be appreciated and admired without all that hype and circumstance.  In the end, it is like arriving at his grave because you do go through his ENTIRE life.  all that was missing was his grave.  I was in tears at the end and realized how good people die young and the most beloved people can truly touch our hearts in the most profound way.  

As a die-hard Disney fan, i cannot say i would go there all the time though.  I do admit that you can soak up all the Disney information and history in this place but it's a good place to go with other Disney people that are interested in knowing Walt Disney.  

I love that parking is not a problem here either.
author: Daphne A.

description: I'm not a Disney fan but this museum tells the biography of Walt Disney in a compelling and interesting manner.  It's fine for kids but I found it more geared towards adults.  The only downside is getting here via public transportation can be a bit tough.
author: Roger H.

description:
We loved this place. The museum is very artfully designed. The displays are excellent. 
What an amazing story of creativity, art, technology and the incredible talent of Mr.Disney! 
I'm old enough to have lived through and enjoyed all of it so this was particularly touching to me. Yet I learned a great deal, both about this wonderfully talented man and the products that his team produced.
I'd go again in a heartbeat.
author: Larry T.

description: I'm a huge Disney fan and so I was excited that they had a museum in my city.  I couldn't wait to go.  Unfortunately the first time I went, we had my son and he had to be  in a stroller and they don't allow strollers.  I didn't like that all too much.  So our first visit was very limited but of course we went again but this time without my son.  I had a great time learning about the Disney background.  All the photos and videos were very entertaining.  I don't know if I'd keep going again and again but it's a great one or more two time visit.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I have purchased the tickets via an online deal, for half of a regular price. The museum consists of 10 galleries, each of which you could give at least half an hour. The galleries are more for adults rather than for children, they walk you through the history of Walt Disney's family, of the development of his ideas, history of multiplication and animation as related to his world, and his fight to succeed. You will also see multiple snippets if various cartoon and animated movies. The developers of the museum has put enormous efforts into the presentation, and you can easily call it a World Class museum. I and my boyfriend had about 2.5 hours to spend there, and we could easily come back and enjoy it again, as there is so much to see. If this is your first time there, try to give yourself at least 3 hours, and do not purchase a special exhibition tickets, as you would have neither time nor energy left to cover that as well. If it is your only opportunity to visit this museum, then... you should decide what you want to see and go with that:, whether it is the main collection or a special exhibit. A side note- after exiting the museum, take a quick walk to the back of the building and catch the sunset with the Golden Gate Bridge at the background!
PS a special exhibit might get the kids' attention, but the main galleries are definitely more for adults.
author: Alina T.

description: Give yourself 2-3 hours and don't let your GPS take you to the wrong Montgomery!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This place  rocks - if you are fascinated with Disney and animation. My family and I are, and spending 4 hours there wasn't enough. It's expensive -  $20 for adults and $12 for kids. On the positive side, if you are a Mary Blair fanatic (as my daughter and I are), the gift shop will make you swoon with richness. 
A little hard to find. I recommend taking the whole day and pausing between rooms to not overwhelm your senses. I plan on returning soon. 

IMPORTANT - by family, they mean the exhibit is about Walt Disney's family - this is NOT for little kids - I'd say be at least 12 years old to really appreciate the Museum and not bug the adults to leave. After 4 hours I still hadn't finished what I wanted to see.
author: jul m.

description: By far the best museum I have ever been to. Granted, I am partial to the subject-matter as a life long fan of the Disney empire and Walt himself, but even so, this place is incredibly well done. Each room tells a section of Walt's life chronologically. What amazed some of the people I was with is that you had to go through almost 80% of the museum before even anything was mentioned about Disneyland! The fact is, Walt had a lot of accomplishments prior to that point, and a life that is interesting enough to fill a museum. By the last rooms, I literally teared up while reading Walt's obituary and gazing at the wall of cartoons published after his death. It's a powerful experience in an extremely well done museum.
author: Nina G.

description:
Absolutely loved it!  Spent four hours and want to go back.  I know I didn't see or read everything.  I loved Walt Disney as a child, as a mother and now as a grandmother.  His genius entertained generations and will continue to do so.  What a remarkable life and story this museum provides for everyone.  His dedication to making children and families happy is priceless.  Thank you Walt and thank you Diane.  
Joy W
author: Joy W.

description:
This is an inspiring museum and a wonderful place ...Do NOT MISS IT!
Anyone who admires innovation and creativity and perseverance and fine values and high ethics will be inspired and thrilled to learn more about the life and leadership of Walt Disney. 

A suggestion for them is that they can definitely do some more to give young families with little or preteen kids who grew up on Little Mermaid (or what ever) a bit more of a current Disney movie section/place to go to allow the kids to be more interactive and active (make your own Disney movie plot etc) and leave the rest of the museum the way it is for us who appreciate the ideas and the history of what Walt thought up and built.

Also
 They should move the war film history part to be more available to be seen and understood by all since evidently by making a film on the topic of airpower, Walt made a huge  impact on the decision to have an American airforce fighting power without which i shudder to think where we as a country, America, would be today!

The museum brilliantly showcases again and again Walt's wisdom in having an objective and sticking to it and going for high quality.
Now where do we buy copies of the nature films or the adventure films?
Janet Beach
author: Janet B.

description: It was a total surprise how good this museum was.  It was well laid layout.  Informative and entertaining.  We also saw the snow white exhibit.  Again the presentation was great.  This is not for young kids.  It gave us a new appreciation for everything Walt Disney did. Highly recommend seeing this.
author: Pauline B.

description: What a great find!  It's nice to learn about the humanistic, family side of the Disney empire.  There's nothing about the corporate Disney here--it's all about Walt and his family's climb to the top.  Loved the early sketches of Mickey and the interviews with old-timer illustrators.  I really appreciated the timed entry, because it doesn't get too crowded so you don't have to fight to read the display plaques. Beautiful setting too, in the Presidio right by the Bay Bridge.
author: Mithra H.

description: Spent 3 hours here.  Had a great time with my 2 Disneyland buddies Kim and Grace
author: Linda L.

description: Great Place, maybe not for a 4 year old, but if they like looking at TV's then it will work. Food prices reasonable, movie with the cost of admission...All this good stuff made me get a membership, should pay for itself after a few visits. Great place for the Disney Historian.
author: Scott D.

description: Wonderful museum that can be toured in 2.75 hours or so. Went here this past Saturday with my husband who is not much of a Disney fan. After the tour, he said he loved it, and appreciated all of the thought and effort put into putting the collection on display. The museum takes you through the stages of Walt's life, and is more about his family then it is about "Disney Co". We both really enjoyed that you not only see the highs but the lows that influenced Walt's work, interests, and loves. Very low key and in a beautiful setting. I would definitely recommend to anyone.
author: Erin M.

description: Very nice time here.  Earliest known pics of one mickey mouse.  Lots to take in and lots of history. Probably needs more than one tour to see and learn from the displays.  Only family history focuses before he was born ???
author: Dandyd S.

description:
This museum is a must if you love all things disney and even for those of you who kind of like disney, maybe you got annoyed with it at one point, but want to come back, or appreciate the good times you had as a child via disney parks, movies, and tv.  The museum is strictly about walt's life and everything that happened in that time. Do not go here if you want to learn about aladdin, lion king, or anything disney past 1965 (the year Walt Disney died).

There are two levels of exhibits along with a gift shop and an extra area with a theater and mini exhibit (it is currently peter pan now).  Tickets are $20 and $15 for students and seniors. Entry is timed, but they weren't strict when I went. They made it this way because there is a lot to read and it's annoying when there is a giant group of people trying to read the same thing - no thanks.  

The museum did a great job integrating multiple forms of media, from traditional written descriptions on the wall and in front of the object, to mixed media cartoon with photos and walt's voice narrating his youth, to audio clips of walt through hand held old time phone receivers, to large tv screens playing disney cartoons and videos from walts life, to a ribbon like HD screen showing clips of disney movies.  There are also many interactive exhibits where you attempt to match the sound effects to steamboat willie and match music to the movie and learn a little bit about appropriate tempo and mood.  

Enjoy the silly symphonies, disneyland tv, miniature replica of the original disneyland park, and world's fair exhibits from 1964 (I found out this was my parents third date and it was cute to see them both view this exhibit and reminisce).

I tend to rush through musuems, but i spent over 5 hours here.  Luckily, there is ample free parking in the presidio!

I found Walt's life to be very inspiring and would recommend that everyone learn more about him and his dream.
author: Valerie S.

description: really a fun museum and soooo well done. Give yourself at least 2-3hrs. A little pricey, but worth it as they spared no expense. It's a walk through animation history.
author: jessica a.

description: Great Museum, Well laid out,  lots to see, touch and read,  very friendly staff.  This is not for young kids.   Great for older kids who can read and have an interest in Disney!   The cafe is nice and has a good variety on the menu. The restrooms are on the top and bottom floors.  Lots of parking. Beautiful views of the GG Bridge from the top floor.  A must see for all Disney fans.
author: Deborah F.

description: This is an extraordinary museum. We only made it thru 1/2 the exhibits and will definitely return to see the rest.  Not for kids.
author: Karen F.

description:
We dropped by on Sunday afternoon without advance tickets, walked right in, and spent  close to 3 hours with minimal crowds . Would recommend to future out-of-town visitors, but would be unlikely to go back again by ourselves. The subject matter entertains a somewhat self-limiting audience, including those who grew up between the 1940's-60's or are interested in animation, film, etc. Those younger may find displays of how it was done "in the olden days before computers" to be tedious.

The exhibits are extremely well-done -- leveraging current technology to meet the various ways in which people can learn. Short audio and video presentations are spread throughout the exhibits, complementing  original documents, drawings, and photos. Information is often repeated in more than one medium, so whether you prefer to listen or read, you won't miss out. And instead of waiting for your turn in a little video cubicle, typical of many museums, there are few bottlenecks in the exhibit flow.

Be forewarned, restrooms are available after more than half-way thru the exhibits. Which is why that area is one of two we found to be more crowded -- the other being towards the end with a plethora of framed tributes at Walt's passing. Is there some intended analogy to feeling as if one is in a slowly narrowing birth canal filled with these accolades, then passing thru a doorway into a large oval room with the final pictorial celebration of his life?

Also be aware that the museum signs are impossible to see from the parking lot -- we had actually been there months ago with visitors and left when we couldn't see where the museum was -- the Presidio restricts larger signs.
author: Karen-n-Rick C.

description: Really nice museum in a beautiful location.  If you're interested in Walt Disney's life story you'll find this museum fascinating.  We purchased tickets online for a Sunday morning, but we arrived a bit earlier than our scheduled time window and they didn't seem to mind.  It wasn't crowded on Sunday morning but it was packed by the time we left at 1:30 p.m.  I didn't time the tour (it's self-paced) but there's a lot to see here so allow yourself at least an hour or more.  I didn't see many small kids here, but the older ones seemed entertained.
author: Kenny P.

description:
This is not a museum for families, it is a museum about the history of the "Disney Family" and Walt Disney's long and varied career. There is nothing there for kids, and most teens would probably get bored too. However it is an exceptional museum for adults who grew up with Disney cartoons, films, and TV shows. And visual art and film buffs/students would also enjoy it.

Note for seniors and others who can't stand for too long: the first 2-3 galleries do not have any benches or any place to sit.

Note for those with "hearing" disorders: there are lots of audio/visual displays going all the time whose sound levels overlap, so it can be hard to filter out the sound from nearby displays while you're trying to listen to another.
author: P B.

description:
If you are a Walt fan and want to learn about Walt-the-man from birth to death, this is a MUST-SEE destination. If you are a typical family with a dog and 2.5 children thinking this will be Disney in San Fran, you will be disappointed.

We went to the Walt Disney Museum with my retired In-laws and my 9 year old daughter. We had read other Yelp reviews and set proper expectations with my 9 year old to the point that we had to talk her into going. She didn't hate it....she didn't love it. She did tolerate it for a 3 hour visit.

If you are a Disney FANATIC without kids, you can easily spend 4-5 hours going through the museum viewing all of the videos, reading all of Walt's letters to Roy and others, reading the dozens of pre-war Telegrams, watching the home movies, etc. Really fascinating stuff for the Disney fan.  If you are a casual fan you will also enjoy it, you will simply spend 90 minutes instead of 4-5 hours. 

The museum itself it not Disney-esq on the outside, as it is in a Presidio building that (I assume) is a historic building that cannot be altered, so other than a small Disney Museum sign, you would have no clue what is inside. Once you step inside, you will see that the museum is exceptionally done in typical Disney quality, it is really well done. Nice blend of history with technology with many interactive exhibits, some of these will appeal to the young kids. There is also a small cafe and a nice gift shop.  The location is great inside the beautiful Presidio, right near the Golden Gate Bridge (with gorgeous views from one of the galleries!). Parking is plentiful and free right in front of the museum, a nice treat for San Fran.

Bottom line, if you are Disney fan, GO TO THIS MUSEUM. If you are fanatical, spend 4-5 hours. If you are a casual fan, plan on 2-3 hours. If you have pre-teens or toddlers in tow, either skip it, or go and plan to spend 60-90 minutes.
author: Craig C.

description: I never even knew this place existed until an unexpected surprise from a special someone.  No I never been to Disneyland, but in the mean time, he surprised me and took me here :).  Walked in an the history of Walt Disney was cool.  All the art work was amazing,  Throughout the whole tour you either pass by a piece of art work, short film, vintage disney goods such as mickey toy figurines, etc.... Price was a bit steep for this exhibit.  It was an ok for me.  Worth checking out if you dont mind chilling out $20.  Forgot to mention there is plenty of free parking and a great view of the bay bridge from inside the museum.  :)
author: Mimi S.

description: Being a former cast member at Disneyland, you would think I would know everything Disney, well I guess I was wrong. This museum was difficult to find since I was walking 6 miles to here from the Caltrain station across town and had never been here before. Upon entering the building, you wouldn't expect a museum this beautiful from the way it looked outside. The museum was perfectly laid out with lots of interactive features such as interactive touchscreen containing everything Disney. Obviously my favorite part was the large scale model of Disneyland from the 50's and 60's. Much more impressive than the model they have at the Opera House in Disneyland. Like everyone else has said, this is not a kid friendly museum. I don't know if the expansion of California Adventure will still include the Walt Disney Story, but I can guarantee that this is probably 10 times more informative. A must for all Disney fans.
author: Paul N.

description:
This museum, quite simply, is an amazing assembly of history and innovation.

As someone who appreciates Disneyland prior to the newer changes in the theme park, it is great seeing the original model of the theme park as it was originally conceived by Walt Disney.

More importantly, going into this museum gives you a new found appreciation for Walt Disney, regardless of whether you have a positive or negative opinion on the man himself.  First you see the early history of Disney as he's born in the very early 20th century, as well as some of the first jobs he had before moving to Los Angeles.  Then you get to see Disney Studios, prior to its development, particularly with some controversies Disney faced with certain investors he dealt with.  At some point, you will then get to see the original drawing paint used for animated classics like Snow White & the Seven Dwarfs, sitting in jars (not even empty).  Then of course you see the various periods in time which Disney, himself, was faced with political and world events and how he dealt with such events as far as making appealing motion pictures.  The whole history continues on and on, it's as if you're being transported back into time and being apart of Disney's life.  Really, the Walt Disney Museum explains the WHOLE history, even the not too great parts that happened in Disney's life.

However, what really touched me the most about this museum was a video of Walt Disney and other voice over artists practicing their craft and bouncing ideas back and forth as far as how to appropriately illustrate the characters.  Not everyone knows this but Walt Disney did voice over work for a number of early Disney pictures.  In this video with Disney and the voice over artists, you can see Disney with a lot of smiles, clearly excited and enthusiastic about practicing the voices with his team.  It is clear that Disney wasn't just a CEO, he was an innovator and loved making films.  This is a stark contrast compared to when Michael Eisner was CEO of Disney Studios, even Robert Iger who is running the Disney Studios these days.  Anyone who loves filmmaking and not the big studios would really appreciate this video.

I encourage anyone who loves Disneyland, Disneyworld, Disney films, is an animator, filmmaker or likes Disney to go to the Walt Disney Museum.  It is an experience you'll never forget.
author: M B.

description: I wish to go back to this museum. Kinda pricey $20.00 per adult admission and $6 for kids. But I wanna  know more about the great thinking behind this man --- Walt. It amazes me how he collected ideas and brought it to life. Even now that I'm older , which I'm sure I'm not only speaking for myself, I still enjoy visiting Disneyland. That's why we try to take the kids once a year.
author: Eva D.

description: OK, five stars for Uncle Walt.  You know, I was surprised that I have heard virtually no buzz about this museum which is an excellent exploration of the art of animation and creativity in general.  It tells you how Disney built the empire.  It is loaded with artifacts like old cameras and drawings, and includes all of his Oscars on display.  Uncle Walt (actually my real uncles were nothing like Walt) comes across here as a flawlessly nice and creative family man.  I was quietly hoping for some depravity but the closest was an exhibit on a strike of the Disney studios.   It is called the Disney Family Museum but I believe that refers to Walt's family (much in evidence here) and is not meant to suggest that this is a place especially for the kiddies.  There were no kids in evidence when I went although there's probably enough representations of Mickey and the gang to keep them occupied while you envy Walt's great and productive life.
author: Frank B.

description:
Great museum for fans of Walt - not geared toward kids so much.  Excellent exhibits with easy to read/follow flow thru the different galleries.  We would like to have stayed to see 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea but didn't have time.  I'd suggest going early or on a weekday to be able to really enjoy and peruse the exhibits.  

It does take awhile to go thru all of the halls of the exhibit and there's so much to see and read.  I'd definitely return!
author: kathe r.

description: Wow, so much more than I expected!  A very elaborate, very large, very interactive experience that clearly is a labor of love (and of a lot of money spent)!  The overview of Disney family history is impressive--and the story of The Walt Disney Company and Walt Disney the man (along with the rest of the Disney family) are interwoven in a facsinating story.
author: Darren J.

description:
Welcome,
Been a member of the Disney Family Museum since it opened October 2009. (Membership fee is tax deductible).
You will experience the most innovative displays anywhere.
There is so much to see and see again. Just today, my fifth visit, I found new displays I had not notice before.
Ten galleries of display in all.  From the beginning of Walt's life and to his final day at the age of 65.  That last gallery before you exit leaves you very emotionally sad.
One visit is not enough to absorb the information and displays.  Very creative displays with audio and hands on experience.  They got the largest Itouch screen to play with.
Lots of hands on display.  High tech display you never seen anywhere.  True to form, Disney is the first to make things special.
Access to the museum is easy and free parking is never a problem.
Bring your own lunch basket and sit on the lawn or porch table. Enjoy the scenery during your break and resume your visit back inside.
Be sure to bring some cash to purchase collectibles from the store.
author: Paul G.

description: Stunning, original, interactive, and beautifully designed.  I learned so much about Walt Disney, and to appreciate him even more than I did before.  It was very interesting to read about the professional difficulties he encountered during WWII and a union strike, too.  How many times that man took risks, is amazing, and what a payoff his legacy is for the entire world!  I spent 3 hours here and didn't see enough and will be back.  $20 price tag is pretty high though.  Students $15, kids $12.  My kids put up with the visit because it was for my birthday, but they were not as interested in absorbing every detail as I was, so they rested on benches (very glad for the benches) and napped in dark corners on the floor.  When I go back, it will be without anyone under the age of maybe 30, although there is a theater where I could perhaps have parked them where the old Parent Trap was playing, so perhaps you could work your trip around the movie schedule.
author: Kim S.

description:
Just went to this museum for the first time today with my brother, mom and dad. We all loved it, and thought it was one of the best museums we have ever been to in terms of an in depth profile of a legend. It completely covered the company's history, Walt's creative process, his family history and how that influenced his work, and huge amounts of film clips and memorabilia. 

The most impressive thing about Walt Disney was his vision, and how that vision created the long form animation film, three dimensional animation photography, and redefined amusement parks and family entertainment. 

We spent two and a half hours in the museum, and bought memberships because we felt like we could have spent several more hours and still not gotten through all of the material presented. 

It was fun, informative, inspiring, creative, and a great way to spend an afternoon. The facility is so well done, and the information so cleverly presented, and doesn't have any of the cheesy commercialism that has unfortunately taken over Disneyland and Disney World. All of the exhibits are interactive, and just fascinating.

Small children will probably be bored. It's not an amusement park, and has huge amounts of information to read, listen to, and watch.
author: Lisa L.

description: You will enjoy this museum if you want to learn about the man who built the happiest place on earth.  I paid $15 with student ID and spent a good time learning about Walt Disney's life. There are so many interesting things to see and read. If you get tired from walking, there are places to sit down. I saw bored kids sleeping on the benches while their parents were looking at the gallery. This place is definitely not for kids and those who do not like reading.
author: Vicky K.

description: I agree with Suzie Q's 29 December review...make sure to plan more time!  I took my 10-year old and his best friend here on a Saturday morning and thought 2.5 hours would be enough (calculating into that the possibility of boredom on their part).  No way!  Was I surprised!  The boys were totally fascinated with almost everything they encountered.  We ended up having lunch there and wanting to come back again one day.  Although I was fascinated with Walt's life when I was my son's age, I never dreamed that such an incredible collection of his life's work was assembled in this museum.  I wish I planned 3-4 hours...but never mind, we'll be back for sure!
author: Randy D.

description:
The most important stuff first: Please don't take your (young) kids here. If they don't have good attention spans and/or dislike large amounts of reading, this isn't going to be their thing. You can take kids when they're about 10 or so, and if they're interested in learning about Walt Disney. The man, not the Park. If that doesn't sound like your kid, then this isn't the place for you. This isn't a replacement for Disneyland.

And that's one of the reasons why I love it so much. I still love Disneyland--and am looking forward to my next trip in July--but I've been here twice and felt that my $15 admission (student rate!) was well worth it. I came here in February with my family (dad, 18-yr-old brother, 15-yr-old sister) and then my boyfriend in late April.

The museum itself advises about two hours for a complete tour, but I'd give yourself around three. It's nice to go through at a leisurely pace, especially if--like me--you find yourself fascinated by concept art of the films or the conversations and speeches you can listen to on old-fashioned phones. 

The family and I left momentarily for lunch--and even got wristbands so we could come back, which was nice--about halfway through our tour. The boyfriend and I had eaten beforehand and we were able to go through the entire museum without a bathroom break.

The museum primarily focuses on things that the company did during Walt's lifetime, so you see everything from the earliest cartoons he did in Kansas City to what he was working on at the time of his death. Films covered are everything from Snow White to Mary Poppins, and it also features the first ever diorama of Disneyland Park. They incorporate both the 1955 elements and the 2010 elements in the diorama, which I thought was a nice touch.

The gift shop's very expensive (although this depends on your taste), but offers really cute Disney merchandise you don't find anywhere else. I fell in love with a Snow White purse that was unfortunately $80: more than I can justify spending on something as replaceable as a purse. Maybe someday when I am not a student, it can be mine. :(

I can't wait to go back again :)
author: Kirsten M.

description: This place is good to go for those that like the history of Disney, old Disney stuff, or like Disney as a whole. The museum is small, but it is nice. I personally think they should get some more building space so they can attract more tourists. Kids might get bored, but then again, you have kids of many personalities: some that enjoy learning and observing in museums, and some that don't. It also depends how those kids are feeling that day they go to any museum.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: This was such a treat. Located in The Presidio with a breathtaking view of The Golden Gate Bridge and bay.  The Disney history from start to finish is fascinating. There are many personal items from the family in the museum dating back to 1887 as well as antique cameras used to film Walt's first creations.  You will also find information on the illustration, the challenges he faced and how he overcame them.  Very inspiring.  Go!
author: Kim R.

description: I was lucky enough to score a pair of preview passes to the museum. :)  It has a WONDERFUL collection of photos and memorabilia of the Disney family and company.  It was really cool to see the progression of the Disney empire and the mini model of Disneyland was freaken amazing. I absolutely loved all the sketches of Mickey Mouse, the seven dwarfs, the 300 still-drawings that would make up merely a minute of animated footage...I can go on and on...but I would definitely recommend checking it out.  Made me want to do a Disney movie marathon and change my ringtone to "Hi Hooooooo."
author: Rose J.

description:
If you are in any way a fan of history and Disney, this is the place for you...don't be fooled by the "1 to 1-1/2 hours" they say it will take you to get through the place, which is extremely well planned and layed out, is only true if... you just walk through and glance at everything. We went on Sunday, 10/18, with our daughters and a friend (5 of us) and it took the whole group almost 5 hours to get through it all...and we STILL missed some stuff! This place is packed with FAMILY MEMORABILIA donated by many and consolidated into this collection by Diane Disney Miller. As the news stories said, this place is a technological wonder, being so close to Silicon Valley, that uses every available CURRENT technology to walk you through Walt's life while not boring you with the same presentation media over and over...it is always something fresh, attention grabbing and "hands-on". In addition to all the technology, there is a lot to read...Letters, telegrams, biographies.
Tickets are "Timed Entry" and best to get online at their website.  You can get tickets at the door, but there are no guarantees they will be available, depending on how full they are.  We purchased a "Dual Membership" which lets us go back as much as we want for the next year.  We WILL go back many times, I am sure.  You need to understand that this is NOT a "Disney" family museum, rather a "Disney Family" Museum.  Also, not really great for small children, as it is all history.  You don't even get to see "Disneyland" until the Gallery 9 after meandering through the first 8...wear comfy shoes!  Thank you Diane Disney Miller for bringing this to us in the Bay Area instead of LA!
author: Matt M S.

description: I have never seen another museum anything like this- "State of the Art" is putting it mildly. It's interactive in every way- audio, video- and the staff really knows their subject- you can talk Disney with them all day. The lovely little theatre in the belly of the building is small, but not in any way cramped. If anything, it feels homey and comfortable. The speakers they get are amazing and incredibly inexpensive. Last month alone we got to listen to the reminiscences of an Original Mouseketeer. And the depth of the collection- I try to go every couple of months as they are always changing things up a bit !  Even the building itself is lovely- there is a little walkway next to a glass wall as you are going from one level to another and you can just stand there and have the best view of the Golden Gate Bridge that I have ever seen.  Last summer, we stood there and watched the America's Cup Boats zoom by on the Bay. The whole experience is wonderful - it is like being inside of Walt's optimistic view of the world. You always come out of there lifted up.
author: Margaret A.

description: what an amazing man.  it takes at least 3 days to truly enjoy all of the information given in this fascinating museum.  plan to break it down...rather than just cram all the info into one day...tmi
author: Pam W.

description: I thought this museum was very interesting.  I'm a big disney fan and I enjoyed learning about Walt's background.  We brought our children with us (ages 6 and 8) and they seemed to enjoy it too.  If you don't have children with you - you can easily spend 3 - 4 hrs. reading all of the Disney history.
author: kristen g.

description: Just went last weekend, but found out about it in town so only had two hours before heading off to show....could have gone twice as long! I took a chance and took my 5-year-old inside and was so glad I did - she was in awe of the chronological journey through Walt Disney's "cartoons" showing in each room...granted, I would have loved to have more time to read, but I read and looked around at most everything and was still having a hard time getting my little girl to leave each room we were in to come to the next room.   Her favorite part was the early Mickey cartoon that had many sound effect makers (including a cat's tail, made of metal and pulled from metal box), xylophone, ratchet  box, drums, tapping things, etc. in front of it -you put on earphones then get to be, well, a Foley artist, basically, and sync the sound effects to the cartoon.  She could have stayed at that all day).  Her second favorite was either the huge, magical model of Disneyland or the cartoon with the live-action little girl (Alice) in it that jumped, ran and rode through 5 different screens).  She also loved listening to the other interactive music "games" based around Disney classic films.  My favorite was seeing how Walt created so much from what was available at each moment in the history of animation and then pushed the art forward into so much more, and then to see how he and his team leaped into creating new techniques, like the multi-layered camera, to add dimension and magic to early animation.   I even loved seeing the first camera he used for his Alice Comedies series in the 20's...funny how it took my breath away, and my daughter asked me why it had a turn crank on it so I got to explain (while I imagined) how they once had to make the camera "go" with a crank (at least their batteries never died).  I guess it's obvious I was transported into how a genius takes what's available and makes it magic...and then add that to his ability to take a new path each time he faced adversity and.... I was inspired by the message that Walt proved...you gotta have heart.  I don't always feel that heart today at Disneyland, that was for sure still there when I was a child at Disneyland, but is sort of diluted by others in the Disney franchise these days...but at this museum, I felt deeply the magnificent heart behind all of it, that made that innocent childlike heart in me respond on such a deep level to everything Walt Disney created, at this museum.
author: Cindy K.

description: history of walt disney i learned a lot after visiting this museum. great staffs and volunteer workers because everyone of them are informative and friendly.
author: Valerie N.

description: This is a wonderful addition to the Presidio. I took my daughter there and had to explain a lot to her about the basic characters that Mr. Disney created. She loved the story boards once I explained the purpose to her. Highly recommend!
author: Gean T.

description: I really can not believe I am not hearing more about this hidden gem. What an amazing museum. When our neighbors told us we were going to need 3-4 hours and kept go on and on about the place, I really thought they were over selling it but, oh no, it is that amazing and in our back yard. The of the most well designed museums I have ever been in... including those in DC. Go see it. Well worth the $20 ticket.
author: andrea a.

description: This is one for the serious Disney/animation fans:  We are big Disney admirers, so of course when we heard about this place which opened in 2009 we had to spend an afternoon there while visiting SF.  For us it did not disappoint, although it may not be the best choice for children.  If they are at all interested in art or animation, they should be ok - but the museum story stops in 1966 so they won't find their current Disney or Pixar movie characters here.  Since we had read biographies of Disney, it was exciting to see many of the original artifacts and creative materials that we had read about, and to enjoy a highly visual retelling of the life of this entertainment icon.   Be aware this is a museum; it tells the story the way the Disney family wanted it told, doesn't have any rides and while there are a lot of film clips to watch, it won't entertain most kids as much as it will adults who remember "Wonderful World of Color" and "The Mickey Mouse Club".  We lunched at the museum sandwich shop which was fine for our purposes - just a healthy light lunch.  We also enjoyed seeing the Presidio itself which is a historic and beautiful former military post.  Take a taxi, and be prepared to wait for the taxi to pick you up on the return trip, because not everyone wants to go out to the Presidio for a fare, apparently.
author: Nelda E.

description:
i love Disneyland!  oh, wait... this is a museum.  it was still fun, but no green jellybeans :(   here's what my owners had to say:

"When we first arrived, we asked the concierge how long it would take.  They answered 'about 2 hours.'  Six hours later, we still weren't done. The exhibits were varied and piqued my interest as animation is a hobby of mine.  I enjoyed the fact that a good portion of the museum was spent on Walt's career PRIOR to Mickey Mouse.  Of course, they can't leave him out or the works that followed.  The entire '50s film decade was showcased in a single room - seemed kind of rushed to me.  But there is a great 3D sculpture of Disneyland park.  There's no photography allowed inside, so don't bother bringing a camera.  eat before you go!  There's a cute gift shop at the end (of course) that sells E Ticket magazine editions!  A fan-produced publication that highlights past and present Disney attractions.
"I also liked the fact that they were not overly biased in favor of him;  they did include a display all about his animators' strike."  -Johnny

"I could have been done with this museum in 2 hours.  But SOMEBODY had to take forever looking at every little thing.  Oy!  It was very nice, though.  Very clever presentations of the information.  Bring your tissues for the last room :("  -Dirkie
author: Chien V.

description: This museum was about as I expected - a nicely done, but too expensive museum ($20/adult).  The museum is about Walt Disney and his family and his career - it is not a "fun" place for kids, so don't bring 'em.  If you have a bookish teenager that likes Disney, s/he'll probably do ok. Quite a bit of the museum is reading vs. interactive or electric media. I did really enjoy the replica of the original Walt Disney World. If the museum had been $10/adult, I would have given it another star - but, I tend to find all the museums in this area too pricey.  There is plenty of free parking in front of the museum (+), but I didn't like that you couldn't take any pics in the museum (-).  During busy times, it's best to go on line and get your tickets in advance.  They have timed entry, meaning only so many people are admitted each 15 minutes or so - I did notice that towards the end of the day, it seemed like there was more availability, so maybe you could walk in.
author: Lea T.

description:
My 12 -year-old daughter and I are not extreme Disney fans, but we decided to go to the museum based on some other reviews that it was more about Walt Disney and his life than about Disney, the huge corporation, and theme park. 
We enjoyed that aspect of it, and learned a lot about the aspiring artist, his trials and travails, his successes. Well done, well laid out.
I must mention as a con I found it a bit difficult to get there by public transportation - being from out of town and never having been to the Presidio before I felt the map on the website was not as clear and helpful as I would have liked. We ended up having to walk quite a bit, not being sure where we were going as we walked into the Presidio.
Also, I would have liked it to have known beforehand that it's $5 off with a AAA card. The website does not advertise that very openly - you have to look under "special discounts" to discover this!
author: Julia S.

description: This place was great. It had a ton of information about Walt and his family. it was very educational but a lot of reading. A note that this is not a fun place for children.  I really enjoyed going it.
author: John D.

description: My wife and I and another couple went today and highly recommend it.  We are seniors and this brought back many fond memories of growing up, along with a deeper appreciation for his vision and genius.  Lots of interactive exhibits.  Cafe was very good.  Not a place for kids looking for Disneyland.  Parking was great and the setting fabulous with views of the Golden Gate.  Highly recommend for seniors and families with older kids.
author: Randall L.

description:
This is definitely a great place to take friends or family who are visiting from out of town. It is located in a great part of the Presidio and offers a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge. A friend of mine came into town and she is a HUGE Disney fan. She begged me to take her here and she was like a kid in a candy store,

I will agree with the others who have said that this museum is not really kid-friendly for those youngsters who hope to see a lot of visually stimulating cartoon stuff. There are a lot of exhibits that require reading, and explain history and technology. Not something most 6 six year olds would be interested in. There was one little kid who told his mom he was bored in the 3rd exhibit hall (there are ten). Definitely set aside at least 3-4 hours if you really want to absorb everything. My friend read *everything* and it took us 4.5 hours to get through the whole museum. On certain days, they even have special screenings in the theater downstairs (which we did not get to see--I imagine this happen on the weekends).

You definitely leave having a better understanding and respect for Walt Disney and his imaginative creations.

I think the part that excited me the most was the FREE, PLENTIFUL PARKING! We all know what a miracle this is in San Francisco!

No photography is allowed though--which includes cell phones. They have volunteers monitoring every exhibit hall, so photographers, you will be caught!

I took off one star because of the ticket situation. They state on the website that you have to purchase your tickets in advance via their ticket-selling contractor. BE CAREFUL WHEN PURCHASING YOUR TICKETS! We had difficulty with the website, and every time the page crashed, we had to go back one step. And if you are not careful, you will miss the fact that the DATE GETS RESET when this happens. This happened to me and I didn't notice until we were getting ready to leave for the museum that the date of entry was for the week prior (the date I purchased the tickets). So I had to spend another $40 on new tickets and they would not let me exchange or return the tickets we did not use (granted, I should have caught the error myself, but it still irked me). And they were allowing people to buy tickets at the door even though the website said they didn't sell at the door. We went on a Thursday afternoon though, so it wasn't crowded at all.

All in all, definitely worth the $20 a ticket (or in my case, the $80 I spent on tickets!)
author: Rachel H.

description: What a great way to spend a day/afternoon. I really enjoyed this museum. My family has been into Disney for a very long time and to come here and see these exhibits were fantastic. They had a lot of things in there that I was shocked to see: for example, some of the first sketches of Mickey Mouse (that might have been one of my favorite things). There was a bunch of info about Walt and his family and the Walt Disney company as it progressed through the years. I sort of felt bad though- in order to read everything, and to listen to all of the audio exhibits, I felt that I was in a lot of people's way, but there really didn't see any other way. I tried to hurry through the stations as fast as I could, but in doing so, I sorta feel like I missed some stuff. Oh well, I guess it can be a reason to go back. :) All in all, it was a very fun and sweet experience. In my opinion, this probably wouldn't be all that fun for younger kids. Well, maybe a rare kid who is interested in early Disney work. :) And of course for all of us kids-at-heart.
author: Roya K.

description: This is a Disney fan MUST.  If you are a Disney fan then the museum is awesome. It walks you through Walt's life and how everything started, such as Mickey and Disneyland. There are some really neat exhibits and interactive things to do, but also a lot of reading.  The interactive things aren't really made for children, so as many said, I  wouldn't recommend taking children.  It does take about 4 hours to get through everything. Its only two stories but it takes a long time to read and do everything. I went on a weekday so it wasn't too busy. they're not strict on the ticket times, but like I said, it wasn't busy when I went.  For the not so big Disney fan, which I dragged a couple friends with me who were not, they still found it interesting and enjoyed themselves.  There were many small clips of Disney movies and shows that bring you back to your childhood.  I would definitely go check it out again.
author: Christopher L.

description:
As a former Disney cast member at Feature Animation and a lifelong fan of the films and the park (my grade school was across the freeway from D-land and we could hear the Mark Twain whistle all day long) I was very excited to visit the Disney Family Museum.  

First thing is first:  Why is this in San Francisco?  The museum is in the most beautiful location, but I don't know that Walt Disney had any connection to this city.  Odd choice.  Even though the museum isn't directly connected to Disney Burbank it still has that slick, well organized, you can't get hurt feel to it.  They have purple coated employees at every turn who smile and say 'hello' and guide you through the process.  The $20 entrance fee is bit much as others have mentioned.  The layout of the museum is very entertaining and informative.  Lots of interactive displays and visual elements everywhere.  Most of the info was old news to me: Walt in WW1, his early work in Kansas City, Oswald, then Snow White and the nine old men of animation.  I didn't have the patience to stand and listen to every old recording but was taken by all of the animation.  My interest began to peak when I hit the Fantasia period, and the very entertaining trip to south America (they even have Walt's 16mm camera he used to document the trip).  The wartime years was when I stopped and started watching the entire video display until it looped back. I love those DD propaganda cartoons and the posters for "Victory Through Airpower".  The live action films of the early 50's were next and this too was very cool.  I was surprised as hell when I came across the "True Life Adventures" and "People and Places" exhibit, which not only showed clips from those fantastic docu's but also afforded you a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate.  They even have the original golden globe model that was used for the true life logo.  Now I was in my wheelhouse and completely hooked. 

The descent from floor 1 to floor 2 was the most amazing.  Artifacts that I was completely (as a fan) amazed by.  An original cirCARama camera!  The red sport autopia car for Walt's grandkids.  The Lilly Belle!  Even small items like Walt's dresser valet with the contents of his pockets.  The last section covering Walt's death was very touching.  

I found the gift shop to be very 'eh' and I didn't try the chow.  The theater I definetly want to come back for (separate admission).  I couldn't believe how much free parking there was at the Presideo.
author: David B.

description: It was ok.  Sometimes hard to hear, because several things are playing all at once and you hear things coming from several directions.  Then when you picking up the audio things to listen it was sometimes very loud and sometimes not loud enough.  I found it frustrating to read something and then pick up the audio thing and hear the exact same thing.  The day we went it was not crowded - the employees words - if you went on a crowded day it would be awful, because it is a small place with displays close together.  It would be better if it was more spread out.  It looks like they plan a headphone audio tour in the future, because they had a room to return them, but they are not provided yet.  I think that would be much much better. I was disappointed that they did not have a place to see the Spin and Marty show or the Hardy Boys show.  Most people these days have not seen them and I think that would be neat. I also thought it was too expensive, but I guess they have to pay rent for that fabulous location that isn't even utilized, by having a place to eat seeing the view.  I do not think I will ever go back or take visitors from out of town.  I think Walt Disney was a unbelieveable man, I don't think this museum told his story that well.
author: mary m.
